Justice (R) Fazal Karim
The Law of
Criminal
Procedure
(An Anthology of Criminal Procedure based
on the Constitutional Law of Pakistan
USA, UK, etc and on the Principal
Criminal Procedural Law of Pakistan, viz the
Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898)
PAKISTAN LAW HOUSE

Page 2
This book is about criminal justice process-
criminal procedure. Whatever meaning 'justice'
may bear in a particular context, justice in its
truest sense of the word, is the ultimate goal of
the criminal procedure in any civilized society
There can be no greater testimony to the
importance of 'Criminal Procedure' than this
that the basic criminal procedural rights, in the
form of fundamental human rights, stand
incorporated in, and guaranteed by, almost all
the democratic constitutions of the world,
including Pakistan. Yet, despite these
constitutional guarantees, the international
community has remained so concerned with
the misuse and abuse of the criminal process
that the right to fairness has been reaffirmed
and elaborated, since 1948, in numerous
international treaties and conventions,
establishing international standards of
fairness, reflecting the saying of Martin Luther
King:
"Injustice anywhere is a threat to justice
everywhere"
'Criminal Procedure thus stands
internationalized; this, in reality, is an
international effort at humanizing criminal
procedure.
So important is the place of 'Criminal
Procedure', in the hierarchy of laws that "the
quality of a nation's civilization can be largely
measured by the methods it uses in the
enforcement of its criminal law". In short,
criminal procedure is criminal justice in action.

PREFACE
William Smellie in his preface to what became the first edition of
Encyclopedia Britannica said: Utility and the diffusion of
knowledge - these are the goals, which "ought to be the principal
intention of every publication".
This is also the intention of this publication, in the hope that it will
stimulate the readers' quest for knowledge of the criminal justice
process. The importance of that process was encapsulated in the
words quoted by Chief Justice Earl Warren in the most famous
American case on Constitutional Criminal Procedure, namely,
Miranda v Arizona, which are as follows:
"The quality of a nation's civilization can be largely
measured by the methods it uses in the enforcement of its
criminal law".
The intended audience of this book, originally, were the law
students. But as the saying goes, the tale has grown in the telling.
and the book, in its finished form, will hopefully be as useful to the
profession at large, the academics, the practicing lawyers and the
judges. Crime affects the very quality of life and my intended
audience may well include every curious and serious lay person,
who wants to be better educated and more informed about the role
of criminal procedure in his everyday life.
The distinctive feature of the book, if I may venture to say, is that it
introduces the "Constitutional Criminal Procedure" - a procedure
that has its roots in a written Constitution to the academic and
forensic landscape of Pakistan. "Constitutional Criminal
Procedure" as a topic is well known to the academics and the
lawyers in the United States of America and in the United
Kingdom, but was unknown in Pakistan. It is a distinction of the

Lahore University of Management Sciences (LUMS) that this topic
has, from the beginning, been part of the curriculum at LUMS.
The credit for this book, in a large measure, goes to Justice Jawwad
S.Khawaja then Head of the Law & Policy Department of LUMS,
and now a Judge of the Supreme Court of Pakistan, who took the
great risk of initiating me as an academic. He was reading the book
in manuscript and sharing his valuable ideas with me when his
elevation to the Supreme Court interrupted that remarkable
intellectual exercise.
I am fortunate in having a bunch of delightful grandchildren living
with and around me -Nisha Aftab, Nida Aftab, Adeel S. Karim,
Noor Aftab, Rohma S. Karim. While all of them helped me in their
small ways, the eldest of them, Nisha Aftab, deserves my special
thanks. She is not a lawyer. Yel, endowed as she is with robust
common sense and sharp intellect, she helped me in a variety of
ways willingly and with enthusiasm.
Last but no the least is the debt of gratitude I owe to Mr. Qasim
Rasool, LLM, Advocate, with whom I had the good fortune to be
associated at the penultimate stage. He was full of zest and ideas
and it was his capacity for hard work and will to learn that enabled
me to put this work together and bring it to fruition. I am also
grateful to Mr. Muhammad Imran and Khalid Mahmood Siddiqi of
LUMS for rendering valuable secretarial services.

PARTI
Some Preliminary Matters
Chapter 1
HISTORICAL PERSPECTIVE OF CRIMINAL
PROCEDURE
Strange things, stranger than fiction, have happened in...
the world of criminal justice.
We often hear it said, "Let justice be done, though the
heavens should fall". You would think that it has a respectable
origin. In fact, it was first used to excuse the most outrageous
injustice. It comes from a story told by Seneca. Piso sentenced a
soldier to death for the murder of one Gaius. He ordered a
centurion to execute the sentence. When the soldier was about to be
executed, Gaius came forward himself alive and wex. The
centurion reported it to Piso. Piso sentenced all three to death. The
soldier, because he had already been sentenced, the centurion, for
disobeying orders, and Gaius, for being the cause of the death of
two innocent men. Piso excused it by the plea: Let justice be done.
though the heavens should fall (The story has been reproduced by
Lord Denning in his book "The Family Story", at p. 172).
In 399 BCE, Socrates was accused of and tried for (i)
not believing in the gods that the citizens believed in and (ii)
corrupting the youth.
The procedure at an Athenian trial was very different
from that at a modern trial. Trials took place during a single day.
To make bribery of jurors more difficult, juries were very large and
were chosen by lot from those citizens who made themselves
available, There were no professional lawyers, and no public
prosecutors. So prosecutions were brought by individuals.
Speeches were timed by a water-clock, which was stopped while
evidence from witnesses was heard.
XXVIII
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 19
The prosecution spoke first followed by the defendant.
After these two speeches, the jury voted the accused innocent or
guilty. If innocent, he was released. If guilty, the jury next voted on
the sentence. The procedure here was for the prosecution and the
defence each to suggest a penalty and for the jury to decide
between the two.
For the trial of Socrates, the jury consisted of as many as
five hundred jurors, and he was found guilty by a narrow margin of
280 to 220.
Many people in Athens did not want Socrates' death.
What they possibly wanted was an apology, which they did not get.
He was condemned to death by drinking hemlock. His friends
offered him an easy escape; they had bribed the officials. He asked
his friends, is it right? And when they failed to satisfy him, he
preferred to die.
From the mid-13 century to the mid-18th century, a
system of judicial torture lay at the heart of continental criminal.
procedure. The application of torture was routine and a judicially
supervised feature of the European criminal procedure. Under
certain circumstances, the law permitted the criminal courts to
employ physical coercion against suspected criminals to induce
them to confess.
In England, in the dark past, when a suspect was brought
before the Star Chamber (essentially a torture Chamber), he was
commanded to answer questions, even when there was no evidence
that he had anything to do with the crime. If he declined to answer,
he could be incarcerated, mutilated or banished. A discussion on
this subject will be found in Part II of this book under the heading
"Privilege against self-incrimination" as guaranteed by the US
Constitution, Fifth Amendment, particularly in the opinion of Chief
Justice Earl Warren in the famous case of Miranda v Arizona (384
US 436; 16 L Ed 2d 694).
There is a method of criminal justice known as pure
procedure. In some areas of Pakistan, suspects of crimes were
made to walk on burning coals, the prevailing myth being that the
fire did not burn the innocent. Under the Frontier Crimes
Regulations, 1901, which have remained in force in the tribal areas
of Pakistan till recently, the Council of Elders, who were the judges
of fact, could adopt any procedure for ascertaining the facts. In
practice, the Council held secret and open inquiries. It examined
witnesses informally, visited the place of crime or its neighborhood
often incognito, to ascertain the truth.
In the field of fiction, an outstanding example of pure
procedure is the justice of Homer as portrayed in the Iliad.
Conflicts brought to court were argued by the parties in the
presence of the spectators, who, after witnessing the process, voted
for a solution, not on the basis of set principles but on how they felt
about what had been put before them. And whatever agreement the
spectators reached was binding. Italo Calvino, in his "A judgment
in Adams, one Afternoon" tells the shocking tale of a trial which
ended in the conviction and execution not of the accused but of the
judge himself.
And to have an idea of what terrible things could happen
in the guise of criminal prosecution in totalitarian regimes, one has
only to read the French novels by Victor Hugo, e.g. Hunchback of
Notre Dame and Les Miserables and the art imitating-life novels by
Solzhenitsyn and Fyoder Dostoevsky, e.g. Crime and Punishment.
Now, there can be many ways to decide a dispute: you
can decide it by throwing dice, or by spinning a coin, or consulting
un astrologer, or on the toss of a coin or by asking the spectators to
vote on which of the two conflicting witnesses to believe as a
Manhattan criminal court judge, as recently as 1983, did.
But cun a modem Judge, in this enlightened age, decide
cases in any of these ways? The answer plainly is 'No'.
3
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 20
Chapter 2
Criminal Procedure-Traditional Perspective:
We may well begin with the Irite words of Justice
Holmes from his famous book, "The Common Law";
"The life of the law has not been logic; it
has been experience. The felt necessities
of the time, the prevalent moral and
political theories, intimations of public
policy, avowed or unconscious, even the
prejudices which judges share with their
fellow-men, have had a good deal more
to do than the syllogism in determining
the rules hy which men should be
governed. The law emphasizes the story
of a nation's development through many
centuries and it cannot be dealt with as if
it contained only the axioms and
corollaries of a book of mathematics".
In order to know what it (the law) is, so says Justice
Holmes, we must know what it has been and what it tends to
become. This is what we propose to do: to know what the law is.
we must first know what it has been.
It has been said, and rightly in our view, that the law is
probably the "institution that changes least in any society. The
reason is that the visible evidence of a continuing legal tradition
enhances the impression of a community living under a permanent
and consistent rule of law "The Day the World Changed" by
James Burke, p.13).
That is why it has been said that "The law, so far as it
depends on learning, is indeed..... the government of the living by
the dead". But it must be remembered that in today's legal world,
Change is the only constant, and Justice Holmes warns us that "the
present has the right to govern itself, so far as it can, and it ought
always to be remembered that historic continuity with the past is
not a duty; it is only a necessity"
WESTERN TRADITIONS
Due Process, Natural Justice, Procedural Fairness:
The expressions. "Due Process". "Natural Justice",
"Procedural Fairness", are customarily employed in describing the
procedural law, both civil and criminal. They all go together.
General ideas about them in the West are usually considered with
reference to three different traditions, namely -
The English Constitution and Common Law
1)
system:
2)
The American Constitutional tradition.
3)
The newer doctrines of the European Union
and the European Convention on Human
Rights.
Common Law: "Common Law" forms the basis of much of the
English statutory and case law. It has often been called the major
source of modem criminal law in common law jurisdictions. The
study of procedures "has never been a major interest of English
lawyers, and yet the growth of the common law, indeed the very
foundations of the common law, are tied inseparably to
procedures" ("Due Process and Fair Procedures" by Professor D.J.
Galligan, p.167). And Lord Denning tells us "to remember that
much of our substantive law is found laced in with procedure".
"Common Law is variously described as English,
Anglo-Saxon or Anglo- American." Despite its conceptualization
by Lord Coke as the perfection of reason, it is indeed a vast and
complete instrument of justice" ("The Judicial Process" by Henry
J. Abraham, 4 ed. p8). It refers to a historical body of unwritten
legal precedents created from everyday English social customs.
rules, and practices that were supported by judicial decisions in the
Middle Ages. As novel situations arose and were dealt with by
English judges, their declarations became the starting point of any
5
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 21
future declarations. These decisions generally incorporated the
customs of the society as it operated at that time. Eventually, this
growing body of judicial pronouncements developed into a set of
legal rules widely accepted as a kind of national law, commonly
applied throughout England. Thus Common Law was bom.
During this early stage, judges often took upon themselves to
formally criminalize actions that had previously been regarded as
the basis for private disputes. Hence many acts we call "crimes"
today, for example, murder, rape, arson and burglary, might have
remained in the private sphere had it not been for the development
of the common law,
Eventually, courts decisions were recorded and made.
available to barristers (the English word for trial lawyers) and
judges. As Howard Abadinsky says:
"Common law involved the
transformation
of
community rules into a national legal system. The
controlling element was precedent". (See "Criminal
Justice Today" by Frank Schmalleger, 4" edition.
p.116).
Due Process
The concept of "Due Process" is to a modern English
lawyer an American concept; it is enshrined in the US Constitution
and several of the State Constitutions. In reality, it was an English
concept; its origin can be traced back to Magna Carta, the Great
Charter of 1215; Clause 39 of the Charter provided: "No freeman
shall be taken and imprisoned or dissiesed of any tenement or of
his liberties or free customs...... except by lawful judgment of his
peers or by the law of the land". The expression "by the law of the
land" in that clause means the same thing as "due process of law".
A statute of Edward IV passed in 1354 stated:
"That no man of what state or condition
that he be, shall be put out of land or
tenement, nor taken nor imprisoned
6
without being brought in answer by due
process of law",
Like some of the best English families, "Due Process"
emigrated to the US in the 17th century.
It needs to be noted that the people in Europe and
England enjoyed only the rights expressly granted by law. But at
the time of the passing of the US Constitution, the prevailing idea
was that certain rights were inherent in human nature; they did not
depend upon being granted by law. As was said by Alexander
Hamilton, one of the US Founding Fathers, "why declare that
things shall not be done which there is no power to do". Thus, the
famous American Declaration of Independence simply invoked the
self-evident truths that "all men are created equal, that they are
endowed by their creator with certain inalienable rights, that among
those are life, liberty and pursuit of happiness".
Accordingly, in the original Constitution, there was no
mention of any human or fundamental rights. Yet, it soon became
apparent that the omission of a Bill of Rights was a serious flaw
and great difficulties were encountered in the ratification of the
Constitution. It was then that the first Ten Amendments, known as
the Bill of Rights, were enacted and included in the US
Constitution.
Thus, the 5 Amendment, among others, provides that
"no person shall be deprived of life, liberty or property.
without due process of law.......
The essential. purpose of the due process clause is to
prevent the Goverment, its officials and instrumentalities, like the
law enforcement agencies, e.g. police, from acting arbitrarily. The
focus is on procedure itself.
"Due process of law" according to the Great English
Judge, Lord Denning (see his book "The Due Process of Law")
means-
7
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 22
"the measures authorized by the law so
as to keep the stream of justice pure; to
see that trials and enquiries are fairly
conducted; that arrests and searches are
properly made; that lawful remedies are
readily available and that unnecessary
delays are eliminated",
Willoboughy explains the term as follows:
As between the State and the individual,
(i)
(ii)
(iii)
(iv)
the individual shall have duc notice of
proceedings which affect his rights;
the individual shall be given reasonable
opportunity to defend:
the tribunal or court before which his rights
are adjudged is so constituted as to give
reasonable assurance of its honesty and
impartiality, and
it is a court of competent jurisdiction. (The
Constitution of the United States, 2 Ed. V.II.
p.1709, cited in Government of Balochistan v
Aziz Ullah Memon-PLD 1993 SC 341).
In determining what process is due, the US Supreme
Court's recent doctrine has involved a balancing of interests at
stake. This utilitarian approach requires that the Court considers -
"First, the private interest that will be
affected by the official action; second
the risk of an erroneous deprivation of
such interest through the procedures
used, and the probable values, if any, of
additional
substitute procedural
safeguards, and finally, the
govemment's interest, including the
function involved, and the fiscal and
administrative burdens that the
additional substitute
procedure
g
requirement would entail" (Mathews y
Eldridge 424 US 319, 334-5; 1976).
The US Supreme Court has continually held that a fair
trial in a fair tribunal is a basic requirement of due process. (e.g. In
re Murchison, 349 US 133; 99 L Ed 942).
Procedural Fairness
Procedural fairness is the modern English concept, and
one can say that "Due Process of Law" is its predecessor, Thus
"when we say in English law that all public authorities are now
subject to the principles of procedural faimess, reference is being
made to a set of procedural doctrines, largely created by the courts
which express fundamental principles about the fair treatment of
persons and the procedures needed to give effect to fair treatment.
When American lawyers talk about procedural due process they are
doing something very similar, except that the primary source of
their procedural doctrines is the Constitution with its general
provisions requiring due process of law when life, liberty or
property is in issue (Professor D.J. Galligan in his "Due Process
and Fair Procedures" p.74).
Natural Justice:
"Natural justice", it has been said, is 'fair play in action'.
(Lord Morris in Wiseman v Borneman - (1969) 3 All ER 275.
278). A natural right is a right which man has simply by virtue of
being bom a human being and that is also true of "natural justice".
Amongst the procedural doctrines recognized and frequently
invoked by the English courts, and other courts following the
common law tradition, including Pakistan and India, the first to be
noted is the maxim "Justice should not only be done, but should
manifestly and undoubtedly be seen to be done".
This means that in trials held in the public eye, the
appearance of faimess is as important as actual faimess itself.
9
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 23
The hearing principle and the principle against bias,
which principles will be discussed below, are illustrations of this
maxim. The principle of public hearing, which will be discussed at
its proper place and which has been accorded legislative
recognition in section 352 of the Code of Criminal Procedure,
1898, is another manifestation of this general principle.
Its Twin Pillars: The rule against bias and right to be heard - two
separate concepts and governed by separate considerations are
the essential characteristics of what is called natural justice. They
are the twin pillars supporting it (Kanda v Government of Malaya
[(1962) AC 322 PC). The rule against bias is put in the maxim-
nemo judex in causa sua-and the right to be heard is "neatly and
briefly stated in the recently resuscitated Latin expression - audi
alteram partem". [Darayappah v Fernando (1967) 2 AC 337 PC).
The two concepts have been recently put in the two words,
impartiality and faimess. (Kanda v Government of Malaya (1962
AC 322 PC: Council of Civil Services v Minister (1984) 3 All ER
935). Lord Devlin put them in one sentence; they are, he said "the
right to be heard by an unbiased tribunal, (United Engineering v
Deveanayagam-(1967) 2 All ER 367, 382).
Right of hearing: Right of hearing may be provided by statute or a
statutory instrument (which is a convenient expression to use for
statutory rules, regulations, bye-laws etc) or it may rest upon the
principles of natural justice.
The maxim, audi alteram partem no man shall be
condemned unheard is of universal application (Faridsons y
Pakistan PLD 1961 SC $37); it is one of the first principles of
justice that no man should be condemned without being heard.
That the conception of natural justice should at all stages guide
those who discharge judicial functions is not merely an acceptable
but an essential part of the philosophy of our law, and it appears
that whenever any person or body of persons is empowered to take
decision after ex post facto investigation into facts which would
result in consequences affecting the person, property or other rights
of any person, then in the absence of any express words in the
10
enactment giving such power, excluding the application of
principles of natural justice, the courts of law are required
generally to imply that the power so given is coupled with the duty
to act in accordance with such principles of natural justice as may
he applicable in the facts and circumstances of a given case.
(Hamood-ur-Rehman J in University of Dacca v Zakir Ahmad -
PLD (1865 SC 90). For its application the rule does not depend
upon whether the proceedings are judicial or quasi judicial as well
as administrative or quasi administrative. The rule applies to
judicial as well as administrative bodies, especially where the
proceedings taken may affect the person or property or other rights
of parties concerned in the dispute. (Chief Commissioner v Mrs.
Dina Sohrab PLD 1959 SC (Pak) 45].
In England, the violation of a statutory provision giving
a right of hearing and the violation of the principle of audi alteram
partem stand on the same footing; both are treated as jurisdictional
defects resulting in a nullity. [Anisminic case (1969), 1 All ER
208; also see Professor Wade's article in (1968) 84 LQR 951.
Reid said:
Thus, in Ridge v Baldwin ((1963) 2 All ER 66], Lord
"Time and again in the cases I have cited
it has been stated that a decision given
without regard to the principles of
natural justice is void...... I see no
reason to doubt these authorities. The
body with the power to decide cannot
lawfully proceed to make a decision
until it has afforded the person affected a
proper opportunity to state his case".
This view was reaffirmed in Anisminic (1969) | All ER 208,
2131 in which Lord Reid said that there are many cases, one of
them being where a tribunal may have failed in the course of the
inquiry to comply with the requirements of natural justice, in which
II
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 24
"Although the tribunal had jurisdiction
to enter on the inquiry, it has done or
failed to do something in the course of
the inquiry which is of such a nature that
its decision is a nullity".
And in AG v Ryan (1980) AC 718). Lord Diplock referred both to
Anisminic and Ridge to hold that "it has long been settled that a
decision affecting legal rights of an individual which is arrived at
by a procedure which offends against the principles of natural
justice is outside the jurisdiction of the decision-making
authority".
In Pakistan, violation of the right of hearing when
provided by a statute or a statutory instrument has been held to be
productive of different results from the right of hearing when it
rests upon the principle of natural justice. Again, when the right of
hearing is provided by a statute or a statutory instrument a
distinction is made between the provision being mandatory or
directory.
The earliest case on the right of hearing provided by a
statute or a statutory instrument is Zafar-ul-Ahsan v Republic of
Pakistan (PLD 1960 SC (Pak) 113). In the Full Bench case of
Muhammad Ishaque v Saeed-ud-Din (PLD 1959 Kar 669), Kaikaus
J. made the distinction between the statutory provision being
mandatory or directory: "If the statutory provision for notice be
mandatory, the order without notice may be wholly void. If it be
directory the court may still presume prejudice for want of notice
till the contrary is shown". This was approved by the Supreme
Court in Collector v Muhammad Akhtar (1971 SCMR 681): "The
principle, so far as this country is concemed, is accordingly well
settled that where notice required to be given by the statute is a
mandatory notice, then the failure to comply with such mandatory
requirement of the statute would render the act void ab initio as
being an act performed in disregard of the provisions of the statute.
Furthermore, any further action on the basis of such a void order
would also be vitiated and the defect at the initial stage would be
incurable by a hearing at a subsequent stage". This view was
reiterated in Atta Muhammad Qureshi v Settlement Commissioner
(PLD 1971 SC 61).
The principle thus is that where a statute provides for
hearing and the provision is mandatory in character its violation
will render the consequent order without jurisdiction, void and a
nullity. In such a case, the argument that opportunity was provided
at a later stage by an appellate or revisional authority and that had
the effect of curing the initial defect will not avail, the rule
applicable being that "if on the basis of a void order subsequent
orders have been passed either by the same authority or by other
authorities, the whole series of such orders, together with
superstructure of rights and liabilities built upon them most, unless
some statute or principle of law recognizing as legal the changed
position of the parties, is in operation, fall to the ground, as such
orders have as little legal foundation as the void order on which
they are founded" (Yousaf Ali v M. Aslam Zia PLD 1958 SC (Pak)
104). But if the statutory provision giving the right of hearing is
merely directory only then its violation is to be treated on an equal
footing as violation of the principle audi alteram partem (Sind
Employees Social Security v Dawood Cotton Mills - PLD 1997
SC 177). As an instance of the statutory provision being merely
directory, Manzoor-ul-Haq v Controlling Authority (PLD 1963 SC
652) may be referred to.
Comments: If we may say so with great respecs, the question
whether an action taken in disregard of a statutory right of hearing
should result in a nullity, ought not to depend on the fine, or if we
may say, esoteric, distinction between mandatory or directory. The
true view seems to be that when a statute gives the right of hearing.
what it does is merely to incorporate the principle of natural justice
- audi alteram partem - into the statute. As Abdul Kadir Sheikh J
put it in Shah Mardan v Chief Land Commissioner (PLD 1974 Kar.
375,391)-
"In making the provision for notice to be
given to the party affected, the rules
12
13
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 25
sought to incorporate only what is
otherwise to be read into them, in spite
of absence of such a provision".
Logically, therefore, there appears no reason to treat cases in which
the right is a statutory right and cases in which it is based on
natural justice differently.
The Rule against Bias: The rule against bias is the second pillar
supporting natural justice. It is commonly (but only partially)
captured in the phrase nemo judex sua causa (1999 Public Law
391; Analysis by Timothy H. Jones), which phrase means that
nobody may be a judge in his own cause (Lord Goff in R v Gough
(1993) 2 All ER 724, 730). There is an overriding public interest
that there should be confidence in the integrity of the
administration of justice, which is always associated with the
statement of Lord Hewart in R v Sussex Justices, ex parte
McCarthy (1923) All ER 233) that it is-
"of fundamental importance that justice
should not only be done, but should
manifestly and undoubtedly be seen to
be done",
So fundamental indeed that almost every Judge swears, before
entering upon his office, to be impartial. Thus the oath that the
Supreme Court and High Court Judges are required to take under
the Constitution of Pakistan needs:
Prends:
"I will not allow my personal interest to
influence my official conduct or my
official decisions; .........in all
circumstances, I will do right to all
manner of people, according to law,
without fear or favour, affection or
ill-will",
When it is said that a judicial decision
maker was
biased, it means "that he was motivated by a desire unfairly to
favour one side or to disfavour the other". (Lord Goff in R v
Gough (1993) 2 All ER 724, 728; in Corpus Juris Secundum, V. X.
pp. 354-5, quoted in Asif Ali Zardari v The State PLD 2001 SC
568, 587, bias is described as under: "bias" has been held
synonymous with "partiality", and strictly to be distinguished from
"prejudice". Under particular circumstances, the word has been
described as a condition of mind; and has been held to refer, not to
views entertained regarding a particular subject-matter, but to the
mental attitude or disposition towards a particular person and to
cover all varieties of personal hostility or prejudice against him).
It is a principle of interpretation of statutes that "the
presumed intention of parliament is that one of the qualifications of
the decision-maker is that of absence of bias" (Diplock L.J. in
Anisminic case (1967) 2 All ER 986). In the determination of
their rights and liabilities, civil or criminal, everyone is entitled to a
fair hearing by an impartial tribunal. That right has been described
as a fundamental right in the European Convention on Human
Rights (Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and
Fundamental Freedoms (Rome, 4 Nov 1950: TS 71 (1953); Cmd
8969). The reason is obvious. All legal arbiters are bound to apply
the law as they understand it to the facts of individual cases as they
find them. They must do so without fear or favour, affection or ill-
will, that is, without partiality or prejudice. Justice is portrayed as
blind not because she ignores the facts and circumstances of
individual cases, but because she shuts her eyes to all
considerations extraneous to the particular case. As Lord Denning
put it in Jones v National Coal Board, (1957) 2 QB 55):
"It is all very well to paint justice blind,
but she does better without a bandage
round her eyes. She should be blind
indeed to favour or prejudice, but clear
to see which way lies the truth......
14
15
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 26
The law on the subject has been exhaustively dealt with
in the recent but already famous House of Lords cases of Locabail
Ltd. v Bayfield Properties (2000) 1 All ER 65, 69), and R v Bow
Street Metropolitan Stipendiary Magistrate ex p Pinochet ((1999) 1
All ER 577), and in Pakistan in the recent case of Asif Ali Zardari
v State (PLD 2001 SC 568).
The fundamental principle is that a man may not be a
judge in his own cause. "There is a species of bias which vitiates
judicial proceedings irrespective of the correctness or otherwise of
the result, but that is not because bias, whatever form it may
assume, avoids the result of judicial proceedings, but because the
judge with that kind of bias is, on grounds of public policy,
disqualified to be a judge" (Muhammad Munir C.J in Anwar v
Crown PLD 1955 FC 185; also see, among others, Farzand Ali
case-PLD 1970 SC 98, Begum Nusrat Bhutto case PLD 1977 SC
657).
The basic rule is not in doubt. Nor is the rationale of the
rule: if a judge has a personal interest in the outcome of an issue he
is to resolve, he is improperly acting as a judge in his own cause;
such a proceeding would, without more, undermine public
confidence in the integrity of the administration of justice.
(Locabail Limited v Bayfield Properties - (2000) 1 All ER 65, 69,
72).
The decision of the House of Lords in what is known as
Pinochet No.2 is, it has been said, of historic importance for two
reasons. It is the first decision in which the House of Lords has
been persuaded to re-open an appeal and set aside one of its own
orders, secondly, it is now well known that undisputed links of
Lord Hoffmann (a member of the Committee which heard the
original House of Lords appeal) to Amnesty International raised
the issue of judicial bias. It is unprecedented for a decision of an
appellate court in England and Wales to have to be set aside on this
ground.
16
Pinochet was a former Head of State of Chile. He was
living in England when the Government of Spain sought his
extradition. He challenged the extradition proceedings in the High
Court. The matter ultimately reached the House of Lords; one of
the parties before the House was Amnesty International. The House
upheld the extradition by its decision dated 25 November. One of
the members of the House who recorded that decision was Lord
Hoffmann who was a director and chairperson of Amnesty
International Charity. Pinochet applied that the 25 November
decision be set aside on the ground that there was a real danger or
reasonable apprehension that Lord Hoffmann might have been
biased. The House of Lords agreed and setting aside the 25
November decision ordered a re-hearing by a new Bench.
Asif Ali Zardari case was an appeal by Ms. Benazir
Bhutto a former Prime Minister of Pakistan and her husband, Asif
Ali Zardari, against their conviction and sentence recorded by a
Bench of two learned Judges of the Lahore High Court under the
Ehtsab Act 1997. After examining the concept of bias, in its
various aspects, the Supreme Court held that the senior member of
the bench "had acquired a personal interest in the case by an out of
the way favour" and that the facts also divulged "a close liaison
between the learned Judge, Senator Saifur Rehman and Mian
Muhammad Nawaz Sharif, the then Prime Minister, whose political
rivalry with Ms Benazir Bhutto appellant is a matter of common
knowledge". In the view of the Supreme Court "there is sufficient
material on record which substantiates the allegation of bias". The
trial, it was held, was not fair and on account of bias of the Ehtsab
Bench, it stood vitiated.
Procedural fairness in Europe: Procedural fairness in Europe is
considered with reference to the (European) Convention of Human
Rights and Fundamental Freedoms (European Convention), which
contains a statement of the Fundamental Human Rights; the
member states of the Council of Europe are bound by international
law to ensure that the principles of the Convention are respected
and enforced in their national legal systems. As an international
convention or treaty is not the law of a country unless it is formally
17
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 27
made part of the law of that country, in England, the Convention
Rights are now, by virtue of the Human Rights Act, 1998, part of
the law of England.
The result of the Human Rights mentioned in the
European Convention becoming part of the law of England is that
any action, legislative, executive or judicial, incompatible with
such a right can now be challenged. This is so provided in sections
6 and 7 of the Human Rights Act. In other words, the position of
the European Convention so far as these Human Rights are
concerned, is now that of a written Constitution for England.
As is well-known, England had no written Constitution
and the Parliament was, in its law making power, supreme. The
position, therefore, was that it was a sin to think that an Act of
Parliament could be challenged by courts. "An Act of Parliament",
it was said in Wood (1701) 12 Mod. Report - 669) "can do no
wrong though it may do several things that look pretty odd". This
was also the constitutional position in Europe. The great change
brought about by the adoption of the European Convention is, as is
provided in the Human Rights Act, 1998, that even an Act of
Parliament can now be challenged as being incompatible with the
Human Rights guaranteed by the European Convention.
As we have seen, anything done by the public authorities
incompatible with the rights concerning procedural fairness can
now be challenged in the Courts. These rights are aimed at
providing procedural fairness; in their application, the European
Court has developed the principle of "Equality of Arms" under
which a defendant in a criminal proceeding must have a reasonable
opportunity of presenting his case to the court under conditions
which do not place him at a substantial disadvantage vis--vis his
opponent.
Only two traditions now: In practical terms, the adoption of the
Human Rights mentioned in the European Convention by the
United Kingdom has reduced the number of the traditions with
reference to which the procedural laws in the West may be
considered to two, namely,
(1)
(2)
the American constitutional tradition; and
the English and the European procedural
faimess tradition.

(i)

The relevance of this to criminal procedure may be
demonstrated as follows.
Article 4 of the Constitution of Pakistan forbids any
action detrimental to the life, liberty, body, reputation or property
to be taken "except in accordance with law" and Articles 9 and 24
of the Constitution guarantee the Fundamental Rights to life,
liberty and property; according to them "no person shall be
deprived of life, liberty and property save in accordance with law.
The Pakistan Penal Code and other laws creating
offences and fixing punishments, (substantive criminal law) and
the Code of Criminal Procedure and other adjectival laws.
including the law of evidence (the aggregate of rules of procedure)
are laws within the meaning of Articles 4, 9 and 24 of the
Constitution in accordance with which one may be deprived of life.
liberty and property.

Justice and Social Justice: The Constitution of Pakistan, by its
preamble, which is a reproduction of the principles and provisions
set out in the Objective Resolution, which Resolution has been
reproduced in the Annex to the Constitution and is, as stated in
Article 2A, now a substantive part of the Constitution and "shall
have effect accordingly", lays down that, among others, the
objectives of the Constitution are to establish an order-
"Wherein the principles of democracy,
freedom, equality, tolerance and social
justice, as enunciated by Islam, shall be
fully observed":
guaranteed
