subject to law and public morality" and
"Wherein the independence of the
judiciary shall be fully secured.
We are here concerned with "justice" and "social justice", in
particular, in the context of the criminal justice system. What do
the terms "justice" and "social justice" mean?
Justice
Justice, it has been said, is largely an abstract and
normative concept and like beauty can be said to be in the eye of
the beholder; as an American author has written, even to attempt to
pen down the meaning of the term is to raise "an unimportant
question to which no definitive answer can be given" (Karl Popper
in his "The Open Society and its Enemies" V.1, p.89). It has been
said that "if it were not for injustice, men would not know justice".
Thus, while "justice" cannot be defined, a starving poor child
begging for a piece of brend and an innocent man rotting in prison
know what injustice is.
Justice has, like many other words, several meanings.
The Greek philosophers, including Plato and Aristotle, thought,
originally on grounds derived from religion, that each thing or
person has its or his proper sphere, to overstep which is unjust.
("History of Western Philosophy" by Bertrand Russell, p.194).
Thus, according to this view, justice is to remain within your own
proper sphere. Otto Bird thinks that the most famous and
influential definition in the entire discussion of Justice is the one
the Roman lawyers enshrined in the Justinian Code which,
translated in English, says that justice is the constant and perpetual
means to render to each one his rights. The well known British
philosopher and statesman, Benjamin Disraeli, once defined justice
as 'truth in action'.
The definition of "justice" namely to render to each one
his rights is neatly illustrated by an old anecdote, from an old book.
relating to Cyrus. Cyrus was asked by his father to give an account
of his last lesson. Cyrus answered thus: one of the boys of our
school had a coat too small for him and gave it to one of his
companions, a little smaller than himself, and forcibly took in
exchange the smaller boy's coat, which was too large for him. The
teacher made me judge of the ensuing dispute and I decided that
the matter should be left as it was, since the parties seemed to be
better accommodated than before. Upon this, the teacher pointed
out to me that I have gone wrong, for I had been satisfied with
considering the convenience of the thing, whereas I ought to first
have considered the justice of it. (The anecdote has been related by
Robson in his excellent book "Justice and Administrative Law" 3
ed p.362. It has been referred to by Akram J. in Hameed-ul-Haq
Chaudhry v GG-PLD 1953 FC 279.297).
Thus, "justice" has been a favourite subject with all the
great philosophers of the world. It must however be remembered
that in a court of law justice does not mean abstract justice or
justice in any esoteric or philosophic sense; it means, and means
20
21
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 29
only, legal justice, that is justice in accordance with law. (Lord
Denning in Jones v National Coal Board (1957) 2 QB 55). Thus, in
Duport Steels v Sirs (1980) 1 All ER 529) Lord Scarman, in setting
aside the decision of the Court of Appeal said:
"My basic criticism of all three
judgments in the Court of Appeal is that
in their desire to do justice, the Court
failed to do justice according to law".
And in Ali Nawaz Gardezi case (PLD 1962 Lah. 558, 619),
Shabbir Ahmed, J. said:
"The invocation of the oft-quoted
judicial maxim to the effect that justice.
should not only be done but must been,
seen to be done would not be apt in a
case where the court has followed the
law because in a court of law justice
means neither more nor less than the
administration of the law of the land"..
Social Justice
Whatever meaning the term 'justice' may bear in a
particular context, justice in its truest sense of the word is the
ultimate goal of criminal justice; "criminal justice cannot be
achieved in the absence of social justice", an ideal "which
embraces all aspects of civilized life and which is linked to
fundamental notions of fairness and cultural beliefs about right and
wrong". ("Criminal Justice Today" by Frank Schmalleger, 4" ed.
P.14).
Criminal justice and civil justice are both aspects of the
wider form of equity termed 'social justice'. Civil justice concerns
itself with faimess in relationship between citizens, government
agencies, and business in private matters involving contractual
obligations, business dealings, hiring and equality of treatment and
22
so on. Criminal justice, in its broadest sense, refers to those aspects
of social justice which concern violations of the criminal law.
Community interests demand apprehension and punishment of law
violators. At the same time, criminal justice ideals extend to the
protection of the innocent, the fair treatment of offenders, and fair
play by the agencies of law enforcement. ("Criminal Justice
Today" at p.14).
An indication of what the concept "social justice" means
and includes is afforded by Article 37 of the Constitution, which
occurs in Part II, Chapter 2, titled "Principles of Policy". Though
the Principles of Policy are not enforceable at law, yet, as Article
29, clause (1), provides "it is the responsibility of each organ and
authority of the State, and of each person performing functions on
behalf of an organ or authority of the State, to act in accordance
with those Principles in so far as they relate to the functions of the
organ or authority".
The heading of Article 37 is: "Promotion of social
justice and eradication of social evils". The State shall, so directs
Article 37, among others, promote, with special care, the
educational and economic interests of backward classes or areas:
ensure inexpensive and expeditious justice etc.
While ensuring inexpensive and expeditious justice is
directly related to the administration of justice, both civil and
criminal, promoting 'economic interests of backward classes" has
an indirect but very significant relation with the economic interests
of the poor and indigent class of accused persons, who have no
means to hire private counsel. This provision can thus serve as an
aid to the interpretation of Article 10 of the Constitution, which.
inter-alia, guarantees the right to counsel. (Please see the
discussion under Article 10 in the Constitutional Criminal
Procedure part of this book).
23
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 30
Social Justice In Islam
As regards 'social justice as enunciated by Islam', the
fundamental principle both in civil and criminal matters, in Islam is
Al-Adl wal Ehsan. Adl is usually translated as 'justice', but is a
much more comprehensive expression. It means social balance or
equilibrium in social and economic relations. (Qazalbash Waqaf
case - PLD 1990 SC 99, 125). "Ehsan' literally means 'restoring
the balance by making up for a loss or a deficiency". The relevant
provisions in the Holy Quran, inter-alia, are S.4:58, S.16:90,
S.4:136, and S.5:8; translated in English, they read:
S.4:58-
S.16:90-
S.4:136-
S.5:8-
"Allah doth command you.....when
ye judge between man and man, to
judge with justice.....
"Allah commands justice, the doing
of good (Ehsan).
O ye who believe! Stand out firmly
for justice, as witnesses to Allah,
even as against yourselves, or your
parents or your kin and whether it
be (against) rich or poor.....
O ye who believe! Stand out firmly
for Allah, as witnesses, to fair
dealing (Qist) and let not the hatred
of others to you make you swerve
to wrong or depart from justice
(Adl). Be just that is next to piety
(Taqwa) and fear Allah.
It will be noted that the Holy Quran uses 'Adl' in S.4:58,
Adl and Ehsan' in S.16.90, 'Qist' in S.4:136 and 'Qist', 'Adl' and
'Taqwa in $.5:8.
Adl and Ehsan thus appear to be comprehensive enough
to include 'social justice'. (See Qazalbash case at p. 125). Unlike
the Western system of administration of justice, it is not all one-
sided all in favour of the accused person. It strikes a fair balance
between the rights of the society, of the victim and his heirs and of
the accused. As was said in Gul Hassan case (PLD 1989 SC 635.
650, 670), all offences affecting human body are, from Islamic
point of view, to be considered from two perspectives; one, as
injuring the rights of the victim or his survivors and two, as
injuring the rights of the society. The Islamic system is dominated
not by the passion of vengeance (a theory of punishment known as
retaliation) alone, but justice tempered with mercy. (Pervaiz Iqbal
case PLD 1985 SC 134). Along with Qisas (retaliation) it
recognizes the in the victim or his heirs to forgive the
offender and compound the offences affecting human body. Under
this system. "To forgive is blessed" and forgiveness is as much part
of justice as revenge. According to Al-Quran, S.2:237, translated
into English, forgiveness is the nearest to righteousness. (Taqwa:
The word "righteousness" does not do justice to Taqwa'; it is a
word of much greater and higher significance).
Thus, one important feature of the Islamic
administration of criminal justice in contrast to the Anglo-
American system is that while in the Anglo-American system.
victims of crime are a vast forgotten class, in the Islamic system,
the victim or his heirs have an important role to play in the decision
of cases of crimes affecting human body. There is, it is interesting
to note, now in the West a new recognition of the need to balance
(1) the respect accorded the rights of individuals facing criminal
prosecution against (2) the valid interests of society in preventing
future crimes..... Thanks to a grass root resurgence of concern for
the plight of victims which began in the early 1970s there is a
move in America for a victim's Bill of Rights. (See "Criminal
Justice Today" by Frank Schmalleger, p. 8 and p. 376. Also see the
book "The Victims" by Frank G. Carrington. What Mr. Carrington
proposes "as our central task" is: We must develop a "victim -
consciousness" ini our society, and reorient the thinking and
concerns of the criminal justice system towards the rights of the
24
24
25
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 31
victims of crime). As was said in a recent case, "justice is not for
one, but is for all and while examining the case of convict, the
court owes a duty to the legal heirs/relatives of the victim and to
the society that justice shall also be done with them as well".
(Kamran Malik v State-PLD 2006 SC 354).
Chapter 4
The Constitutional Setting
It is one of the basic and underlying principles of every
constitutional government that governmental powers are divided
into three principal departments the Legislative, the Executive
and the Judicial (Exparte Virginia- 100 US 339-25 L Ed 676). In
other words, a State acts by its legislative, its executive or its
judicial authorities. It can act in no other way. As Chief Justice
Marshall put it, "The legislature makes, the executive executes and
the judiciary construes the law. (Wayman-(1825) 6 L Ed 253).
Pakistan is a Federation, and it is a special feature of the
federal system of government that the powers of sovereignty are
divided between the federation and the federating units; in our
country, it is between the Federation and the Provinces, in US, it is
between the Federation and the States.
Chapter 1 of Part V of the Constitution of Pakistan
provides for the distribution of legislative powers between the
Parliament, which is the legislative organ of the Federation, and the
Provincial Assemblies of the Provinces, which are the legislative
organs of the Provinces. The legislative powers are listed in the
Federal Legislative List, which contains a list of the matters in
respect of which the Parliament has the exclusive power to
legislate, in the Concurrent Legislative List, which contains a list of
the matters in respect of which both the Parliament and the
Provincial Assemblies can legislate. The matters which are not
mentioned in either of these Lists are within the exclusive
legislative competence of the Provincial Assemblies. A relevant
example is "land"; it is a matter not mentioned in either of the Lists
and is therefore an exclusive provincial legislative matter.
These lists are to be found in the 4 Schedule of the
Constitution.
"Criminal Law" including all matters included in the
Pakistan Penal Code and "Criminal Procedure" including all
matters included in the Code of Criminal Procedure, are matters
which appear as items 1 and 2 in the Concurrent Legislative List;
that is to say, these are matters on which both the Parliament and
the Provincial Assemblies can legislate.
Other matters relating to procedure, such as civil
procedure, evidence and limitation, are also in the Concurrent
Legislative List; they are items 3 and 4 respectively.
Subject to the Constitution, Parliament may make laws.
so provides Article 141, including laws having extra-territorial
operation, for the whole or any part of Pakistan and a Provincial
Assembly may make laws for the Province or any part thereof.
Regarding such areas as are not included in any Province, e.g.
Tribal Areas, the Parliament has, under Article 142, exclusive
power to make laws.
Article 143 makes provision for a situation where on a
matter in the Concurrent Legislative List, both the Parliament and a
Provincial Assembly choose to legislate, or where there is
inconsistency between an existing law and a Provincial. In such a
case, the Act of Parliament or as the case may be, the existing law
"shall prevail and the Act of the Provincial Assembly shall, to the
extent of the repugnancy, be void".
"Existing law" is defined in Article 268(7) of the
Constitution to mean all laws in force in Pakistan immediately
before the Constitution of 1973 came into effect.
26
27
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 32
All three organs of the State the Legislature, the
Executive and the Judiciary - are involved in an effective criminal
justice system. The Legislature makes laws creating offences,
fixing penalties for them and providing for the procedure for their
enforcement; the Executive executes these laws by detecting
crimes, arresting the offenders, collecting the evidence and
determining whether the case against the alleged offender merits
prosecution, and the Judiciary tries the alleged offender to
determine his guilt and if found guilty to punish him in accordance
with law. Every trial, it is to be mentioned, involves the exercise of
judicial power, and the criminal justice system is an important
element in the rule of law.
Chapter 5
Substantive and Procedural Criminal Law
General Observations:
Crime affects the quality of life of citizens and non-
citizens alike and it is the direct responsibility of the criminal
justice system to control it.
The basic purpose of government is to protect the life,
liberty and property of its citizens and this purpose is largely
achieved by the enforcement of its criminal law. The stress is on
preservation of social order and the society's values. By
'enforcement we mean the detection and investigation of crimes,
and the arrest, charging, adjudication, sentencing and execution of
punishment. A system of criminal law, including its enforcement
by the State, is therefore an essential component in the existence of
a civilized society under the rule of law, (R v Connor (2004) I All
ER 925, 965).
Criminal justice is said to have two aspects: substantive
and procedural. Substantive criminal law creates offences and
provides punishments for them; and procedural criminal law (or
criminal procedure) provides for the means and mechanism for the
enforcement of the substantive criminal law. It is the substantive
law which tells us what we can and cannot do in our relationship
with other individuals as well as the society, represented by the
State. In the field of criminal law, for example, the statutes which
define crimes are substantive laws. In the words of Hart, "The aim
of making an act criminal is to announce to society that these acts
are not to be done...". Procedural law, on the other hand, is that
law which tells us how we may enforce the substantive law. It
defines the process (ie. the procedure) of the law, dealing with
such subjects as the method of determining whether the substantive
law has been violated. In the field of criminal law, procedural law
encompasses the processes followed in investigating crimes,
apprehending the offender, determining his guilt or innocence and
applying the sentence ordered by the court". (Introduction to the
"Criminal Justice System" by Hazel B. Kerper, 2d ed. p.32).
Thus substantive criminal law tells us what constitutes a
crime, and if it is duly proved to have been committed, what its
punishment will be for the offender, and procedural criminal law
tells us how to enforce it. In the words of Karam Elahi Chohan J. in
S. M. Junaid case (PLD 1981 SC 12) "substantive law is concerned
with the ends but the procedural law with the means and
instruments by which those ends are to be attained".
Nature of distinction - Drawing the line:
It is not always easy to state with precision the exact
nature of the distinction between the substantive law and the
procedural law:
"The reasons for this are not far to seek.
Generally it is said that substantive law
is that which defines the rights (and
obligations) while procedural law
determines the remedies, but this may
not always be correct, inasmuch as there
are many rights in wide sense which
belong to the sphere of procedure, for
28
29
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 33
example, a right of appeal, a right to give
evidence on one's own behalf.........
which are considered as substantive
rights. This shows that rules defining the
remedies may sometimes be as much
part of the substantive law as are those
which define the right itself....... what
then is the true distinction? In our
opinion the law of procedure may be
defined as that branch of law which
govers the process of litigation. It is the
law of action using the term
'action' in a wide sense to include all
legal proceedings, civil and criminal. All
the residue is substantive law and relates
not to the process of litigation but to its
purpose and subject-matter. Substantive
law is concerned with the ends but the
procedural law with the means and
instruments by which those ends are to
be attained.
These are the broad outlines of some of
the principles with reference to which
the nature of each law or of a provision
of any law should generally be
examined. in its own context, hefore
holding whether it is a procedural law or
a substantive law, taking notice also of
such rules of procedure as mentioned
earlier which in practical operation are
sometimes wholly or substantially
equivalent to rules of substantive law,
and wherein difference between two
branches is merely one of form rather
than of substance". (S. M. Junaid v
President of Pakistan PLD 1981 SC
12, 15).
30
In this behalf, Adnan Afzal v Sher Afzal (PLD 1969 SC
187) is also frequently cited. Reference may also usefully be made
to Hakim Ali Zardari v State (PLD 1998 SC 1), a bail matter which
has been considered under the heading 'Bail' in a later part of this
book.
S. M. Junaid case did not turn upon the facts of a
particular case. The question was an abstract question whether
section 3 of the Limitation Act. 1908, was repugnant to the
Injunctions of Islam within the meaning of Article 203D of the
Constitution. That section provides that any suit instituted, appeal
preferred, and application made after the period of limitation
prescribed in the First Schedule to the Act "shall be dismissed.
although limitation has not been set up as a defence". Under Article
203B of the Constitution, the jurisdiction of the Federal Shariat
Court does not extend, inter-alia, to any law relating to the
procedure of any court or tribunal, and the question in S. M. Junaid
case was whether section 3 of the Limitation Act was a law relating
to the procedure of any court or tribunal. The answer was 'yes'.
The general observation of the Supreme Court that "the law of
procedure may be defined as that branch of law which governs the
process of litigation. It is the law of 'action', using the term
'action' in a wide sense to include all legal proceedings, civil or
criminal" (which observation seems to be based largely upon
Salmond's Jurisprudence) must therefore be read in that limited
context. The question whether one can acquire a vested right under
a procedural law, e.g. under the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898.
or under the Limitation Act, 1908, is altogether a different question
and will be dealt with when we consider the rule that generally
procedural laws are retrospective.
Chapter 6
Importance and Status of Criminal Procedure
There can be no greater testimony to the importance of
the criminal procedure than this that in the US Constitution and in
31
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 34
almost all the democratic constitutions of the world, including
Pakistan, which follow the US pattern, the basic criminal
procedural rights stand incorporated and guaranteed. This is "based
on the cognizance of the historical and potential abuses of the
criminal prosecution and therefore of the necessity of erecting
elaborate procedural safeguards between the govemment and the
individual". But as has been said it is a very easy thing to devise
good laws; the difficulty is to make them effective. Despite these
constitutional guarantees, the international community has
remained so concerned with the misuse and abuse of the criminal
justice process that the right to due process and fairness has been
reaffirmed and elaborated since 1948 in numerous binding
international treaties and conventions, establishing international
standards of faimess, They reflect the saying of Martin Luther
King:
"Injustice anywhere is a threat to justice
everywhere".
"Criminal procedure" has thus been internationalized
(Based upon these treaties and conventions, Amnesty International
has prepared a Fair Trial Manual listing as many as 32 Human
Rights which assure that individuals receive fair treatment and are
not unjustly punished). This is in reality an international effort at
humanizing criminal procedure. The result is that no country can
now afford to be a 'republic of bees'; no country can now remain
unconcemed with and uninfluenced by what is going on around the
world. Decisions of courts such as the English Courts, the US
Supreme Court and the European Court of Justice have great
persuasive value and decisions of one country are frequently cited
and followed in other countries.
We have seen that 'criminal law' creates offences; in so
doing it identifies certain ends, which it seeks to achieve. However
good and just the laws and the political principles supporting them
may be, without suitable procedure, they would fail in their
purposes" (Professor DJ. Galligan in his "Due Process and Fair
Procedure").
Much of our substantive law, Lord Denning tells us to
remember, "is found laced in with procedure". For example, Justice
Frankfurter said that "the history of American freedom is, in no
small measure, the history of procedure". But in addition, "the
procedural rules which have been fashioned from the generality of
due process are our best instruments for the distillation and
evaluation of essential facts from the conflicting welter of data that
life and our adversary methods present. It is those instruments of
due process which enhance the possibility that truth will emerge
from the confrontation of opposing versions and conflicting data.
Procedure is to law what scientific method is to science". (In re
Guait-387 US I per Justice Fortas).
Thus, procedure is a means to an end; as Justice William
0. Douglas of the US Supreme Court said in a 1956 case-
"A civilized system of law is as much
concerned with the means employed to
bring people to justice as it is with the
ends themselves. A first principle of
jurisprudence is that the ends do not
justify the means".
So important is the position of the criminal procedure in the
hierarchy of laws that-
"The quality of a nation's civilization
can be largely measured by the methods
it uses in the enforcement of its criminal
law" (quoted by Warren CJ. in Miranda
v Arizona-384 US 436).
In sum, the substantive criminal law and the procedural criminal
law complement each other and failure of the latter is failure of the
former, which can mean failure of the social goals which the
society seeks to achieve by enacting the substantive criminal law.
Thus, criminal procedure is the criminal justice system in action.
32
33
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 35
Chapter 7
Procedural Laws their purpose, and interpretation
The law of procedure is what is commonly termed by
jurists as 'adjective law the aggregate of rules of procedure or
practice, as opposed to the body of law which the courts are
established to administer, that is, the substantive law; it means the
rules according to which the substantive law is administered; that
part of the law which provides a method or mechanism for
enforcing or maintaining rights or obtaining redress for their
invasion. (This statement has been taken from Black's Law
Dictionary; it is based upon some American cases cited there).
i)
Their purpose and status
Rules of procedure are a means of ascertaining and
reaching the truth and doing justice in accordance with law. "While
considering the importance of legal technicalities and rules of
procedure in the administration of justice, it is inevitable to recall
the various evolutionary stages in the transition from justice
without law of primitive society to justice in accordance with law
of modern society and the conflict between equity and law in
judicial history. It cannot be denied that legal precepts were
devised with a view to impart certainty, consistency and uniformity
to administration of justice and to secure it against arbitrariness,
errors of individual judgment and malafide... Mere
technicalities unless offering an insurmountable hurdle should not
be allowed to defeat the ends of justice..." (Khuda Yar case -
PLD 1975 SC 678, 691). "I think", said Kaikaus J. in Imtiaz
Ahmad v Ghulam Ali, (PLD 1963 SC 382, 400) "the proper place
of procedure in any system of administration of justice is to help
and not to thwart the grant to the people of their rights. All
technicalities have to be avoided unless it be essential to comply
with them on ground of public policy. The English system of
administration of justice on which our own is based may be to a
certain extent technical but we are not to take from that system its
defects. Any system, which by giving effect to the form and not to
the substance defeats substantive rights and is defective to that
extent. The ideal must always be a system that gives to every
person what is his". As has been said by Lord Donaldson MR, in a
recent English case, Kenneth Allision Ltd. v A. E. Lime House,
(1990) 2 All ER 723, 727) "The rules are servants of the courts and
of their customers, not their masters; unless expressed in a wholly
mandatory and exclusive fashion........it would be wholly contrary
to the spirit of the times that the rules should be construed in a
manner which would forbid parties to litigation to act reasonably
with a view to eliminating or reducing the acerbilies inevitable in
litigation.......
ii)
To be construed liberally:
Keeping in view the purpose that the procedural laws are
intended to subserve and the status of procedural rules, as noticed
above, procedural statutes must receive broad and beneficial
construction (Maxwell on "Interpretation of Statutes". 12th ed.
p.102). It is a sound rule of construction that procedural enactments
should be construed liberally and in such manner as to render the
substantive rights effective (Veluswami v Raja Nainar - AIR 1959
SC 422, 426). The rules are made for the advancement of justice
and they should not, as far as possible, be allowed to operate so as
to defeat the ends of justice. The rules are in the nature of enabling
provisions and substantial compliance with them should be enough
(Toor Gul v Mumtaz Begum - PLD 1972 SC 9, 13). It is on this
principle that the law of pleadings has never been strictly construed
and rigorously applied in its technicalities to this country (S. M.
Ayub v Yusaf PLD 1967 SC 486).
Procedural statutes are remedial statutes and the
principle is that remedial statutes should be construed in a manner
so as to advance the remedy and suppress the mischief or else it
would frustrate the legislative intendment (Divl. Supdt v Bashir
Ahmad-PLD 1973 SC $89).
34
35
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 36
As to the rules of construction applicable to the statutes
like the Code of Civil Procedure and the Code of Criminal
Procedure, the classic statement of the law is to be found in
Mehmood J's judgment in Narsingdas v. Mangle Dubey (1882) s
All 172); said that great Judge:
"the courts are not to act upon the
principle that every procedure is to be
taken as prohibited unless it is expressly
provided for by the Code, but on the
converse principle that every procedure
is to be understood as permissible till it
is shown to be prohibited by the law. As
3 matter of general principle,
prohibitions cannot be presumed, and in
the present case therefore it rests upon
the defendants to show the suit in the
form in which it has been brought is
prohibited by the rules of procedure
applicable to the courts of justice in
India".
It is now a settled rule of interpretation of procedural
laws that the Court should proceed on the principle that every
procedure which furthers administration of justice is permissible
even if there is no express provision permitting it, and that the
court ought not to act on the principle that every procedure is to be
taken as prohibited unless it is expressly provided for (S. M. Saya
and Co. v Wazir Ali-PLD 1969 SC 65).
Also, it is a sound rule, recognized by almost all general
codes of procedural law and absolutely essential for the
preservation of all duly considered verdicts that an omission or
error in procedure, unless it has occasioned a failure of justice of
prejudiced a party in the presentation of his case, is not a sufficient
ground for reversing the decision (Mst. Bibi Jan and others versus
R. A. Monny and another PLD 1961 SC 69).
iii)
Retrospectivity and Procedural Laws:
Power to legislate includes the power to
legislate Retrospectivity
The established rule is that subject to any constitutional
bar there is no legal limit to the making and un-making of laws by
a Legislature. Also, it is within the domain of the Legislature to
appoint a date for the commencement of the laws made by it
including a date preceding the making of the laws. In short, the
authority to legislate includes the authority to legislate with
retrospective effect, even from a date earlier than the formation of
the legislative body itself (Sh. Amin Ullah v Pannu Ram - PLD
1967 SC 289). As long as the power to enact laws remains in force,
it is a power to make laws for all times past as well as future, that
is, with prospective as well as retrospective operation, unless of
course there be some limitation on the power of the Legislature
(Noorani Cotton Corp. v Sales Tax Officer PLD 1965 SC 161).
For example, in Sh. Amin Ullah v. Pannu Ram (PLD 1967 SC
289), the Governor had promulgated the Rent Restriction
Ordinance 1959 in pursuance of the proclamation of emergency
issued on 7 October 1958 and the question was whether he could
give effect to the Ordinance from an earlier date. It was held that
the Governor could make law with retrospective effect. In Khaliq
and Najam Company v. Sales Tax Officer (PLD 1959 (WP) Lah.
915), the President promulgated an Ordinance amending Section
2(11) of Sales Tax Act 1951 with retrospective effect, making
cotton ginners liable to sales tax from a back date. The power was
up-held.
b)
Constitutional bar to Retrospectivity
The only constitutional bar against retrospectivity is
contained in Article 12 of the Constitution, which forbids any law
to authorize the punishment of a person (a) for an act or omission
that was not punishable by law at the time of the act or omission; or
(b) for an offence by a penalty greater than, or of a kind different
36
37
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 37
from, the penalty prescribed by law for that offence at the time the
offence was committed".
The equality clause in Article 25 of the Constitution
does not, however, create a bar against retrospective laws
(Muhammad Yousaf v Chief Settlement Commissioner - PLD
1968 SC 101).
c)
Meaning of Retrospectivity
"Retrospectivity has been variously defined. "If an Act
provides that at a past date the law shall be taken to have been what
it was not, that I understand to be retrospective........"; (1891) 2
Ch.1.11,12 cited in Emperor v Sibnath Bannerjee - AIR 1943 FC
75); according to Halsbury's Laws of England Vol. 36, p.436. "The
courts regard as retrospective any statute which operates on cases
or facts coming into existence before its commencement" (cited in
Nabi Ahmad v Home Secretary - PLD 1969 SC 599). A statute is
retrospective if it takes away or impairs a vested right acquired
under existing laws, or creates a new obligation or imposes a new
duty, or attaches a new disability, in regard to events already past
(Yew Bon Tew - (1962) 3 All ER 833, 836).
There is no fundamental difference between
retrospective and ex post facto law. The former expression is used
in respect of civil matters and the latter in respect of criminal
matters which by their nature are more serious (Nabi Ahmad v
Home Secretary-PLD 1969 SC 599, 610). The leading authority
in America on the meaning of ex post facto legislation is Calder v
Bull (3 US (3 Dall) 386): "(i) Every law that makes an action done
before the passing of the law, and which was innocent when done,
criminal, and punishes such action; (ii) Every law that aggravates a
crime or makes it greater than it was when committed; (iii) Every
law that changes the punishment, and inflicts a greater punishment,
than the law annexed to the crime when committed; (iv) Every law
that alters the legal rules of evidence, and receives less or different
testimony than the law required at the time of the commission of
the offence, in order to convict the offender" is an ex post facto law
38
(cited in Nabi Ahmad v Home Secretary PLD 1969 SC 599,
611).
d)
The Rule against Retrospectivity
Power to legislate retrospective laws is one thing and the
power to determine whether a law is or is not retrospective in
operation is another. The latter is a question of interpretation and is
for the courts. For the determination of that question, the
fundamental rule is that the statutes "are construed as operating
only on cases and on facts which come into existence after the
statutes were passed unless a retrospective effect is clearly
intended. It is a fundamental rule that no statute shall be construed
to have a retrospective operation unless such a construction appears
very clearly in the terms of the Act, or arises by necessary and
distinct implication". (This statement of law is at page 215 of
Maxwell on Interpretation of Statutes. It has been "so frequently
quoted with approval that it now itself enjoys almost judicial
authority". See Amir Ashfaque Qureshi v University of
Engineering 1992 CLC 2186, 2189).
The general principle with regard to the interpretation of.
statutes as laid down in the well known case of Colonial Sugar
Refining Company v. Irving (1905) AC 369) is that "if the matter
in question is a matter of procedure only", the provision would be
retrospective. "On the other hand, if it be more than a matter of
procedure, if it touches a right in existence at the passing of the
Act", then "in accordance with a long line of authorities extending
from the time of Lord Coke to the present day", the legislation
would not operate retrospectively, unless the Legislature had either
"by express enactment or by necessary intendment" given the
legislation retroactive effect. In the Colonial Sugar Refining
Company Ltd. case, right of appeal was treated as a substantive
right and not a procedural right: "In principle their Lordships see
no difference between abolishing an appeal altogether and
transferring the appeal to a new tribunal".
39
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 38
1
c)
Exception-Procedural Laws
Procedural laws are generally retrospective, and
constitute an exception to the rule pertaining to retrospectivity of
statutes generally. The reason why there is an exception in the case
of a statute which is 'purely procedural", is because "no person has
a vested right in any particular course of procedure, but a right to
prosecute or defend a suit according to the rules for the conduct of
an action for the time being prescribed". (A. M. Qureshi v USSR -
PLD 1981 SC 377,421)
Though the rule is that all alterations in procedure are
retrospective unless there is some good reason to the contrary, yet
as was emphasized by the Federal Court in Venugopala Reddiar
case, (AIR 1943 FC 24) this rule is sometimes too broadly stated.
In one sense, a right of appeal may be spoken of as a matter of
procedure as it is usually provided for in codes relating to
procedure. But as was recognized in Colonial Sugar Refining
Company v. Irving, that is not sufficient to make a legislative
provision governing the right of appeal retrospective. In short, all
that is contained in a procedural code, such as the Code of Criminal
Procedure 1898, is not necessarily procedural. Similarly a
Limitation Act is usually described as procedural, but in fact it may
be both procedural and substantive. For example, Section 28 of the
Limitation Act, 1908, was an example of a substantive law; it
provided that at the expiration of the period of limitation for
recovery of property, the title of the owner stood extinguished.

Amending Law affecting rights:
This question assumes importance, when the law is
enacted or amended during the pendency of a suit or proceeding. In
Adnan Afzal v Sher Afzal (PLD 1969 SC 187) 'A' applied for
maintenance under section 488 of the Code of Criminal Procedure
before a Magistrate on 4 of September 1964. The matter was
pending when the West Pakistan Family Courts Act 1964 came
into force giving jurisdiction in such matters to the Family Court.
The Magistrate directed 'A' to seek his remedy in Family Courts.
In these facts it was held that the Family Courts Act had changed
the forum, altered the method of trial and empowered the Family
Courts to grant better remedies and it had "in every sense of the
term brought about only procedural changes and not affected any
substantive right". As there was nothing in the West Pakistan
Family Court Act to the contrary, that Act was given retrospective
effect and the Magistrate was held to have rightly directed 'A' to
seek his remedy in the Family Courts. This principle was applied in
Hakim Ali Zardari v Siate (PLD 1998 SC 1). The amendment in
bail law was treated as procedural and hence retrospective. (This
view has been commented upon under the title 'Bail').
But, when the question is whether an amending law has
affected or impaired existing rights or obligations, it is not enough
to decide what label to apply to the amending law - procedural or
substantive or whether the amending law is procedural or
substantive For as was said in Yew Bon Tew v Kenderaan Bas
Mora (1982) 3 All ER 833), the expressions 'retrospective' and
"procedural', though useful in a particular context, are equivocal
and therefore can be misleading. This question can best be
illustrated by some cases under the law of limitation.
The relevance of the law of limitation, itself a procedural
law, to the 'criminal procedure is that time-limits may be fixed
within which a prosecution will be brought, and if the prosecution
is not brought within that time-limit, it may not be brought at all.
For example, section 198A, Cr.P.C. by its sub-section (4), forbids
the court to take cognizance of the offence mentioned in sub-
section (1) thereof, unless the complaint is made within six months
from the date of the offence. And one important change brought
about by the re-enacted Indian Code of Criminal Procedure 1973,
successor of the 1898 Code, is that by its section 468(2), it has
fixed the following periods of limitation:
six months, if the offence is punishable with
fine only;
(a)
(b)
one year, if the offence is punishable with
imprisonment for one year,
40
41
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 39
(c)
three years, if the offence is punishable with
imprisonment for a term exceeding one year
but not exceeding three years.
In Yew Bon Tew (1982) 3 All ER 833), an action could be
brought, under a 1948 Ordinance, within a period of 12 months,
which ended on 5 April 1973. No action was brought within that
period. On 13 June 1974, the law was, amended and the period of
limitation for such actions was fixed as 36 months. An action was
actually brought on 20 March 1975. It was held that the proper.
approach to the construction of the 1974 Act-
"is not to decide what label to apply to it,
procedural or otherwise, but to see
whether the statute, if applied
retrospectively to a particular type of
case, would impair existing rights and
obligations. A Limitation Act
may be procedural in the
context of one set of facts but
substantive in the context of a different
set of facts".
As the action here was brought long after the lapse of the period of
limitation prescribed by the 1948 Ordinance, the defendant had
acquired a right to plead the time-bar which-
"is in every sense a right, even though it
arises under an Act which is
procedural".
Let us apply this principle to a criminal case. Suppose
that the 1948 Ordinance prescribed a period of 12 months for
bringing a prosecution against an accused, but no prosecution was
brought within that period. Suppose also that after the expiry of the
period of 12 months, the 1948 Act was amended prescribing a
period of 36 months for such an offence and taking advantage of
the amended law, a prosecution is brought long after the period of
12 months under the 1948 Ordinance had expired. On the principle
42
enunciated in Yew Bon Tew, such a prosecution must fail, for the
accused had acquired under the 1948 Ordinance, a vested right to
plead the time-bar, which was in every sense a right even though it
had arisen under a procedural law.
But if by the amending law, the time is enlarged while a
person is still within time under the existing law, the statute will be
procedural and retrospective. Thus, in R v Chandra Dharma (1905)
2 KB 335: (1904-7) All ER 570), an offence was committed on 15
July 1904. Under the relevant law, a prosecution could be brought
within 3 months, that is up to 15 October 1904. On 1 October
1904, the law was amended and the time-limit was extended to 6
months. The prosecution was initiated on 27 December, 1904. It
was held that the prosecution was within time, for the amended law
was, in the facts of the case. applied retrospectively.
The principle, thus, is that if the new statute alters the
character of the offence or takes away any defence which was open
to the defendant, it is a matter of substantive law. But if it merely
alters the time-limit, it is a matter of procedure..
However, if the time-limit under the old law had expired
before the new law extending the period of limitation is passed, the
new law would not apply, because then the accused's right to plead
the time-bar, acquired under the old law, would be affected, and the
new law would not be applied retrospectively.
It is, therefore, unwise to attribute a prima facie
retrospective effect to all that is contained in a procedural statute.
e.g. a statute of limitation. Statutes which enable a person to
enforce a cause of action which was then barred or provide a bar to
an existing cause of action by abridging the time of its institution
could hardly be described as merely procedural. They would affect
substantive rights.
The view taken in Yew Bon Tew and Chandra Dharma
cases seems to be in accord with Article 264 of the Constitution
and the corresponding provision in the General Clauses Acts,
43
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 40
which provide for the effect of repeal of laws. They provide that
the repeal of a law shall not, among others, "affect any right,
privilege, obligation or liability acquired, accrued or suffered under
the (repealed) law". These provisions make no distinction between
a right, privilege, obligation or liability acquired, accrued or
incurred under a substantive or a procedural law. As Yew Bon Tew
holds, a right acquired under a procedural law is as much a right as
the one acquired under a substantive law.
g)
Rule applies to prevent unfairness
It is chiefly where the enactment would prejudicially
affect vested rights, or the legality of past transactions, or impair
existing contracts, that the rule against retrospectivity prevails
(Nagina Silk Mill v Income Tax Officer PLD 1963 SC 322).
A vested right must be distinguished from a contingent
right. Also, there is a distinction between a vested right and a mere
right (assuming it to be properly so called) to take advantage of an
enactment (Rafi-ud-Din v Chief Settlement Commissioner - PLD
1971 SC 252, 271 and Amir Ashfaq Qureshi v University of
Engineering 1992 CLC 2186).
Thus, the doctrine of retrospectivity operates only 10
prevent unfaimess and when the effect of a law is not unfair, the
presumption against retrospectivity will not apply. (Plewa v Chief
Adjudicating Officer-(1994) 3 WLR 317).
h)
Subordinate legislation and Retrospectivity
The general rule is that subordinate legislation operates
prospectively (Hashwani Hotels v Federation PLD 1997 SC 315).
But it can operate retrospectively if it is beneficial (Anoud Power
Generation y Federation-PLD 2001 SC 340).
PART II
Categories of Criminal Procedure
We propose to divide "Criminal Procedure" into the
following two categories, and to discuss it accordingly:
1.
2.
Constitutional Criminal Procedure; and
Ordinary or Legislative Criminal Procedure.
Chapter 1
Distinction between Constitutional and Ordinary Criminal
Procedure
Before we begin with a discussion of the two categories
of criminal procedure, we need to know what distinguishes the one
from the other.
"Constitutional Criminal Procedure" is the criminal
procedure which has been provided for, and has its roots in a
written Constitution. And as the Constitution is the supreme and
paramount law, so are the provisions relating to criminal procedure
enshrined in it, c.g. the Fundamental Rights guaranteed by the
Constitution, the underlying theory of a written Constitution, in the
trite words of the great Chief Justice John Marshall being, "that an
act of the Legislature repugnant to the Constitution is void"
[Marbury v Madison-5 US (1 Cranch) 137 (1803)].
A striking illustration is an English enactment of 1503
called the Boiling of Prisoners Act. Suppose the US Congress had
re-enacted that Act now. Would the courts have to sentence
prisoners to be boiled? The answer is 'no', for Amendment VIII to
the US Constitution forbids the infliction of "cruel and unusual
punishment". The same will be true if such a law were tested on the
touchstone of the Fundamental Right guaranteed by Article 14 of
44
45
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 41
the Constitution of Pakistan, clause (1) whereof ensures "the
dignity of man",
An Act of Legislature is an ordinary legislative
enactment enacted by a competent legislative authority in exercise
of the powers derived from the Constitution. The Code of Criminal
Procedure, 1898, which is the principal criminal procedural law of
Pakistan, is an example of an ordinary Act of the legislature, and
that Act or for that matter any other criminal procedural enactment,
will be, to the extent of any inconsistency or repugnancy to the
Constitution, void. Article 8 of the Constitution of Pakistan so
provides expressly.
We can illustrate the distinction with reference to Article
9 of the Constitution of Pakistan. That Article guarantees one of the
Fundamental Rights relating to criminal procedure and reads: "No
person shall be deprived of life and liberty save in accordance with
law".
The "law" here obviously means a valid law a
constitutionally valid law. Thus, a law made by a Provincial
Assembly, which under the Constitution is within the exclusive
legislative competence of the Parliament, will not be a valid law;
nor will a law made by any legislature be valid which contravenes
any of the Fundamental Rights guaranteed by Part II, Chapter 1, of
the Constitution. Thus a law which, for example, permits the
detention of an arrestee by the police beyond twenty-four hours of
his arrest without being produced before a magistrate, or which
provides for retroactive punishment, or which permits double
jeopardy or self-incrimination in contravention of Article 10, 12 or
13 respectively, will not be a valid law. As was said in Zia-ur-
Rehman case (PLD 1972 SC 49, 67) by Hamoodur Rahman C.J.
".....even non-constitutional provisions, if incorporated in a
Constitution, acquire a higher sanctity and stand on the same
footing as strictly constitutional provisions. No differentiation can
be made between them, once they have been given a constitutional
status by being incorporated in the Constitution itself. (For a
detailed discussion, see the author's book "Judicial Review of
Public Actions", p616).
We often say that "no person has a vested right in any
particular course of procedure". This seems to be true only of the
procedure prescribed by an ordinary enactment. This does not
apply to the procedural rights guaranteed by the Constitution. Thus,
an ordinary enactment cannot deprive a person of his constitutional
right to silence or the right against double jeopardy guaranteed by
Article 13 of the Constitution. These and other rights enshrined in
Part II, Chapter 1, of the Constitution are vested rights, vested in
the people of Pakistan by the Constitution and no ordinary law can
take them away or abridge them.
This distinction is hierarchical; it establishes the relative
importance of the two categories of criminal procedure. In the
hierarchy of laws the Constitution is supreme, and where the
Constitution and a statute collide, the latter must yield.
The second distinction lies in the consequences which
flow from the contravention of the rights guaranteed by the
Constitution and the consequences which flow from the
contravention of the tights given by ordinary legislation. It is a
well-established principle of the constitutional law that an act of
the legislature or the executive which violates, or is inconsistent
with, the Constitution is void. This principle has been expressly
recognized by Article 8 of the Constitution, which occurs in
Chapter 1 of Part II of the Constitution, which chapter confers the
Fundamental Rights enumerated therein; this principle seems to be
the basis of the American exclusionary rule namely "all evidence
obtained by searches and seizures in violation of the Constitution is
......inadmissible..." (Mapp v Ohio - 367 US 643). On the
contrary, the common law rule was that the court had no discretion
to exclude evidence simply because it had been illegally or
improperly obtained (R v Sang (1979) 2 All ER 1222, 1230).
Provided the evidence was relevant, it was admissible in law
regardless of how it was obtained. "It matters not how you get it; if
you steal it even, it would be admissible in evidence" (Crompton J.
in R v Leatham-(1861) 8 Cox CC 499, 501). Then, consequences
of the violation of any procedural provision will be determined
46
47
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 42
1
with reference to the relevant procedural law, e.g. section 537 of
the Code of Criminal Procedure or Article 162 of Qanun-e-
Shahadat, 1984, and those consequences may not be as serious as
treating the act in question void and non-existent.
Chapter 2
Constitutional Criminal Procedure
"Constitutional Criminal Procedure" is a new creature in
the legal landscape of Pakistan; it is also new as an academic topic.
But it is well-known to the Anglo-American legal literature as also
to the academics of the United States of America and the United
Kingdom. [See, for example Carol S. Steiker's "First Principles of
Constitutional Criminal Procedure: A Mistake" (1999) 112
Harvard LR 680; "Criminal Procedure and the Constitution" by
Jerold H. Israel, Yale Kemisar and Wayne R. LaFave, 1994 ed; that
book presents a collection of leading Supreme Court of US
decisions in the field of "Constitutional Criminal Procedure" and
"The Bill of Rights as a Code of Criminal Procedure" by Henry J.
Friday in (53) 1965 California Law Review 929. Also sce
"Criminal Evidence" by Professors Paul Roberts and Adrian
Zuckerman, in which at p 32 is discussed the subject under the
heading "The Human Rights Act, Constitutional Criminal
Procedure, and Beyond".]
48
PART II A
Chapter 1
Criminal Procedure In US Constitution
Bill of Rights
The First Ten Amendments to the US Constitution,
passed in 1791, also known as the Bill of Rights, read with the 14"
Amendment, contain several procedural provisions that have
exclusive applicability to criminal cases. The constitutional rights
to counsel, to indictment by grand jury, to trial by impartial jury
['grand' is sometimes misunderstood. It only means large and
distinguishes the grand jury from the petit (small) jury. So the term
refers to the size, not to the importance of the jury. The function of
the grand jury is not to determine whether someone is guilty or not,
that is the responsibility of the petit jury. The function of the grand
jury is to determine whether there is probable cause that a crime
was committed and that the accused committed it, to freedom
from cruel and unusual punishment, right against excessive bail
and double jeopardy, right to freedom from unreasonable searches
and seizures and to confront one's accusers and to have
compulsory process for one's witnesses, right not to incriminate
oneself and not to be deprived of life, liberty and property without
due process of law, have all their roots in the US Constitution.
Concepts such as the presumption of innocence, proof
beyond a reasonable doubt, general notions of fair procedure and
right to privacy are not specifically mentioned in the US
Constitution, but are part of the constitutional law of America, as
developed by the US Supreme Court. Presumption of innocence,
proof beyond reasonable doubt, it has been held, are part of the
"due process of law" Clauses in Fifth and Fourteenth Amendments.
Thus, the Constitution of the United States provides a
constitutional model of a fair criminal procedure. Of the twenty
three fundamental rights guaranteed by the First Eight
Amendments (Bill of Rights), twelve relate to criminal procedure.
"Criminal procedure was a major part of these bill of rights. The
basic rights of man turned out, in large part, to be rights to fair
criminal trial. The fundamental rights of man were closely
49
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 43
identified........with the basic rights to a fair trial. ("A History of
American Law" by Lawrence M. Friedman, pp 100, 207). In the
words of the learned author of "A History of American Law" (at p
74)-
"The Bill of Rights contained, in a way,
a mini-code of criminal procedure -
rules about warrants, searches and
seizures, forms of punishment, the
privilege against self-incrimination, and
so on".
The American Criminal Justice System, as has been said:
"values procedural faimess both as a
means to an end and as an end itself.
(The Most Wonderful Work" by Thomas
E. Baker, p 482).
The following leading cases will serve to show how this
"mini-code of criminal procedure" has developed at the hands of
the US Supreme Court, gradually, keeping pace with the changing
times; they contain what, in philosophers' language, may be called
"conceptual analysis" of the ideas enshrined in the Bill of Rights.
To quote Judge Henry J. Friendly (see his Article "The Bill of
Rights as a Code of Criminal Procedure" in 53 California Law
Review, 1965, 929, 930)-
"There are fewer brighter pages in the
history of the Supreme Court than its
efforts over the past forty years to
improve the administration of criminal
justice".
The period, if we may add, will come to about fifty years
if we add another ten years of the Warren Court, during which
period such land-mark cases as Miranda v Arizona were decided.
This should naturally lead us to a consideration of the
relevance of the American Constitution and the American
constitutional law to the Constitution of Pakistan and the
Fundamental Rights guaranteed by it. That question will be dealt
with immediately after we have had a feel and flavour of the
leading American cases.
Chapter 2
Searches and Seizuers; the Right to Privacy-
Fourth Amendment
The Fourth Amendment to the US Constitution reads:
"The right of the people to be secure in
their persons, houses, papers, and effects
against unreasonable searches and
seizures shall not be violated, and no
warrants shall issue but upon probable
cause, supported by oath or affirmation,
and particularly describing the place to
be searched and the persons or things to
be seized".
In Katz v US (389 US 347; 19 L Ed 2d 576-1967), the
petitioner was convicted in the District Court on the charge of
transmitting information by telephone from Los Angeles to Miami
and Boston, in violation of a federal statute. At trial the
Government was permitted over the petitioner's objection to
introduce evidence of the petitioner's end of telephone
conversations, overheard by FBI agents who had attached an
electronic listening and recording device to the outside of the
public telephone booth from which he had placed his calls. In
affirming his conviction, the Court of Appeals rejected the
contention that the recordings had been obtained in violation of the
Fourth Amendment, because there was no physical entrance into
the area occupied by the petitioner. On certiorari, the US Supreme
Court reversed:

The defendant challenged the search of

by the Fourth Amendment to the

The Government defends the

Entry to defendant's living quarters,

right.
At the time entry was demanded the

justify issuance of a search warrant.

Page 46
Indeed it might very well be found to be

The point of the Fourth Amendment,
which often is not grasped by zealous
officers, is not that it denies law
enforcement the support of the usual
inferences which reasonable men draw
from evidence. Its protection consists in
requiring that those inferences be drawn
by a neutral and detached magistrate
instead of being judged by the officer
engaged in the often competitive
enterprise of ferreting out crime (United
States v Lefkowitz, 285 US-452, 464).
Any assumption that evidence sufficient
to support a magistrate's disinterested
determination to issue a search warrant
will justify the officers in making a
search without a warrant would reduce
the Amendment to a nullity and leave
the people's homes secure only in the
discretion of police officers (Agnello v
United States. 269 US 20, 33). Crime,
even in the privacy of one's own
quarters, is, of course, of grave concern
to society, and the law allows such crime
to be reached on proper showing. The
right of officers to thrust themselves into
a home is also a grave concern, not only
to the individual but to a society which
chooses to dwell in reasonable security
and freedom from surveillance. When
the right of privacy must reasonably
yield to the right of search is, as a rule,
to be decided by a judicial officer, not by
a policeman or government enforcement
agent.
There are exceptional circumstances in
which, on balancing the need for
effective law enforcement against the
right of privacy, it may be contended
that a magistrate's warrant for search
may be dispensed with. But this is not
such a case, No reason is offered for not
obtaining a search warrant except the
inconvenience to the officers and some
slight delay necessary to prepare papers
and present the evidence to a magistrate.
These are never very convincing reasons
and, in these circumstances, certainly are
not enough to by-pass the constitutional
requirement. No suspect was fleeing or
likely to take flight. The search was of
permanent premises, not of a movable
vehicle. No evidence or contraband was
threatened with removal or destruction,
except perhaps the fumes which we
suppose in time would disappear. But
they were not capable at any time of
being reduced to possession for
presentation to court. The evidence of
their existence before the search was
adequate and the testimony of the
officers to that effect would not perish
from the delay of getting a warrant.
If the officers in this case were excused
from the constitutional duty of
presenting their evidence to a magistrate,
it is difficult to think of a case in which
it should be required".

probable cause to arrest the defendant until they entered the

In Illinois y Gates (462 US 213; 76 L Ed 2d 527-1983)
the respondents, Lance and Susan Gates, were indicted for
violating state drug laws, after police officer executing a search
warrant discovered marijuana and other contraband substances in
their automobile and home. Prior to that the Gates moved to
suppress evidence seized during the search. The lower court
granted the motion to suppress evidence and the State Supreme
Court affirmed. The warrant application was based upon an
anonymous handwritten note received by the police by mail and
subsequent enquiries made by the police. In pursuance of the
search warrant about 350 pounds of marijuana was recovered from
a trunk and a search of Gates' home revealed marijuana, weapons
and other contrahands. The ground on which this evidence was
suppressed by the lower court was that the affidavit submitted to
the Circuit Judge failed to support the necessary determination of
probable cause to believe that the Gates', automobile and home
contained the contraband in question...
The US Supreme Court granted certiorari and reversed:
"We agree with the Illinois Supreme
Court that an informant's veracity.
reliability and basis of knowledge are all
highly relevant in determining the value
of his report. We do not agree, however,
that these elements should be understood
as entirely separate and independent

understood simply as closely intertwined
issues that may usefully illuminate the

believe that contraband or evidence is
located in a particular place.
This totality of the circumstances
approach is far more consistent with our
prior treatment of probable cause than is
any rigid demand that specific tests be
satisfied by every informant's tip
Perhaps the central teaching of our

Probable cause is a fluid concept
on the assessment of

concluding that a search would
uncover evidence of wrongdoing, the
Fourth Amendment requires no more.

impeding the task of law enforcement.
