The Exclusionary Rule
There are two extremes of a wide spectrum:
At one end of the spectrum is the traditional common
law rule, going back at least to the mid-18" Century, succinctly
put by Lord Scarman in R v Sang (1979) 2 All ER 1222, 1242) as
follows:
"...subject to exceptions, of which
hearsay evidence is far the most
125
A
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 81
important, evidence which a judge rules
relevant is admissible however obtained.
"It matters not how you get it; if you
steal it even, it would be admissible":
this was the stark assertion by Crompton
1 in R v Leatham (1861) 8 Cox CC
498,501). The modem foundation of the
principle is to be found in the opinion of
the Judicial Committee of the Privy
Council prepared by Lord Goddard CJ in
Kuruma son of Kania v R (1955) 1 All
ER 236, 239):
"...In their Lordships' opinion the test
to be applied in considering whether
evidence is admissible is whether it is
relevant to the matters in issue. If it is, it
is admissible, and the court is not
concerned with how the evidence was
ob:ained....."
In 2 recent English case, Fox v Chief Constable (1986) 1 AC 281),
which was decided shortly before section 78 of the (English) Police
and Criminal Evidence Act 1984 (PACE) came into force, which
section changed the common law rule by giving discretion to the
court to admit or not to admit any evidence, the facts were that in
the aftermath of a road traffic accident involving the accused, the
police officers unlawfully entered the accused's home and asked
him to provide a specimen of breath. When he refused, the accused
was arrested, taken to a police station and forced to comply with
the officer's request. His breath specimen duly showed that he had
consumed alcohol more than the prescribed limit. This led to his
conviction. Lord Fraser in the House of Lords held:
"The duty of the court is to decide
whether the appellant has committed the
offence with which he is charged, and
not to discipline the police for exceeding
their powers.....
Accordingly, the evidence of the breath specimen, obtained after a
wrongful arrest of the accused and unlawful entry into his house.
was not excluded.
The common law rule that seizure of evidence by illegal
means did not affect its admissibility at the trial prevailed in
America until the Supreme Court ruled in Weeks v US (1914) 232
US 383) that in a federal prosecution, the Fourth Amendment
barred the use of evidence secured through an illegal search and
seizure. This is known as the Exclusicnary Rule. In Weeks the
question was whether the court could retain in a criminal
prosecution for the purpose of evidence the letters and
correspondence of the accused, seized from his house in his
absence and without his authority by the police holding no warrant
for his arrest and none for the search of his premises in violation of
Fourth Amendment. It was held:
"The efforts of the courts and their
officials to bring the guilty to
punishment, praiseworthy as they are,
are not to be aided by the sacrifice of
those great principles established by
years of endeavour and suffering which
have resulted in their embodiment in the
fundamental law of the land......... To
sanction such proceedings would be to
affirm by judicial decision a manifest
neglect if not an open defiance of the
prohibitions of the Constitution intended
for the protection of the people against
such unauthorized action".
This was followed in Welf v Colorado (338 US 25; 93 L Ed 1782
(1949).
126
27
127
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 82
The Fourth Amendment says nothing about how it is to
be enforced, and in Wolf, the Supreme Court explained:
"This ruling (in Weeks)... was not
derived from the explicit requirements of
the Fourth Amendment; it was not based
on legislation expressing congressional
policy in the enforcement of the
Constitution. The decision was a matter
of judicial implication. Since then it has
been frequently applied and we stoutly
adhere to it. But the immediate question
is whether the basic right to protection
against arbitrary intrusion by the police
demands the exclusion of logically
relevant evidence obtained by an
unreasonable search and seizure..... As a
matter of inherent reason. one would
suppose this to be an issue as to which
men with complete devotion to the
protection of the right of privacy might
give different answers. When we find
that in fact most of the English speaking
world does not regard as vital to such,
protection the exclusion of evidence thus
obtained, we must hesitate to treat this
remedy as an essential ingredient.......".
The Exclusionary Rule was therefore not extended to prosecutions
in a State court for a State crime; the Fourth Amendment, it was
held, "does not forbid the admission of evidence obtained by an
unreasonable search seizure" in the States.
Mapp v Ohio (367 US 643; 6 L Ed 2d 1081 (1961)
described by a writer as a bombshell in the form of exclusionary
rule, extended the rule to the States for State crimes. The facts in
Mapp were as follows: On May 23, 1957, three Cleveland police
officers arrived at Mapp's residence pursuant to information that a
128
person was hiding out in the home who was wanted for questioning
in connection with a recent bombing and that there was a large
amount of policy paraphernalia hidden in the home. Mapp and her
daughter lived on the top floor of the dwelling. Upon their arrival
at the house, the officers knocked on the door and demanded
entrance but Mapp. after telephoning her attorney, refused to admit
them without a search warrant.
The officers again came to the house some three hours.
later and forced their entry into the house by forcibly opening one
of the doors. In the meantime Mapp's attorney arrived, but the
officers would not allow him to enter or to see Mapp. Mapp
demanded to see the search warrant. A paper claimed to be a
warrant was held up by one of the officers. She grabbed the paper
and placed it in her bosom. A struggle ensued in which the officers
recovered the paper and handcuffed Mapp. She was taken to her
bedroom which was searched. After a widespread search, some
obscene materials were recovered and it was for their possession
that she was tried and convicted.
At the trial, no search warrant was produced. The State
argued that even if the search was without warrant, or otherwise
unreasonable, the seized evidence was admissible. In extending the
exclusionary rule to the State crimes, Justice Clark wrote for the
Court:
"Today we once again examine Wolf's
constitutional documentation of the right
to privacy free from unreasonable state
intrusion........ We hold that all
evidence obtained by searches and
seizures in violation of the Constitution
is, by that same authority, inadmissible
in a state court..........
In extending the substantive protection
of the process to all constitutionally
unreasonable searches state or federal
129
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 83
it was logically necessary and
constitutionally necessary that the
exclusion doctrine an essential part of
the right to privacy be also insisted
upon as an essential ingredient of the
right newly recognized by the Wolf case.
In short, the admission of the new
constitutional right by Wolf could not
consistently tolerate denial of its most
important constitutional privilege,
namely, the exclusion of the evidence
which an accused had been forced to
give by reason of the unlawful seizure.
To hold otherwise is to grant the right
but in reality to withhold its privilege
and enjoyment the purpose of
exclusionary rule is to deter - to compel
respect for the constitutional guarantee
in the only effective available way by
removing the incentive to disregard".
Justice Clark found intimate relation between a coerced
confession and coerced testimony by way of unconstitutional
seizure of goods, papers, effects, documents etc:
"They express 'supplementary phases of
the same constitutional purpose - to
maintain inviolate large areas of
personal privacy'. The philosophy of
each Amendment and of each freedom is
complementary 10, although not
dependent upon, that of the other in its
sphere of influence - the very least that
together they assure in either sphere is
that no man is to be convicted on
unconstitutional evidence",
Dealing with the argument of those who say, as did Justice (then
Judge) Cardozo in People v Defore, that under our constitutional
exclusionary doctrine "the criminal is to go free because the
constable has blundered", Justice Clark said:
"In some cases, this will undoubtedly be
the result. But, as was said in Elkins
'there is another consideration - the
imperative of judicial integrity, The
criminal goes free, if he must, but it is
the law that sets him free. Nothing can
destroy a government more quickly than
its failure to observe its own laws, or
worse, its disregard of the charter of its
own existence. As Justice Brandeis said
in Olmstead... 'If the government
becomes a law-breaker, it breeds
contempt for the law; it invites anarchy".
In US v Leon (468 US 897; 82 L Ed 2d 677 (1984), the
US Supreme Court created what is called 'good faith' exception to
the exclusionary rule. The question was whether the Fourth
Amendment exclusionary rule should be modified so as to bar the
use in the prosecution's case-in-chief of evidence obtained by
officers acting in reasonable reliance on a search warrant issued by
a detached and neutral magistrate but ultimately found to be
unsupported by probable cause.
Justice White, writing for the Court, said:
"The (exclusionary) rule
operates
as judicially created remedy designed to
safeguard Fourth Amendment rights
guaranteed through its deterrent effect,
rather than a personal constitutional right
of the person aggrieved.........
130
131
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 84
Justice Brennan in his dissenting opinion, which, if we may say so,
is one of the best statements of the rationale behind the
exclusionary rule, said that "the deterrence theory is both
misguided and unworkable". In his view, "By remaining within its
redoubt of empiricism and by basing the rule solely on the
deterrence rationale, the court has robbed the rule of legitimacy".
He went on to say that the Fourth Amendment, like other
provisions of the Bill of Rights, "restrains the power of the
govemment as a whole........ The judiciary is responsible, no less
than the executive, for ensuring that constitutional rights are
respected". He went on to say:
"When that fact is kept in mind, the role
of the courts and their possible
involvement in the concems of the
Fourth Amendment comes into sharper
focus. Because seizures are executed.
principally to secure evidence, and
because such evidence generally has
utility in cur legal system only in the
context of a trial supervised by a judge,
it is apparent that the admission of
illegally obtained evidence implicates
the same constitutional concerns as the
initial seizure of that evidence. Indeed,
by admitting unlawfully seized evidence,
the judiciary becomes a part of what is in
fact a single governmental action
prohibited by the terms of the
Amendment. Once that connection.
between the evidence-gathering role of
the police and the evidence-admitting
function of the courts is ucknowledged,
the plausibility of the Court's
interpretation becomes more suspect.
Certainly nothing in the language or
history of the Fourth Amendment
suggests that a recognition of this
132
evidentiary link between the police and
the courts was meant to be foreclosed. It
is difficult to give any meaning at all to
the limitations imposed by the
Amendment if they are read to proscribe
only certain conduct by the police but to
allow other agents of the same
government to take advantage of
evidence secured by the police in
violation of its requirements. The
Amendment therefore must be read to
condemn not only the initial
unconstitutional invasion of privacy
which is done, after all, for the purpose
of securing evidence but also the
subsequent use of any evidence so
obtained".
-
Thus, the rationale for the Exclusionary Rule articulated
in Weeks and repeated in later cases is two-fold:
i)
that the exclusionary rule is the only effective
means of protecting Fourth Amendment
rights; and
ii)
that judicial integrity requires that the courts
do not sanction illegal searches by admitting
the fruits of illegality into evidence.
As regards the consequences of the violation of the Fifth
and Sixth Amendments rights namely the right to silence and the
right to counsel, we have noticed the Exclusionary Rule laid down
in Massiah (377 US 201) that the accused's incriminating
statements (not necessarily confessions), obtained in violation of
these rights "could not constitutionally be used by the prosecution
as evidence against him at his trial"; and that laid down in Miranda
(384 US 436) namely that "the prosecution may not use statements,
whether exculpatory or inclupatory, stemming from custodial
interrogation of the defendant unless it demonstrates the use of
133
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 85
procedural safeguards effective to secure the privilege against self-
incrimination".
The Exclusionary Rule, it has been said, is simple to
state, but difficult to apply. (See the book "Justice Overruled by
Judge Burton S. Katz, p 37). Any evidence seized or obtained by
the police in violation of a fundamental constitutional right may not
be used as evidence against a criminal defendant. There are indeed
some extensions, exceptions, and permutations.
Doctrine of Fruit of Poisonous Tree
"Fruit of the poisonous tree" doctrine is an extension of the
Exclusionary Rule. (The phrase 'fruit of the poisonous tree was
coined in Nordone (308 US 338) and was used in Brown (1975)
422 US 590). Linder this doctrine, 'derivative evidence' would also
be excluded so that e.g. evidence obtained by virtue of an
inadmissible confession such as the recovery of stolen goods
hidden by the accused, would also be inadmissible. To illustrate:
suppose that the police fail to read Miranda warnings to a person
suspected of murder. The suspect confesses the killing and tells the
police the he hid the weapon of offence at a certain place. He
actually leads the police to the recovery. The confession will be
suppressed as being in violation of the Miranda rights and the
recovery of weapon, as being "the fruit of the poisonous tree".
It needs to be explained that the Exclusionary Rule is
specific to systems of government with a written constitution,
which guarantees some fundamental rights relating to criminal
procedure.

PART II B
CRIMINAL PROCEDURE AND THE CONSTITUTION OF
PAKISTAN
Chapter 1
Preliminary
We have seen, that one of the objectives of the
Constitution of Pakistan is to ensure that the principles of "social
justice" as enunciated by Islam are observed. We have discussed
the meaning and implications of "social justice" in the context of
the Islamic concept of 'Adl'. We shall discuss below the impact of
the Fundamental Rights generally on the criminal justice system in
Pakistan. Suffice it to say here that besides the Fundamental
Rights, the Constitution sets out, in Chapter 2 of Part II. certain
principles known as the "Principles of Policy", and though, as
clause (2) of Article 30 declares. those principles are not
enforceable at law, as the Fundamental Rights guaranteed by
Chapter of Part II are, yet, under Article 29(1). "it is the
responsibility of each organ and authority of the State, and of each
person performing functions on behalf of an organ or authority of
the State, to act in accordance with those principles in so far as they
relate to the functions of the organ or authority". Articles 37 and 38
are particularly relevant in this context: Article 37 enumerates the
principles for the "promotion of social justice and eradication of
social evils", one of them being the responsibility of the State to
"ensure inexpensive and expeditious justice", and Article 38 sets
out the principles for the "promotion of social and economic well-
being of the people".
Chapter 2
Relevance of cases from America and other foreign
jurisdictions:
While discussing the Fundamental Rights as guaranteed
by the Constitution of Pakistan, reference will frequently be made
135
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 86
to cases from foreign jurisdictions, such as America, Britain, and
European Union. The justification for doing so may be briefly
stated as follows.
As regards the cases from America, it is a well
recognized fact that since the incorporation of the Bill of Rights
into the US Constitution, guaranteeing the fundamental human
rights, "the same pattern has been followed in almost all the written
constitutions of incorporating a declaration of fundamental rights
therein. (Hamoodur Rehman CJ in State v Zia-ur-Rehman - PLD
1973 SC 49, 67). Muhammad Yaqub Ali J. said in Manzoor Elahi v

"Part II, Chapter I of the Constitution
(of Pakistan) contains in all twenty
Fundamental Rights which provide for
security of persons, safeguard as to
arrest and detention, prohibition of
slavery, forced labour etc. Most of these
rights reflect the Charter of Human
rights adopted by the United Nations
Organization and to which all states are.
required to subscribe when admitted to

constitutions of a number of civilized
states of the world. Pakistan has, in fact,
improved on them in more than one

Thus, it was acknowledged in Jibendra Kishore case (PLD 1957

"Article 14 of the Constitution of India

of apparent similarity of expressions or
concepts in an alien jurisprudence
developed by a society whose approach
to similar problems on account of
historical or other reasons differs from

In Deoman, the Supreme Court of India relied upon
some American cases to determine the scope of the equality clause
in the Indian Constitution. In a recent case, District Registrar v
Canara Bank (AIR 2005 SC 186), a number of American cases
were relied upon to show how the concept of 'privacy of the home'
had developed in America and what relevance the concept so

Katz (389 US 347), which holds that the US Fourth Amendment
protects "people and not places", it was held that the Indian
Supreme Court had accepted that the right to privacy (which itself

was not expressly provided but was derived, inter alia, from the

As regards cases from the United Kingdom, they have.
so said Anwar-ul-Huq J. in Manzoor Elahi case (PLD 1975 SC 66.
145)
A word of caution:
"a direct bearing under the system of law
and the constitutional pattern we have
chosen to adopt in Pakistan".
The idea is to stimulate an interest in the development of
a Constitutional Criminal Procedure of our own and for that
purpose to encourage the gleaning of guidance from all available
sources. Obviously, everybody concerned with the development of
this branch of the law the academics, the law students, the
practicing lawyers and most importantly the courts have each a
role to play. Yet, far be it from us to suggest that in the
performance of this task, the participants would wear blinkers, and
follow blindly the cases from the American jurisdiction. Linguistic
differences might suggest differences in meaning; that would
require the juxtaposition of the provision in our constitution and
the provision in the constitution of the country whose precedent is
sought to be relied upon. History, traditions and effect of the
decisions on the jurisprudence and social conditions of the country
whose decisions are invoked are all matters that will enter into the
courts consideration in the development of our own Constitutional
Criminal Procedure.
We know of Blackstone's famous boast that English law
considers it better "to let ten guilty men go free than to convict one
innocent". The American approach is exemplified by Justice Oliver
W. Holmes' statement that "it is a lesser evil that some criminals
should escape than that the government should have played an
ignoble part",
138
We have seen that the rules enunciated in the American
case of Miranda have become the national culture of America. Yet
Miranda and the cases on Exclusionary Rule noticed above have
been severely criticized. We have noticed Justice Harlan's
dissenting opinion in Miranda; he believed that the decision
"represents poor constitutional law and entails harmful
consequences for the country at large"; in his view, there was no
adequate basis for extending the 5 Amendment privilege against
self-incrimination to the police station. Judge Harold J. Rothwax in
his book "Guilty - the Collapse of Criminal Justice", thinks that
Miranda "was folly - a terrible decision atop many other terrible
decisions". The authors of "The Devil's Advocates" (at p 258, the
authors are Michael S Lief and H. Mitchell Caldwell) note that
"Following Miranda, public outcry against the Warren Court
intensified. For many, 'Impeach Earl Warren was not merely a
suggestion, it was a mandate. How could the court let a confessed
rapist go free?
Aside from the immediate effect of the
Miranda ruling, the more controversial issues lay in its effects upon
future police interrogation. One police chief declared
that the Supreme Court interpreted the Constitution as a shield for
criminals. As to the American Exclusionary Rule. US Chief

"The result of this case ought to be

he is guilty of wrongdoing. It
mechanically and blindly keeps reliable
evidence from juries whether the

gross police misconduct or bonest

Judge Bowman in US v Jefferson (906 F.2d 346-1990)
used the very strong expression "the perversity of the exclusionary
rule" in a case in which discovery of evidence (nine kilogram of
cocaine) of substantial criminal activity had to be excluded.
It may be pointed out that in the United Kingdom the
Report of the Royal Commission on Criminal Procedure (Cmnd
8092, para 4.126) referred to the American automatic exclusionary
rule and took the view that its use appeared to be justified as a
deterrent to unlawful conduct by the police and to preserve the
integrity of the court by preventing its involvement in illegal
activity. The Report comments that the United States Supreme
Court had felt constrained to develop the rule to protect the
citizens' constitutional rights and that the Supreme Court's
assumptions of this role derived its moral and political force from
its responsibility to protect and interpret the rights of the citizens of
the United States that are enshrined in the Bill of Rights. (See
Michael S. Pike's "The Principles of Policing", P 54).
Yet, the American automatic exclusionary rule, it is
interesting to note, has not been adopted by the British Parliament.
That Parliament has, by enacting section 78 of the Police and

Page 89
Criminal
Evidence Act, 1984, (PACE) departed from the
traditional common law rule, stretching back at least to the mid-
eighteenth century, namely, that admissibility of evidence at trial is
wholly unaffected by the circumstances in which it was obtained.
Section 78 of PACE provides:
"In any proceedings the court may refuse
to allow evidence on which the
prosecution proposes to rely to be given
if it appears to the court that having
regard to all the circumstances, including
the circumstances in which the evidence
was chained, the admission of the
evidence would have such an adverse
effect on the faimess of the proceedings
that the court ought not to admit it".
Section 78 of PACE seems to have devised a middle
course between the American exclusionary rule and the traditional
common law rule; it gives discretionary power to the court to
determine, in the circumstances of each particular case, whether it
would be fair or unfair to admit or not to admit a piece of evidence.
Comments:
It may well be that in the light of the American and the
English experience and in view of our own tradition and the
doctrine of Adl, this middle course, is followed in Pakistan. As in
America, sa in Pakistan, there is no provision in the Constitution
providing for the automatic exclusionary rule. The rule is a judge-
made rule, the object being to preserve the Constitution inviolate.
That object can as well be achieved by leaving the judges with a
judicial discretion to decide on a case-to-case basis whether the
exclusion of evidence will serve the ends of justice. In so doing,
they will naturally be guided by the doctrine of proportionality-
whether the suppression will be proportionate to the alleged
constitutional violence and whether or not it will amount to
suppression of truth.
142
Chapter 3
Rights relating to Criminal Procedure in the Constitution of
Pakistan
We have noticed that of the twenty three fundamental
rights guaranteed by the American Bill of Rights, twelve related to
criminal procedure, and that, for that reason, the American Bill of
Rights has been described as a "mini-code of criminal procedure"
and the provisions in that constitution relating to criminal
procedure as the Constitutional Criminal Procedure.
Similarly, of the Fundamental Rights guaranteed by
Articles 9 to 28 of the Constitution of Pakistan, almost 16 belong to
criminal procedure, and it may as well be described as a mini-code
of criminal procedure. These Fundamental Rights have both
substantive and procedural contents; the focus here of course is on
the procedural aspects of these rights. (For a detailed study of these
rights, the reader may consult the author's book "Judicial Review
of Public Actions", Part VIII, Sections A and B).
Article 9
This Article confers two rights:
i)
ii)
the right to life; and
the right to liberty.
It provides-
"No person shall be deprived of life or
liberty, save in accordance with law".
This right seems to have been modeled on the Fifth and
Sixth Amendments of the US Constitution.
The significance of the Fundamental Rights conferred by
this Article and their relevance to the criminal procedure lies in this
that whenever someone faces a criminal charge what is at stake is
his life or liberty or property. This may be put in another way, that
143
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 90
is, by considering the punishments that a person can suffer in a
criminal case.
severity:
Punishments fall into three categories of relative
1)
2)
3)
Fines, which involve loss and deprivation of
property;
Imprisonment, which
and
means loss
deprivation of liberty; and
Death, which means loss and deprivation of
life.
Article 9, reproduced above provides protection against
deprivation and loss of life and liberty, and Article 24, clause (1),
provides protection against deprivation and loss of property.
Right to life is the most fundamental of all human rights and "any
decision affecting human life, or which may put an individual's life
at risk, must call for the most anxious scrutiny". (Lord Bridge in
Bugdaycay v Secretary of State-(1987) 1 All ER 940, 972).
The constitutional law in America, as was observed in
Shehla Zia case (PLD 1994 SC 693), provides an extensive and
wide meaning to the word "life".
The leading authority on the meaning of life' as it
occurs in the American Constitution. Amendments Fourth and
Fourteenth, is the opinion of Justice Field in Munn v Illinois (94
US 113); life, it says, is something more than mere animal
existence. This view has been adopted in Shehla Zia case.
Access to Justice means the right to have access to justice through
independent judiciary as envisaged by the Constitution and
includes the right to have a fair and proper trial, by an impartial
court or tribunal. A person cannot be said to have been given a fair
or proper trial unless he is provided reasonable opportunity to
144
defend the allegations made against him. Trial by military courts
established in the purported exercise of the power under Article
245 of Pakistan Constitution, or by courts manned and run by
executive authorities is violative of the right to access to justice,
(Liaqat Hussain v Federation PLD 1999 SC 504, 632: Mehram
Ali v Federation - PLD 1998 SC 1445) which right is part of the
right to life guaranteed by Article 9.
Validity of primary as well as subordinate legislation
may be tested on the ground that it violates the right of access to
justice. A recent English case, R v Lord Chanceller ex parte
Witham (1997) 2 All ER 779) provides an interesting illustration.
In it, the Supreme Court Fees (Amended) Order 1996, was declared
invalid because it had by prescribing fees barred absolutely many
persons from seeking justice from the courts. Dr. Mehmood-ur-
Rehman v Secretary, Ministry of Law (PLD 1997 Lah 434) and
Sind High Court Bar v Islamic Republic of Pakistan (PLD 1991
Kar. 178) are also cases in which the imposition of court fee as
affecting the right of access to justice was held invalid.
The right of accused to be present at the trial
At common law, the defendant has, in general, a right to
be present at his trial and a right to be legally represented; those
rights can be waived, separately or together, wholly or in part, by
the defendant himself. As was held in R v Jones (2002) 2 All ER
1131, under the English Law, there is a discretion in the trial judge
to proceed with the trial in the absence of the defendant. In
expressing that view, due notice was taken of the provisions of the
European Convention. That Convention does not expressly
mention the right to be present at the trial, but the European Court
has held that the object and the purpose of Article 6 of the
Convention mean that a person charged with a criminal offence is
entitled to take part in the trial hearing. (Colozza and Rubinat, 12
February 1985, cited at p 38 of the Amnesty International Fair
Trials Manual).
145
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 91
In the United States, the right to be present at the trial is
"rooted to large extent in the confrontation clause of the Sixth
Amendment" as also in the due process clause (US v Gagnon - 470
US 522 (1985). Accordingly the right is not restricted to those parts
of trial in which the defendant is "actually confronting witnesses or
evidence against him". The question is related to the fullness of his
opportunity to defend against the charge.
The question whether the right of the accused to be
present at the trial is so absolute that no matter how unruly or
disruptive the defendant's conduct might be, he could never be
held to have lost that right, fell for consideration in Illinois v Allen
(397 US 337, 25 L ED 2d 353 (1970). Allen insisted to conduct his
own defense, although he had a court-appointed counsel. During
the trial, he started arguing with the trial Judge, threatened him
with death and when the trial Judge wamed him that he would be
removed from the court room, there was another outbreak. After
more abusive remarks, the Judge ordered the trial to proceed in his
absence. After the recess, the Judge allowed Allen to return but he
continued with his abusive behaviour and he was again removed
from the court room.
He was convicted and sentenced and the conviction and
sentence were affirmed in appeal. By way of habeas corpus, the
matter reached the Court of Appeals, who held that the right to be
present at his trial was an absolute right and reversed. The Court of
Appeals was, in turn, reversed by the US Supreme Court. Justice
Black speaking for the US Supreme Court recognized that one of
the most basic of the rights guaranteed by the Confrontation Clause
is the accused's right to be present in the courtroom at every stage
of his trial and held:
"We cannot agree that the Sixth
Amendment, the cases upon which the
Court of Appeals relied....so handicap a
trial Judge in conducting a criminal
trial.....No doubt the privilege (of
personally confronting witnesses) may
146
be lost by consent or at times even by
misconduct. Although mindful that
courts must indulge every reasonable
presumption against the loss of
constitutional rights, we explicitly hold
today that a defendant can lose his right
to be present at trial if, after he has been.
wamed by the Judge that he will be
removed if he continues his disruptive
behaviour, he nevertheless insists on
conducting himself in a manner so
disorderly, disruptive and disrespectful
of the court that his trial cannot be
carried on with him in the courtroom
It is essential to the proper
administration of criminal justice that
dignity, order, and decorum be the
hallmarks of all court proceedings
The flagrant disregard in the courtroom
of elementary standards of proper
conduct should not and cannot be
tolerated. We believe that trial judges
confronted
with disruptive,
contumacious, stubbornly defiant
defendants must be given sufficient
discretion to meet the circumstances of
each case".
Justice Black went on to say that "no one formula for
maintaining the appropriate courtroom atmosphere will be best in
all situations". He thought that "there are at least three
constitutionally permissible ways for a trial judge to handle an
abstreperous defendant like Allen (1) bind and gag him, thereby
keeping him present; (2) cite him for contempt; (3) take him out of
the court room until he promises to conduct himself properly".
Justice Black did not approve of binding and gagging the
accused, for such a technique "arouses a feeling that no person
147
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 92
should be tried while shackled and gagged except as a last
resort..... The use of this technique is itself something of an affront
to the very dignity and decorum of judicial proceedings that the
judge is seeking to uphold". As to the remedy of contempt of court,
the US Supreme Court observed that "citing or threatening to cite a
contumacious defendant for criminal contempt might in itself be
sufficient to make a defendant stop interrupting a trial. If so, the
problem would be solved easily.... Of course, if the defendant is
determined to prevent any trial, then a court in attempting to try the
defendant for contempt is still confronted with the identical
dilemma..... And criminal contempt has obvious limitations as a
sanction when the defendant is charged with a crime so serious that
a very serious sentence such as death or life imprisonment is likely
to be imposed. In such a case the defendant might not be affected
by a mere contempt sentence when he ultimately faces a far more
serious sanction. Nevertheless, the contempt remedy should be
bome in mind by a judge in the circumstances of this case.......
The court however found nothing unconstitutional about Allen's
removal from the courtroom and held that "under these
circumstances...... Allen lost his right guaranteed by the Sixth and
Fourteenth Amendments to be present throughout his trial".
In the Constitution of Pakistan, there is no provision.
expressly providing for the accused's right to be present at his trial;
yet, in Mehram Ali case (PLD 1998 SC 1445, 1488), the right
seems to have been treated as an absolute right, for, so held the
Supreme Court, right to access to justice is enshrined in Article 9.
In that case, section 19 of the Anti-Terrorism Act, 1997 authorized
the court to order removal of an accused person from the court if
his behaviour was such as to impede the course of justice and then
to proceed with the case in absentia. It was held that if an accused
person is removed from the court on account of misbehaviour and
in his absence the trial is concluded and he is sentenced to death, he
will be deprived of his life without due course of law and also of
his right to consult and be defended by a legal practitioner of his
choice guaranteed by Article 10. Section 19 of the Act was
therefore held to be violative of the Constitution, Articles 9 and 10,
and of no legal effect.
Despite the holding in Mehram Ali, provisions
permitting trial in absentia continue to be part of the statutory law
of Pakistan. For example, section 5(4) of the Offences in respect of
Banks (Special Courts) Ordinance 1984 authorizes the court to try
an accused in his absence if. in its opinion, his absence is deliberate
and brought about with a view to impeding the course of justice or
behavior of the accused has been such as to impede the course of
justice and the court has on that account ordered his removal from
the court room. In M.B. Abbasi v State (PLJ 2009 SC 458), the
petitioners were accused of banking offences; they were tried in
their absence and convicted and sentenced. Relying upon Articles 4
and 9 of the constiution and upon the precedent cases of Mehram
Ali (PLD 1998 SC 1445), Muhammad Fazil v State (2006 SCMR
1432), Muhammad Arif v State (2008 SCMR 829) and Mir Ikhlaq
Ahmad v State (2008 SCMR 951) the petitioners challenged their
conviction and sentence. It was found that the petitioners were, at
the relevant time, out of the country; that they were never served
because they could not be traced out. It was held:
the proceedings in absentia hed
lost efficacy besides being violative
of the principle of natural justice as per
maxim audi alteram partem and Articles
9 and 10 (1) of the Constitution.......
The conviction and sentence were set aside.
Mir Akhlaq Ahmad v State (2008 SCMR 951) and
Muhammad Arif v State (2008 SCMR 829) were cases under the
Anti-Terrorism Act 1997, which also permitted the accused to be
tried in his absence. The accused was an abscondor, he was tried in
his absence and was convicted and sentenced. The convictions and
sentences were set aside as being violative of the legal and
constitutional provisions namely Articles 9 and 10(1) of the
Constitution and Section 10(11-A) of the Anti-Terrorism Act.
1997.
148
149
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 93
These cases call for two observations: (i) The provisions
permitting trial in absentia were not declared void; and (ii) it is not
clear how the provisions of Article 10 (1) of the Constitution were
attracted. In other words how did the court reach the conclusion
that Article 10 (1) of the Constitution was violated,
Position under the Code of Criminal Procedure
There are three provisions in the Code of Criminal
Procedure, which bear upon this subject. Under section 205 a
Magistrate, issuing a summons may, if he sees reason so to do,
dispense with the personal attendance of the accused and permit
him to appear by his pleader. However, at any subsequent stage of
the trial or enquiry, the Magistrate can require the personal
attendance of the accused. Section 353 provides that except as
otherwise expressly provided, all evidence in trials by Magistrates
under Chapter XX, in summary trials under Chapter XXII, and in
trials before the High Courts and Courts of Session under Chapter
XXII-A, "shall be taken in the presence of the accused or when his
personal attendance is dispensed with, in the presence of his
pleader". Section 540A provides:
"(1) At any stage of an enquiry or trial
under this Code, where two or more
accused are before the court, if the Judge
or Magistrate is satisfied, for reasons to
be recorded, that any one or more of
such accused is or are incapable of
remaining before the court, he may, if
such accused is represented by a pleader;
dispense with his attendance and
proceed with such enquiry or trial in his
absence, and may at any subsequent
stage of the proceeding direct the
personal attendance of such accused.
(2) If the accused in any such case is not
represented by a pleader, or if the Judge
150.
or Magistrate considers his personal
attendance necessary, he may, if he
thinks fit, and for reasons to be recorded
by him, either adjourn such enquiry or
trial or order that the case of such
accused be taken up or tried separately".
Section 540A was considered in Z A Bhutto case (PLD
1978 SC 53) in which his absence on account of illness and his
removal from court room on account of what was treated as
misbehavior were held to fall within the meaning of the words.
"is....incapable of remaining before the court". It was held that the
elements necessary for attracting the jurisdiction of the Judge or
Magistrate under the section are:
a)
b)
that there two or more accused before the
court facing an enquiry or trial under the
Code;
that one or more such accused is or are
incapable of remaining before the court; and
that such accused is represented by a pleader.
"It is only on the fulfillment of these conditions precedent that the
jurisdiction of the Judge or Magistrate is attracted, and he may after
having so satisfied himself in his discretion dispense with the
personal attendance of such accused and proceed in his absence".
This section, it was held, "was enacted not merely for the benefit of
the accused who is incapable of remaining before the court, but
also for the benefit of other accused whose trial is likely to be
delayed unnecessarily for no fault on his part".
Comments:
Now imagine that the validity of Mr. Z A Bhutto's trial
had been questioned before the Supreme Court on the ground that
his trial in his absence was in violation of the right to access to
justice guaranteed by Article 9 or Article 4. Imagine also that the
Supreme Court were persuaded, as it was in Mehram Ali case, that
the provision authorizing an accused to be tried in his absence or
151
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 94
that his alleged misbehavior did not justify his removal, was void.
Having allowed your imagination to run so far, imagine also what
would have been the consequences. The consequences would be
one, that section 540A would have been declared unconstitutional
being in violation of the right to access to justice and two, that his
trial in his absence and the resulting death sentence would, in view
of the decision in Mehram Ali case, be deprivation of life without
due course of law.
As observed above, the Constitution of Pakistan does not
provide in express terms that an accused has a right to be present at
his trial. That right is, as was held in Mehram Ali case, derived
from the Fundamental Rights expressly granted by Articles 9 and
10 of the Constitution. It is to be noted that the rights conferred by
Article 9 are not absolute rights, for they can be interfered with in
accordance with law, be it substantive or procedural law. And if
that right is subject to law, so is, it follows logically, its penumbras
namely the right to access to justice or the right to be present at the
trail. Unfortunately for the development of the law, the English and
the American cases referred to above were not brought to the
notice of the Bench which decided Mehram Ali case. However that
may be, the view taken therein, it is submitted with respect, needs
reconsideration. The view taken in the English and American
cases, it is further submitted, is more in accord with the provisions
of Article 9 of the Constitution.
Right to liberty:
The world has, so said Abraham Lincoln, never had a
good definition of liberty. The shepherd, he said, drives the wolf
from the sheep's throat, for which the sheep thanks the shepherd as
his liberator, while the worlf denounces him for the same
act.....plainly, the sheep and the wolf are not agreed upon the
definition of liberty. What is freedom for the lion is death for lamb.
(See the Article "On the meaning of the First Amendment.
Absolutes in the Balance"-50 California Law Review 821(1962).
The term "liberty' has been given a wide meaning in
America. A summary of what 'liberty" comprises may be found
stated in the concurring opinion of Justice Douglas in Roe v Wade
(410 US 113):
First is
the autonomy over the
development and expression of one's
intellect, interests, tastes and personality:
Second is the freedom of choice in the
basic decisions of one's life respecting
marriage, divorce, procreation.
contraception and the education and
upbringing of children......
Third is the freedom to care for one's
health and person, freedom from bodily
restraint, or compulsion, freedom to
walk, stroll or loaf..........
Thus liberty has been held to include the liberty of
contract (Allgeyer v Louisiana - 165 US 578 and Lochner v New
York (198 US 45), right of privacy (Griswold case-381 US 479;
and Roc v Wade (410 US 113), which limits the State's right to
interfere with a person's most basic decisions about family and
parenthood as well as bodily integrity including a woman's right to
terminate her pregnancy in its early stages.
The American view of 'liberty' has been followed in
India in cases on the corresponding provision in the Indian
Constitution namely Article 21, and it is submitted that the term
"liberty' as used in Article 9 has also the same meaning.
As to its procedural aspect, according to Lord Denning.
the English law respecting the freedom of the individual has been
built up from the procedure of the courts (Family Story. pp. 172,
178). The history of liberty, so said Justice Frankfurter in McNabb
(318 US 332)-
152
153
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 95
"has largely been the history of the
observance of procedural safeguards"
And Justice Jackson said in Shaughnessy (345 US 206)-
"Procedural faimess and regularity are
of the indispensable essence of liberty.
Some substantive restrictions can be
endured if they are fairly and impartially
applied."
"In accordance with law"
While the procedural right to liberty etc. in the
American Constitution. Amendments V and XIV, has been
guaranteed by providing that no person shall be
"deprived of life. liberty or property.
without due process of law"
in the Constitution of Pakistan, Article 9, the right guaranteed is as
follows:-
"No person shall be deprived of life or
liberty save in accordance with law
Thus, what is ensured by the expression "due process of law" in the
American Constitution is ensured by Article 9 in the Constitution
of Pakistan by using the expression "in accordance with law."
The expression "in accordance with law" emphasizes, in
the famous language of Massachusetts Bill of Rights the distinction
between 'government of laws" and "govemment of men'.
Do the two expressions "due process of law" and
"in accordance with law" mean the same thing? In Hurado v
California (110 US 516; 28 LEd 232), which is a classic
example of procedural due process of law, Justice Mathew.
after observing that each State prescribes its own modes of
judicial proceedings, went on to say what the term 'law' in the
phrase "due process of law" means:
"But it is not to be supposed that these
legislative powers are absolute and
despotic. and that the Amendment
prescribing due process of law is too
vague and indefinite to operate as a
practical restraint. It is not every act,
legislative in form that is law. Law is
something more than mere will exerted
as an act of power. It must not be a
special rule for a particular person or a
particular case, but in the language of
Mr. Webster, in his familiar definition.
the general law, the law which hears
before it condemns, which proceeds
upon injury, and renders judgment only
after trial, so that every citizen shall hold
life, liberty, property and immunities
under the protection of the general rules
which govern society and thus
excluding, as not due process of law.
acts of attainder, bills of pain and
penalties, acts of confiscation, acts
reversing judgments and acts directly
transferring one man's estate to another,
legislative judgments and decrees, and
other similar special, partial and
arbitrary exertion of power under the
forms of legislation. Arbitrary power.
enforcing its edicts to the injury of the
persons and property of its subjects, is
not law, whether manifested as the
decree of personal monarch or of an
impersonal multitude".
154
155
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 96
It should be mentioned here that a number of Constitutions and
Instruments, such as the European Convention, use a number of
variants e.g. "prescribed by law". "as provided by law"
"established by law", "in accordance with law".
The European Court of Human Rights has held that the
phrases "prescribed by law" and "in accordance with law" must be
given an identical meaning in order to ensure that all the relevant
Articles of the European Convention "can be read as a coherent
whole". (See among others Silver v UK-(1983) 5 EHRR 347, para
85). And the Privy Council has held, in cases from Singapore
namely Haw Tua v Public Prosecutor (1981) 3 All ER 14 and On
Ahg Chuan v Public Prosecutor (1980) 3 WLR 855) that so long as
Article 9 of the Singapore Constitution, which also uses the
expression "in accordance with law" remained unamended,
provision that "purports to assure to all individual citizens the
continued enjoyment of fundamental liberties or rights, reference to
'law' in such contexts as in accordance with law, equality before
law, protection of the law.and the like.......refer to a system of law
which incorporate those fundamental rules of natural justice that
had formed part and parcel of the common law of England that was
in operation in Singapore at the commencement of the
Constitution.
The Indian Constitution, in its corresponding Article 21,
provides that no person shall be deprived of life and personal
libeny except according to procedure established by law. In A.K.
Gopalan case (AIR 1950 SC 27), the Supreme Court of India held,
by a majority, that 'procedure established by law' means any
procedure established by law made by the Parliament or the
legislatures of the State. As was said in M. Nagaraj (AIR 2007 SC
71, 82) the Supreme Court refused to infuse the procedure with
principles of natural justice. It concentrated solely upon the
existence of enacted law. A.K. Gopalan was overruled in Maneka
Gandhi case (AIR 1978 SC 597) which held that the procedure
contemplated by Article 21 must be fair, reasonable and just
procedure and should also be in conformity with the principles of
natural justice.
The same view seems to have been taken of the
expression "in accordance with law" in Government v Muhammad
Akbar Mir (PLD 1971 SC. 60) as it occurred in Article 2(2) of the
1962 Constitution of Pakistan (predecessor of Article 4 of the 1973
Constitution). The rule of natural justice it was held is presumed to
be grafted into every law. According to this rule, no action
affecting the reputation (also life and liberty) of any person can be
taken unless he has been given an opportunity of showing cause
against the action proposed to be taken. Similarly, in every statute.
the presumed intention of the legislature is that one of the
qualifications of the decision-maker is that of absence of bias
(Diplock L.J. in Anisminic- (1967)2 All ER 986).
While Article 9 of the Constitution guarantees the right
of life and liberty, and ordains against deprivation of this right save
in accordance with law. Article 4 (which is not part of Chapter 1 of
Part II providing for the Fundamental Rights) state, as one of the
foundational principles of the Constitution, that-
"(1) To enjoy the protection of the law and to be
treated in accordance with law is the inalienable
right of every citizen, wherever he may be, and of
every other person for the time being within
Pakistan.
(2) In particular-
(s) No action detrimental to the life.
liberty, body, reputation or property
of any person shall be taken except
in accordance with law;
(b) No person shall be prevented from
or be hindered in doing that which
is not prohibited by law; and
(c) No person shall be compelled to do
that which the law does not require
him to do".
Anticle 5 of the Constitution provides:
156
157
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 97
"S. Loyalty to the State and obedience to Constitution and law;
Loyalty to the State is the basic duty of every
citizen.
Obedience to the Constitution and law is the
inviolable obligation of every citizen
wherever he may be and of every other person
for the time being within Pakistan."
In a system of government under a written Constitution, the written
constitution is the rule of law. (For a discussion on "The Rule of
Law" please see Part II Chapter 4, of the author's book "Judicial
Review of Public Actions", p 46). The maintenance of the rule of
law, so said Lord Bridge in X Ltd. v Morgan Grampian (1990) I
All ER 616) "is in every way as important in a free society as the
democratic franchise". There is, to quote Lord Bridge again from
another landmark case Bennet v Horseferry Road Magistrates'
court (1993) 3 All ER 138), "....no principle more basic to
any proper system of law than the maintenance of the rule of law
itself".
Articles 4 and 5 of the Constitution embody the essence of the
rule of law. (Manzoor Elahi v Federation - PLD 1975 SC 66, 101).
While Article 4 stresses the right to enjoy the protection of law and
to be treated in accordance with law, Article 5 stresses the
obligations and duties of the citizens. Thus, the Constitution is not
a code of rights only; it lays equal stress on obligations. Nobody is
above the law; everybody. "even the Prime Minister is, under
clause (2) of Article 5 of the Constitution bound to obey the
Constitution and law as that is the basic obligation of every
citizen". (Zahoor Elahi v Zulfikar Ali Bhutto - PLD 1975 SC 383,
393, 395). To every subject in this land, said Lord Denning in
Gouriet v Union of Post Office Workers (1977) 1 All ER 696.
718), "no matter how powerful. I would use Thomas Fuller's
words over 300 years ago: 'Be you never so high, the law is above
you. To this may be added the following observations of Wilmot
CJ in that historic case, Wilkes v Woods (1769) 19 St. Tr. 1406):
"The law makes no distinction between
great and petty officers; thank God, they
are all amenable to justice".
So predominant is the position of Article 4 that it "confers a
right which is more basic than fundamental rights because while
the fundamental rights can be suspended, the right given by Article
4 cannot. (Muhammad Munir, former Chief Justice of Pakistan in
his commentary on the Constitution of Pakistan 1973, 1976 ed. p
82).
Article 199, clause (1)(c) of the Constitution, empowers
the Supreme Court to enforce the Fundamental Rights guaranteed
by Part II, Chapter 1, of the Constitution. Clause 1(b) of Article
199 provides that the High Court may, on the application of any
person, make an order-
"directing that a person in custody
within the territorial jurisdiction of the
court be brought before it so that the
court may satisfy itself that he is not
being held in custody without lawful
authority or in an unlawful manner"
It was held in Government of West Pakistan v Begum Agha Abdul
Karim Shorish Kashmiri (PLD 1969 SC 14), a case under Article
98 of the Constitution which was the predecessor of Article 199 of
the 1973 Constitution, that-
"The words 'in 2n unlawful
manner have been used
deliberately to give meaning and content
to the solemn declaration under Article 2
of the Constitution (now Article 4 of the
1973 Constitution) itself that it is the
158
159
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 98
inalienable right of every citizen to be
treated in accordance with law and only
in accordance with law........Law is here
not confined to statute law alone but is
used in its generic sense as connoting all
that it is treated as law in this country
including even the judicial principles
laid down from time to time by the
superior courts. It means according to
the accepted forms of legal process and
postulates a strict performance of all the
functions and duties laid down by law. It
may well be as has been suggested in
some quarters, that in this sense it is as
comprehensive as the American 'due
process' clause in a new grab".
Article 4, so said Salahuddin Ahmad J. in Manzoor Elahi case
(PLD 1975 SC 66, 109). "may be compared with the 'due process
of law in the American Constitution". The above cited Begum
Agha Shorish Kashmiri's case, so said the learned Judge, "supports
this view".
The cases determining the validity of proceedings under
section 11 of the Frontier Crimes Regulation provide an apt
illustration of what, in the context of Articles 4 and 9, the word
'law' means. Section 11 of the FCR gave unfettered powers to the
Deputy Commissioner. to refer the question as to the guilt or
otherwise of a person to the Council of Elders. No rule of
procedure or evidence had been prescribed for the proceedings
before the Council. The Council could make such enquiry 'as may
be necessary' including secret enquiries, there being nothing to
prevent it "from adopting methods which are arbitrary and
inconsistent with reason and the civilized decencies". Even the
proceedings before the Deputy Commissioner and the
Commissioner were not amenable to any rule which might be
regarded as a rule of 'due process' or 'best evidence'. It was
accordingly held in Samundar v Crown (PLD 1954 FC 228) that
160
"the proceedings which have been taken in the present case are not
to be regarded as proceedings in justice, but they are from every
point of view to be regarded as proceedings before an
administrative agency....". The process of decision provided under
the Regulation, so held Cornelius J. "is also foreign to justice as
administered by the courts". In Malik Muhammad Usman v State
(PLD 1965 Lah. 229), a Full Bench of the High Court of West
Pakistan declared the reference under sections 8 and 11 of the
Regulation and convictions based on them vaid, inter alia, on the
ground that they were "repugnant to the Fundamental Right No. I
(the same as Article 9 of the 1973 Constitution) it being now
settled that the Jirga procedure cannot be described as "law" in any
recognized sense of the term".
After considering all these cases, it was held in Manzoor
Elahi case (at p 120), that section II of the Regulation "does not
seem to me to be 'law' as contemplated by Articles 4 and 9 of the
Constitution".
We shall consider later the remedies that the
Constitution itself, by its Articles 8 and 199, provides for the
enforcement of the Fundamental Rights guaranteed by the
Constitution. It is sufficient to say here, in the context of the right
of liberty, that the most well-known and important remedy
commonly known as habeas corpus, is to be found in Article 199,
clause 1 (b), which empowers the High Court to direct that the
person in custody be brought before it so that the High Court may
satisfy itself that he is not being held in custody (a) without lawful
authority or (b) in an unlawful manner. The expression "in an
unlawful manner" in that clause seems to have the same meaning
as not "in accordance with law" in Articles 4 and 9 of the
Constitution. This is clear from the following observations of
Hamood ur Rehman CI in Begum Shorish Kashmiri case (PLD
1969 SC 14, 31):
"It is in this sense that an action which is
malafide or colorable is not regarded as
action in accordance with law. Similarly,
