Page 99
action taken upon extraneous DE
irrelevant considerations is also not an
action in accordance with law. Action
taken upon no ground at all or without
proper application of mind of the
detaining authority would also not
qualify as action in accordance with law
and would, therefore, have to be struck
down as being an action in an unlawful
manner."
Article 10:
This Article can be divided into two parts:
(1) clauses (1) and (2), which provide safeguards against
arrest followed by detention;
(2) clauses (3) to (9) which provide safeguards against
preventive detention.
Arrest followed by detention
Clauses (1) and (2) of Article 10 read:
"No person who is arrested shall be detained in
custody without being informed, as soon as
may be, of the ground of such arrest, nor shall
he be denied the right to consult and be
defended by a legal practitioner of his choice.
Every person who is arrested and detained in
custody shall be produced before a Magistrate
within a period of twenty-four hours of such
arrest, excluding the time necessary for the
journey from the place of arrest to the court of
nearest Magistrate, and no such person shall
be detained in custody beyond the said period
without the authority of a Magistrate."
162
It is important to note that sections 60 and 61 of the Code of
Criminal Procedure 1898 provide similar safeguards against arrest.
Sections 60 and 61 Cr.P.C. apply to arrest without warrant, as
distinguished from arrest under the order or warrant issued by a
court. Section 60 provides that "A police officer making an arrest
without warrant shall, without unnecessary delay.....take or send
the person arrested before a Magistrate.......or before the officer in
charge of a police station". Section 61 provides that "No police
officer shall detain in custody a person arrested without warrant for
a longer period that under all the circumstances of the case is
reasonable, and such period shall not, in the absence of a special
order of Magistrate under section 67, exceed twenty four
hours........
Section 81 Cr. P.C. deals with arrest under a warrant. It
requires the police officer or other person executing a warrant of
arrest "without unnecessary delay to bring the person arrested
before the court before which he is required by law to produce such
person".
The reason why the Constitution makers thought it
necessary to give these safeguards constitutional protection is
obvious. It is to take these safeguards out of the reach of ordinary
or sub-constitutional legislation. It is now well-settled that merely
because such protections are also provided by sections 60 and 61
Cr. P.C. would not reduce the provisions of Article 10 (and Article
22 of the Indian Constitution) to a sub-constitutional level. The
effect of these provisions being incorporated into the Constitution
is that the rights conferred by them are as much Fundamental
Rights as any other right guaranteed by Chapter 2 of Part 11 of the
Constitution. (See State v Zia-ur-Rehman PLD 1973 SC 49,67;
Manzoor Elahi v Federation - PLD 1975 SC 66; Bazal Ahmad v
West Pakistan- PLD 1957 WP 388). Cases such as Government of
East Pakistan v Mrs. Rowshan Bijya Shaukat Ali Khan (PLD 1958
SC (Pak) 499) and Habib Jilani v Federation (PLD 1974 Lah. 53)
which seem to take the contrary view should be deemed to have
ceased to be good law.
163
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 100
The Rights conferred by Clauses (1) and (2)
Article 10, by its clause (1), prescribes the procedure to
be followed when a person is arrested to be detained, and requires
that such person-
(i) shall be informed, as soon as may be, of the grounds of
such arrest; and
(ii) shall not be denied the right to consult and be defended
by a legal practitioner of his choice.
Clause (2) of Article 10 requires that a person who is arrested and
detained in custody-
(i)
(ii)
shall be produced before a Magistrate, within a period
of twenty four hours of such arrest; and
shall not be detained in custody beyond that period of
twenty four hours without the authority of a Magistrate.
It was held in Manzoor Elahi case (PLD 1975 SC 66, 84, per
Yaqoob Ali J.) that any law or action which is violative of these
rights will be void under Article 8 of the Constitution.
Arrest, detention, custody
The safeguards and the protections, provided by clauses
(1) and (2) of Article 10, are for persons arrested and detained or to
be detained in custody. Our enquiry must therefore start with an
understanding of the expressions-
(i) arrest;
(ii) detention in custody; and
(iii) magistrate
Arrest: We have seen that the American Constitution, Fourteenth
Amendment, does not use the words "arrest". What in traditional
terminology is 'arrest' is according to that Amendment 'seizure of
person'; there is no doubt therefore that by reference to the seizure
of person, the Fourth Amendment was intended to apply to arrests.
(Terry-392 US 1).
'Arrest' is a public act that may seriously interfere with
the defendant's liberty, whether he is free or on bail, drain his
financial resources, curtail his associations, subject him to public
chloquy and create anxiety in him, his family and friends. (Marion
404 US 307 (1971)). At common law, "it is the right of every
citizen to be free from arrest unless there is in some other citizen,
whether a constable or not, the right to arrest him....it is a corollary
of the right of every citizen to be thus free from arrest that he
should be entitled to resist arrest unless that is lawful. How can
these rights be reconciled with the proposition that he may be
arrested without knowing why his is arrested"? (Lord Simonds in
Christie v Leachinsky-(1947) I All ER 567, 574-5)
The term 'arrest" has various definitions and that may
tend to confusion in the discussion of Article 10 of the Constitution
when the question is whether a particular seizure of person by a
public authority amounts to arrest.
The Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898, by its section
46, provides that "in making an arrest, the police officer or other
person making the same shall actually touch or confine the body of
the person to be arrested, unless there be submission to the custody
by word or action".
This provision obviously applies to arrests under the
Code of Criminal Procedure only and may not necessarily apply to
arrests under other statutes; in particular, this meaning of "arrest"
will not be binding upon a court in a case in which the question is
whether a seizure of one's person is or is not arrest within the
meaning of Article 10 of the Constitution.
164
165
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 101
According to Lord Denning. "when a police constable
says to a man 'come with me, I am taking you to the station"", this
is an arrest. ("The Due Process of Law" by Lord Denning, p 103).
In Holgate Muhammad v Duke (1984) 1 All ER 1054, 1056), it
was held that the word "arrest' as used in criminal statutes is a term
of art. First, it should be noted that arrest is a continuing act, it
starts with the arrester taking a person into custody (by action or
words restraining him from moving anywhere beyond the arrester's
control) and it continues until the person so restrained is either
released from custody or having been brought before a Magistrate,
is remanded in custody by the Magistrate's judicial act. In practice,
since the creation of organized public forces....an arrested person,
on being taken into custody, is brought to a police station and it is
there that he is detained until he is either brought before a
Magistrate or released on bail. In modern conditions, any other way
of dealing with an arrested person would be impracticable;
provisions for bail by the police are drafted on the assumption that
this will be done.
There is a common statutory definition of "arrest" in
America. It means 'the taking of a person into custody for the
purpose of charging him with crime. This ordinarily involves the
police officer's exercise of physical control over the arrestee for the
purpose of first transporting him to a police station followed by
what is called 'booking'. In Terry y Ohio (392 US 1), it was held
that-
"It is quite plain that the Fourth Amendment
governs 'seizures" of the person which do not
eventuate in a trip to the station house and
prosecution for crime arrests' in traditional
terminology. It must be recognized that whenever a
police offics: accosts an individual and restrains his
freedom to walk away, he has 'seized" that person".
Broadly speaking, there can be an arrest authorized by a court or
Magistrate (arrest under warrant) and an arrest without the
authority of a court or Magistrate (arrest without warrant). In State
166
of Punjab v Ajaib Singh (AIR 1953 SC 10), the respondent, Ajaib
Singh, had three abducted persons in his possession. The police
raided his house and took a girl named Sardaran into custody and
delivered her to the custody of officer in charge of the Muslim
Transit Camp at Ferozpur from where she was transferred to a
camp in Jalandher. The question was whether the recovery of
Sardaran was an arrest within the meaning of Article 22(1) of the
Indian Constitution, which corresponds to Article 10(2) of the
Constitution of Pakistan. It was held that the taking of Mst.
Sardaran into custody did not fall within the definition of 'arrest",
and that should have been the end of the matter. Yet, the court went
on to consider the question whether an arrest under a warrant of the
court was an arrest governed by Article 22(1) of the Indian
Constitution. The learned Judges expressed the opinion-they were
careful to say that it was not a final opinion- that such an arrest was
not governed by Article 22(1), for that Article applied to arrests
without warrant only.
The view also seems to have been taken in Ajaib Singh
that Article 22 applied only to cases in which the arrest was in
connection with any allegation or accusation of any actual or
suspected or apprehended commission of any offence of a criminal
or quasi-criminal nature. In Collector v Ebrahim Hajce (AIR 1957
SC 388) the respondent had been arrested in pursuance of a warrant
issued by the Collector under the Madras Revenue Recovery Act,
1864, for a civil debt as arrears of land revenue. It was held that
this was not an 'arrest' within the meaning of Article 22 of the
Indian Constitution.
These Indian cases fell for consideration in Bazal
Ahmad v West Pakistan (PLD 1957 WP Lah. 388) a case under the
Punjab Control of Goondas Act 1951. Under that Act, a Tribunal
was constituted with the power to declare persons, against whom
information was laid by a police officer, goondas or dangerous
goondas. The petitioners challenged, by way of judicial review, the
proceedings against them on various grounds. The petitioners had
been arrested in pursuance of an order of the Tribunal, and it was
held that Article 7 (the present Article 10 of the Constitution) was
"apparently attracted", The decision in Ajaib Singh case, it was
167
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 102
said, "takes too narrow a view of the corresponding provision in
the Indian Constitution". In Manzoor Elahi y Federation (PLD
1975 SC 66,86), the arrest of Ch. Zahoor Elahi, detenue, was in
pursuance of a warrant issued by the Additional District
Magistrate, Kohlu. The Supreme Court held that the arrest was
unlawful, on the basis that Article 10(2) applied to arrests in
pursuance of a warrant, for the detenue had not been produced
before a Magistrate within 24 hours of his arrest.
It appears that Ajaib Singh adopts the view enacted in
sections 60, 61 and 81 Cr.P.C. Sections 60 and 61 apply to arrests
without warrant and section 81 to arrests under the authority of a
warrant or order of a court. Section 81 provides that a person
arrested in pursuance of a warrant will be produced, without
unnecessary delay (not necessarily within 24 hours) befor: the
court before which he is required by law to be produced. So, the
Code treats arrest under warrant and without warrant differently.
Validity of Sections 60, 61, 81 Cr.P.C.
It follows logically that the view taken in Bazal Ahmad case would
raise questions as to the constitutional validity of sections 60, 61
and 81 Cr.P.C. For example, suppose a person is arrested under a
warrant, but is not produced before a Magistrate within 24 hours of
his arrest, and is produced before a court which issued the warrant
long after 24 hours. Such an arrest and detention would be, as
Bazal Ahmad holds, invalid under Article 10 of the Constitution.
Detention in custody: The protection under Article 10, clause (1).
is for a person arrested and under clause (2) thereof, for a person
arrested and detained in custody.
"Detain' is defined in Black's Law Dictionary to mean,
among others, to arrest, to hold or to keep in custody and
'detention' is defined therein to mean the act of keeping back or
withholding either accidentally or by design, a person or thing.
'Detention' may be-
(i)
ordinary detention, that is detention for a
criminal offence; and
(ii)
preventive detention.
Ordinary detentions are governed by clauses (1) and (2) of Article
10, and preventive detentions by clauses (4) to (9) of Article 10. As
clause (3) of Article 10 provides;
"Nothing in clauses (1) and (2) shall apply to any
person who is arrested or detained under any law
providing from preventive detention".
Clause (4) of Article 10 requires a law to be made providing for.
preventive detention to deal with persons acting in a
manner prejudicial to the integrity, security, or defence of Pakistan
or any part thereof, or external affairs of Pakistan, or public order,
or the maintenance of supplies or services. Under such a law, a
person can be detained for a period not exceeding three months
"unless the appropriate Review Board has, after affording him an
opportunity of being heard in person, reviewed his case and
reported, before the expiration of the said period, that there is, in its
opinion, sufficient cause for such detention".
Custody: The essence of custody is that-
"there should be lack of freedom to
move about where and when one
pleases, coupled with a physical power
immediately available to prevent an
attempt at breaking the restrictions
imposed as distinguished from the power
subsequently to punish a breach of such
restrictions".
And if a person is told that he must not go beyond certain
boundaries and
168
169
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 103
"he sees or is told that if he did, physical
force would be available to prevent him
from doing so, there would.....then be
no difference of kind between his
confinement or custody and that of a
person confined in jail, though there
would, of course, be a difference of
degree". (Muhammad Anwar
Government PLD 1963 Lah. 109;
Begum Nazir Abdul Hamid v Pakistan-
PLD 1974 Lah. 7, 16-17).
V
On this view, an order confining a person to the limits of his house
will be confinement in custody.
Magistrate Production before him within 24 hours: Under
clause (2) of Article 10 of the Constitution, "Every person who is
arrested and detained in custody shall be produced before a
Magistrate within a period of twenty four hours of such arrest...."
We have seen that the US Constitution, by its Fourth
Amendment, protects privacy and provides that "no warrants shall
issue but upon probable cause........"
Issued by whom? On this, Fourth Amendment of the US
Constitution is silent. This gap has been filled by the Supreme
Court. The Constitution, it has been held, interposes a judicial
officer a neutral officer between the police and the suspect to
decide whether the probable cause and other requirements have
been satisfied. The requirement does not turn upon the labeling of
the warrant issuing authority. While the term 'judicial officer'
implies some connection with the judicial branch, the judicial
officer may not necessarily be a Magistrate. (See US cases Gates
and Shadwick noticed earlier).
Meaning of Magistrate: We have seen that in the constitutional
law of America, the term 'magistrate in the arrest and search
warrant context has not been used in a technical sense. Thus, the
arrest warrant issuing authority in Shadwick (407 US 345) noticed
earlier was a clerk of the Muncipal Court and the question,
"whether these clerks qualify as neutral and detached magistrates.
for purposes of Fourth Amendment". was answered in the
affirmative; and the clerk was held to satisfy the requirement of a
neutral and detached magistrate.
Does the term 'Magistrate' in Article 10 have a technical
meaning? Does it mean a Magistrate under the Code of Criminal
Procedure, 1898, or does it mean any neutral and detached judicial
officer authorized by law to perform this function?
In a general sense, a magistrate is a public officer
possessing such power, legislative. executive or judicial. as
government appointing him may ordain, although in a narrow sense
he is regarded as an inferior judicial officer. (Black's Law
Dictionary). The word magistrate' has several meanings:
arbitrator, assessor, judge, jurist, justice, legist, moderator, and
officer, official. (Legal Thesaurus by William C.Burton, 3rd
edition)
Suppose that in a special law, e.g. an anti-terrorism law,
an arrestee is required to be produced before the Judge appointed
under that law within 24 hours of his arrest. Would it satisfy the
requirement of Article 10? In view of the law developed by the US
Supreme Court, the answer ought to be "yes"..
The word 'Magistrate occurring as it does in the
Constitution may be understood in its generic sense of a judicial
officer and may not have the same meaning as it has in the Code of
Criminal Procedure. For the definition of 'Magistrate' in the Code
of Criminal Procedure, section 4(1)(ma), is for the purposes of that
Code only and the court, in interpreting Article 10, and in
determining the meaning of 'Magistrate' as used therein, may
adopt its generic sense and not the sense in which it has been used
in the Code.
170
171
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 104
Right to be Informed of the grounds for arrest:
Clause (1) of Article 10 forbids the detention in custody
of an arrestee "without being informed, as soon as may be, of the
grounds of such arrest".
Grounds- meaning and significance:
The word 'grounds' means that which can form a basis
for an order and what cannot form a true basis can hardly be called
a ground. (B.Z. Kaikaus J, Rowshan Bijaya - PLD 1966 SC 286,
323). As there must be grounds, there can be no order without
grounds; therefore, grounds are the basis supporting the order of
arrest and detention; they are the necessary substratum of fact upon
which the satisfaction of the detaining authority is founded (Shazia
Parveen v D. M.-PLD 1988 Lah. 611).
It was an established proposition at common law
that-
"If a policeman arrests without warrant
on reasonable suspicion of felony, or of
other crime of a sort which does not
require a warrant, he must in ordinary
circumstances inform the person arrested
of the true ground of arrest".
This proposition was stated in the speech of Viscount Simon in
Christie v Leachinsky (1947) I All ER 567, 571), and it was held
that an arrest without informing the arrestee of the grounds of
arrest is unlawful, and the arrestor is liable in tort for false
imprisonment.
There are practical considerations, as well as theory, said
Viscount Simon in Christie,
"to support the view I take. If the charge
on suspicion of which the man is
arrested is then and there made known to
172
him, he has the opportunity of giving an
explanation of any misunderstanding or
of calling attention to other persons for
whom he may have been mistaken, with
the result that further enquiries may save
him from the consequences of false
accusation......
The general proposition thus is "that it is a condition of lawful
arrest that the man arrested should be entitled to know why he is
arrested.....The exigency of the situation, which justifies or demand
arrest without a warrant cannot... justify or demand either a
refusal to state the reason or a misstatement of the reason. Arrested
with or without warrant, the subject is entitled to know why he is
deprived of his freedom, if only in order that he may without a
moments' delay take such steps as will enable him to regain it".
(Lord Simond in Christie, at p 575).
Christie illustrates that "the liberty of the subject and the
convenience of the police or any other executive authority are not to
be weighed in the scales against each other....." and that "a man is
not to be deprived of his liberty except in due course and process of
law"
As soon as may be:
The grounds for arrest must be conveyed "as soon as
may be". These words in clause (1) of Article 10 must be construed
in the light of clause (2) of Article 10, bearing in view the object of
the requirement that the arrestee must be produced before a
Magistrate. That object is to enable the arrestee to have a neutral
and detached judicial mind applied to the question whether there are
grounds for arrest. To borrow from the American law, there should
be screening by a judicial officer to determine whether there was a
probable cause for arrest. And as the arrestee must, under clause (2).
be produced before a Magistrate within 24 hours, that seems to be
the maximum period within which the arrestee must know of the
grounds. For, unless he knows of the grounds, he would not be able
173
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 105
to plead against them when he is produced before the Magistrate.
"As soon as may be" therefore means within a maximum period of
24 hours of the arrest.
Unlawful arrest and detention- their consequences:
(1) A person's arrest and detention are unlawful when
he is, under clause(1) of Article 10, not informed of
the grounds of his arrest. As was held in Christie v
Leachinsky (1947) I All ER 567, 579), omission to
tell a person who is arrested at, or within a
reasonable, time of arrest, (under Article 10 within
a maximum period of 24 hours of the arrest) with
what offence he is charged (that is, why he is being
arrested) is not a mere irregularity; it renders the
arrest unlawful and the person arresting, be he a
private citizen or a public functionary, liable,
among others, in tort to pay damages.
(2) A person's arrest may also be unlawful, when he is
arrested but is not produced before a Magistrate
within twenty four hours of arrest.
The view, at one time was that the mere fact that a person has been
arrested in an unauthorized manner does not, generally, affect the
subsequent proceedings. (See, among others, Prebhu v Emperor-
AIR 1944 PC 73). At that time, distinction perbaps was not made
between arrest in violation of ordinary law and arrest in violation
of the Constitution. Thus. the mainstream of the English authority
had followed the rule regardless of the circumstances in which the
accused was brought before the court, the court's jurisdiction to try
him was not affected. This rule was departed from in the recent
Jandmark case- Bennett y Horsferry Road Magistrates (1993) 3 All
ER 138) in which the House of Lords extended the concept of
abuse of process and beld-
"That if the court is to have the power to
interfere with the prosecution in the
174
present circumstances it must be because
the judiciary accept a responsibility for
the maintenance of the rule of law that
embraces a willingness to oversee
executive action and to refuse to
countenance behaviour that threatens
either basic human rights or the rule of
law".
"I have no doubt", said Lord Griffiths, that-
"the judiciary should accept this
responsibility in the field of criminal
law. The great growth of administrative
law during the latter half of this century
has occurred because of the recognition
by the juridiciary and Parliament alike
that it is the function of the High Court
to ensure that executive action is
exercised responsibly and as Parliament
intended. So also should it be in the field
of criminal law and if it comes to the
attention of the court that there has been
a serious abuse of power it should, in my
view, express its disapproval by refusing
to act upon it.
The appellant in that case was a New Zealand citizen who was
wanted for criminal offences committed in connection with the
purchase of a helicopter in England in 1989. The English police
traced the appellant and the helicopter to South Africa. The English
police, after consulting with the Crown Prosecution Service, decided
not to request the return of the applicant through extradition process.
Instead the English police colluded with the South African police to
have the appellant arrested in South Africa and forcibly returned to
England against his will. He was arrested by the South African
police and held in custody until he was placed on an airplane
Ostensibly to be deported to New Zealand via Taiper. From Taipei
175
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 106
he was returned to South Africa and held in custody until he was
placed, handcuffed to the seat. on a flight from Johannesburg
arriving at Heathrow where he was arrested by the English Police.
He was then brought before a Magistrate for committal proceedings.
The Magistrate committed him for trial to the Crown Court. He
brought proceedings for judicial review to challenge the decision of
the Magistrate. In staying the trial proceedings and ordering the
release of the appellant, Lord Griffiths held:
"The courts, of course, have no power to
apply direct discipline to the police or
the prosecuting authorities, but they can
refuse to allow them to take advantage
of abuse of power by regarding their
behavior as an abuse of process and thus
preventing a prosecution",
And Lord Bridge after noticing cutses from South Africa, the US,
and England, wrote:
"Whatever differences there may be
between the legal systems of South
Africa, United States, New Zealand and
this country, many of the basic
principles to which they seek to give
effect stem from common roots. There
is, I think, no principle more basic to any
proper system of law than the
maintenance of the rule of law itself.
Since the prosecution could never have
been brought if the defendant had not
been illegally abducted, the whole
proceeding is tainted......"
In Manzoor Elahi case (PLD 1975 SC 66), the detenue, Ch. Zahoor
Elahi, was arrested in pursuance of a court warrant in Lahore in
connection with an offence to be tried in Kollu, a tribal area in
Balochistan. He was taken to Kohlu without being produced before
176
a Magistrate within 24 hours of his arrest. It was argued on behalf
of the State that the initial illegality in arrest was not material, for
he was being detained in Kohlu for trial on charges under the
Pakistan Penal Code. This contention was repelled by Yaqub Ali J:
"We are not concerned at this stage with the
legality of the trial of the prisoner which has not
yel commenced but we are dealing with the legality
of his arrest. If it is found to be illegal the prisoner
will be discharged though he may again be taken
into custody in accordance with law and placed for
trial before a court of competent jurisdiction".
Right to Counsel and Right against Self-incrimination:
Their relation:
This subject will be discussed later under Article 13(b)
of the Constitution.
PREVENTIVE DETENTION; CLAUSES (4) to (9) of
ARTICLE 10:
The Constitution of Pakistan treats "preventive
detention" as a category apart, so much so that the safeguards
provided by clauses (1) and (2) of Article 10, as to ordinary arrest
and detention, do not apply to preventive detention. This is
expressly provided by clause (3) of Article 10:
"Nothing in clauses (1) and (2) shall apply to any
person who is arrested or detained under any law
providing for preventive detention".
The expression "preventive detention" has not been
defined in the Constitution; it has also not acquired a technical
sense. It means "detention, the object of which is to prevent the
doing of an act. Whatever the circumstances under which detention
is ordered and whatever the act which is sought to be prevented, if
the detention is not a punishment for what the person concerned
177
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 107
has already done, but a means of preventing an act, it is preventive
detention". (The Government of East Pakistan v Rowshan Bijya
Shaukat Ali-PLD 1966 SC 286, 320).
The object in giving constitutional status to preventive
detention is to prevent anti-social and subversive elements from
imperiling the welfare of the State, and the safeguards provided by
Article 10 are intended-
"to mitigate its harshness and one of
them is that in case of detention for a
period of more than three months, the
sufficiency of the cause of detention has
To be reviewed by the Review Board and
also that law cannot authorize detention
beyond the maximum period. Thus,
when the Board has found that there are
not sufficient grounds for detention, a
fresh order or extension of an existing
order will be without lawful authority".
(Begum Nazir Abdul Hamid v Pakistan
-PLD 1974 Lab. 7, 16).
It is plain that preventive detention makes an inroad on
the personal liberty of a citizen without the safeguards in a formal
trial before a judicial tribunal and it must be jealously kept within
the bounds fixed for it by the Constitution and the relevant law
(Rowshan Bijya case). It is an exception to the general rule that a
person may not be detained without trial and without a judgment of
guilt, and therefore the law authorizing such detention must be
strictly construed, and in case of doubt, in favour of the detenue.
Article 10, by its clause (4), authorizes the making of
law providing for preventive detention to deal with persons acting
in a manner prejudicial to the integrity, security or defense of
Pakistan or external affairs of Pakistan, or public order, or
the maintenance of supplies or services, and no law shall authorize
178
the detention of a person for a period exceeding three months
unless the appropriate Review Board has after affording him an
opportunity of being heard in person, reviewed his case and
reported before the expiration of the said period, that there is, in its
opinion, sufficient cause for such detention...." (For a detailed
study of the subject and the meaning of various expressions used
here. please see the author's book "Judicial Review of Public
Actions, V-I).
ARTICLE 11-SLAVERY, FORCED LABOUR
PROHIBITED
This Article forbids slavery, prohibits all forms of forced
labour and traffic in human beings, forbids the engagement of
children below 14 in any factory, mine or any other hazardous
employment but saves and permits compulsory service -
a)
b)
by any person undergoing punishment for an
office, and
required by any law for public purpose
provided such compulsory service is not of a
criminal nature or incompatible with human
dignity. This is thus a special provision
protecting human dignity in relation to
compulsory service, whether by way of
punishment in a criminal case or required for
a public purpose, as against the general
protection provided by Article 14 for human
dignity.
ARTICLE 12-PROTECTION AGAINST
RETROSPECTIVE PUNISHMENT
The general rule is that the power to legislate includes
the power to legislate retrospectively having effect from a back
date. For example a law made in November 2007 can provide that
179
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 108
it shall take effect from November 2006 and even from a date
farther back in the past.
Article 12 is addressed to the Legislature the
legislative organ of the State-and enacts an exception to the above
-stated general rule and hence a limitation upon the general
legislative power of the State. It is a species of law protective of
vested rights, and embodies the basic principle of criminal
jurisprudence, namely, there can be no crime or punishment unless
it is in accordance with law that is certain, unambiguous and not
retroactive. The rationale underlying this principle is clear:
"Law-abiding members of society
regulate their lives according to the law
as it exists at the time of their actions
and they expect the law to be steadfast
and reliable they assess and weigh
the consequences according to the
demands of existing law, including the
requirements implicit in the existing
system of law and are entitled to feel
cheated if the law later lets them down
by taking or reducing their rights, or
increasing their burdens". (Qadeeruddin
J. in Nabi Ahmad case PLD 1969 SC
599,610).
This is especially important in the criminal law, where
citizens are potentially liable to a deprivation of life, liberty and
property if their conduct is in conflict with the law, (Lamer J. in a
Canadian case (1990) 56 CCC(3)65).
Article 12 reads
1)
No law shall authorize the punishment of a
person-
2)
a)
b)
for an act or omission that was not
punishable by law at the time of the
act or omission; or
for an offence by a penalty greater
than, or of a kind different from,
the penalty prescribed by law for
that offence at the time the offence
was committed.
Nothing in clause (1) or in Article 270 shall
apply to any law making acts of abrogation
and subversion of a Constitution in force in
Pakistan, at any time since the twenty third
day of March, one thousand nine hundred and
fifty six, an offence".
The corresponding provision in the US Constitution is
Article 1, Section 10, which in its relevant part, reads:
"No State shall pass any ex post facto law ......"
In the leading case on the point, Calder v Bull (3 US (3
Dall.) 386; 1 L Ed 648, (1798), the US Supreme Court held that
this provision bars only retroactive penal legislation, that is,
legislation affecting an individual either by making something a
crime after the act was committed or heightening the penalty for an
existing offence after commissien of the crime, and not retroactive
state enactments which affect property interests or contractual
obligations.
Though Article 12 of the Constitution of Pakistan does
not use the expression retrospective' or 'ex post facto', or
retroactive, yet it seems to have adopted the meaning of the 'ex
post facto laws given to the expression in Calder v Bull.
180
181
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 109
It is to be noted that there is no fundamental difference
between 'retrospective law' and 'ex post fact law'. Only the former
expression is used in respect of civil matters and the latter in
respect of criminal matters, which by their nature are more serious
(Nabi Ahmad case; this statement has been borrowed from Corpus
Juris Secundum Vol 16A Art. 435).
An illustration of sub-clause (b) of clause (1) of Article
12 is provided by Abdul Rehman v State (1978 SCMR 292). The
accused was tried for murder, which was committed in 1964. He
was convicted and sentenced in 1970 to death. His appeal to the
High Court failed, but in the Supreme Court, his sentence was
reduced to life imprisonment. He filed a review petition praying
that his sentence be reduced to transportation for life (20 years)
because the sentence of life imprisonment (25 years) was
introduced by the Law Reforms Ordinance in 1972, and at the time
of the offence he could be sentenced to transportation for life only.
It was held that the 1972 law could not be applied retroactively;
accordingly, his sentence was reduced to transportation for life.
Obviously where the sentence awardable under the new
law is different in kind but beneficial to the convict, Article 12 will
not apply. This is the view taken in Calder V Bull, in an Indian
case (Rattan Lal v State of Punjab - AIR 1965 SC 444) as also in
Bhai Khan case (PLD 1992 SC 14, 24).
Clause (2) of Article 12 creates an exception to the
above stated right. It permits the making of a retroactive law, a law
having effect from a back date, where there is abrogation or
subversion of the Constitution. Suppose that the Constitution is
abrogated or subverted today, but there is no law treating such
abrogation or subversion an offence; a future legislature, a year, ten
or even a hundred years from today, can under this clause, make it
an offence and punishable as such without the fear of being hit by
the prohibition against retroactive punishment. The reason for this
exception seems to be that abrogation or subversion of the
Constitution is, under Article 6 of the Constitution, high treason
and treasons are not to be allowed to go unpunished even if you
have to have resort to retroactive laws.
This provision reminds one of the only time in the
British history when the constitutional system of government was
overturned. Oliver Cromwell, the author of the revolution, died in
1659 and was buried in Westminster Abbey. In 1661, after the
restoration of Charles II as King, Oliver Cromwell's body was
exhumed and was subjected to the ritual of a posthumous
execution; his body was hanged in chains and his head was not
buried till as recently as 1960. This was a kind of retroactive
punishment.
ARTICLE 13: PROTECTION AGAINST DOUBLE
PUNISHMENT AND SELF-INCRIMINATION.
It reads:
"No person.........
a)
b)
DOUBLE JEOPARDY
be
or
shall
prosecuted
punished for the same office
more than once; or
shall, when accused of an
office, be compelled to be a
witness against himself".
The corresponding provision in the US Constitution, S
Amendment, known as the double jeopardy clause, reads:
"Nor shall any person be subject for the same
office to be twice put in jeopardy of life and limb".
182
183
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 110
And before its incorporation in the Constitution of Pakistan, the
right against double jeopardy was provided in section 403 Cr.P.C.
That section is still part of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898; it
will be sufficient to refer here to sub-section (1) of that section:
"403(1) Person once convicted or
acquitted not to be tried for same
offence: A person who has once been
tried by a court of competent jurisdiction
for an offence and convicted or acquitted
for such offence shall, while such
conviction or acquittal remains in force,
not be liable to be tried again for the
same offence, nor on the same facts for
any other offence for which a different
charge from the one made against him
might have been made under section 236
or for which he might have been
convicted under section 237".
The right against double jeopardy as provided in the US
Constitution had, it was observed in one of the leading American
cases-US v Scott (437 US 82), its origin in the three common-law
pleas of autre-fois acquit (formerly acquitted), autre-fois convict
(formerly convicted) and pardon. "These three pleas prevented the
retrial of a person who had previously been acquitted, convicted or
pardoned for the same offence". As was held in Benton (395 US
784 (1969), the clause provides three related protections: "It
protects against a second prosecution for the same offence after
acquittal. It protects against a second prosecution for the same
offence after conviction. And it protects against multiple
punishments for the same offence after conviction". As was said in
Green v US (355 US 184):
"The underlying idea, one that is deeply
ingrained in at least the Anglo-American
system of jurisprudence, is that the state
184
with all its resources and power should
not be allowed to make repeated
attempts to convict an individual for an
alleged offence, thereby subjecting him.
to embarrassment, expense and ordeal
and compelling him to live in a
continuing state of anxiety and
insecurity, as well as enhancing the
possibility that even though innocent he
may be found guilty".
There are, it was said-
"two venerable principles of double
jeopardy jurisprudence. The successful
appeal of a judgment of conviction, on
any ground other than the insufficiency
of the evidence to support the verdict
(Burks v US-437 US 1; 57 LED 2d 1)
poses no bar to further prosecution on
the same charge. A judgment of acquittal
whether based on a jury verdict of not
guilty or on a ruling by the court that the
evidence is insufficient to convict, may
not be appealed and terminates the
prosecution when a second trial would
be necessitated by a reversal.... the
law attaches particular significance to an
acquittal. To permit a second trial after
an acquittal, however mistaken the
acquittal may have been, would present
an un-acceptably high risk that the
Government, with its vastly superior
resources, might wear down the
defendant so that even though innocent
he may be found guilty".
185
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 111
pros
As to what is an acquittal, it was held that a defendant is
acquitted only when the ruling of the Judge, whatever its label,
actually represents a resolution in the defendant's favour, correct or
not, of some or all of the factual elements of the offence charged.
In Burks v US (437 US 1:57 LED 2d I) it was held that:
"Since we hold today that the Double
Jeopardy clause precludes a second trial
once the reviewing court has found the
evidence legally insufficient, the only
just remedy available for that court is
the direction of a judgment of acquittal.
To the extent that our first decisions
suggest that by moving for a new trial, a
defendant waives his right to a judgment
of acquittal on the basis of evidentiary
insufficiency, those cases are overruled".
Also embodied in the US 5 Amendment guarantee
against double jeopardy is the "extremely important principle in
our adversary system of justice" namely, the principle of "collateral
estoppel" which simply means "that when an issue of ultimate fact
has once been determined by a valid and final judgment, that issue
cannot again be agitated between the same parties in any future
lawsuit". Although first developed in civil litigation, collateral
estoppel has been "an established rule of federal criminal law since
this
decision more than 50 years ago in US v Oppenheimer
(242 US 85-1916)". A striking illustration of this principle is
Ashe v Swenson (397 US 436; 25 L Ed 2d 459-1970) which will
be noticed in the discussion below under the heading "Prosecuted
and Punished for the same Offence"
An enunciation of the common law doctrine of double jeopardy is
to be found in the speech of Lord Morris in the House of Lords
decision in Connelly v DPP (1964) 2 All ER 401).
Is the ambit and scope of the right conferred by Article
13(a) the same as has been described in the American cases noticed
above?
If the origin of the right is and there seems to be no
doubt that it is - in the common law pleas of autre-fois acquit and
autre-fois convict, then the right guaranteed by the American
Constitution, 5 Amendment, and the right guaranteed by Article
13(b) of the Constitution of Pakistan, have a common root. It
should follow therefore that guidance can be gleaned from the
American cases to determine the ambit of the right under Article
13(a).
In Alamdar Hussain Shah v Abdul Baseer Qureshi (PLD
1978 SC 121), the petitioner, a sub-inspector of police, and two
others, were accused of killing a person in police custody. The
petitioner was tried before a Special Military Court (it was a period
of Martial Law) under sections 330, 342 and 304 PPC. The trial
had almost concluded when the martial law was lifted. The case
was then tried by a magistrate under section 304 PPC. Prosecution
evidence was closed on 07.2.1976. But the trial under section 304
PPC was challenged and the court of revision held that the
petitioner was liable to be tried under section 302 PPC. This order
was challenged in the High Court on the ground that the
prosecution would be against Article 13(a). It was held that in none
of the forums was prosecution pursued to the end and it could not
be said that the petitioner's trial would be against Article 13(a) or
against the general principle of autre-fois acquit or autre-fois
convict. It is only if the prosecution has finally concluded and
ended either in acquittal or conviction that a fresh prosecution for
the same offence would be barred.
186
187
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 112
PROSECUTED AND PUNISHED FOR THE SAME
OFFENCE:
While the prohibition in Article 13(a) of the Constitution
of Pakistan is against being "prosecuted or punished for the same
offence more than once", in the US Constitution the prohibition is
that "no person shall be subject for the same offence to be twice
put in jeopardy of life and limb".
Though the US Constitution does not use the
expressions "prosecution" and "punishment" in the Double
Jeopardy clause, yet, "the two bedrock elements of the clause are
the prohibitions against reprosecution for the same offence
following an acquittal or a conviction". This guarantee, so said
Justice Brennan in Ashe (397 US 436; 25 L Ed 2d 469) "is
expressed as a prohibition against multiple prosecution for the
same offence", and in the words of Justice Scalia in US v Dixon
(125 L Ed 2 556 (1993).
"This protection applies both to
successive punishments and to
successive prosecutions for the same
criminal offence".
And successive prosecutions are barred by the Fifth
Amendment, so said Justice O'Connor in Heath v Alabama (474
US 82, 88 L Ed 2d 387 (1985), only if the two offences for which
the defendant is prosecuted are the same for double jeopardy
purposes.
The term "offence" is defined in the Code of Criminal
Procedure, 1898, section 4(o), to mean an 'act or omission made
punishable by the law for the time being in force....... The
General Clauses Act, 1897, section 3(37), uses the same definition.
Though, these definitions do not by their own force
apply to the Constitution, yet they do give a fair idea of what an
offence means. It means a criminal offence.
For the doctrine of autre-fois acquit or autre-fois
convict, so said Lord Devlin in the English case of Connelly.
(1964) 2 All ER 401). "it is necessary that the accused should have
been put in peril of conviction for the same offence as that with
which he is then charged. The word "offence' embraces both the
facts which constitute the crime and the legal characteristics which
make it an offence. For the doctrine to apply it must be the same
offence both in fact and in law".
Muhammad Ayub v Chairman Electricity Board (PLD
1987 SC 195) illustrates that 'offence' here means criminal
offence. The petitioner, a Sub-Divisional Officer, was tried under
section 161 PPC and section 5 of the Prevention of Corruption Act,
1947, for accepting illegal gratification but was acquitted.
Thereafter, he was proceeded again departmentally; he was found
guilty and was punished with compulsory retirement from service.
He challenged the penalty as being violative of Article 13(b). It
was held that while sometimes the word offence is used in various
senses, it-
"here implies a crime infringing public
as distinguished from mere private rights
and is punishable under the criminal law.
Indeed this provision is a protection
against double punishment and the
punishment contemplated under Article
13 is a punishment that has been
imposed upon a person as a result of
criminal prosecution".
In Ashe v Swenson (397 US 436; 25 L Ed 2d 469), six
men, including Donald Knight and Roberts, were playing poker in
a house when three or four masked men, armed with pistols and
guns, broke into the house and robbed each of the poker players of
188
189
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 113
money and other belongings. The robbers then fled in a car
belonging to one of the victims of the robbery. Shortly thereafter
the stolen car was found in a field and later four persons were
arrested. They were charged with seven separate offenses - the
armed robbery of each of the poker players and the theft of the car,
The petitioner, Ashe, was tried for robbing Knight, the
main question being as to the identity of Ashe as one of the
robbers. The jury found the petitioner "not guilty due to
insufficient evidence".
Six weeks later, the petitioner was brought to trial again,
this time for robbing Roberts; this time, the jury found him guilty
and he was sentenced to 35 years in prison; the verdict being that
he was one of the robbers.
The question was whether the acquittal of the petitioner
in the first trial barred his second prosecution and punishment. In
the words of Justice Stewart, the question was not "whether he
could have received a total of six punishments if he had been
convicted in a single trial of robbing the six victims. It is simply
whether, after a jury determined by verdict that the petitioner was
not one of the robbers, the State could constitutionally hale him
before a new jury to litigate that issue again".
It was held that the principle of "collateral estoppel" is
part of the Fifth Amendment guarantee against double jeopardy
and that the second prosecution resulting in conviction and
punishment was unconstitutional.
As to what is the precise meaning of the term "same
offence", Justice Brennan, in his concurring opinion, noticed that at
common law, the "same evidence" test was applied. This test, so
held Justice Brennan, "is not constitutionally required". Instead, in
his view --
"the double jeopardy clause requires the
prosecution, except in most limited
190
circumstances, to join at one trial, all the
charges against a defendant that grow
out of a simple criminal act, occurrence,
episode or transaction. This same
transaction test of 'same offence' not
only enforces the ancient prohibition
against vexatious multiple prosecutions
embodied in the double jeopardy clause,
but responds as well to the increasingly
that the
wide-spread recognition
consolidation in one law-suit of all
issues arising out of a single transaction
or occurrence best promotes justice,
economy and convenience".
The word 'prosecution' or 'prosecuted' has different
meanings when used in different relations and has a limited or
extended signification according to the intention of the law-maker
and the context in which it is used. In Muhammad Ashraf V State
(1995 SCMR 626), two sets of accused persons were prosecuted
for murder in two separate trials; the appellant, Muhammad Ashraf
alias Achu, was common to both the sets. The trial Judge convicted
and sentenced the first set. As regards the second set of the accused
persons, the trial Judge acquitted the accused persons other than the
appellant; as regards him the trial Judge said that he already stood
convicted and sentenced in the first trial. The plea raised was that
in one of the trials the appellant was acquitted and hence his
punishment was contrary to Article 13(a). It was held: -
"It will be seen that the protection given
by this Article is against prosecution and
double punishment. By prosecution is
meant a trial followed by judgment of
acquittal or punishment. It includes the
entire proceedings starting with taking
cognizance of an offence by the court,
followed by examination of evidence,
addressing of arguments and ending with
191
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 114
pronouncement of judgment. It seems to
us that if as a result of prosecution for an
offence the trial ends in acquittal, Article
13(a) is not attracted. Constitutional
guarantee is available only if the accused
is convicted and punished. Thus, if the
first prosecution results in acquittal, so
far as this Article is concerned, the
second prosecution is not prohibited. It
is, however, open to the legislature to
enlarge the scope of constitutional
further extend the
guarantee and
protection envisaged by Article 13(a).
Such extension of rule of double
jeopardy is to be found in Section 403 of
the Criminal Procedure Code",
It is to be noticed, so observed the learned Judge, that
the constitutional guarantee is confined only to duplicate
punishment and is silent in so far as acquittal is concerned. Section
403(1) however prohibits the second trial for an offence during the
course of existence of conviction or acquittal of a person, as the
case may be, in consequence of final adjudication of such an
offence by a court of competent jurisdiction. "Thus, the rule against
autre-fois acquit finds place in Section 403(1) and the counterpart
of this rule autre-fois convict has received recognition in the
constitutional guarantee embodied in Article 13(a)".
COMMENT:
If we may say with great respect, on the facts of that
case, the decision was correct, but the reasoning that led to it is, it
is submitted, open to question. The view that, if as a result of
prosecution for an offence the trial ends in acquittal, Article 13(a)
is not attracted; that constitutional guarantee is available only if the
accused is convicted and punished and that, if the first prosecution
results in acquittal, so far as this Article is concerned, the second
prosecution is not prohibited, does not take into account the history
192
of the principle of double jeopardy, as traced in the English and
American cases noticed ahove namely "that the law attaches
particular significance to an acquittal. To permit a second trial after
an acquittal however mistaken the acquittal may have been, would
present an unacceptably high risk....." (Scott case). This view also
does not take account of the fact that its origin is in the common
law pleas of autre-fois acquit (former acquittal) and autre-fois
convict (former conviction); most of all, this view ignores the
important word "prosecuted" in Article 13(a). As was said in US v
Scott. "A detailed canvass of history of the double jeopardy
principle in US v Wilson (420 US 332 (1975) led us to conclude
that the double jeopardy clause was primarily directed at the threat
to multiple prosecutions". This, it is submitted, is the law laid
down in Alamdar Husain Shah v Abdul Bashir Quershi, namely,
that it is only if the prosecution has finally concluded and ended
either in acquittal or conviction that a fresh prosecution for the
same offence would be barred.
In defining the word "prosecution", in Muhammad
Ashraf case itself, it was observed that the word "prosecution"
means a trial followed by judgment of acquittal or punishment. "It
includes the entire proceedings starting with taking cognizance of
the offence by the court, followed by examination of
evidence and ending with the pronouncement of judgment".
On this view, if there is no prosecution or trial there can be no
conviction or acquittal. So, if a person has once been duly tried and
acquitted, he cannot be prosecuted again and if he cannot be
prosecuted again, there will be no occasion for putting him twice in
peril for the same offence. This way of looking at the matter, it is
submitted, will save the word 'prosecuted' from being rendered
surplusage. It is no part of the court's interpretative function to
render words, particularly those guaranteeing valuable rights
relating to life and liberty, redundant.
Apart from the fact that Muhammad Ashraf case does
not enunciate the law correctly, the observations, such as that if as
a result of prosecution for an offence, the trial ends in acquittal,
Article 13(a) is not attracted, were not necessary for the decision
193
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 115
of the case and were obiter dicta. This is because the Court itself
I noted that the judgment of conviction "in point of time was
rendered first" and that "the appellant's subsequent acquittal cannot
reflect upon his conviction and sentence".
It is submitted therefore that the decision in Muhammad
Ashraf case should be treated as an authority for its own facts, not
as enunciating a general principle of law within the meaning of
Article 189 of the Constitution.
In this view of the provisions of Article 13(a), the scope
of section 403, sub-section (1) of the Code of Criminal Procedure,
it is submitted, is the same as that of Article 13(b).
Does "prosecution" Include investigation stage
We have seen that in conferring the right to counsel the
US Sixth Amendment uses the expression "prosecutions":
"In all criminal prosecutions, the
accused shall enjoy the right ... to
have the assistance of counsel for his
defence".
We have also seen that the right to counsel, read with the
right against self-incrimination, has been held in Miranda and other
American cases to be available at the investigation stage when
interrogation of an accused person begins at the police station or
any other place. An arrest, so observed Chief Justice Warren in
Terry (392 US 1), is the initial stage of a criminal prosecution.
Should this extended meaning of "prosecution" apply
also in the interpretation of Article 13(a)?
We have seen that the idea underlying the principle of
double jeopardy as incorporated in the American 5" Amendment
and Article 13(a) of the Constitution of Pakistan is to save a
person, who was duly tried and convicted or acquitted, from being
194
subjected again to the "embarrassment, expense and ordeal" of a
second prosecution. The criminal justice process, it ought be
remembered, starts, not with the commencement of trial but with
the investigation and interrogation by the police and all that it
entails. The atmosphere at the police station, we all know, is not
only coercive but also derogatory to human dignity. There is
therefore greater need for saving such a person from suffering that
ordeal all over again. These are, it is submitted, reasons enough for
giving the word "prosecuted" in Article 13(a) the extended
meaning, so that not only the second trial but also the second
investigation and interrogation are also barred.
Article 13 (b)
RIGHT TO COUNSEL AND RIGHT AGAINST SELF-
INCRIMINATION; THEIR RELALIONSHIP
There is an intimate connection between the right to
counsel and the right against self-incrimination. As we have seen,
that connection was established in the famous American case of
Miranda which has survived many an attempt, legislative as well as
judicial, at its reversal. Miranda treated both the rights together.
Originally, both these rights were viewed as primarily, if not
exclusively, concerned with the trial stage; it was also, at one time,
the view that as regards the right to counsel, only the person able to
hire a lawyer could utilize a lawyer's services. As we have seen, all
these views have changed.
The right to counsel, as we saw, is guaranteed by the
American Sixth Amendment: "In all criminal prosecutions, the
accused shall enjoy the right...... to have the assistance of
counsel for his defence".
In the Constitution of Pakistan, this right is conferred by
Article 10, Clause (1): "No person who is arrested shall be
detained nor shall he be denied the right to consult and be
defended by a legal practitioner of his choice".
195
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 116
The right against self-incrimination is guaranteed by the
American Fifth Amendment: "No person shall be...... compelled
in any criminal case to be a witness against himself.
In Pakistan, Article 13(b) provides: "No person shall,
when accused of an offence, be compelled to be a witness against
himself".
We have seen that the expressions "in any criminal case"
in US Amendment VI. according to the US Supreme Court
decisions e.g. Miranda v Arizona (386 US 436). Rhode Island v
Innis (46 US 291), Brewer v Williams (430 US 387), include the
investigation stage; the right to counsel and the right against self-
incrimination come into play as soon as a person is arrested and his
interrogation begins.
If the provisions in the US Constitution and the
Constitution of Pakistan are considered in juxtaposition, one cannot
fail to see the remarkable similarity between their language. Both
the Constitutions use the words "compelled to be a witness against
himself. If we read Article 13(b) with Article 10(1), as we must, it
would appear, inexorably in our opinion, that when a person is
arrested and is served with the grounds of arrest, he is being
accused of an offence within the meaning of Article 13(b). It
should follow logically therefore that the right under Article 13(b)
read with Article 10(1), is more plainly designed to apply to the
investigation stage than the right under the American Amendment
V, which uses the expression "in any criminal case". As to the right
to counsel, the context of Article 10(1) is 'arrest', and there could
not be a plainer indication than this of the availability of this right
at the police investigation and interrogation stage.
Then, the right under Article 10(1) is a two-fold right;
the right to ccnsult, and the right to be defended by, a legal
practitioner, and this is therefore a much wider right than the right
under the US Amendment VI. The words "to be defended" in
Article 10(1) of the Constitution of Pakistan, are obviously another
way of saying "for his defence" as does the US Constitution.
196
This view of Articles 10(1) and 13(b) is reinforced by
the provisions of Article 14 of the Constitution of Pakistan which
protects the dignity of man and privacy of home and also provides:
"No person shall be subjected to torture
for the purpose of extracting evidence"
Long detention in custody, and long interrogation by the
police in privacy and in the suffocating and humiliating atmosphere
of the police station, we have seen, may amount to both physical
and mental torture.
If this discussion has stimulated sufficient interest in this
branch of constitutional law, then hopefully a beginning has been
made for the development in Pakistan of the jurisprudence of the
right to counsel and the right against self incrimination in the light
of principles enunciated in the American cases. However, in
embarking upon that course, the participants in the process will do
well to bear in mind the word of caution articulated above.
By way of illustration: The way to the development of
that jurisprudence can be illustrated as follows. Suppose that A is
arrested on the complaint of B that A has stolen his buffalo. He is
informed of the grounds of arrest, and A is taken to the police
station, where he will undergo the ordeal of interrogation in an
interrogation cell. Here, it is plain that A is being accused of an
offence. The object of the interrogation will obviously be the
extraction of information from A as to the whereabouts of the
stolen buffalo. This information from A will obviously amount to
self-incrimination. This is how the right against self-incrimination
comes into play.
A's relatives approach a lawyer, C, and ask him to assist
A in the protection of his right against self-incrimination.
guaranteed by Article 13(b) of the Constitution of Pakistan. Can C
do this?
197
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 117
In view of what has been said above, he certainly can.
As we saw, the right to consult and be defended by a legal
practitioner occurs in Article 10(1), which provides safeguards as
to arrest and detention. An arrest and detention by the police is
invariably followed by interrogation to extract evidence from the
arrestee. The intention of Article 10(1) read with Article 13(b) is
thus clear, it is to provide safeguards, including the right to consult
a lawyer before and during interrogation, for protecting the right
against self-incrimination of the arrestee.
Right to counsel under Article 10(1) of the Constitution and
Section 340(1) Cr.P.C.
Both these provisions, Article 10(1) of the Constitution
of Pakistan and section 340, sub-section (1), of the Code of
Criminal Procedure, 1898, confer the right to counsel. But there are
significant differences between them:
(1)
the right conferred by Article 10(1),
i)
ii)
is a constitutional right; and
is wider in scope and application,
in that, it is a right to consult and be
defended by a legal practitioner of
one's choice. The right is not
confined to any particular stage of
prosecution. It is available not only
at the trial stage that is, in the
courtroom only, but also at the
investigation stage.
The right conferred by section 340. subsection
(2)
(1)-
i)
is a statutory right; and
ii)
is available at the trial stage only,
As we have seen, a statutory provision inconsistent with
a constitutional right is void. Thus in Bazal Ahmad (PLD 1957
198
Lah. 388), section 6(i)(g) of the Punjab Control of Gondas Act
1951 which permitted the exclusion of counsel at trial was held
unconstitutional and in Moslimuddin Sikdar v Chief Secretary
(PLD 1957 Dacca 101) a trial in which the prisoner was denied the
right to consult a lawyer and be represented by him was held to be
violative of the right to be defended by a legal practitioner.
Article 10(1) uses the expression "legal practitioner" and
section 340(1) uses the word "pleader". These and the expressions
"counsel", and "lawyer" and "legal practitioner" are all used
interchangeably, and have the same meaning.
Counsel for the poor
Neither Article 10(1) of the Constitution nor section
340(1) Cr.P.C. says, expressly or even impliedly, that the right to
counsel is available only to those who can afford to hire a lawyer
of their own. As we saw, the law in America is that the right to be
heard includes the right to be heard by counsel and that any person
haled in court who is too poor to hire a lawyer cannot be assured a
fair trial unless counsel is provided to him by the State. The
language of Article 10(1), "nor shall he be denied the right to
consult and be defended by a legal practitioner of his choice" as
compared with the American Sixth Amendment; "shall enjoy the
right to have the assistance of counsel for his defence", does
not present any linguistic difficulty. The right conferred is the right
to consult and he defended in one case and the right to "have the
assistance of counsel for his defence" in the other, and both are
substantially the same; both confer the right to counsel. And if the
right to counsel is conceded, the words "of his choice" in Article
10(1) ought not to be allowed to defeat that right. Those who can
afford can hire counsel of their choice and those who cannot must
be content to have counsel of their choice from among those
provided by the State. This way of looking at the matter will save
not only the right to counsel but also the equality clause, Article 25
of the Constitution of Pakistan: "All citizens are equal before law
and are entitled to equal protection of law" from being defeated. As
was said by Justice Black in Griffin (351 US 12);
199
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 118
"There can be no equal justice where the
kind of trial a man gets depends on the
amount of money he has.......
To be fair to indigent accused persons and to place them
on an equal footing with the prosecution and those who can afford
their own lawyer, Chapter 24C of the High Court Rules and
Orders, V.III, provides that accused persons tried for capital
offences should have the assistance of a lawyer at State expense.
Similarly, the High Court Rules and Orders, Volume-III, Chapter
25E, makes provision for counsel to be provided at State expense
to the defendants in appeals against acquittals and appeals for the
enhancement of sentence.
It is submitted that the Constitution, Article 10(1), and
the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898, section 340(1), make as
regards the right to counsel no distinction between capital and non-
capital cases and the right should, therefore, be available to all
indigent defendants accused of any offence. All criminal offences,
when tried, can produce serious, severe, consequences; fine means
loss of property, imprisonment means loss of liberty as also a
stigma, as well as a reminder, that the convict is literally a social
outcast, and death means loss of life.
We propose therefore that in order to make the
constitutional right to counsel effective, the State should provide
counsel to all indigent and poor accused persons, irrespective of the
offence with which they are charged being a capital or non-capital
offer.ce, and that a law to that effect be enacted and the High Court
Rules and Orders be amended accordingly.
Similarly under Article 10(1), the right to be defended
includes the right to be defended by counsel (Bazal Ahmad at page
234) and that means the same thing as the right to be heard by
counsel.
ARTICLE 13(b)-RIGHT AGAINST SELF-
INCRIMINATION
The source of the US Fifth Amendment right against
self-incrimination is the ancient Latin maxim of the common law:
"nemo tenetur prodere seipsum"
(nobody is bound to accuse himself).
There is no constitutional or statutory declaration of the
privilege against self-incrimination in English law, but it has been
recognized judicially in R v Sang (1980) AC 402) in Lord
Diplock's speech:
"The underlying rationale is, in my view,
to be found in the maxim - nemo debet
prodere se ipsum no one can be
required to be his own betrayer".
The history of the right is sometimes traced back to
Christ, who refused to answer the questions of his accusers at his
trial. We have already referred to the Star Chambers and to the case
of John Lilburne, whose struggles in 1637 resulted in the abolition
of the Star Chambers and the establishment of the right against
self-incrimination. To this may be added another interesting
historical fact namely that in Europe from the mid-thirteenth
century to the mid-eighteenth century a system of judicial torture
lay at the heart of the continental criminal procedure. The
application of torture was a routine and judicially supervised
feature of the European criminal procedure. Under certain
circumstances, the law permitted the criminal courts to employ
physical torture to suspected criminals to force them to confess.
i)
We have noticed cases in which-
the constitutional foundation underlying this
right was identified (Miranda).
200
201
Scanned with CamScanner

SELF-INCRIMINATION THROUGH PRODUCTION OF
DOCUMENTS:
We have seen that there is a close relationship between
the US Fourth Amendment right against unreasonable search and
seizure and the Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination.
In Boyd (116 US 616 (1886), it was held that "the seizure of a
man's private books and papers to be used in evidence against
him" is not "substantially different from compelling him to be a
witness against himself".
This and other American cases were considered in Alpha
Insurance Co. v United Insurance Co. (1996 SCMR 1668); there
the police issued notices to the appellant Insurance Companies
requiring them to produce certain record. The notice was sought to
be justified on the basis of section 94 of the Code of Criminal
Procedure. It was held that the word 'person' in that section
includes a person accused, and that the right against self-
incrimination under Article 13(b) was available at the investigation
stage. It is a privilege of the accused. It can be exercised against the
whole world, its exercise can be waived as well. The question
whether the right was violated or not, was however not for the
police to decide; that question was for the court. As soon as the
right was claimed, the police had "to hold its hands"; "The police
therefore cannot take the coercive steps that are reserved for it
under Section 94 Cr.P.C for getting, through the accused, such
documents".
THE RIGHT APPLIES AT INVESTIGATION STAGE:
Alpha Insurance is thus also authority for the view that
the right against self-incrimination applies at investigation stage
and the cases which hold otherwise must be deemed to have been
overruled.
"PERSON" IN ARTICLE 13(b)
CORPORATION:
DOES IT INCLUDE
The question whether the protection against self-
incrimination as ensured by Article 13(b) is available only to
natural persons, or is also available to corporations, was also
considered in Alpha Insurance. In doing so, the Supreme Court
noticed, among others the Indian case of M P Sharma v Satish
Chandra (1954) SCR 1077), and some American cases, eg, Edwin
F. Hale (201 US 43), Christopher C. Wilson (221 US 361 (1910),
US v Jasper White (322 US 694 (1943) and Joseph Curcio (354 US
118).
In the Indian case, the Supreme Court held that the
protection was also available to corporations. in doing so, the
Indian Supreme Court took account of the significance of the
words "to be a witness". In the American cases noticed by the
Supreme Court in Alpha however the view taken was that the
protection was available to "natural individuals" and not to
corporations. The Supreme Court in Alpha followed the American
view and on a review of the case law from various jurisdictions
held that-
"the guarantee contained in Article 13(b)
of the Constitution is not available to
incorporated bodies but is restricted to
natural persons".
In reaching that conclusion, reference was made to Article 260 of
the Constitution, which defines "person" to include any body
politic or corporate, unless the context otherwise requires. In clause
202
203
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 120
(b) of Article 13, it was observed, "only those accused are granted
protection who can appear as a witness against themselves. The
protection is against appearing as a witness against oneself. The
court then posed the question-
"Can a company or an incorporate
entity appear as a witness?"
Reference was then made to Qanun-e-Shahadat, Article 3 (section
118 of the Evidence Act, 1872), which "provides the ........ test for
persons to be witnesses", and it was held that--
COMMENTS:
"This Article of the Qanun-e-Shahadat
as well as its predecessor envisage a
natural person and not an incorporated
entity".
If we may say so with great respect, the view in Alpha,
that the right conferred by Article 13(b) is not available to
corporations lays too much emphasis on the words "to be a
witness" and too little on what the right is about. For the meaning
of the words "to be a witness", that view depends entirely upon the
provisions of Qanun-e-Shahadat which is a sub-constitutional law
and therefore subject to the Constitution, Article 13(b) in this case.
In other words, the view in Alpha has made the Fundamental Right
conferred by Article 13(b) subordinate to a sub-constitutional law.
That is plainly against the provisions of Article 8 of the
Constitution. To illustrate, suppose that the Supreme Court in
Alpha had held that Article 13(b) applies to corporations. That
would have become the law of the land and anything inconsistent
therewith in Article 3 of Qanun-e-Shahadat would have been void.
Then, a corporation can be accused as well as be guilty of an
offence like a natural person. When found guilty, its directors or
other functionaries - all natural persons can be punished. So,
when it comes to punishment e.g. imprisonment, it is the natural
persons constituting the corporation who suffer.
204
As regards the American cases, one distinction is that
the word "person" is not defined there as it is in the Constitution of
Pakistan: here a person includes a body politic or corporate.
The real context of Article 13(b), it is submitted, is that
it is a protection against self-incrimination; that protection ought to
be available both to natural persons and those who are in law
treated as persons, for both can be accused of offences and both
can be punished.
It is hoped that the decision in Alpha will be
reconsidered in an appropriate future case.
"ACCUSED OF AN OFFENCE":
It has been held that though the US Sixth Amendment
right to counsel generally attaches-only after formal proceedings
have commenced, "if the authorities take a person into custody in
order to interrogate him or to otherwise facilitate the process of
making a case against him then under the rationale of Escobedo,
Miranda and other cases, the person is sufficiently 'accused' to be
entitled to the protection of the Sixth Amendment". (US v Gonveia
-467 US 180 (1984).
This, as has been seen, is the position in Pakistan. When
a person is arrested on a particular criminal charge and is informed
of the grounds of his arrest under Article 10(2), he is being accused
of an offence within the meaning of Article, 13(b), and the right
against self-incrimination as well as the right to counsel comes into
play so that the suspect can refuse to speak without the assistance
of a counsel.
