ARTICLE 14: INVIOLABILITY OF DIGNITY
OF MAN ETC
Article 14 reads-
1)
The dignity of man and, subject to law,
privacy of home, shall be inviolable;
2)
No person shall be tortured for the purpose of
extracting evidence.
While the right to dignity of man and woman and the
right against being tortured to extract evidence are couched in
absolute terms and seem therefore to be absolute rights, the right to
privacy of home is subject to law.
SUBJECT TO LAW:
Like Article 14, there are a number of Fundamental
Rights in the Constitution of Pakistan, e.g. the freedom to profess
religion (Article 20), the right to provide religious instructions
(Article 22(3), and right to establish institutions to preserve and
promote language, script or culture (Article 28) which are subject
to law. It is a very bold assertion to make, as it was made in
Jibandra Kishore (PLD 1957 S.C. (Pak), 9) that these rights are
subject to law, and may therefore be taken away by law, That
assertion was rejected in the following emphatic terms by
Muhammad Munir CJ:
"The very conception of a fundamental right is that
it being a right guaranteed by the Constitution.
cannot be taken away by the law and it is not only
technically inartistic but a fraud on the citizens for
the makers of a Constitution to say that a right is
fundamental but that it may be taken away by the
law"
In Jibandar Kishore, the Fundamental Right in question was the
right to profess, practice and propagate religion. The learned Chief
Justice observed:
"I am unable to attribute any such intent
to the makers of the Constitution who in
their anxiety to regulate the lives of the
Muslims of Pakistan in accordance with
the Holy Quran and Sunnah could not
possibly have intended to empower the
legislature to take away from the
Muslims the right to profess, practice
and propagate their religion...... If the
argument is sound, it would follow
... that the legislature may today
interdict the profession of Islam by the
citizens because the right to profess,
practice and propagate religion....... is
under the Article as much subject to the
law as the right to establish, maintain
and manage religious institutions......
it seems to me that what Article 18 (of
the 1956 Constitution) means is that
every citizen has the right to profess,
practice and propagate his religion and
every sect of a religious denomination
has the right to establish, maintain and
manage its religious institutions, though
the law may regulate the manner in
which religion is to be professed,
practiced and propagated... the
words... cannot and do not mean that
such institutions may be abolished
altogether by the law..........
When a Fundamental Right is subject to law, all that it
means, it was held in Tikamdas Hiranand (PLD 1968 Kar. 703.717
206
207
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 122
FB), is that the right has been made subject to restrictions and
exceptions that may be imposed by law.
If we may add, to tell a person that he has a
constitutionally entrenched Fundamental Right but that Right can
be taken away by an ordinary law is no more than a teasing illusion
like a munificent bequest in a pauper's will (see the author's book
"Judicial Review of Public Actions" Vol.1, page 662 onwards).
"SUBJECT TO LAW" IN THE CONTEXT OF CRIMINAL
PROCEDURE:
The wisdom underlying the right to privacy of home
being subject to law is evident. The right to privacy of home cannot
possibly extend to saving criminals from being brought to justice.
There is therefore an obvious need for the power in the legislature
to make law authorizing the law enforcing authorities to enter into
the premises of those accused or suspected of crimes or other
unlawful acts for the purpose of search and seizure of persons
(arrest) and property in the exercise of their investigative powers.
The Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898, is one such law.
RIGHTS GUARANTEED BY ARTICLE 14:
Article 14 guarantees protection against-
i)
ii)
iii)
violation of the dignity of man and woman;
violation of privacy of home; and
torture to extract evidence.
It may, broadly speaking, be said that in the "dignity of man (and
woman)", is embraced the right to privacy of home and the right
against torture. They are related concepts. As was said by Saleem
Akhtar J. in Benazir Bhutto case (PLD 1998 SC 388, 621) -
"The inviolability of privacy is directly
linked with the dignity of man. If a man
is to preserve his dignity, if he is to live
with honour and reputation, his privacy
208
whether in home or outside the home has
to be saved from invasion and protected
from illegal intrusion".
Similarly, torture, whether or not applied to extract
evidence, is related to the dignity of man and woman (see Begum
Shamim Afridi case PLD 1974 Lah. 120).
Yet, as the right to privacy of home and the right against
torture have been treated in Article 14 as independent Fundamental
Rights, it is appropriate to deal with them as rights related to, but
independent of, the right to dignity of man and woman.
RIGHT TO PRIVACY OF HOME:
The right to privacy or as the American describe it the
right to be let alone, has in the Anglo-American Law, its origin in
the "castle doctrine": "a man's home is his castle" - a phrase
coined by the great English Jurist, Sir Edward Coke, in the early
1600's. (In this connection, William Pitt is often quoted: "The
poorest man may in his cottage bid defiance to all the forces of the
Crown. It may be frail; its roof may shake; the wind may blow
through it; the storm may enter, the rain may enter; but the King of
England cannot enter- all his forces dare not cross the threshold of
the ruined tenement").
In Islam, the right has divine origin; the Holy Quran, by
its S.24: 27-28, ordains:
"O ye who believe, enter not houses
other than your own until you have
asked permission and saluted those in
them.......
The command not to enter into another man's house
without permission becomes in law a prohibition against
unjustifiable entry and unreasonable searches and seizures.
209
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 123
PRIVACY IN ARTICLE 14 COMPARED WITH OTHER
CONSTITUTIONS:
As has been observed in the "Judicial Review of Public
Actions" (by Justice Fazal Karim at page 675). "Article 14 is not as
elaborate in the description of the rights intended to be embraced
by it as Amendment IV of the American Constitution and is
content to use such general expressions as "dignity of man",
"privacy of home" and "torture".
Amendment IV of the American Constitution reads:
"The right of the people to be secure in
their persons, houses, papers and effects
against unreasonable searches and
seizures, shall not be violated, and no
warrants shall issue, but upon probable
cause, supported by oath or affirmation,
and particularly describing the place to
be searched, and the persons or things to
be seized".
Article & of the European Convention for the Protection
of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms is even more
elaborate: it reads:
"1.
2.
Everyone has the right to respect for his
private and family life, his home and his
correspondence.
There shall be no interference by a public
authority with the exercise of this right except
such as is in accordance with the law and is
necessary in a democratic society in the
interest of national security, public safety or
the economic well being of the country, far
the prevention of disorder or crime, for the
protection of health or morals or for the
210
protection of the rights and freedoms of
others".
We shall see that what, under the American
constitutional law, is protected by the Fourth Amendment's
mandate is "one's privacy against arbitrary intrusion" by the police
or other state functionaries "which is at the core of the Fourth
Amendment" and "is basic to a free society" (Wolf - 338 US 25).
One may ask, is this right wider in its sweep than the right to
"privacy of home" in Article 14?
This is a legitimate question and needs serious
consideration. But we shall be content to say that even if the right
to privacy as developed in the American constitutional law is wider
than the right to privacy of home in Article 14, the general right to
privacy is covered by the "dignity of man (and woman)"
guaranteed by Article 14. This was expressly held by Saleem
Akhtar J. in Benazir Bhutto case (PLD 1998 SC 388. 621). Thus.
the general right to privacy is as much guaranteed by Article 14 of
the Constitution of Pakistan as it is by the American constitutional
law.
This should, in our opinion, lead to the conclusion that
what is protected by the American Fourth Amendment namely
"one's privacy against arbitrary intrusion" and by the European
Convention's Article & right to respect for one's private and
family life, home and correspondence is also guaranteed by
Article 14 of the Constitution of Pakistan. Dignity of man and
woman and privacy of home run into each other. The expression
"privacy of home" in Article 14 of our Constitution is a wide
expression, comprehending all that is included in the US 4
Amendment. This will also establish the relevance of the cases
decided by the US Supreme Court and cases from other
jurisdictions.
We have noticed some of the leading American cases on
the Fourth Amendment, and the readers may read them for such
guidance as they afford. They establish the following principles:

The Fourth Amendment protects people, not

By interposing a judicial officer a neutral

There is an intimate relation between the

In India, there is no provision protecting privacy such as
the American Fourth Amendment and Article 14 of the
Constitution of Pakistan. Yet, relying on Katz and other cases from
the American jurisdiction to show how the concept had developed

Supreme Court has held in District Ragistrar v Canara Bank (AIR
2005 SC 186) that the right of privacy protects persons and not
places.
As regards Article 8 of the European Convention,
concept of privacy was, as was pointed out by Lord Hope in Qazi

"It is abundantly clear

Torture: Torture can be-
i)
ii)
for the purpose of extracting evidence; or
for any other purpose.
Torture for extracting evidence is expressly prohibited;
but that does not mean that torture for other purposes is permitted
and is not prohibited. Torture affects the dignity of man and
woman which is an absolute right and must be preserved inviolate;
torture for whatever purpose applied must be held unconstitutional.
Torture for extracting evidence may be applied to the
suspects and witnesses alike and is prohibited in either case.
ARTICLE 15; FREEDOM OF MOVEMENT ETC:
Article 15 of the Constitution of Pakistan reads:
"15. Every citizen shall have the right to remain in, and,
subject to any reasonable restrictions imposed by law in
the public interest, enter and move freely throughout
Pakistan and to reside and settle in any part thereof.
214
The rights under this Article are available to citizens, as
distinguished from "persons", only. They are-
1)
the right to remain in Pakistan;
2)
the right to enter and move freely throughout
Pakistan; and
3)
the right to reside and settle in any part of
Pakistan. (For a detailed discussion, please
see the author's book "Judicial Review of
Public Actions", Vol-1, page-678......).
While the right to remain in Pakistan seems to be
absolute right which means that no citizen of Pakistan can be
compelled, by way of punishment or otherwise, to be sent out of
Pakistan, yet it has been held in Nasrullah Khan Henjra v
Government of Pakistan (PLD 1994 SC 23) that this right "was
never intended to afford protection against extradition to citizens
who are accused of serious crimes in other countries".
The right to reside anywhere in Pakistan, irrespective of
a citizen's property or financial status (Edward v California - 314
US 160) the right of a citizen to enter into, or return to, Pakistan
(Muhammad Shahbaz Sharif v Federation PLD 2004 SC 583)
and the right to travel abroad (Wajid Shamsul Hasan v Federation -
PLD 1997 Lah. 617; Muhammad Shahbaz Sharif case) are all
subject to reasonable restrictions imposed by law, in the public
interest.
Indeed, the question of the reasonableness of the
restrictions, whether imposed by primary or subordinate
legislation, is for the courts. (Abul Ala Moudoodi V Govt. of West
Pakistan PLD 1964 SC 673). An unfettered absolute discretion to
impose restrictions is not a reasonable restriction. (Montgomery
Flour and General Mills v Director Food - PLD 1957 (WP) Lah.
914) and one test to determine reasonableness can be the doctrine
of proportionately whether the restriction is so disproportionate
that it amounts to using a sledgehammer to crack a nut - as
developed under the European Convention for the Human Rights.
215

Freedom of Speech, Freedom of Assembly and Freedom of
Association:
The Constitution of Pakistan confers-
1)
freedom of speech, by its Article 19:
"Every citizen shall have the right to freedom
of speech and expression and there shall be
freedom of the press, subject to any
reasonable restrictions...
2)
freedom of assembly, by its Article 16:
3)
"Every citizen shall have the right to assemble
peacefully and without arms, subject to any
reasonable restriction....
freedom of association, by its Article 17:
"(1) Every citizen shall have the right to form
associations or unions, subject to any
reasonable restriction......
(2) Every citizen, not being in the service of
Pakistan, shall have the right to form or be a
member of a political party........
The right granted by these Articles, it will be noted, are
for the citizens of Pakistan only; secondly they are not absolute
rights. (For a further treatment of these freedoms, please see the
author's book "Judicial Review of Public Actions").
The US Constitution, by its First Amendment, forbids
the Congress to make any law-
216
"abridging the freedom of speech, or of
the press, or the right of the people
peaceably to assemble and to petition the
Government for a redress of grievances".
Freedom of association is not expressly mentioned; yet, it has been
held, in NAACP V Alabama (357 US 449; 2 L Ed 2d 1488), to be
part of the freedom of expression protected by the First
Amendment,
Decided cases in America indicate that it is not
significant whether one is engaged in speech, association, assembly
or petition. All four are now considered to be elements of a broad
right to freedom of expression.
The American Sixth Amendment guarantees that "In all
criminal prosecutions, the accused shall enjoy the right to a speedy
and public trial
The relevance of these freedoms to the criminal justice
process is that they are directly related to the basic function of that
process, namely, the prevention of crime and maintenance of law
and order. For example, "Unlawful Assemblies and Maintenance of
Public Peace and Security" are specifically dealt with in the Code
of Criminal Procedure, 1898, Chapter IX, Sections 127 to 132 and
these provisions and actions taken under them can be challenged on
the ground that the restrictions imposed are not reasonable
restrictions imposed by law in the interest of public order etc.
within the meaning of Articles 16, 17 and 19 of the Constitution of
Pakistan.
Fair Trial and Freedom of Electronic Media:
Article 19 of the Constitution of Pakistan and the US
First Amendment protect the freedom of "press", but that
expression includes other media of mass communication e.g. radio,
television (AG v Guardian (1997) 3 All ER 316, 375). In other
words, liberty of the press is not confined to newspapers and
217
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 127
periodicals. As was observed in Chandla v Florida (449 US 560; 66
L Ed 2d 740) still photographic, radio and television coverage are
all covered by the guarantee.
Free speech and fair trial "are two of the most cherished
policies of our civilization, and it would be a trying task to choose
between them". (Justice Black in Bridges v California - 314 US
252 (1941). There are instances when potential conflicts arise
between the media's right to report and the accused's right to fair
trial. When the case is a sensational one, the accused's right to
impartial trial may be severely threatened and that may require the
making of a gag order', barring the publication of certain
information about the accused.
The right of the public and the press to attend criminal
trials is implicit in the guarantee of the First Amendment - the
guarantees of freedom of speech, of the freedom of the press and to
peaceably assemble. (Richmond Newspapers v Virginia-448 US
555 (1980)). In Richmond, in the leading opinion, Chief Justice
Burger observed that "the Bill of Rights was enacted against the
backdrop of the long history of trials being presumptively open"
and that "the First Amendment can be read as protecting the right
of everyone to attend trials.......... so as to give meaning" to the
explicit guarantees of freedom of speech and press. Justice Brennan
emphasized in that case that public access to trials is essential-
"to achieve the objective of maintaining
public confidence in the administration
of justice".
The judicial system, "and in particular our criminal justice courts,
play a vital part in a democratic state, and the public has a
legitimate interest in their operations". (Justice Kennedy in Gentile
v State Bar-501 US 1030; 115 L Ed 2d 888 (1991)). As was said
in Landmark Communications (435 US 829 (1978))-
"It would be difficult to single out any
aspect of government of higher concern
218
and importance to the people than the
manner in which criminal trials are
conducted......".
In Nixon v Warner Communications (435 US 589
(1978)) cited in Chandler V Florida (449 US 560; 66 L Ed 2d 740
(1981), it was held:
"In the first place, there is no
constitutional right to have live witness
testimony recorded and broadcast.
Second, while the guarantee of a public
trial, in the words of Justice Black is 'a
safeguard against any attempt to employ
our courts as instruments of persecution.
it confers no special benefit on the press.
Nor does the Sixth Amendment require
that the trial or any part of it - be
broadcast alive or on tape to the public.
The requirement of a public trial is
satisfied by the opportunity of members
of the public and the press to attend the
trial and to report what they have
observed".
As to whether "televised trials" are inherently a denial of due
process, Chief Justice Burger, in delivering the opinion of the
Court in Chandler, referred to Justice Harlan's opinion in Estes v
Texas (381 US 532 (1965)) who began by observing that the
question of the constitutional permissibility of televised trials was
one fraught with unusual difficulty:
has
"Permitting television in the courtroom
undeniably
mischievous
potentialities for intruding upon the
detached atmosphere which should
always surround the
judicial
process. My conclusion is that
219
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 128
there is no constitutional requirement
that television be allowed in the
courtroom, and, at least as to a notorious
criminal trial such this one, the
considerations against
allowing
television in the courtroom so outweigh
the countervailing factors advanced in its
support as to require a holding that what
was done in the case infringed the
fundamental right to a fair trial assured
by the due process clause of the
Fourteenth Amendment.
In the context of a trial of intense public
interest, there is certainly a strong
possibility that the timid or reluctant
witness, for whom a court appearance
even at its traditional best is a harrowing
affair, will become more timid or
reluctant when he finds he will also be
appearing before a hidden audience of
unknown but large dimensions. There is
certainly a possibility that the cocky"
witness having a thirst for the limelight
will become more cocky' under the
influence of television. And who can say
that the juror who is gratified by having
been chosen for a front-line case, an
ambitious prosecutor, a publicity minded
defence attorney, and even 2
conscientious judge will not stray, albeit
unconsciously, from doing what 'comes
naturally into pluming themselves for a
satisfactory television performance".
Despite these grave potentialities' for distorting the
integrity of the judicial process, it was held in Chandler that the
220
Constitution did not prohibit a State from "experimenting" with
televised trial, and that, as Justice Stewart put it, "televising
criminal trial is not inherently prejudicial even when carried out
ander properly controlled conditions.........
A defendant may however show that the media's
coverage of his case - printed or broadcast - compromised the
ability of the Judge or the Jury to judge him fairly or "that the
broadcast coverage of his case had an adverse impact on the trial
participants to constitute a denial of due process" (Chandler).
Thus, in Irvin v Dowd (366 US 717), a unanimous
Supreme Court for the first time struck down a conviction because
of the effect of pretrial publicity, and because "the build-up of
prejudice is clear and convincing"; Rideauv v Louisiana (373 US
723) is another case in which a conviction was overturned because
of adverse media publicity and prejudice.
In Ali Nawaz v Muhammad Yousaf (PLD 1963 SC
81,82) a case under sections 497 and 498 PPC, grievance was made
of the fact that "undue publicity" given to the proceedings of the
case in the press had resulted in "contributing to an atmosphere
charged with dramatic effect" causing "considerable
embarrassment to the accused, the lady and to other witnesses in
the case". The Supreme Court held that "the circumstances that a
high officer of Government, who also held military rank. was cited
as an accused person, by a private complainant, and this at a time
when the country lay under martial law, were compelling
considerations that favoured an open trial so that justice should not
only be done, but should manifestly be seen to be done".
Freedom of Expression and Terrorism:
In any civilized and law-abiding society, the defeat of
terrorism is a public interest of the first importance, and therefore
some restriction on the freedom of the terrorist and his supporters
to propagate his cause, e.g. prohibiting the broadcasting of direct
statements of representatives of proscribed terrorist organizations
21
221
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 129
may well be justified in the public interest. (Brind (1991) | All ER
720) and in the interest of integrity, security or defence of the
country.
Freedom of Expression and Contempt of Court:
The right to freedom of speech and expression and the
right to freedom of the press are subject, among others, to any
reasonable restriction imposed by law in relation to contempt of
court.
There is, then. Article 204 of the Constitution, which
codifies the law of the contempt of the superior courts the
Supreme Court and the High Courts.
The position of 'contempt of court is thus unique; not
only does the Constitution, by its Article 19, permit the making of
a law imposing reasonable restrictions in relation to contempt of
court, so that the rights of speech and expression will be subject to
that law, but also it empowers the superior courts by Article 204 to
punish those guilty of their contempt, on the grounds mentioned
therein, one of the grounds being that the accused "does anything
which tends to prejudice the determination of a matter pending
before the court". Thus "Article 19 of the Constitution is in a way
subject to Article 204......It (Article 204) contains, if we may say
so, constitutional safeguards against any attempt to scandalize the
court or undermine its dignity in public interest. (State v Sh.
Shaukat Ali, PLD 1976 Lah. 355, 364).
Thus, when an application is made to commit for
contempt of court a journalist or editor for the publication of
information relating to the proceedings of a court, freedom of
speech and the public nature of justice are at once put at risk. (Lood
Scarman in AG v Leveller Magazine (1979) 1 All ER 745,757).
by-
Contempt of Court may be committed, among others,
i)
ii)
iii)
invading the court as a protest (Morris v
Crown Office (1970) 2 QB 114);
suboming the witnesses (AG v Butterworth-

case
case
scandalizing the courts and judges (S.M.Haq
case PLD 1953 FC 247; Sir Edward Snelson
PLD 1961 SC 237; Mansoor Ahsan

The task is to strike the best balance between the
constitutionally guaranteed right of freedom of speech and
expression on the one hand and the constitutional power to punish
contempt of court. In this connection what Lord Denning said in R
v Metropolitan Police Commissioner (1968) 2 All ER 319), which
case, in the words of Dorab Patel, J. in Yousaf Ali Khan case (PLD
1977 SC 482, 490) "is a milestone in the development of law of
contempt", deserves to be quoted:
"This is the first case, so far as I know, when this Court
has been called on to consider an allegation of contempt
against itself. It is a jurisdiction which undoubtedly
belongs to us, but which we will most sparingly
exercise. Let me say at once that we will never use
this jurisdiction as a means to uphold our own dignity.
That must rest on surer foundations we do not
fear criticism, nor do we resent it. For there is something
more important at stake. It is no less than freedom of
speech itself. All we would ask is that those who
criticize us will remember that, from the nature of our
office, we cannot reply to their criticism. We cannot
enter into public controversy. Still less into political
controversy.......

In sum, the task is to harmonize the two important constitutional
provisions Article 19, which guarantees the right to freedom of
expression, including the right to freedom of speech and press and
which at the same time makes those rights subject to reasonable
restrictions imposed by law in relation to contempt of court and
Article 204, which expressly preserves the superior court's power
to punish their contempt. In harmonizing these provisions, both
must be preserved inviolate, and a fair balance struck between
them.
Articles 23 and 24: Protection of Property.
By Article 23, every citizen has the right to acquire, hold
and dispose of property in any part of Pakistan, subject to the
Constitution and any reasonable restrictions imposed by law in the
public interest and Article 24, so far as relevant, provides that "No
person shall be compulsorily deprived of his property save in
accordance with law".
Thus, the right under Article 23 is for the citizens only.
hut the right under Article 24 is available to all persons - citizens
and non-citizens alike.
Just as no person "shall be deprived of life or liberty
save in accordance with law" (Article 9 of the Constitution), so
also "No person shall he compulsorily deprived of his property
in accordance with law". (Article 24 of the Constitution).
Save
Thus, what the Fifth Amendment to the US Constitution
accomplishes by providing: "No person shall be........ deprived of
life, liberty or property without due process of law", is
accomplished by Articles 9 and 24 of the Constitution of Pakistan,
read together.
The expression "save in accordance with law" is
common to both Articles 9 and 24, and for its discussion and
whether it means the same thing as "due process of law" in the US
Constitution, the reader is referred to the comments under Article
It suffices to say that just as the punishments of death
and imprisonment involve the loss of life and liberty within the
meaning of Article 9, so does the punishment of fine and forfeiture
involve the deprivation of property within the meaning of Article
24.
This establishes the relevance of criminal procedure to
Articles 23 and 24. The punishments of fine and forfeiture both
involve deprivation of property. They are provided by the criminal
law (e.g. the Pakistan Penal Code) and the power to impose them is
provided by the criminal procedure law (e.g. the Code of Criminal
Procedure). In other words, these are the laws which provide the
authority for the courts to deprive an accused person of his
property, by imposing fine and ordering forfeiture. And if they are
valid laws, the deprivation of property under them will be "in
accordance with law".
Article 25: Equality before law
Article 25 of the Constitution of Pakistan reads:
"(1)
All citizens are equal before law and are
entitled to equal protection of law.

of these
This Article gives effect to the most powerful idea of
equality before the law and equal protection of the law. This and
Articles 2A, 4 and 18 "are designed, intended and directed to bring
about an egalitarian society based on Islamic concept of social
justice". (Mushtaq Ahmad Mohal case-1997 SCMR 1043).
The corresponding provision in the US Constitution is
Amendment XIV, which as was said by the Supreme Court of
America (163 US 537; 41 L. Ed 256), is "majestic in its sweep":
Nor shall any state....... deny
to any person within its jurisdiction the
equal protection of the laws".
It has been acknowledged in Jibendra Kishore case
(PLD 1957 SC (Pak) 9, 39) and Brig. F.B. Ali case (PLD 1975 SC
506, 528) that the expression "equal protection of law" as used in
our constitution has been borrowed and derived from the
Fourteenth Amendment to the US Constitution. This affords
justification, as the decided cases demonstrate, for a liberal use of
decided cases from the American jurisdiction.
The right conferred by Article 25 is the right not to be
discriminated against; it is "one of the most significant
requirements of the protection provided by the rule of law". (Lord
Woolf in A v Secretary of State (2003). All ER 816, 827); it means,
what Thomas Fuller said some 300 years ago; "Be you never so
226
high, the law is above you". (Quoted by Lord Denning in Gouriet v
Union of Post Office Workers ((1977) I ALL ER 696, 718) and as
was tersely put by the Privy Council in Matadeen v Pointer (1998)
3 WLR 18, 26). "treating like cases alike and unlike cases
differently is a general axiom of rational behaviour".
The doctrine of classification has been judicially
accepted as an integral part of the equal protection clause. As
explained in I.A.Sharwani case (1991 SCMR 1041), the clause
does not envisage that every citizen is to be treated alike in all
circumstances; it contemplates that persons similarly situated or
similarly placed are to be treated alike and that reasonable
classification is permissible but it must be founded on reasonable
distinction or reasonable basis. In order for a classification to be
reasonable, it should be based-
(a)
(b)
Procedural aspects:
on
an intelligible differentia which
distinguishes persons or things that are
grouped together from those who have been
left out;
the differentia must have natural nexus to the
object sought to be achieved by such
classification.
The equal protection clause does not demand uniformity
of procedure and this has been consistently held by the American
courts; as was said in Brig. F.B. Ali case:
"The legislature may well classify
litigation and adopt one type of
procedure for one class and a different
type for another. The American Supreme
Court has even held that a State may
make different arrangements for trials
227
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 132
under different circumstances of even
the same class of offences......".
In F.B. Ali case, the appellants were retired army
officers. By an amendment in the Pakistan Army Act, 1952, they
were brought within the ambit of the Act. The argument was that
this deprived them of the nonmal safeguards of a criminal trial, and
this was clearly arbitrary and unreasonable. The argument was
dismissed:
in the field of criminal justice,
a classification may well be made on the
basis of the heinousness of the crime
committed or the necessity of preventing
certain anti-social effects of a particular
crime. Changes in procedure may
equally well be effected on the ground of
the security of the State, maintenance of
public order, removal of corruption from
amongst public servants or for the
meeting of an emergency.......
Thus, provided the classification is reasonable within the
meaning of the equal protection clause, nobody has a vested right
in any particular procedure. Nobody can therefore claim that be, for
example, must be tried under the Code of Criminal Procedure, and
not under a special law, providing a special procedure for the
offences for which he is being tried. This principle finds expression
also in section 1, sub-section (2) of the Code of Criminal Procedure
itself:
"It extends to the whole of Pakistan but,
in the absence of any specific provision
to the contrary, nothing herein contained
shall affect any special or local law now
in force, or any special jurisdiction or
power conferred, or any special form of
procedure prescribed by any other law
for the time being in force".
The above observations, it needs to be pointed out, do
not apply where the question is of inconsistency between the
procedure provided by the Constitution and the one provided by an
ordinary law. Indeed in such a case, the constitutional procedure
will prevail, for the constitutional rights of procedural nature are
vested rights which cannot be taken away or abridged by an
ordinary law,
Relevance of Equality in Criminal Cases:
The contest in a criminal case is between the State, all
powerful and all resourceful, and an individual, who may not even
be in a position to hire a counsel of his own. Self-evidently, the
contest is unequal. This is the reason that in all civilized democratic
societies, great emphasis is now laid on "procedural and
substantive safeguards designed to assure fair trials before
impartial tribunals in which every defendant stands equal before
the law. This noble ideal cannot be realized if the poor man
charged with crime has to face his accusers without a lawyer to
assist him". (Justice Black in Gideon v Wainwright 372 US 335;
9L Ed 2d 799). There can be no equal justice, said Justice Black in
Griffin (351 US 12), "when the kind of trial a man gets depends on
the amount of money he has ..........".
We have seen that the courts in America have held that
indigent defendants must be granted equal access to all aspects of
the criminal process which are basic to the fair determination of
their guilt or innocence (Smith v Bennett-365 US 708; 6 L Ed 2d
39) and the US Supreme Court has consistently held that the
govemment is not permitted to restrict the ability to engage in
fundamental constitutional rights on the basis of individual wealth.
This is called "wealth classification" and is treated to be suspect.
The procedural and substantive safeguards to ensure
faimess and equal justice referred to above are now part of almost
228
229
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 133
all the written constitutions of civilized and democratic countries of
the world. We have seen that the equality clauses in the Indian and
Pakistani Constitutions have been borrowed from the American
Constitution and therefore the constitutional law as developed in
America requiring that indigent defendants are entitled to the
assistance of counsel at all stages of the criminal justice process is
equally applicable to Pakistan.
The European courts have developed the "equality of
arms" principle of fairness under the European Convention which
has roots in both common law and civil law traditions. It is a
principle which affords every party to the proceedings a reasonable
opportunity to present his case in conditions that do not place him
at substantial disadvantage vis--vis his opponent.
If we may venture to quote from a non-legal source,
great philosopher Immanuel Kant, in presenting the principle of
just retribution poses the question: what kind and what degree of
punishment does public justice adopt as its principle and standard?
and answers: "None other than the principle of equality that
is, the principle of not treating one side more favourably than the
other.......
As all are equal before the law, the court will not
countenance the contention that since a particular accused is an
important personality, the court should or should not interfere.
Such an argument was raised in Brig. Imtiaz Ahmad case (1994
SCMR 2142), in which the petitioner had retired from the army as
Brigadier and was then employed on contract as Director,
Intelligence Bureau. The Supreme Court recalled, for the benefit of
all concerned, the following observations of Wilmot CJ. in Wilkes
v Wood (1769) 19 St. Tr. 1406):
"The law makes no distinction between great and
petty officers; thank God, they are all amenable to
justice".
230
Chapter 4
REMEDIES FOR THE ENFORCEMENT OF
FUNDAMENTAL RIGHTS
Constitutional Remedies:
The Constitution of Pakistan is not content merely with
identifying and guaranteeing certain Fundamental Rights only. It
also provides, by its Articles 199 and 184(3), the remedies for the
enforcement of the Fundamental Rights so conferred. In doing so,
the Constitution gives effect to the well-known maxim - Ubi Jus
Ibi Remedium (there is no wrong without a remedy); for. "it is a
vain thing to imagine a right without a remedy, for want of right
and want of remedy are reciprocal". (per Holt CJ. in Ashby v
White 2 Raym. Ld. 938, 953 quoted in "Legal Maxims" by
Herbert Broom, 10" P118).
The Fundamental Rights, with one notable exception.
are all directed against the State and State functionaries. The
exception is the right to liberty, which can be, by Article 199,
Clause (1), sub-clause (b), enforced against the State and its
functionaries as also against private persons.
Article 7 of the Constitution defines the term "State".
and Article 8 establishes the supremacy and predominance of the
Fundamental Rights conferred by Chapter 1 of Part II of the
Constitution, by declaring by its clause (1), that any law or custom
or usage having the force of law "in so far as it is inconsistent with
the rights conferred by this Chapter shall to the extent of such
inconsistency, he void". At the same time, it forbids by its clause
(2), the making of any law "which takes away or abridges the
rights so conferred", and declares that "any law made in
contravention of this clause shall, to the extent of such
contravention, be void". Thus, existing (that is existing at the date
of the coming into force of the Constitution - Article 268, clause
(7) as well as future laws must conform to the Fundamental
Rights granted by Chapter 1 of Part II of the Constitution. (For a
231
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 134
somewhat elaborate discussion of this subject, the meaning of
"void" and other related topics, the reader may refer to the author's
book "Judicial Review of Public Actions", Vol-1, Chapter 5, pages
567 onwards).
Article 199, by its clause (1), sub-clause (c), of the
Constitution makes express provisions for the enforcement of the
Fundamental Rights; it empowers each High Court, if it is satisfied
that no other adequate remedy is provided by law, to-
"(e) on the application of any aggrieved
person, make an order giving such
directions to any person or authority.
including any Government, exercising
any power or performing any function
in, or in relation, to any territory within
the jurisdiction of that court as may be
appropriate for the enforcement of any
of the Fundamental Rights conferred by
Chapter 1 of Part II".
In view of the importance of the Fundamental Rights,
and in the interest of their speedy and effective enforcement, the
Supreme Court also, by Article 189, clause (3). has been conferred
original, albeit somewhat limited jurisdiction, to enforce those
rights, Article 184, clause (3) of the Constitution reads:
"(3) Without prejudice to the provisions
of Article 199, the Supreme Court shall,
if it considers that a question of public
importance with reference to the
enforcement of any of the Fundamental
Rights conferred by Chapter 1 of Part II
is involved, have the power to make an
order of the nature mentioned in the said
Article".
Enforcement of Fundamental Rights:
Both Article 199, clause (1)(c), and Article 184, clause
(3), use the word 'enforcement'. The significance of that word is
this: when the Supreme Court or a High Court decides that a law or
an action is inconsistent with or is in contravention of a
Fundamental Right, what it is doing is that it is enforcing the
Fundamental Right. The Court also enforces a Fundamental Right,
if it declares a law or an action in contravention of that Right void
on the ground that the restriction imposed is unreasonable. In short,
declaring a law or an action to be void as being inconsistent with or
in violation of a Fundamental Right is enforcing that right. Also
the making of any order of the nature mentioned in Article 199 and
the giving of any appropriate direction to any Government or any
public authority is a way of enforcing that Right.
In the field of Constitutional law of evidence, what is
known as Exclusionary Rule the rule that requires evidence
obtained in contravention of Constitution is inadmissible -
provides the means to enforce the Fundamental Right in question.
Awarding damages:
Awarding money compensation for the contravention or
violation of a Fundamental Right is another means of enforcing it.
The leading authority on the point is the Privy Council case of
Maharaj v AG of Trinidad and Tobago (1978) I All ER 670); that
case is remarkable for two reasons: first, it provides a private law
remedy in public law and secondly, it arose out of an order of a
Judge of the High Court, that is, what the Judge had done in the
exercise of the Judicial Power of the State. In the view of the Privy
Council, awarding money compensation in such cases involves no
change in the rule that a Judge cannot be made personally liable for
what he has done when acting or purporting to act in judicial
capacity. The claim in such cases is against the State for what has
been done by the Judge in the exercise of the Judicial Power of the
State. This is not vicarious liability; it is a liability, in the public
232
233
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 135
law, of the State, not of the Judge himself, "which has been newly
created by the Constitution".
Such compensation, it was held in Maharaj, would
include any loss of earnings consequent on the imprisonment and
recompense for the inconvenience and distress suffered by the
person during his incarceration.
On the same analogy, compensation can be awarded
against the State where due to the contravention or violation of a
Fundamental Right committed by an executive authority, c.g.
Police, in the exercise of the Executive Power of the State, the
petitioner has suffered mentally, physically or financially.
This is also the law in England (R v Governor of
Brockhil Prison ((2000) 4 All ER 15), in America (Bivens - 403
US 388; 29 L Ed 2d 619), in India (Nilabati v State - AIR 1993 SC
1960 etc) and also in Pakistan (Mazharuddin v State - 1998 P Crl J
1035).
In Mazharuddin v State (1998 PCY LJ 1035), the
liability to pay such compensation was held to devalve jointly and
severally upon the State and the public officer concemed in the
violation of the Fundamental Right
Modes of Challenging Violation of Fundamental Rights:
Violation of a Fundamental Right may be challenged
I.
before the trial court;
2.
in direct proceedings such as appeal or
revision, if any, provided by law;
3.
in collateral proceedings e.g. by way of
judicial review under Articles 199 and 184(3)
of the Constitution.
As regards (1) and (2), that is, challenge before the trial,
appellate or revisional court or tribunal, the objections can be that
234
the law under which the accused is being held or tried is
constitutionally invalid, or that the court or the tribunal has not
been validly constituted or that there has been a violation of a
Fundamental Right. All these objections go to the vires of the
proceedings and as the trial courts or tribunals in our country are.
generally speaking, conceived of as courts of law as well as of fact,
they are competent to decide these objections. As was said in Sahir
Shah v Shad Muhammad Khan (PLD 1995 SC 66, 244), this view
can be safely based upon a rule of statutory construction vouched
by respectable authority (among others, Chief Adjudicating Officer
y Foster (1993) 1 All ER 705) namely, that included in the
questions of law that a tribunal or authority is empowered to decide
is the objection based on vires. An invalid law is incapable of
conferring jurisdiction and of creating rights and liabilities, civil or
criminal, and a tribunal which is not constituted or appointed
validly under a valid law is no tribunal at all. To be told to
approach another court (e.g. the High Court under Article 199) to
raise such an objection obviously involves "cumbrous duplicity of
proceedings" and considerable expense and in any case may
amount to reducing the right to be dealt with in accordance with
law, guaranteed by Articles 4 and 9 of the Constitution, to a mere
nothing. For, as has been observed in "Judicial Review of Public
Actions" (at page 432):
"Judicial review jurisdiction is a
discretionary jurisdiction and to require
a person to invoke that jurisdiction is to
throw him to a discretionary remedy.
and to deprive him of his constitutional
right to be dealt with in accordance with
law".
In the words of Lord Fraser in Winder (1984) 3 All ER 976, 981)-
"He puts forward his defence as a matter
of right, whereas in an application for
judicial review success would require an
235
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 136
exercise of the court's discretion in his
favour":
and discretionary remedies, so said Kaikaus I in Abul Ala
Maudoodi case (PLD 1964 SC 673, 761),
"are no substitute for remedies to which
a person has a right even though the
discretion be a judicial one".
So the courts have sufficiently moved away from the
doctrine that vires questions are exclusively for the courts
exercising judicial review jurisdiction. (The subject has been more
fully discussed in the author's book "Judicial Review of Public
Actions" at page 426 onwards).
Coming to the collateral challenge, by way of judicial
review, under Articles 199(1)(c) and 184(3), the power to grant
reliefs under Article 199(1)(c) is expressed in the widest possible

PART III
PARTICIPANTS IN THE CRIMINAL JUSTICE PROCESS
There are four groups of persons primarily responsible
for the administration of the criminal justice process. They are:
the police and justices of the peace;
the prosecutors;
iii)
the defence counsel;
iv)
the judges and magistrates:
Here is a brief introduction of these groups and of some significant
aspects of the institutional settings within which they perform their
respective roles.
General Observations
Chapter 1
POLICE
An influential group of thinkers has argued that just as a
society must maintain armed forces to defend itself against foreign
aggression, so it must maintain a force of internal peace keeping to
defend itself against aggression from within. That force is Police.
In safeguarding our freedoms, so writes Lord Denning in his book
"The Due Process of Law", (at p 102,-
"the police play a vital role. Society for
its defence needs a well-led, well-trained
and well-disciplined force of police
whom it can trust: and enough of them to
be able to prevent crime before it
happens, or if it does happen, to detect it
and bring the accused to justice".
In searching for principles of policing, Michael S. Pike,
the author of that small but very useful book "The Principles of
238
Policing"-a post-Scarman Commentary on Policing (the reference
is to Lord Scarman's report on the Brixton Disorder, Comnd 8427
HMSO) observes: The police are the public and the public are the
police aptly describes the collective responsibility for law and
order which existed in Anglo-Saxon times. A crime was regarded
as an act contra pacem Domini (against the peace of the Lord King)
and was not merely a crime against the victim but also a crime
against the whole community. The responsibility for 'keeping the
peace was placed firmly on the male population and this prompted
a mutual participation of all the citizens.
Hence the principle of policing by consent' which
Lord Scarman emphasized in his Report:
"If the Police are to secure the assent of
the public for their actions they must
strike an acceptable balance between the
three elements of their functions".
The three elements referred to by Lord Scarman are those
identified by Sir Richard Mayne when drawing up the instructions
for the New Police of the Metropolis in 1829 namely the
prevention of crime, the protection of life and property and the
preservation of public tranquility. Lord Scarman emphasizes that
the primary duty of the police is to maintain the 'Queen's peace'
and that a police officer's first duty is to cooperate with others in
maintaining the normal state of society'. He considers that the
police officer's second duty is to enforce the law but if law
enforcement puts at risk public tranquility he will have to make a
difficult decision:
"Inevitably there will be situations in
which the public interest requires him to
test the wisdom of law enforcement by
its likely effect upon public order. Law
enforcement, involving as it must, the
possibility that force may have to be
used, can cause acute friction and
239
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 138
division in a community - particularly if
the community is tense and the cause of
the law-breaker not without support.
'Fiat Justitia; ruat caelum' (let justice be
done, though heavens collapse) may be
apt for a judge but it can lead a
policeman into tactics disruptive of the
very fabric of society".
Lord Scarman refers, in his Report, to "two well known
principles of policing a free society', as "consent and balance" and
"independence and accountability". Crucial to the principle of
policing by consent are police ethics, police discretion and
sensitive policing. The independence of the police from political or
other control, as has been observed in "The Principles of Policing
(at page-23), "Though not totally accepted, is well established but
this independence does not give the police the right to act
irresponsibly. They are accountable in many ways and....... one of
the most important regulating factor is that the police must secure
public approval for their actions". In other words, independence
does not mean irresponsibility.
Most importantly, the police are accountable to law.
Execution and administration of laws belong to the Executive
Organ of the State, to the Govemment, and it is an established
constitutional principle, in Great Britain (see Easter Trust Co case
- (1915) AC 750, 759; M. v Home Office (1993) 3 All ER 537,
541); in America (see US V Nixon 418 US 683, 41 L Ed 2d
1039) as well as in Pakistan (See Syed Sharif-ud-din Pirzada v
Federation PLD 1973 Kar. 132, 147; Mian Nawaz Sharif case
PLD 1993 SC 473, per Nasim Hassan Shah J and Muhammad
Bashir v SHO (PLD 2007 SC 539, 547) that the Executive has no
power except such as has been given to it by the constitution and
law. The police are an instrumentality of the Government, the
Executive organ of the State, and must work within the framework
of the law the Constitution and statutory law as interpreted by
the courts. For what they do, that is, are empowered to do, affects
the life. liberty and property of the citizens and by Articles 9 and
240
24 of the Constitution, no person "shall be deprived" of them "save
in accordance with law". In R v Met. Police Commissioner (1968)
2 WLR 893, what Lord Denning said of the duties of the Chief
Constable is worth repeating:
"I know it to be the duty
of
every Chief Constable to enforce the law
of the land........... he is not the servant
of any save of the law itself. The
responsibility of law enforcement lies on
him. He is answerable to the law and to
the law alone".
A police service, it has been said, is a reflection of the
society it serves. Thus the British Police and their capacity for
controlling incidents of disorder without resorting to extreme
measures of control "have been the envy of the world and they
have been regarded as a model on which policing in a democracy
can be based". (The Principles of Policing, p.ix). So much so, that
the British police did not, till recently, carry weapons beyond a
simple billy club'. Among some of the significant reasons for the
British reluctance to arm their police, one was the fact that the
British citizens are themselves unarined. The "right to bear arms"
is foreign to English law. Though it is upon the British model that
much of the early American policing was based (see Frank
Schmalleger's "Criminal Justice Today" 4" ed pp 160, 630), yet in
a tradition dating back to the days of the "wild west", American
law enforcement officers routinely carry guns and are, especially
on the federal level, routinely well armed.
There is a very low rate of crime in Japan and the one
thing which, more than any other, may account for it is "a sense of
personal honour and responsibility that makes up the Japanese
national character, Symptomatic of the interpersonal trust which
underlies social relationship in Japan is a police-run program that
allows anyone to go to a police station or police call box and
borrow money (usually $ 10-20) at any time on the honour
system. ...it surprises Americans (and Pakistanis also) to

learn that almost all the borrowed money is quickly returned
Position under the Constitution and Police Order
"Police" and "Law and Order" as legislative matters, do
not figure in the 'Federal List' or the 'Concurrent List' in the 4
Schedule to the Constitution of Pakistan. Under the Constitution.
therefore, these are matters in respect of which the Provincial
Legislatures have exclusive power to make laws, and to establish a
police force for that purpose. Indeed, there are matters on which
the Parliament has either the exclusive or the concurrent legislative
power to legislate. For example:-
a.
b.
Federal Intelligence Bureau; detention for
reasons of State (item 1 of the Federal
Legislative List, Part 1);
Offences against laws in respect of the matters
in Part 1 and Part II of the Federal Legislative
List (item 56 of Part I and item 6 of Part II of
that List).
It should be noted that the power to create offences includes the
power to have them investigated, and this brings in a law
enforcement agency, such as police.
C.
Preventive detention for reasons connected
with maintenance of public order etc, persons
subjected to such detention (items 14 and 15
of the Concurrent List).
At present, we have the Police Order 2002, which
provides the institutional setting in which the police operates in the
Provinces and the Islamabad Capital Territory. This Order repealed
the Police Act, 1861, which was a relic of the colonial period
consisting of strategies tailored to the needs of the colonial power.
The Police Order was an extra constitutional measure; a gift of the
military rule imposed in 1999. It has borrowed concepts and
practices from other countries, e.g. US, UK, and imposed them
upon Pakistan. It applies to the whole of Pakistan and the
legislative power to repeal, amend or alter it was subject to the
condition of previous sanction of the President accorded after
consultation with the Prime Minister. (Article 268(2) and items 35
of the Sixth Schedule to the Constitution). By the proviso to clause
(5) of Article 268, "the laws mentioned at entry 35 in the
Sixth Schedule shall stand omitted after six years". This proviso
was enacted by the Constitution (17 Amdt) Act of 2003, and the
position now is that counting the period of six years from the date
of the coming into force of the 17th Amendment the condition of
previous sanction of the President ceased to apply somewhere in
2009, and the Police Order has required the status of a pure
provincial law, so far as the provincial territories are concerned.
In the Code of Criminal Procedure, two expressions
occur frequently namely 'officer in charge of a police station' and
'police officer. The former is defined in section 4(p) of the Code
of Criminal Procedure to include, when the officer in charge of the
police station is absent, the police officer present at the police
station who is next in rank to the officer in charge and is above the
rank of constable. Section 551 Cr.P.C. provides that a police officer
superior in rank to an officer in charge of a police station may
exercise the same powers as may be exercised by the officer in
charge of a police station.
In the Police Order, Article 2(1), clause (xviii), "police
officer" means a member of the police who is subject to the Police
Order. The expression "police station" means any post or place
declared to be a police station by the Provincial Government.
The objects of the Police Order, as stated in its
preamble, are:-
242
243
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 140
ii,
iii.
to ensure that the police performs its functions
according to the Constitution, law and
democratic aspirations of the people;
to ensure that in the performance of its

and accountable to the people;
to re-define the police role, its duties and
responsibilities; and
iv.
to
reconstruct the police for efficient
prevention and detection of crime and
maintenance of law and order.
The principal job of the police is to deal with actual and
potential violations of the law. Actual violation means violation
which has already taken place and potential violation meats
prospective crimes. Although when we refer to the police we
generally mean the law enforcement officers yet enforcement of
the criminal law, that is, the investigation of crimes, and
apprehension of criminals with a view to bringing them to justice is
one of the several tasks allocated to the police. The professional
roles of the police also include the providing of basic social
services, the maintenance of order and the prevention of crime.
Thus, the police have multiple functions to perform.
Like the police laws in many other countries, one of the
objects of the Police Order is to humanize the police role. Thus, it
is, under Article 3 of the Police Order, the duty of every police
officer to behave with the public with due decorum and courtesy, to
promote amity, to guide and assist the poor, disabled, the
physically weak and the children and to help such individuals as
are in danger of physical harm. By clause (2) of Article 4 of the
Police Order the police are required to afford relief to these in
distress, such as victims of road accidents, their heirs and
dependants, and educate such victims etc to enable them to assert
and enforce their rights. These are the basic social services which it
244
is now the statutory and, therefore, the legal duty of the police to
provide.
Article 4, clause (1), of the Police Order enumerates the
duties of the police officers, which, among others, include the duty:
ii)
iB)
iv)
to ensure that the rights and privileges, under
the law, of a person taken in custody, are
protected;
to ensure that the information about the arrest
of a person is promptly communicated to a
person of his choice;
to prevent the commission of offences and
public nuisance;
to keep order at public places, and to prevent
harassment of women and children at such
places:
iii)
to detect crimes and bring offenders to justice;
iv)
to obey and promptly execute all lawful
orders.
Article 8 of the Police Order provides that the police
shall be organized on functional basis into branches, divisions etc.
which may include, among others, investigation branch, crime
against women branch, legal affairs branch.
Under Article 18 of the Police Order, the head of
Investigation in a general police area is an Additional Inspector
General, the head of investigation in a capital city district or city
district is a Senior Superintendent of Police and the head of
investigation in a district is a Superintendent of Police. The
Superintendent of Police investigation is responsible to his own
245

investigation hierarchy and subject to the general control of the
District Police Officer. All registered cases are to be investigated
by the investigation staff in the district under the supervision of the

of Article 18 expressly so provides, interfere with the process of
investigation", but shall provide full support to the head of
investigation in the performance of his duties. Investigation is
normally not to be changed from one police officer to another; it
can be changed only on the recommendation of a board of three

relationship between the district police and the district local
government. The head of the district police is responsible to the
Zila Nazim for police functions under the Police Order, but the
Nazim cannot interfere with any investigation or with the
prosecution of criminal cases. However, under Article 35 of the
Police Order, the Zila Nazim may direct the Head of District
Police, if he has reason to believe that any police official has
committed an act of neglect etc, to take action against such official,
This action may result in the registration of a criminal case and
arrest of the official.
The object sought to be achieved by a separate and
independent investigation branch scems to be to ensure
specialization and effectiveness of the investigation of crimes, and
the object can be achieved only if the investigation branch is not
involved in other unrelated activities.
Article 167 of the Police Order requires a register of
daily diary in prescribed form to be maintained at all police
stations; in that register are to be recorded the names of all
complainants, persons arrested, the offences charged against them,
the weapons or property taken into possession and the names of the
witnesses examined. The Sessions Judge may call for and inspect
such diary.
This provision is analogous to section 172 of the Code
of Criminal Procedures.
There are countries in which the key element of the
police structure is the fragmentation of the police authority among
a large number of separate units of government. For example, in
the United States at the federal level, the primary police agency is
the Federal Bureau of Investigation, at the State level, the key
general agency is the state police; but by far the most general
agencies are those found at the local government level. In those
countries, a centralized police force is viewed with deep suspicion,
for fear that it would be misused by politicians; decentralization of
police authority is considered a safeguard against such misuse and
subversion of democracy.
Under the Police Order, we have a highly centralized
general police force at all levels, with the Federal Government
playing the dominant role. For example, under Article 11 of the
Police Order, the Provincial Inspector General of Police is to be
appointed out of a panel of three police officers recommended by
the Federal Government.
The scheme of the Police Order seems to militate against
the principle of police autonomy which means, first, independence
of the police from the political forces in the community and from
the community in general; second, independence of the police
officer within the department. The scheme also seems to offend
against the doctrine of "constabulary independence" (Fisher-
(1930)2 KB 364) which regards the police constable as an
independent officer who cannot be instructed by a governmental
agency about how to exercise his powers. The constable is
accountable only to law.
Every member of the police on appointment is required
by Article 24 of the Police Order to take an oath that he shall inter
alia be faithful and bear true allegiance to Pakistan and to the
Constitution; that he shall honestly, impartially and truly serve the
people without fear, favour or affection, malice or ill-will; and
that he shall discharge his functions according to law and in such
manner as to protect the dignity and rights of the citizen. We may
presume that the vast majority of the men who take this oath do so
246
247
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 142
seriously and that they will and do perform their duties honestly.
Also, the police have wide discretionary powers, e.g. power to
arrest, search, seize; the power of stopping, questioning, frisking of
the so-called suspicious persons, of the use of informants and
undercover agents. These are great powers, and are liable to abuse.
As has been said. power corrupts and absolute power corrupts
absolutely. They are often abused and have rightly led the critics to
pose the rhetoric question: who will police the police? A
policeman, on the other hand, may, as does the author of the book
by a retired American police officer, titled "The Police" think, that
"Criminals are made public heroes, the
crooked politician is excused with well,
politics is a dirty game; the absconder
banker is punished by being made to
return the reminder of his loot; the
prostitute is explained away as being a
member of the oldest profession"
but there is no mercy for the policeman; he is a consistent target of
criticism and ridicule. The people are unforgiving, so far as the
policeman is concerned,
11 may be noted here that there are federal law
enforcement agencies such as the Federal Investigation Agency,
Pakistan Railway Police, Anti-Narcotic Force, Pakistan Motorway
and Highway Police, Islamabad Police, Frontier Constabulary.
They are statutory bodies and their functions are those described in
their respective statutes.
We shall have at appropriate places something to say as
to the relationship between the police and the prosecutor and that
between the police and the courts.
POLICE POWER IS DISCRETIONARY POWER
Powers of the police involve the exercise of wide
executive discretionary power; us was said by Lord Scarman in his
248
Report of Inquiry into Bixton Disorder (Comnd 1981 para 4:58).
the exercise of discretion lies at the heart of the policing function.
It is well recognized that successful policing depends on the
exercise of discretion in how the law is enforced. The good
reputation of the police depends upon the skill and judgment which
policemen display in the particular circumstances of the cases and
incidents which they are required to handle. Discretion is the art of
suiting action to particular circumstances. It is a policeman's daily
lask.
The lawfulness of the way in which the executive
discretion of the police is exercised in a particular case can be
questioned on the principles laid down in Wednesbury (1947) 2 All
ER 680) namely bad faith and irrationality, as the test of
reasonableness (Horgate Mohammad v Duke (1984) I All ER
1054, 1057),
ARMY AND THE POLICE FUNCTION OF LAW AND
ORDER
The Armed forces are a part of the executive organ of
the State and this is made plain by Articles 243, 244 and 245 of the
Constitution; they are, like the police, subject to the civilian
control. There is power in the Federal Government, under Article
245 of the Constitution, to call the armed forces "in aid of civil
power". As was held in Liaqat Hussain v Federation (PLD 1999
SC 504):
"It seems that the above expression (in
aid of civil power) presupposes that the
civil power is still there, it is neither
supplemented nor effaced. The civil
power is to be preserved and invigorated
through the employment of the armed
forces. The armed forces can be called in
aid under the above clause by the
Federal Government inter alia to
perform a police function for limited
249
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 143
purpose of suppressing riots

preventing threatened disorder or for
maintaining law and order..........
Then, under sections 129, 130, 131 and 131-A Cr.P.C.
the armed forces may be required by the police officers or the
Provincial Governments to assist in maintaining law and order.
There is here an apparent conflict between Article 245 of the
Constitution and these sections, for if the Constitution empowers
the Federal Government to call the armed forces in aid of the civil
power, that power must be exercised by the Federal Government or
not at all. Its exercise by the Provincial Government is necessarily
excluded.
JUSTICE OF THE PEACE AND POLICE FUNCTIONS
Justice of the Peace' was in America the traditional title
for a Magistrate Court, but that title is now used primarily in rural
areas using non-lawyer Magistrates in courts not of record.
Under the Code of Criminal Procedure, the Provincial
Government may appoint a citizen of Pakistan as to whose integrity
and suitability the Government is satisfied to be a Justice of the
Peace for a local area. Under section 22A, a Justice of the Peace
has the same powers of arrest as a police officer under sections 54
and 55 Cr.P.C. The arrestee shall forthwith be taken before the
officer in charge of the police station with a report and the latter
shall re-arrest the arrestee. Also, a Justice of the Peace has under
that section power to call upon any policeman to aid him in the
prevention of crime generally or in the arrest or in preventing the
escape of any person.
Under sub-section (5) of section 22A, a Justice of the
Peace can exercise certain non-police powers e.g. issuing a
certificate as to the identity of any person, verifying any document
or attesting any such document. Under section 22B, a Justice of the
Peace shall perform the duties mentioned therein, namely:

involving a breach of the peace or the
commission of an offence;

from or the interference with the place of

when required by a police officer, to render all
assistance in making such an investigation
and to record any statement of a dying man in

By virtue of their respective offices, section 25 Cr.P.C.
so provides. "the Sessions Judges and on nomination by them, the
