PRELIMINARY
Chapter 2
PROSECUTOR
A Prosecutor may be a public prosecutor or he may be a
private prosecutor.
The British Common Law tradition was one of private
prosecution, that is, the complainant hired private counsel to press
the prosecution. Until 1986, England was one of the only a few
countries which allowed the police to prosecute rather than hand
over this task to a state agency like the district attomey in the
United States. The Crown Prosecution Service was established by
the Prosecution of Offences Act, 1985, and the police now play no
part in prosecutions beyond the stage of charging the suspect.
The Americans had established an office of public
prosecutor even when America was still a British Colony. In some
States, there was the system of private prosecutions, but private
prosecution was eventually found impracticable, too often subject
to abuse.
The idea of public prosecution in the Anglo-American
system proceeds on the view that crimes are "acts against the
State" and not simply wrongs inflicted upon individual victims.
Law officers and their functions
Under the Constitution of Pakistan the highest law
officer, at the federation level, is the Attomey General of Pakistan.
who under Article 100, is appointed by the President, serves during
the pleasure of the President, advises the Federal Government upon
all legal matters and performs such legal functions as may be
referred to or assigned to him by the Federal Government and has
the right of audience in all courts and tribunals in Pakistan. At the
provincial level, there is an Advocate General in each Province,
who, under Article 140, is appointed by the Governor, serves
252
during the pleasure of the Governor, advises the Provincial
Govemment upon such legal matters and performs such other legal
functions as may be referred or assigned to him.
Under section 492 of the Code of Criminal Procedure,
1898, the Provincial Government may appoint generally or for any
class of cases in any local area one or more Public Prosecutors. By
its sub-section (2), which was enacted in 2001, the officer in charge
of prosecution in a district may in the absence of a Public
Prosecutor, appoint any other person as public Prosecutor for the
purpose of any case.
Under section 493 Cr.P.C., the Public Prosecutor can
appear before any court in any case of which he has charge,
without any written authority; if a private person has engaged a
private counsel to prosecute any person in any such case, that is,
any case of which the Public Prosecutor has charge, the Public
Prosecutor shall conduct the prosecution and the private counsel
shall act in that case under the direction of the Public Prosecutor.
Under section 494 Cr.P.C., the Public Prosecutor has
power, with the consent of the court, before the final judgment, to
withdraw from the prosecution of any person either generally or in
respect of any one or more of the offences for which he is being
tried. The effect of such withdrawal is that if the withdrawal is
before the charge has been framed, the accused shall stand
discharged and if the withdrawal is after the charge, the accused
shall be acquitted.
Section 495 Cr.P.C. relates to cases being inquired into
r tried by a Magistrate. The Magistrate may permit any person,
even a police officer provided he is not below the rank of an
officer prescribed by the Provincial Government and he has not
taken part in the investigation of the offence to conduct the
prosecution. The person so permitted can exercise the powers of
withdrawal under section 494.
253
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 145
Under section 265A of the Code of Criminal Procedure,
"In every trial before a Court of Session initiated upon a police
report, the prosecution shall be conducted by the Public
Prosecutor"
The reference here obviously is to the Public Prosecutor
appointed under the Code of Criminal Procedure.
There is no such provision as regards cases in the courts
of Magistrates, the intention perhaps being that such cases shall be
dealt with under section 495 of the Code.
In Noor Elahi v State (PLD 1966 SC 708), the question
was how to proceed with cases in which there is a police challan
and there is also a private complaint, arising out of the same
incident, each implicating a different set of accused persons. S A
Rehman J. speaking for the majority held that the trial court should
take up the complaint case first. "If that trial results in a conviction,
it will be for the Public Prosecutor to consider whether or not he
should withdraw from the prosecution, with the permission of the
court, under section 494 of the Code of Criminal Procedure in the
police challan case
In this behalf, it was noticed that there will be difficulty
in conducting the case on behalf of the complainant in the first
trial, i.e. the complaint case:
"Normally, of course, under the law the
Public Prosecutor is to be in charge of
the case even if the trial is based on a
private complaint. The Public
Prosecutor, however, in the special
circumstances, could
the
permit
complainant's counsel to conduct the
proceedings on his behalf under his
directions. Alteratively, and that may
meet the situation more adequately,
Govemment, in the interest of justice,
could notify the complainant's counsel
254
as a Special Public Prosecutor for the
conduct of that case alone.......
Kaikaus J, dissenting, was, however, of the view that the two cases
should be consolidated so that there would be a single hearing. He
noticed that under section 270 (now section 265A) of the Code,
every trial before the Sessions Court is to be by a Public
Prosecutor:
Comments
"It may be said that the Public
Prosecutor may
the
hand over
prosecution in such a case to the private
complainant. But we will again be trying
to get over a legal provision. The
Criminal Procedure Code does not refer
to handing over by the Public Prosecutor
of the prosecution to anybody else. At
the same time section 270 gives an
indication as to the mind of the
legislature. The law intends that all
prosecutions before the Sessions Judge
shall be by the Public Prosecutor so that
it is not envisaged that two versions of
the same incident should be put forward
in two different proceedings......
Section 265A (its predecessor was section 270) of the
Code requires, not that in every trial before a Court of Session, the
prosecution shall be conducted by the public prosecutor; what it
says is that in every trial before a Court of Session, initiated upon a
police report, the prosecution shall be conducted by the Public
Prosecutor. So, in a private complaint case, the prosecution of the
case is not the responsibility of the Public Prosecutor, it is, by
necessary implication, that of the complainant who will have to
engage a private counsel and that counsel may not act under the
directions of the Public Prosecutor.
255
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 146
Section 493 Cr.P.C. envisages a case "of which he (the
Public Prosecutor) has charge, and in which the complainant has
engaged his own private counsel. In such a case also, it is the
Public Prosecutor who "shall conduct the prosecution"; the role of
the private counsel is to act....... under his directions". But if we
read this provision with section 265-A. can it be said that a trial
initiated on a private complaint is a case of which the Public
Prosecutor has charge within the meaning of section 493 of the
Code. The answer seems to be in the negative. The result must
therefore be that with the cases initiated on private complaint, the
Public Prosecutor has no concern and these cases are not therefore
cases "of which he has charge".
Prosecution Service under Provincial Laws
Each Province has now established a Criminal
Prosecution Service with a view to having as, for example, the
preamble to the Punjab Criminal Prosecution Service (Constitution,
Functions and Powers) Act, 2006, says, "an independent, effective
and efficient service for the prosecution of criminal cases, to ensure
prosecutorial independence, for better coordination in the criminal
justice system". The Service under the Punjab Act consists of the
Prosecutor General, Additional Prosecutors General, Deputy
Prosecutors General. District Public Prosecutors and Assistant
District Public Prosecutors.
The general superintendence of the Service vests in the
Provincial Goverment, and the administration of the Service vests
in the Prosecutor General, who is, as Section 6 of the Punjab Act
provides, removable from service by the Provincial Government on
grounds of misconduct or physical infirmity. The Prosecutor
General can represent the Government in all the courts.
Under section 9, of the Punjab Act, all prosecutions are
to be conducted by the Prosecutors of behalf of the Government. At
the district level, the head of prosecution agency is the District
Public Prosecutor, who is to distribute work among the
prosecutors.
Under section 9, sub-sections (4) and (5), a police report
under section 173 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, whether it
recommends the prosecution of the person accused, or cancellation
of a first information report or the discharge of an accused, shall be
submitted to the court through the Public Prosecutor, who may
return it to the investigation officer for the removal of any defect,
or if it is fit for submission, to file it in the competent court. Under
section 10, sub-section (2), the Prosecutor General or the District
Public Prosecutor may refer to the competent authority to initiate
disciplinary action against any investigating or prosecution officer.
The prosecutor also has power to summon any report or record
from a government department or law enforcement agency.
Need for a Public Prosecution Service
It is wrong for a person to be prosecuted if the evidence
is insufficient. "The essence of wrongness lies in the prosecution of
the innocent; if this principle is taken seriously, it should mean not
merely that innocent people are not convicted, but also that
innocent people should not be prosecuted. The reason for this may
he found in the dictum that 'the process is the punishment'; being
prosecuted is an inconvenience at least, often a source of profound
und sometimes a considerable expense, and it may also lead to an
element of stigma and loss of social esteem. The homely phrase
"no smoke without fire" might well be applied ("The Criminal
Process" by Andrew Ashworth, p.180). There are sound moral and
economic reasons for not prosecuting a person against whom the
evidence is insufficient or there is no realistic prospect of
conviction. It was for these reasons that the (English) Royal
Commission on Criminal Procedure recommended the introduction
of a Public Prosecution Service to provide independent review, to
examine not only that the evidence is sufficient to stand judicial
scrutiny but also, "even if a case satisfies the test of evidentiary
sufficiency, there may be strong reasons of public policy or, as it is
termed in England and Wales, public interest, in favour of dealing
with the case by means other than prosecution".
256
257
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 147
RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN POLICE AND PROSECUTOR
The prosecutor has no legal authority to direct the police
to engage or not to engage in certain investigation or investigative
practices. But the police may seek the legal advice of the
prosecutor and usually do follow it; they do so not because they are
legally required to do so, but because the interaction between the
police and the prosecutor makes cooperation necessary. The
Prosecutor General is however authorized by section 10 of the
Punjab Act to issue general guidelines to the prosecutors and
investigating officers for effective and efficient prosecution.
Although the principal concern of both the police and
the prosecutor is effective law enforcement, yet, their immediate
goals and interests tend to differ. While the police are primarily
concerned with the prevention and investigation of crime, the
prosecutor is the legal representative of the State, and his principal
job is to see that the case as prepared by the police is fit for
prosecution so that no one is subjected to the ordeal of trial unless
there is good case against him. This is the first step in what may be
called the process of scrutiny and screening. This involves the
determination of the question whether there is sufficient legal
evidence to support a prosecution. Even if the answer to this
question is in the affirmative, the prosecutor may not, as a matter of
enforcement policy, consider it in the public interest to prosecute.
When the prosecutor decides that the case should go to the court
for trial, it is, under section 9 of the 2006 Punjab Act, the
responsibility of the prosecutor to conduct the prosecution in the
court on behalf of the Government.
Thus, the prosecution agency is now institutionally
separate from the police; there is no client-lawyer relationship
between the police and the prosecutor, and the police are in no
position to give instructions to the prosecutor as to how to proceed.
Generally speaking, a prosecutor has traditionally exercised
considerable discretion in deciding whether to prosecute or not, and
258
this discretion is largely uncontrolled; and both in America and the
UK it has never been the rule that suspected criminal offences must
automatically be the subject of prosecution and trial.
This also now seems to be the law in Pakistan. Under
section 173 Cr.P.C., the police report (the challan) has to be filed in
court through the Public Prosecutor. That section makes no
provision for the scrutiny of the police report by the Public
Prosecutor, but under section 9, sub-section (4) of the 2006 Punjab
Act, a police report under section 173 of the Code of Criminal
Procedure has to be submitted to the court through the prosecutor
and if the prosecutor finds some defect, he may return the case to
the police for the removal of the defect; and if it is fit for
submission to the court for trial, he may file it in court. Though
there is no express provision in that Act saying that even if there is
sufficient legal evidence to proceed to trial, the prosecutor may
decide not to prosecute, yet, the word 'may' in the expression.
"The prosecutor shall scrutinize the report and may file it before
the court" seems to give him discretion not to submit the case to
the court for trial even in such a case. In other words, the power to
prosecute is an executive discretionary power and includes the
power not to prosecute. Indeed, in this matter as in all others, the
prosecutor must uct, as section 13, sub-section (9)(a) of the Punjab
Act says "fairly, honestly, with due diligence, in the public interest
and to uphold justice".
Section 12 of the 2006 Punjab Act requires the
investigating officer to:
ii,
immediately report to the District Prosecutor,
the registration of each criminal case by
sending a copy of the first information report;
send the police report under section 173 of the
Cr.P.C. to the concerned prosecutor within the
prescribed period; and
259
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 148
if the investigation has not been completed
within the prescribed time, record reasons and
send them to the prosecutor concemed.
However, this provision, read with the powers of the prosecutor
under section 9, sub-section (7), and section 13, sub-section (9)(b)
to scrutinize the police report under section 173 Cr.P.C., and the
power under section 10, sub-section (2) to report against an
investigating officer, does give the prosecutor a kind of supervisory
role over the police and the District Public Prosecutor may well be
described as the chief law enforcement officer in the district.
INCONSISTENCIES BETWEEN THE TWO LAWS:
There are some apparent inconsistencies between the

to 495 and the provisions of the provincial enactments e.g. the

1.

responsible for the conduct of prosecution on
behalf of the Government" (that is
Government of the Punjab - Section 2(1)(e)

Now, if prosecution "initiated upon a police

Under section 493 of the Code, there is scope

HOW TO RESOLVE THESE INCONSISTENCIES?
It is important to note that this is not a case of implied
repeal by a later enactment of an earlier enactment. That principle
applies where the repealing and the repealed laws are by the same
or an equal legislative authority. Here the Code of Criminal
Procedure is an existing law within the meaning of Article 268(7)
of the Constitution and the 2006 Act is a Provincial Law.
"Criminal Procedure" including all matters in the Code of Criminal
Procedure" is item 2 of the Concurrent Legislative List. And as
provisions relating to Public Prosecutors occur in sections 265A,
492 to 495 of the Criminal Procedure Code and the Provincial
Laws such as the 2006 Punjab Act also make provisions on the
same subject the repugnancy or the inconsistency falls to be
resolved with reference to Article 143 of the Constitution, which
declares that the "existing law shall prevail and the Act of the
Provincial Assembly shall, to the extent of the repugnancy, be
void",
In view of this constitutional position, section 20 of the
2006 Act which says: "The provisions of this Act shall have effect
notwithstanding anything contained in any other law for the time
being in force" is an exercise in sheer futility; no ordinary law can
override the Constitution.
CHALLENGE TO DECISION NOT TO PROSECUTE
Under the English Common Law tradition, there is a
very limited way in which the courts can control the exercise of
prosecutorial discretion. Lord Denning in Ex parte Blackburn
(1968) All ER 763) gave the example of a Chief Constable
issuing a directive to his men that no person should be prosecuted
for stealing goods worth less than 100 Pounds and said "I should
have thought the court could countermand it". In the leading case
on the subject-R v Inland Revenue (1993) 1 All ER 772), the
discretion of selective prosecution was upheld. The American
criminal justice system has followed the English Common Law
tradition and it has been held that the Government retains a broad
discretion as to whom to prosecute and for what. The leading case
on the subject is Wayte (470 US 598) which was a case in which
under what was called 'selective prosecution' of the offenders
similarly situated, some were prosecuted and others were not; it
was held:
"So long as the prosecutor has probable
cause to believe that the accused
committed an offence defined by statute,
the decision whether or not to prosecute
and what charge to file or bring..
generally rests entirely in his discretion".
But although the prosecutor's discretion is broad, it is
not unfettered. As was held in Wayte, selectivity in the
enforcement of criminal law is subject to constitutional restraints,
in particular that the decision to prosecute must not be based on
ground of race, religion or other arbitrary classification.

DUTIES OF PROSECUTOR GENERALLY:
We have seen that one of the duties of the prosecutor
under section 13, sub-section (9)(a) of the Punjab Act of 2006 is to
"perform his functions and exercise his powers fairly, honestly.
with due diligence, in the public interest and to uphold justice".
This assumes special importance in the context of the prosecutor's
function to determine, when the police report under section 173
Cr.P.C. is submitted to him for scrutiny and screening, whether the
case as made out by the police is fit to stand the test of trial and his
function to determine whether to withdraw from a prosecution.
In England, the prosecutors are "generally regarded as
having special ethical responsibilities in their capacity of ministers
of justice which defence counsel do not share. Whilst both parties
to criminal litigation are expected to develop their best
arguments..... in accordance with the adversary model of contest,
the prosecutor is expected to conduct his or her case with
temperance and restraint (encapsulated in the aphorism that
prosecutors should prosecute, not persecute), whereas defence
counsel is afforded greater leeway to press for acquittal by
engaging the passions and sympathies, of the Jury
Prosecutorial restraint has generally been viewed by lawyers as
promoting the interests of justice. It would be entirely
inappropriate, after all. for prosecutors to pursue the goal of
conviction at any cost, regardless of proper standards of decorum
and making no allowances for the fact that the accused is to be
treated as innocent unless and until proven otherwise" ("Criminal
Evidence" by Professors Paul Roberts and Adrain Zuckerman,
p.57).
The idea of 'minister of justice seems to have been
borrowed from the memorable judgement of Crompton J. in R. v
O'Connel (1844) 7 Ir. LR 261, 312). He said: "This court in which
we sit is a temple of justice, and the advocates at the bar, as well as
the Judge upon the Bench, are equally ministers in that temple".
Thus, an additional burden, essentially incidental to the
nature of his office. lies on the prosecutor. In the classic words of
Justice Sutherland in Berger (295 US, 78, 88), the prosecutor-
"is the representative of not an ordinary
party to a controversy, but of a
sovereignty whose obligation to govem
impartially is as compelling as its
obligation to govern at all; and whose
in a criminal
interest, therefore,
prosecution is not that it shall win a case
but that justice shall be done. As such,
he is in a peculiar and very definite sense
the servant of the law, the twofold aim
of which is that guilt shall not escape or
innocence suffer. He may prosecute with
earnestness and vigor-indeed, he should
do so. But while he may strike hard
blows, he is not at liberty to strike foul
ones. It is as much his duty to refrain
from improper methods calculated to
produce a wrongful conviction as it is to
use every legitimate means to bring
about a just one".
A public prosecutor must, in the performance of his
public duties, act in the public interest, regardless of considerations
of loyalty to Government; he is not and he must not act as the
megaphone of the Government in power. The example was set by
Lord Shawcross before Lynskey Tribunal in 1948. The task of this
tribunal was to enquire into allegations of corruption against
certain members of the Attlee Government and there were many in
the Labour Party who suggested that, as Attomey General of that
Government, Shawcross should not appear. He maintained the
position that it was his duty, however, personally unpleasant, to
represent the public interest with complete objectivity and
detachment, that is "the duty to be wholly detached, wholly
independent and to keep the implication of an obligation to protect
265
Paki
264
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 151
what he conceives to be the public interest whatever the political
results may be".
To quote from the Code of Conduct adopted by the Bar
Council for the Bar of England and Wales, "The Prosecuting
Counsel should not attempt to obtain conviction by all means at his
command. He shall not regard himself as appearing for a party, he
should use his best endeavours to ensure that all evidence or
material that ought properly be made available is either presented
by the prosecution or disclosed to the defence".
Summary:
To sum up. the role of a Public Prosecutor a
government lawyer who instigates the prosecution of an accused
and represents the State at the trial-spans over the entire course of
criminal justice process. He may serve as police's "house counsel"
has, in theory at least, a discretion to choose whom to prosecute
and for what, represents the State at the hearing and the trial, and is
at the same time an officer of the court. He is a servant of the law
and not of the Government for the time being in power.
Chapter 3
DEFENCE COUNSEL:
Right to be heard by the Counsel
In all criminal cases, the right of the person accused to
be heard has come to mean the right "to be heard by counsel". For,
as was said in Johnson v Zerbst (304 US 458-1938), the right to
counsel as guaranteed by the Sixth Amendment of the American
Constitution embodies "the obvious truth that the average
defendant does not have the professional legal skill to protect
himself when brought before a tribunal" and that the Amendment
"withholds from.... courts, in all criminal proceedings, the power
and authority to deprive an accused of his life or liberty unless he
has or waives the assistance of counsel".
266
The right has sometimes been called "the most pervasive
right" or "the master key" to all rights, because it ensures the
reliability of the guilt-determining process. This right to counsel
has been extended to counsel at state expense for indigent
defendants - defendants who are too poor to afford to engage their
own counsel. As was held in Gideon (372 US 335; 9 L Ed 2d 799)
"in our adversary system of criminal justice, any person haled into
court, who is too poor to hire a lawyer, cannot be assured a fair
Irial, unless counsel is provided for him (by the State). This seems
to us to be an obvious truth".
One of the fundamental rights guaranteed by Article 10
of the Constitution of Pakistan is the right of an accused person 'to
be defended by a legal practitioner of his choice'. Then, section
340, sub-section (1), provides for a right to an accused person to be
defended by a pleader.
Like the American Constitution, the Constitution of
Pakistan, too, does not impose on the State any obligation to
provide for the defence of indigent persons accused of serious
criminal offences. Yet, this State obligation has been judicially
recognized in America, and is, and ought to be, recognized as a
constitutional right in Pakistan. Governments, both Federal and
Provincial, quite properly spend vast sums of money to establish
machinery to try the accused persons. Then, there are defendants
who can hire good lawyers at their own expense. This affords
strong indication that lawyers, both for the prosecution and the
defence, "are necessities, not luxuries". To be fair to the accused
persons who are too poor to engage their own lawyers, to preserve
some parity between the State and such accused persons and to
place them on an equal footing with the prosecution, it is. therefore.
necessary that there is a State machinery which enables the
indigent defendants to be defended at public expense. It is on this
principle that Chapter 24C of the High Court Rules and Orders
Vol. II requires that indigent defendants be provided with counsel
at Government expense at the sessions trials, and Chapter 25E of
the High Court Rules and Orders Vol. III requires counsel to be
provided at Government expense at appeal stage. The right needs
267
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 152
to be extended to all indigent defendants accused of serious crimes
regardless of the tribunals in which they are tried,
FORENSIC DUTIES OF DEFENCE COUNSEL:
The right to the assistance of counsel under the US Sixth
Amendment has come to mean that "the right to counsel is the right
to effective assistance of counsel [McMann v Richardson-397 US
759), so much so that the convict can ask the conviction and
sentence to be set aside because counsel's assistance at the trial or
sentencing was ineffective. "the benchmark for judging any claim
of ineffectiveness" being "whether counsel's conduct so
undermined the proper functioning of the adversarial process that
the trial cannot be relied on as having produced a just result".
(Strickland v Washington-466 US 668; 80 L Ed 2d 674 (1984).
While "no particular set of detailed rules for counsel's
conduct can satisfactorily take account of the variety of
circumstances faced by defence counsel or the range of legitimate
decisions regarding how best to represent a criminal defendant" yet
"Representation of a criminal defendant
entails certain basic duties. Counsel's
function is to assist the defendant, and
hence counsel owes the client a duty of
loyalty, a duty to avoid conflicts of
interest. From Counsel's function as
assistant to the defendant derive the
overarching duty to advocate, the
defendant's cause and the more
particular duties to consult with the
defendant on important decisions and to
keep the defendant informed of
important developments in the course of
the prosecution. Counsel also has a duty
to bring to bear such skill and
knowledge as will render the trial a
268
reliable adversarial testing process"
(Justice O'Conner in Strickland).
One of the best statements on the subject of forensic
duties (we often say forensic fact-finding. forensic duties, the word
"forensic" is derived from the Roman forum: forensic literally
means pertaining to legal proceedings) of defence counsel is to be
found in the oft-quoted and memorable words of Crompton J. in
O'Connel (1844) Ir. LR 312):
"This Court in which we sit is a temple
of justice; and the advocates at the Bar
as well as the Judge upon the Bench are
equally ministers in the temple. The
object of all equally should be the
attainment of justice...through the
ascertainment of the truth..... I would
say to the advocates upon this subject:
Let your zeal be as warm as your heart's
blood, but let it be tempered with
discretion and with self respect; let your
independence be firm, but let it be
chastened by personal humility; let your
love of liberty amount to a passion, but
let it not appear to be a cloak for
maliciousness".
To the suggested doctrine that counsel was the mere
mouthpiece of his client, Crompton J. said;
"Such. I do conceive, is not the office of
an advocate. His office is a higher one.
To consider him in that light is to
degrade him. I would say of him..... He
is a representative, but not a delegate. He
gives to his client the benefit of his
learning, his talents and his judgment;
but all through he never forgets what he
269
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 153
owes to himself and to others. He will
not knowingly misstate the law, though
it be to gain the cause for his client, He
will ever bear in mind that if he be the
advocate of an individual and retained
and remunerated for his valuable
services, yet he has a prior and perpetual
retainer on behalf of truth and
justice...."
And, in the words of Gibson CJ in Rush (2 Pa.187) (1845) -
"It is a popular, but gross mistake, to
suppose that a lawyer owes no fidelity to
any one except his client; and that the
latter is the keeper of his professional
conscience",
A lawyer is, Gibson CJ continued, "bound by those obligations
which, without oaths, rest upon all men. The high and honourable
office of a counsel would be degraded to that of a mercenary, were
he compelled to do the biddings of his clients against the dictates of
his conscience".
In short, in the words of the "Standard for Criminal
Justice" by the American Bar Association:
i)
ii)
the defence lawyer has no duty to execute any
direction of the accused which does not
comport with law...... The defence lawyer is
the professional representative of the accused,
not the accused's alter ego; and
it is unprofessional conduct for a lawyer
intentionally to misrepresent matters of fact or
law to the court.
Sometimes, it may so happen that when a counsel is
approached to defend an accused person, he is reluctant to do so.
The reluctance may be due to the fact that the accused is a known
scoundrel, having been involved in a variety of crimes. He is hated
by the public. Or, it may be due to the nature of the crime, you feel
repelled by the cruel, inhuman and barbaric manner in which it was
committed. Should you refuse the brief in such a
a case?
The answer is "no", and here is a little lesson in civics.
Under the constitutions and the laws of all civilized countries every
person is entitled to a fair trial, every person is presumed to be
innocent until proved guilty and every person is entitled to be
represented by counsel.
John Adams was one of the founding fathers of
America. He was the first Vice President of independent America.
and the second President of America.
In 1870, John Adams was in the forefront of the
American independence movement, when on March 5, in what is
known as the Boston massacre, five colonials lay dead or dying, six
others wounded as a result of shots by the British soldiers, captain
Preston and his redcoats, who became the most vilified men in
America. Nobody was ready to represent captain Preston. The
captain sent a request from jail to Johan Adam to represent him,
and this was what Johan Adam said:
"I had no hesitation in answering that
counsel ought to be the very last thing
that an accused should want in a free
country, that the bar ought, in my
opinion, to be independent and impartial
at all times, and in every circumstance,
and that the persons whose lives were at
stake ought to have counsel they
preferred"
270
271
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 154
He took the case. Boston was stunned and this very nearly cost him
his political career.
Gerry Spence, the famed American lawyer, who had
spent his life representing ordinary poor people against the
corporate giants, was also once in a similar fix. He was asked to
represent one Leyland, son of a millionaire, who had shot his girl
friend, Maria, innocent, decent, loving, without any reason. The
bullet slashed the spinal cord of Maria's neck. At the hearing Maria
was still clinging to life and was able to testify with great
difficulty. Spence felt uneasy about representing Leyland; the facts
repelled him. Yet, he argued away his misgivings. Would not a
doctor worth his salt do his best to save a seriously wounded
heinous murderer brought to him. No body would condemn the
doctor. Why then should lawyers be called to task for protecting
the rights of the accused under the Constitution. Is not the highest
calling of a lawyer to defend the damned? So, he accepted the
brief. (See Gerry Spence in his "With Justice for None" pp 9-10).
Chapter 4
JUDGES AND MAGISTRATES
In talking about the Judges and Magistrates, as
participants in the criminal justice system, we are in the realm of
"Judicial Power", a constitutional concept, itself a part of the larger
constitutional concept, namely, that a State acts by its legislative,
its executive and its judicial authorities. (Exparte Virginia - 100
US 339; 25 L Ed 2d 676; also Cooper v Aaron-358 US 1:31 Ed
2d 5).
Part VII of the Constitution of Pakistan is titled "The
Judicature" and keeping in view the organizational scheme of the
Constitution, it is the constitutional concept of "Judicial Power"
with which this Part deals (Registrar v Wali Muhammad - 1997
SCMR 141, 155); that Power is inherent in the judiciary as an
independent and co-ordinate branch of government (with a small
"g"; the term "govemment" compendiously describes and includes
the Legislative, the Executive and the Judicial branches of
. 272
'government' as distinguished from 'Government' with a capital
"G" which expression is sometimes used to describe the Executive
Organ of the State) as contrasted with the Legislative and
Executive Power of the State. (For a detailed treatment of the
subject and related matters, see the author's book "Judicial Review
of Public Actions" Part III, Chapters 1-4).
The term "Judicial Power" is not capable of a precise
definition, but one of the best definitions of the term is that given
by Griffith CJ. In Huddard Parker and Co. v Moorehead (8 CLR
330, 357) where he says that the term means:
"the power which every sovereign
authority must, of necessity, have to
decide controversies between its
subjects, or between itself and its
subjects, whether the rights relate to life.
liberty or property".
ESTABLISHMENT AND JURISDICTION OF COURTS:
Chapter 1 of Part VII of the Constitution is a one-
Article Chapter, but its importance is self-evident. It reads:
Establishment and jurisdiction of courts.
"175.
(1)
There shall be a Supreme Court of Pakistan, a
High Court for each Province and such other
courts as may be established by law.
No court shall have any jurisdiction save as is
or may be conferred on it by the Constitution
or by or under any law.
(2)
(3)
The Judiciary shall be separated progressively
from the Executive within fourteen years from
the commencing day".
273
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 155
There is a general proposition that the power to make laws includes
the power to establish courts to enforce them (Mirza Gulzar Beg v
SHO-PLD 1977 Lah. 435. cited with approval in Abdul Hafeez v
State-PLD 1981 SC 352. 356). But clause (1) of Article 175 does
not leave the power to establish courts to be derived by implication.
Thus, besides providing for the establishment of a Supreme Court
and a High Court for each Province, it also expressly empowers the
Legislature to establish other courts by law.
When a court or a tribunal has been set up then it
becomes a question of policy as to what jurisdiction should be
conferred on it. The combined effect of clauses (1) & (2) of Article
175 is that the Supreme Court and the High Courts have been
established by the Constitution; that the Supreme Court and the
High Courts have such jurisdiction as has been conferred upon
them by the Constitution; that the Supreme Court and the High
Courts have also such other jurisdiction as is or may be conferred
upon them by or under any law and that when other courts are
established, they have such jurisdiction as may be conferred upon
them by or under the law establishing them.
MEANING OF LAW IN ARTICLE 175:
The expression 'law' here has been used to distinguish it
from the Constitution', which is higher in authority, in other
words. the expression 'law' here means any ordinary or
sub-constitutional law made in exercise of the powers granted by
the Constitution (Brothers Steel Mills v Ilyas Miraj - PLD 1996 SC
543, 569). It means positive law, that is to say, a formal
pronouncement of the will of a competent law giver. Thus 'law' in
this Article means statute law or enacted law (Federation v United
Sugar Mills-PLD 1977 SC 397, 405).
Meaning of 'by or under law':
It is note-worthy that while under clause (1), 'other
courts' may be established by law, by clause (2) jurisdiction may
be conferred by or under any law. Obviously, the expression 'by
274
law' means the law made by primary legislation and the expression
'under any law' means law made by subordinate legislation. Thus
clause (2) makes distinction between primary and subordinate
legislation. In other words, while a court can be established only by
primary legislation, jurisdiction may be conferred upon a court so
established both by the primary legislation and by subordinate
legislation.
PROPOSITIONS EMERGING FROM ARTICLE 175:
Three propositions are firmly established-
i)
ii)
Under a written Constitution, a court has only
such jurisdiction as is conferred on it by the
Constitution or by or under law (Shahnaz
Begum case PLD 1971 SC 677, 687;
Muhammad Khan v Border Allotment
Committee-PLD 1965 SC 623. 633).
The jurisdiction of a court is never established
by the court itself, but by some authority
external to it either in a statute or the
Constitution.
It is for the Constitution, and subject to the
Constitution, for the law to determine the
nature and extent of the jurisdiction, and the
forum upon which it will be conferred
(Constitutional Interpretation by Craig R.
Ducat and Harold W. Chase S ed p.5;
Brothers Steel Mills v Ilyas Miraj - PLD 1996
SC 543, 569). The courts are creatures of the
Constitution; they derive their powers and
jurisdiction from the Constitution and must
confine themselves within the limits set by the
Constitution (Chief Justice Hamood-ur-
Rehman in Federation of Pakistan v Saeed
Ahmed- PLD 1974 SC 151, 165).
275
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 156
COURTS IN WHICH THE JUDICIAL POWER OF THE
STATE VESTS:
The Judicial Power of the State is exercised through
judges appointed by the State. As was said in State v Zia-ur-
Rehman (PLD 1973 SC 49) "in a system where there is a
trichotomy of sovereign power then ex necessitate rei-from the
very nature of things - the judicial power must be vested in the
judiciary".
Articles 175, 202 and 203 of the Constitution provide
the framework of judiciary in Pakistan. Article 175 has already
been reproduced; Articles 202 and 203 read:
of
"202. Rules of procedure. - Subject to the Constitution
and law, a High Court may make rules regulating the
practice and procedure of the Court or of any court
subordinate to it".
"203. High Court to superintendent subordinate courts, -
Each High Court shall supervise and control all courts
subordinate to it".
The word 'law' has been, as has been noticed above, used in
Article 175 to distinguish it from the Constitution and means an
ordinary or a sub-constitutional law made in the exercise of the
legislative power granted by the Constitution (Brothers Steel Mills
v Ilyas Miraj-PLD 1996 SC 543, 569). This means that the source
power for the legislature to establish courts in which shall vest
the Judicial Power of the State is Article 175, unless the
Constitution itself, by another Article, permits the establishment of
other courts or tribunals (Mehram Ali v Federation of Pakistan -
PLD 1998 SC 1445, 1447). It follows inevitably that the
Constitution recognizes only such other specific courts and
tribunals to share the Judicial Power with the courts expressly
mentioned in Article 175 as have been specifically provided by the
Constitution itself. The distinction thus is between the courts
established by the Constitution itself (the constitutional courts) and
other courts established by law (the legislative courts).
276
other constitutional courts and tribunals are:
Besides the Supreme Court and the High Courts, the
i)
The Federal Shariat Court established under
Part VII, Chapter 3-A, of the Constitution;
ii)
Tribunals under Article 212; and
iii)
Election Tribunals under Article 225.
CHARACTERISTICS OF 'COURT' AND 'JUDICIAL
PROCESS':
The power of the Legislature to establish courts by or
under law conferred by Article 175, that is, the courts in whom
shall also vest the judicial power of the State, is not an unlimited
power. The limitation upon this power has its source in the fact that
the tribunal which it by law establishes is a 'court'. Some of the
basic ideas which go with the notion of a court are that it is the
characteristic of courts to decide and not merely to advise, that a
court must have the independence of judgment in cases before it
and the cases and the controversies which it is required to handle
must be fit for them (Nasrullah Khan v Member Election
Commission PLD 1066 Lah. 850; 873; also see the article
"Power of Congress - a Study in Separation of Power" by Professor
(as he then was) Frankfurter and Professor Landis (1923-24)
Harvard Law Review 1010, 1020-1). For example, courts do not
decide abstract, hypothetical or contingent questions or give mere
declaration in the air (Chief Justice Muhammad Munir in Md.
Mehdi Ali Khan case PLD SC (Pak) 387, 407), nor are they
concerned with questions which are in their nature academic rather
than judicial ((1986) AC 348 PC). The essential steps of a judicial
process are the ascertainment of facts, determination of the law
applicable to the facts found or admitted, an inference as to the
existence or otherwise of a right or obligation from the
determination of the law and a decision as to the final order to be
made in respect of such right or obligation. Since the ultimate
277
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 157
object of such process is the enforcement of a right or obligation,
every step of the process has a necessary reference to and is limited
by that object (Chief Justice Muhammad Munir in Md. Mehdi Ali
Khan case-PLD 1959 SC (Pak) 387).
LABEL 'COURT' OR 'TRIBUNAL' IS NOT DECISIVE:
There are many tribunals or bodies with the label 'court'
attached to them which have many of the trappings of a court and
which are required to act judicially, yet they are not courts of
judicature or courts of law within the meaning of Article 175. A
court may be identified as a court of judicature if it has been
established to exercise, either generally or subject to defined limits,
the judicial power of the State. "If the body under review is
established for a purely legislative or administrative purpose, it is
part of the legislative or administrative system of the State, even
though it has to perform duties which are judicial in character"
(Lord Scarman in AG v BBC (1980) 3 All ER 161). Thus, a
tribunal is not necessarily a court in this strict sense-
i)
ii)
iii)
iv)
v)
vi)
33
because it gives a final decision;
nor because it hears witnesses on cath;
nor because two or more contending parties
appear before it between whom it has to
decide;
nor because it gives decisions which affect the
right of subjects:
nor because there is an appeal to a court;
nor because it is a body to whom a matter is
referred by another body (Lord Sankey LC in
Shell Company of Australia v Federal
Commissioner (1930) All ER 671).
A distinction has, therefore, to be made between courts
of law which form part of the judicial system of the country, on the
one hand, and courts which are to resolve problems which arise in
the course of administration of the government of the country and
the test is not whether the forum is described as a court or tribunal,
278
for 'tribunal' is a generic term which includes a court, and often
these terms are used inter-changeably (Muhammad Gul, J. in
Zahoor Elahi v State PLD 1977 SC 273, 357), nor whether the
authority under review is required to act judicially, that is to say, to
act with such fairness and impartiality as characterize proceedings
in courts of justice that being a duty common to all State or public
power (Bahadur v State - PLD 1985 SC 62, 68).
OTHER
COURTS' IN
SUBORDINATE COURTS:
ARTICLE 175 MEAN
The expression 'other courts' in clause (1) of Article 175
"is relatable to the subordinate courts referred to in Article 202 and
203 of the Constitution" (Mehram Ali v Federation of Pakistan -
PLD 1998 SC 1445, 1469). What the Constitution contemplates.
therefore, is not a batch of unconnected courts but a judiciary
composed of the superior courts and the subordinate courts. The
subordinate courts are, therefore, an integral part of the judiciary
and the judicial system of Pakistan (Muhammad Mansha v State -
PLD 1996 SC 229, 233).
The civil courts established by enactments such as the
Civil Courts Ordinance read with the Code of Civil Procedure 1908
and the criminal courts established under the Code of Criminal
Procedure 1898 are examples of the subordinate courts, which
exercise the judicial power of the State within the meaning of
Article 175.
SPECIAL COURTS:
But it frequently happens that the Legislatures, from
time to time, carve out special matters out of the general
jurisdiction of the ordinary civil and criminal courts and in the
interest of economy, speed or expertise, give the jurisdiction to deal
with them to special courts or tribunals especially created for the
purpose. Similarly, there is power in the legislature to create new
rights and liabilities and to create special courts to try those rights
and liabilities and to prescribe special procedure for that purpose
279
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 158
(Brothers Steel Mills v Ilyas Miraj - PLD 1996 SC 543, 569). This
legal position is reflected in so far as civil matters are concerned, in
the words "excepting suits of which their cognizance is either
expressly or impliedly barred" in section 9 of the Code of Civil
Procedure as also by section 4 thereof which reads:
"4.(1)
(2)
In the absence of any specific provision to the
contrary, nothing in this Code shall be
deemed to limit or otherwise affect any
special or local law now in force or any
special jurisdiction or power conferred, or any
special form of procedure prescribed, by or
under any other law for the time being in
force.
In particular and without prejudice to the
generality of the proposition contained in
subsection (1), nothing in this Code shall be
deemed to limit or otherwise affect any
remedy which a land-holder or landlord may
have under any law for the time being in force
for the recovery of rent of agricultural land
from the produce of such land".
Similarly, section 1, subsection (2), of the Code of
Criminal Procedure provides: "... Nothing herein contained
shall affect any special or local law now in force, or any special
jurisdiction or power conferred, or any special form of procedure
prescribed, by any other law for the time being in force".
Examples of special courts vested with the judicial
power of the State in civil matters are the Courts established under
the Financial Institutions (Recovery of Finances) Ordinance, 2001.
the
Revenue Courts under the Punjab Tenancy
Act...established to decide cases arising out of the
relationship of landlord and tenant of agricultural land and the
Family Courts under the Family Courts Act 1964; and the
examples of special courts vested with the judicial power of the
State in criminal matters are the courts established under the
Foreign Exchange Regulation Act 1947, Pakistan Criminal Law
(Amendment) Act 1958, Suppression of "Terrorist Activities
(Special Courts) Act, 1975 and the National Accountability Bureau
Ordinance, 1999.
THE PLACE AND IMPORTANCE OF SUBORDINATE
COURTS:
It is necessary to emphasis the importance of the place
the subordinate courts, primarily in their capacity of trial courts,
occupy in the hierarchy of courts and in the criminal judicial
system. The subordinate courts include, under the Code of
Criminal Procedure, the Courts of Sessions Judges, Additional
Sessions Judges and Magistrates.
These courts have, as trial courts at the District and
Tehsil levels, the greatest public contact, and as the bulk of
litigation, touching the life, liberty and property of the common
man, is handled by them, they present the image of justice to the
people and the opinion held of them reflect the respect in which the
judiciary as an institution is held. The judge, says Lord Denning.
"who tries the case is the judge who is
seen by the people. It is on his good
administration that law and order
ultimately depend".
Woodrow Wilson, later President of America, while still a
Professor at Princeton University, said:
"So far as the individual is concerned, a
constitutional government is as good as
its courts, no better, no worse. Its laws
are only its professions. It keeps its
promises, or does not keep them, in its
courts".
280
281
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 159
While these observations apply to the judiciary, as a whole, they
are more particularly true of the subordinate judiciary.
Sometimes, and in some jurisdictions, these courts are
also described as "inferior courts" (See, for example, section 435 of
the Code of Criminal Procedure). This description is a categorizing
and not a derogatory description. Such courts or tribunals, says
Lord Denning in AG v BBC (1979) All ER 45, cited in
Muhammad Mansha case (PLD 1996 SC 229,233),
"are not inferior in the doing of justice,
nor in the judges who man them nor in
the advocates who plead in them".
TREATMENT THAT SUBORDINATE COURTS DESERVE:
It has been said of the subordinate courts in America
that, historically, such courts have been the most significant, yet,
typically the most neglected of all courts. Charles Evans Hughes,
later Chief Justice of America, commented in 1919 in his address
to the members of New York Bar Association:
Pakistan.
"The Supreme Court of the United States
and the Courts of Appeals will take care
of themselves. Look after the courts of
the poor, who stand most in the need of
justice. The security of the Republic will
be found in the treatment of the poor and
the ignorant, in indifference to their
misery and helplessness lies disaster".
This applies equally to the subordinate courts in
JUDICIAL INDEPENDENCE AND IMPARTIALITY:
Independence of judiciary is one of the basic general
principles of the Constitution of Pakistan. Its preamble declares
282
that it is "the will of the people of Pakistan to establish an order"
wherein, among others.
secured".
"the independence of the judiciary shall be fully
And lest there be any doubt about it, the same words are repeated
as substantive part of the Constitution in Article 2A, read with its
Annex.
So important is the judicial independence, which is
defined in terms of the relationship of the courts to others.
particularly the Executive branch of the government, that it has
been recognized as a universal human right. (See, for example, the
Universal Declaration of Human Rights, art. 10, and the European
Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental
Freedoms, 1959, art. 6).
Generally speaking. a court or tribunal which is not
independent is not an impartial court or tribunal. We have seen that
"bias" is synonymous with partiality, so that when we say that a
Judge or Magistrate was biased, it means that he was partial; it
means "that he was motivated by a desire unfairly to favour one
side or disfavour the other" (See the discussion under the heading
"Bias" in an earlier part of this book).
The rule that nobody can be a judge in his own cause has
received legislative recognition in section 556 of the Code of
Criminal Procedure which prohibits a Judge or Magistrate - "to try
any case to or in which he is a party or personally interested"
except "with the permission of the court to which an appeal lies
from his court".
This later part of section 556 namely that a biased Judge
or Magistrate may try a case in which he is interested with the
permission of his appellate court, is unfortunate and, if challenged.
will be, in view of the recent developments in the law, difficult to
sustain.

We have seen that the High Courts are constitutional

exercises such jurisdiction as is conferred on it by the Constitution;
it also has such jurisdiction as may be conferred on it by or under
any law. The latter may conveniently be called the statutory
jurisdiction of the High Court. For example, under Section 410 of
the Code of Criminal Procedure, the High Court has jurisdiction to
hear appeals against the decisions of the Courts of Session.
Court of Session: A Court of Session, so provides section 9 of

Subordination of Sessions Judges and Magistrates: For the

POWERS OF COURTS
Powers of the courts to try offences:
Any offence under the Pakistan Penal Code (PPC) may
be tried (a) by the High Court or (b) by the Court of Session, or (c)
by any other court by which such offence is shown in the eighth
column of the Second Schedule of the Code of Criminal Procedure
to be triable. (Section 28 Cr.P.C). As regards an offence under a
law other than PPC, it can be tried by the court mentioned in that
other law, but if no such other court is mentioned in that law, then
by the courts under the Code of Criminal Procedure. (Section 29
Cr.P.C).
Sentences which the High Courts and Sessions Judges may
pass:
This is governed by section 31 Cr.P.C. A High Court
may pass any sentence authorized by law. In other words, there is
no limit upon its sentencing power.
A Sessions Judge and an Additional Sessions Judge may
pass any sentence authorized by law subject to the condition that a

PART IV
STAGES OF CRIMINAL PROCESS
Criminal process can broadly be divided into two stages,
the administrative stage; and
the judicial stage.
Chapter 1
The Administrative Stage
The power to prosecute someone for an offence is the
power to execute and enforce the laws and is a part of the
Executive Power of the State. But before the stage of prosecution is
reached, there is the duty and power to investigate into suspected
offences with a view to identifying the perpetrators of them and
obtaining sufficient evidence admissible in a court of law. This
involves the exercise of the power of the police - the power to
arrest, the power to seize and search etc and that too is
necessarily a part of the Executive Power. Hence the label
'administrative stage'. Thus, the State. through its Executive
Organ, is not only the principal prosecutor, but also the primary
investigator of serious crimes.
In the criminal process, there are, so observed Geoffrey
Lane LJ in Norwest Holst (1978) 3 All ER 280, 296) cited in Brig.
Imtiaz Ahmad (1994 SCMR 2142, 2153), three different phases.
First of all, the administrative phase, next the judicial phase and
finally, the execution phase, when the orders of the court or
tribunal are, if necessary, executed or promulgated. Quite plainly.
faimess to the suspect....... demands that he should be given a
chance of stating his case before the final period: the
execution........... Equally fairness demands that the suspect shall
be given a chance of putting his side of the case before the judicial
enquiry is over. But on the other side, and the other side are
entitled to fairness just as the subject is, fairness to the inquirer (or
the investigator) demands that during the administrative period he
should be able to investigate without having at every stage to
enquire from the suspect what his side of the matter may be. Of
course, it may be difficult to find out the particular point at which
the administrative phase ends and the judicial phase
begins. Requirement of natural justice, such as preliminary
notice of the accusation, opportunity to be heard, do not therefore
apply at that stage. Nor does the presumption of innocence apply at
the administrative stage, for the police are not to decide; they are to
investigate and report.
In Wiseman (1969) 3 All ER 275, Lord Reid said:
"Every public officer who has to decide
hether to prosecute or raise proceedings
ought first to decide whether there is a
prima facie case but no one supposes
that justice requires that he should first
seek the comments of the accused or the
defendant on the material before him. So
there is nothing inherently unjust in
reaching such a decision in the absence
of the other party".
We are here concerned with the administrative and
judicial phases only.
into.
The administrative stage may further be sub-divided
Investigation and prosecution. We have already dealt with this
subject.
An important distinction which needs to be made at the outset is
that the pre-trial administrative stage, particularly the investigation
289
288
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 163
part of it, is, by its nature, inquisitorial, followed by the judicial
part of the criminal procedure namely the trial, which, by its nature,
is adversarial. This mixed model is being followed in the Anglo-
American systems as also in the modern European system of
criminal procedure. This is also the position in Pakistan.
Chapter 2
Ways to set the Law in Motion:
The machinery of criminal justice under the Code of
Criminal Procedure may be set in motion in the following ways:
208
(1)
(2)
(3)
by an information received by the police;
by a complaint to the court;
upon information received by a Magistrate
from a person other than a police officer or
upon his own knowledge or suspicion that an
offence of which he can take cognizance has
been committed.
Information to the Police
The law is set in motion in cognizable cases, when an
information relating to a cognizable offence is given to the police
officer in charge of the police station concerned whether orally or
in writing. Section 154 of the Code of Criminal Procedure requires
that every such oral information shall be reduced to writing by the
officer in charge of the police station concerned and shall be read
over to the informant. Both the oral information when so reduced
to writing and the written information shall be signed by the
informant and shall be entered in the register of FIRS.
Under section 155 of the Code, in cases relating to non-
cognizable offences also, information may be given to the officer
in charge of the police station concerned, who shall enter it in the
prescribed register.
Then, there may be cases in which an officer in charge
of a police station receives secret information, from a police
informant or has otherwise reason to suspect the commission of a
cognizable offence. In such cases, section 157 of the Code requires
the police officer to forthwith send a report of such information or
suspicion to the concerned Magistrate and to proceed to the spot
and investigate the facts and circumstances of the case.
As was held in Emperor v Khawaja Nazir Ahmad (AIR 1945 PC
18).
"...the receipt and recording of an
information report is not a condition
precedent to the setting in motion of a
criminal investigation. No doubt in great
majority of cases, criminal prosecutions
are undertaken as a result of information.
received and recorded in this way, but
their Lordships see no reason why the
police, if in possession through their
own knowledge or by means of credible
though informal intelligence which
"genuinely leads them to the belief that a
cognizable offence has been committed,
should not of their own motion
undertake an investigation into the truth
of the matters alleged. Section 157
Cr.P.C., when directing that a police
officer, who has reason to suspect from
information or otherwise that an offence
which he is empowered to investigate
under section 156 has been committed
shall proceed to investigate the facts and
circumstances, supports this view. In
truth, the provision as to information
3 first
report (commonly called
information report) are enacted for other
reasons".
290
291
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 164
These views have been reiterated in Muhammad Bashir
SHO (PLD 2007 SC 539).
Object of FIR
The object of a first information report is to obtain early
information of alleged criminal activity, to record the
circumstances before there is time for them to be forgotten or
embellished; the first information report, it has to be remembered,
can be put in evidence when the informant is examined if it is
desired to do so. (Khawaja Nazir Ahmad case). An FIR is, "only a
mode of recording or preserving an information and is one of the
means to set the machinery of criminal law into motion. Otherwise
we know that presence or existence of an FIR did not confer any
extra or additional powers on a police officer nor did the non-
existence of the same withhold or take away any power vesting in
him (Muhammad Bashir v SHO-PLD 2007 SC $39).
Investigation or enquiry before recording FIR
When the police receive information about the
commission of an offence, they are expected first to find out
whether the offence disclosed falls into the category of cognizable
offence or is one which is non-cognizable. If the offence appears to
be cognizable, the police 'shall' record it, as is required by section
154 Cr.P.C., in the First Information Report Register; if it is non-
cognizable, the police shall, as is required by section 155 Cr.P.C.,
record it in the Diary. Sections 154 and 155 do not visualize or
authorize the holding of an enquiry to assess the correctness or the
falsity of the information before recording the information in the
manner provided by those sections. If such an enquiry is made
before the recording of the information, the FIR would be hit by
the provisions of section 162 and the FIR would be inadmissible at
the trial. (Muhammad Bashir v SHO-PLD 2007 SC 539).
Distinction between Cognizable and Non-Cognizable Offences
For the purposes of investigation, there is a distinction
between a cognizable offence and a non-cognizable offence, and a
292
cognizable case and a non-cognizable case. These expressions are
defined in section 4, sub-section (1) clauses (f) and (n) Cr.P.C. By
clause () 'cognizable offence', means an offence for which, and
'cognizable case' means a case in which, a police officer may, in
accordance with the 2 Schedule to the Code or under any other
law, arrest without warrant. By clause (n) 'non-cognizable offence'
means an offence for which, and 'non-cognizable case" means a
case in which a police officer may not arrest without warrant.
It appears that what is a "cognizable offence", under the
Code is an "arrestable offence" in the English Law.
The broad distinction between a cognizable offence and
a non-cognizable offence, so far as the powers of police officers are
concerned, is that a police officer (i) may arrest a person accused of
a cognizable office without warrant and (ii) may investigate such
offence without the authority of a Magistrate, but may not arrest a
person accused of a non-cognizable offence without warrant and.
as section 155 Cr.P.C. says, "no police officer shall investigate a
non-cognizable case" without the order of the competent
Magistrate.
But when a police officer receives the order of the
competent Magistrate to investigate a non-cognizable offence he
may exercise all the powers that he has while investigating a
cognizable office except that he cannot arrest without warrant.
Cognizable or Non-Cognizable-what is the test
No set principle has been followed in making the
distinction between cognizable and non-cognizable offences. The
criterion of heinousness of the offence may at first sight appear to
be the determining factor but a closer examination of the two
categories of offence would reveal that there is quite a long list of
offences, the heinousness of which can hardly be doubted, as for
instance, the offence of sedition, waging war against the State and
treason, which are not cognizable offences. On the other hand,
some minor offences and even those which are punishable with
fine only, as for instance, the offence of causing danger.
293
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 165
obstruction or injury in any public way under section 283 PPC is
punishable with a fine of Rs.200, are cognizable offences. The
other criteria may be the quantum of sentence provided for the
offence. But this too does not appear to be the determining factor
because the offence of waging or attempting to wage war against
the State under section 121 PPC is punishable with death though it
is not a cognizable offence. Similarly, giving or fabricating false
evidence which results in the conviction and execution of an
innocent person is punishable with death but it is not a cognizable
offence.
Remedies against non-registration:
Under section 154 Cr.P.C. "Every information relating
to the commission of a cognizable offence if given orally to an
officer in charge of a police station shall be reduced to
writing.... and under section 155 Cr.P.C., "when
information is given to an officer in charge of a police station, of
the commission.......... of a non-cognizable offence, he shall
enter in a book to be kept.......the substance of such information
and refer the informant to the Magistrate".
But what is the informant to do if the information that he
conveys to the SHO relates to the commission of a cognizable
offence but the SHO does not reduce it to writing, or as it is
commonly known, register an FIR. The informant may complain to
the higher police authorities, or he may invoke the High Court's
jurisdiction under Article 199 of the Constitution. There is now
another remedy under section 22A, sub-section (6) Cr.P.C.; under
it the informant may approach the Sessions Judge of his district,
who, in his capacity of ex-officio Justice of the Peace, may himself
entertain the complaint or may make over the complaint to an
Additional Sessions Judge nominated by him for disposal. The ex-
officio Justice of the Peace may issue appropriate directions to the
police officer concerned regarding "non-registration of criminal
case".
294
Thus. "these provisions create a new forum to rectify a
wrong done by an officer in charge of police station by refusing to
register a criminal case i.e. not recording an FIR...........Undoing
this wrong of non-registration of a criminal case could mean only
an order to the SHO to register the case. The provisions of sub-
section (6) of section 22A Cr.P.C. confer no additional powers on
an ex-officio Justice of the Peace to hold an enquiry to assess the
credibility of such an information communicated for the purpose in
question nor do the said provisions give any extra authority to the
said ex-officio Justice of the Peace to refuse registration or order
non-registration of an FIR in violation of or beyond the mandatory
requirement of section 154 Cr.P.C.". (Muhammad Bashir v SHO -
PLD 2007 SC 539).
