case itself or direct an enquiry or investigation
to be made by a Justice of the Peace, by a
Police Officer or by any other person for
ascertaining the truth or falsehood of the
complaint; sub-section (3) of that section
provides that a Court of Session may, instead
of directing an investigation under sub-section
(1), direct the complaint to be investigated by
a Magistrate or Justice of the Peace.
Chapter 4
Investigation of Offences
Before dealing with the investigation of offences, it is
necessary to be familiar with certain, expressions. The term
"offence" is defined in section 4(1), clause (o) Cr.P.C. to mean any
act or omission made punishable by any law for the time being in
force...
Thus, no act or omission is an offence unless it is so
declared by a competent law-making authority. There is, therefore,
in Pakistan, no such thing as a common law offence. The principal
law of Pakistan which creates offences and provides for their
punishment is the Pakistan Penal Code. Other important laws are
the Hadood Laws, which not only codify a part of the Islamic law
of crimes, but also make some procedural provisions applicable at
investigation and trial stages of Hadood cases.
It is also necessary to understand clearly that an
investigating officer exercises only the powers expressly conferred
on him by law. There is no such thing as inherent powers of the
police. As has been succinctly put in Muhammad Bashir v SHO
(PLD 2007 SC 539, 547)-
296
"The powers enjoyed by the members of
the police force are limited to the
authority conferred on them by law".
The general idea of 'investigation' is, first, to find out.
what happened, and, secondly, to report on the matter to some
ather authority, often with a recommendation that certain action
should be taken. It is an administrative process, and like many.an
administrative process need not end in a decision.
The object of investigation is to ensure that no one is put
on trial unless there is a good case against him; it is "to enquire into
the allegations of offence... and to find out if the allegations.
are true or not". (Muhammad Nawaz Khan v Noor Muhammad-
PLD 1967 Lah. 176). The situation is not that of a detective fiction.
The investigator's duty, it must be emphasized, is to collect all
evidence. He is not to wear blinkers so as to proceed on a priori
notion that a particular suspect is guilty. He must collect all
evidence including that which favours the suspect "Merely.
because an FIR has been recorded need not necessarily lead to
investigation or arrest of the person alleged to have committed the
offence". As has been said in Muhammad Bashir v SHO (PLD
2007 SC 539, 550)-
"Nor was there any provision in any law
which commanded or even envisaged
that whenever an FIR got recorded, a
police officer was obliged to go through
the entire length of investigation as he
was permitted by section 157(1)(6) of
the Cr.P.C. to refuse to investigate a
case".
In the context of criminal law, investigation is a process
whereby the administrative expertness, primarily that of the police
and the prosecutor, ascertains the truth or falsehood of the
information or complaint, reaches an early determination of
probable innocence or probable guilt of the person suspected of the
297
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 167
crime. Thus, those who are probably innocent are screened out and
those who are probably guilty are to face the adjudicative part of
the criminal process.
In that context, investigation means investigation by the
police. This notion is reflected in the definition of 'investigation' in
section 4(1)(e) Cr.P.C; it says that 'investigation" "includes all the
proceedings under this Code for the collection of evidence
conducted by a police officer or by any person (other than a
Magistrate) who is authorized by a Magistrate in this behalf.
But, this definition is not exhaustive; also, as section 4
itself says, the words defined in the section have meanings
assigned to them in the section, unless a different intention appears
from the subject or context. For example, under section 202
Cr.P.C.,  court, on receipt of a complaint of an offence, may
postpone the issue of process to the person accused and either
enquire into the case itself or direct an enquiry or investigation to
be made by a Justice of the Peace or by a police officer or even by
a private person; and a Court of Session may direct an investigation
to be made by any Magistrate or Justice of the Peace for the
purpose of ascertaining the truth or falsehood of the complaint.
Thus, investigation under the Code of Criminal
Procedure does not mean investigation by the police only. The
police are of course the principal agency to investigate offences,
yet, there can be investigation by a Magistrate, by a Justice of the
Peace and even by a private person.
The change under the Police Order 2002:
The Police Order, 2002, by its Article 8, establishes and
organizes the police on "functional basis" into branches, divisions,
bureaus and sections, including "investigation", "crime prevention"
and "crime against women". Thus, investigation is now a
recognizably independent branch of the police. This is made plain
hy Article 18 of the Order, which, among others, provides for the
posting of an Additional Inspector General of Police as the head of
298
investigation in a General Police Area, of a Senior Superintendent
of Police as head of investigation in a Capital City District or City
District and a Superintendent of Police as head of investigation in a
District. That Article requires that "the Investigation Wing shall be
located within the Police Station and shall be responsible to its
hierarchy in the District under the general control of officer in
charge of the police station". Clause (4) of Article 18 lays down
that-
shall be
"All registered cases
investigated by the investigating staff in
the District under the supervision of the
head of investigation".
However, the Government may, by a special or general order.
entrust investigation of offences under local or special laws as
defined in the Pakistan Penal Code and punishable with
imprisonment for a term not exceeding three yeas with or without
any other punishment to the police station staff.
Clause (5) of Article 18 of the Order is important.
Although the head of investigation in a District is, as clause (3) of
Article 18 provides, "subject to the general control of the District
Police Offices", yet the latter "shall not interfere with the process
of investigation". The relationship between the investigation head
and the District Police Officer, so provides clause (5) read with the
Explanation at the end of Article 8, is that "the head of
investigation shall....keep the District Police Officer
informed of the progress of all cases which have a bearing on
public order. The District Police Officer shall provide full support
to the head of investigation in the performance of his duties".
That the investigation is free from interference by the
local government administration is ensured by Article 33 of the
Police Order. Subject to the provisions of the Order, the head of
District Police shall, so provides Article 33, "be responsible to the
Zila Nazim for police functions under this Order but this shall not
include administration of the district police, investigation of
299
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 168
criminal cases and police functions relating to prosecution, which
shall rest with the police". It is important to note that the District
Nazim writes "the Annual Performance Report" of the head of
District Police, but this power to write the Annual Performance
Report does not seem to include the power to write such a report on
the work of the investigation branch. The Zila Nazim may however
visit a police station to find out if any person is under unlawful
detention and make an appropriate order in accordance with law.
Change of Investigation under the Police Order:
Article 18, clause (6) of the Police Order provides for
the procedure to be observed when investigation by one officer is
required to be changed and entrusted to another:
"Investigation shall not be changed
except after due deliberations and
recommendations by a board headed by
an officer not below the rank of Senior
Superintendent of Police and two
Superintendents of Police, one being in
charge of the investigation of the
concerned District".
The final order for the change of investigation "shall be passed by
head of investigation....... who shall record reasons for change of
such investigation", but if it is second change of investigation, it
can be allowed only "with the approval of Provincial Police
Officer, or the Capital City Police Officer, as the case may be".
This topic has also been discussed under the general
heading "Change or transfer of Investigation" in a later part of this
book.
Inconsistencies between the Code of Criminal Procedure and
the Police Order.
The Supreme Court, in Muhammad Bashir case (PLD
2007 SC 539, 559) observed:
"Section 18 and some other provisions
of the Police Order of 2002....
certain
carry
provisions regarding
investigation of criminal cases which
are, at least prima facie, not reconcilable
with the special and the parent
provisions on the subject ie. the
provisions of the Code of Criminal
Procedure and if it be so then what
would be the effect of such like illegal
investigation on the trials that
followed?"
The question of inconsistency or need to reconcile can arise
because the Code of Criminal Procedure is an "existing law" within
the meaning of Article 143 read with the definition of that
expression in Article 168(7) of the Constitution and the Police
Order 2002, although a legacy of martial law, is a Provincial Law.
The Code of Criminal Procedure is, under the Constitution, a
concurrent subject. The conflict or inconsistency, if any, will
therefore have to be resolved with reference to Article 143, which
provides that if a Provincial Law is repegnant to an existing law,
the existing law will prevail and the Provincial Law shall, to the
extent of repugnancy, be void.
The Supreme Court did not, in Muhammad Bashir case,
identify the provisions in Article 18 of the Police Order which are
"not reconcilable with the special and parent provisions on the
subject i.e. the provisions of the Code of Criminal Procedure"
because that question was not directly in issue before the Supreme
Court. When such a question is raised in the facts of a particular
case, and the answer returned is that the provisions of the Code will
prevail, then the further question namely what is the effect of
"such-like illegal investigation on the trials that followed" will turn
on the provisions of the Code itself and some well-known general
principles. For example, section 156 of the Code, by its sub-section
(2) provides:
300
301
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 169
"No proceedings of a police officer in
any such case (i.e. investigation into
cognizable cases) shall at any stage be
called in question on the ground that the
case was one which such officer was not
empowered under this section to
investigate".
It may be stated here that so far the courts do not seem to
have been confronted with such a constitutional question. In some
cases, the questions raised were as to the competence of the police
to investigate cases and of changing investigations and the courts
seem to have assumed that the governing law is the Police Order,
2002. Thus, in Aziz Ahmad v Provincial Police Officer (PLD 2005
Lah. 185), it was held that "the spirit of Article 18(6) of the Police
Order 2002 is to discourage re-investigations. That is why re-
investigation has been made difficult and a clear procedure has
been provided"; in Imran Shaukat v Incharge Investigation (2006
MLD 501) that view was re-iterated and in Muhamamd Farooq
Khan v State (2007 PCr.L J. 89), the SHO had entrusted the
investigation to one of his subordinates presumably under section
57(1) Cr.P.C. This was held to "be in clear violation of Article
18(4) of the Police Order, 2002". This violation, it was held
further, "may not have the effect of vitiating the trial, it will
certainly damage the fairness of the investigation, one of the main
objects sought to be achieved by the Police Order..........".
Basic Functions of investigation:
As to what are the basic functions of 'investigation', we
may again emphasize that the definition of the term is not
exhaustive; it is inclusive and all that it says, as regards the
investigative functions, is that it "includes all the proceedings
under this Code (of Criminal Procedure) for the collection of
evidence conducted by a police officer......... ". That necessarily
means that collection of evidence, though one of the primary
functions, is not the only investigative function of the police.
302
Besides the collection of evidence, the other basic investigative
functions that need to be identified are -
i)
iii)
iv)
determining whether the alleged crime has
been committed;
detecting the possible offender;
apprehending that person;
formation of a prima facie opinion on the
basis of the evidence collected and other
matters as to the truth or falsehood of the
information and the probable guilt or
innocence of the suspect.
Reference in this behalf may usefully be made to section
157(1) Cr.P.C.. which provides that if from information received or
otherwise, the officer in charge of the police station has reason to
suspect the commission of a cognizable offence, he or an officer
deputed by him shall proceed to the spot "to investigate the facts
and circumstances of the case and if necessary to take measures for
the discovery and arrest of the offender".
There are however some observations in Muhammad
Bashir case (PLD 2007 SC 539, 548. 557) which need to be
considered. In the context of investigation, the learned Judge
wrote:
"And "investigation' as defined in
section 4(1)(b) of the said Code means
only the collection of evidence and no
more".
As if to leave no doubt as to what the learned Judge intended to
hold, he added-
"Therefore, in any criminal proceedings.
the job of a police officer only is to
collect evidence and to place the same
along with the information before the
303
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 170
and that-
competent Magistrate in the form of a
report in terms of section 173 Cr.P.C",
"Needless to say that determination of
guilt or innocence of accused persons
would be a futile desire if no evidence
was available with the Courts of that
purpose. The Code of Criminal
Procedure, therefore,
devised
mechanism for collection of evidence
and gave it the name of investigation".
The conclusion that "investigation" means "only the collection of
evidence, and no more" is, it is submitted, supportable if, and only
if, the word 'includes' in section 4(1)(1) is read as 'means", so as to
make the definition exhaustive. There seems to be no compelling
reason to do so. The only other way out of the difficulty seems to
be to confine those observations to the facts of that case only.
Discretion not to investigate:
There is under section 157(1), proviso (b), discretion in
the police not to investigate a case, even through an FIR disclosing
the commission of a cognizable case has been registered "if it
appears to the officer in charge of a police station that there is no
sufficient ground for entering on an investigation". Thus, while
there is no power in the police officer to refuse to record an FIR
provided the information conveyed to him disclosed the
commission of a cognizable offence, the provisions of section 157
Cr. P. C. "equip a police officer only with a discretion to refuse to
investigate a case"; nor does -
"the recording of an FIR mean that the
SHO or a police officer deputed by him
was obliged to investigate the case or to
go through the whole length of
304
investigation of the case mentioned
therein or that any accused person
nominated
be
therein
must
arrested." (Muhammad Bashir v
SHO-PLD 2007 SC 539, 550, 552).
Investigation and Women:
Under section 156B Cr.P.C no police officer below the
rank of Superintendent of Police shall investigate an offence of
Zina under the Offence of Zina (Enforcement of Hadood)
Ordinance 1979; nor shall a woman accused be arrested without the
permission of the court. This provision is obviously for the
protection of women.
Then, section 48 Cr.P.C. provides for a situation in
which the police needs entry into a place for the arrest of a person
and the place is occupied by a woman. The police shall before
forcing its entry into such a place "give notice to such woman that
she is at liberty to withdraw and shall afford her every reasonable
facility for withdrawing and may then break open the apartment
and enter it".
Section 51 Cr.P.C. empowers the police to search the
person of an arrestee, but when the arrestee is a woman, section 52
Cr.P.C. requires that "the search shall be made by another woman
with strict regard to decency".
Section 167, sub-section (5), forbids remand to police
custody of a woman during investigation except in cases of dacoity
and gatl, and that too for reasons to be recorded in writing.
Investigation of such female accused can be in the prison in the
presence of an officer of jail and a female police officer.
Investigation of offence under Section 295C PPC:
An offence against section 295C PPC (Defiling of the
sacred name of the Holy Prophet) can be, section 156A Cr.P.C. so
305
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 171
provides, investigated by a police officer not below the rank of
Superintendent of Police.
Pre-arrest investigation:
What usually happens is that a possible crime comes to
the attention of the police after it has been committed. But it may
happen, e.g. in victimless crimes, such as gambling and narcotics,
that the police initiates investigation of a crime even before it is
completed. In such cases, the police often use under-cover agents
and other investigative information aimed at trapping potential
offenders.
Then, there is pre-arrest investigation aimed primarily at
determining (i) whether the crime actually was committed; and (ii)
if it was committed, whether there is sufficient material as to the
guilt of a particular person to justify his arrest.
Arrest:
Chapter 5
Arrest and Custody
The term 'arrest' has various definitions; a commonly
accepted meaning is the taking of a person into custody for the
purpose of charging him with a crime. This ordinarily involves the
officer's exercise of physical control over the suspect. The general
principle is that to make an arrest the officer must have reasonable
grounds or probable cause to believe that the person to be arrested
is the offender. The authority for this general principle is to be
found in Article 10 of the Constitution. That Article among others,
requires that the person arrested must be informed, as soon as may
be, "of the grounds for such arrest". Grounds for the arrest must
therefore exist before the arrest takes place, Then, the grounds must
be reasonable grounds, that is, grounds upon which a reasonable
man can act, or otherwise the arrest will be illegal. As was pointed
out in Muhammad Bashir case (PLD 2007 SC 539, at 550) the
power to arrest is subject to the conditions prescribed in section 54
Cr PC:
"...irrespective of the fact whether
an FIR did or did not stand recorded and
also irrespective of the fact whether
person did or did not stand nominated as
an accused person, a police officer could
arrest a person only after the conditions
prescribed therefore, by the said section
54 stood satisfied.
It must, therefore, be kept in mind that
mere registration of an FIR could bring
no harm to a person against whom it had
been recorded. No one, consequently,
need fear a fake FIR. And if a police
officer arrested a person in the absence
of the requisite material justifying the
same and only on the pretext of such a
person being mentioned in the FIR then
such would be an abuse of power by him
and the remedy for such a misuse of
power would not be to permit another
abuse of law by allowing an unlawful
exercise of collection of evidence to
assess the veracity of allegations leveled
through the information conveyed to a
SHO before recording of an FR. The
remedy lies elsewhere".
'Arrest' is a public act that may seriously interfere with
the defendant's liberty, whether he is free on bail or not, drain his
financial resources, curtail his associations, subject him to public
obloquy (abuse, censure) and create anxiety in him, his family and
his friends. (Marion, 404 US 307 (1971).
As used in criminal statutes, the word "arrest' is a term
of art; it is constituted by a physical seizure or touching of the
arrested person's body, with a view to his being taken into custody
in connection with a criminal charge but there may be arrest by
306
307
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 172
mere words. According to Lord Denning (The Due Process of
Law" p. 103) "when a police constable says to a man 'come along
with me, I am taking you to the station, that is an arrest". It should
be noted that 'arrest' is a continuing act; it starts with the arrester
taking a person into custody (by action or words restraining him
from moving anywhere beyond the arrester's control) and it
continues until the person so restrained is either released from
custody or having been brought before a Magistrate, is remanded in
custody by the Magistrate's judicial act. In practice, since the
creation of organized police forces an arrested person, on being
taking into custody, is brought to a police station and it is there that
he is detained until he is either brought before a Magistrate or
released on bail. In modem conditions any other way of dealing
with an arrested person would be impracticable; provisions for buil
by the police are drafted on the assumption that this will be done".
(Holgate-Mohammad v Duke-(1984) 1 All ER 1054, 1056).
Section 46 Cr.P.C. provides that in making an arrest, the
police officer or other person shall actually touch or confine the
body of the person to be arrested, unless there be a submission to
the custody by word or action. If there is resistance or attempt to
evade arrest, the police officer or other person may use all means
necessary to effect the arrest. The words "all means" are very wide;
they include the act of pursuing the offender and the taking of
assistance from others in effecting the arrest. Under section 59 read
with section 46 Cr. P. C., a person who affords assistance, even
though the crime had not been committed within his view, is as
much protected as the person within whose view the crime had
been committed. (Sultan Ahmad v State PLD 1990 SC 206, 211).
Sections 47 to 53 Cr.P.C. authorize police officers to
enter into any place to arrest the required person, even to break into
any such place, to search the person of the arrestee and to seize any
weapon from him.
Persons who may be arrested and by whom:
There are two categories of persons who may be arrested
without warrant: Section 54 Cr.P.C. enumerates one category of
persons and the power to arrest here is in "any police officer", and
section 55 enumerates the second category of persons and the
power to arrest under it is in "any officer in charge of a police
station". Included in the first category are-
1)
2)
3)
4)
any person "who has been concerned in any
cognizable offence or against whom a
reasonable complaint has been made or
credible information has been received or a
reasonable suspicion exists of his having been
so concerned";
any person "having in his possession without
lawful excuse, the burden of proving which
shall lie on such person, any implement of
house-breaking":
any proclaimed offender,
any person found in possession of property
reasonably suspected to be stolen property:
5)
any person who obstructs a police officer in
the execution of his duty or escapes or
attempts to escape, from lawful custody;
6)
a deserter from armed forces;
7)
8)
any person who has been concerned or is
reasonably suspected to have been concerned
in the commission of an offence outside
Pakistan;
any released convict who has committed a
breach of any rule made under section 565(3)
Cr.P.C; and
308
309
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 173
9)
any person for whose arrest a requisition has
been received from another police officer.
The second category of persons who may be arrested
without warrant under Section 55 Cr.P.C. include-
b)
c)
any person found taking precautions to
conceal his presence under the circumstances
which afford reason to believe that he is doing
so for the purpose of committing a cognizable
offence;
any person "who has no ostensible means of
subsistence or who cannot give a satisfactory
account of himself;
any person who is reputed to be an habitual
robber, house-breaker or thief etc.
We have seen that the power to arrest seriously affects
the most cherished right to liberty of citizens, guaranteed by no less
an authority than the Constitution itself and must therefore be
construed strictly, that is, every doubt must be resolved in favour of
the citizen. To repeat what the Supreme Court has said in
Muhammad Bashir case, the power to arrest under these sections is
subject to the fulfillment of the conditions mentioned therein; those
conditions provide the justification for arrest without warrant, non-
fulfillment whereof is abuse of power.
With these prefatory remarks, we proceed to consider
some of those provisions, which deserve special treatment.
Arrest in Cognizable Cases:
We have noticed that the general principle is that to
make an arrest the police must have reasonable ground or probable
cause to believe that the person to be arrested is the offender. In the
310
words of Section 54, the police officer must be satisfied that the
person to be arrested has been concerned in the commission of the
offence or is reasonably suspected to be so concerned. Merely
because a person is named in the FIR is not a sufficient justification
to arrest.
Arrest for possession of house-breaking implement:
This gives a very wide power to the police. No definition
of "house-breaking implement" has been given, and this makes the
power all the more awful. There, thus, seems to be no basis in law
for depriving a citizen of his liberty, or to leave him at the mercy
and unguided discretion of the police.
These are serious considerations for the removal of this
provision from the Statute Book.
Arrest under Section 55 Cr.P.C:
While arrest under clause (a) of section 55 Cr.P.C. read
with Section 109, clause (a), is understandable, there seems to be
no basis in law for the arrest of a person covered by clause (b) or
(c) of section 55. An unemployed or jobless person may well be, in
the opinion of a police officer, a person "who has no ostensible
means of subsistence". And why should a citizen be required to
give a satisfactory account of himself? Is it not sufficient that he is
a citizen of Pakistan? Clause (c) punishes status, and that too based
on reputation-one who is reputed to be a habitual robber, house-
breaker or thief etc- and not an act, and the question is, does the
Constitution permit the imprisonment of a person for a mere
reputation or for what is a man's status or condition and not an act?
Item 46 of the Concurrent Legislative List authorizes the
Legislature to create "offences against laws with respect to any of
the matters in this List", and an offence is an act or omission made
punishable by law. Mere intention or a bare desire is not an
offence, and nobody can be imprisoned for it. If one can be
imprisoned and deprived of his liberty for having the reputation of
being a thief, robber etc, he may as well be imprisoned for being
311
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 174
mentally ill or for having a common cold. The power given by
section 55, clauses (b) and (c), therefore seems to exceed the
authority that the Legislature may exercise in enacting its criminal
law.
In Lawrence Robinson v California (370 US 660; 8 L Ed
2d 758), it was an offence to be addicted to the use of narcotics.
This was held by the US Supreme Court to amount to punishing
status and the conviction was set aside on various grounds,
including that such a punishment will be cruel and that it would
amount to treating the man as something less human.
Arrest by persons other than Police:
A Justice of the Peace for any local area has, under
section 22A Cr.P.C., the power to make arrest and to exercise for
that purpose the powers of police officers under sections 54 and 55
Cr.P.C.
Even a private person has power under section 59
Cr.P.C. "to arrest ay person who in his view commits a non-
bailable and cognizable offence, or any proclaimed
offender...........
The procedure as to how further to deal with an arrestee
under section 22A is that the Justice of the Peace shall take or
cause to be taken the arrestee to the officer in charge of the nearest
police station and furnish a report of the circumstances of the arrest
and the said officer shall then re-arrest the person, and under
section 59 is that the private person shall, without unnecessary
delay, make over the arrestee to a police officer or take or cause the
arrestee to be taken to the nearest police station. The police officer
shall, if there is reason to believe that the arrestee comes under the
provisions of section 54, re-arrest him.
Important questions can arise when the person sought to
be arrested resists his arrest or tries to escape, is given a chase and
causes hurt or death.
In Sultan Ahmad v State (PLD 1970 SC 206), Sultan
Ahmad accused armed with a pistol and Rafiq accused armed with
a rifle went to the house of Nazir Ahmad PW, knocked at the door.
which was opened by Rabia deceased. Both the accused fired and
killed Rabia. Nazar Hussain and Talib Hussain PWs saw the killing
and ran after the accused. On the way, others, including Ali
Muhammad deceased, joined in the chase. The accused fired at the
pursuers, who remained undeterred and continued the chase.
Ultimately, Ali Muhammad deceased overtook Sultan Ahmad
accused and tried to catch hold of him. Sultan Ahmad accused told
him to desist and when Ali Muhammad did not, Sultan fired at and
killed Ali Muhammad.
On behalf of Sultan Ahmad accused, the plea taken was
that he had killed Ali Muhammad in self defence, for under section
59 Cr.P.C. a private person's right to arrest was limited to only a
culprit who had committed a cognizable and non-bailable offence
within his view, and Rabia's murder had not been committed
within the view of Ali Muhammad deceased, and he had therefore
no legal right to pursue or arrest him. It was held:
"While section 59 Cr.P.C. provides for
the circumstances in which a private
person may arrest an offender, section
46 lays down how is that arrest to be
effected and authorizes the use of all
means necessary to execute that purpose.
the protection under section 59 Cr.P.C.
afforded to a private person for the
apprehension of an offender who
commits a cognizable and non-bailable
offence in his presence would be
available to him if he can establish his
connection with the crime either by sight
or sound, that is to say, not only if he
312
313
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 175
personally witnesses the crime but also if
he comes to know of it from what he
hears about it from persons concerned in
the crime immediately after the
commission of that crime".
The Supreme Court went on to hold that -
to
section 59 should not be
construed so as to burden the legislature
with the intention that in providing the
shield to private individuals
apprehend the culprits who commit
cognizable and non-bailable offences in
their presence, it had intended that this
shield is to be limited only for those
individuals who actually see the
commission of the crime by their own
eyes and is not available to those who
come to their assistance on their outcry
for help. Such a restricted view, in our
opinion, would destroy the much wanted
but rarely displayed public spirit on the
part of the neighbours and others who
might come to the rescue of the victims
of dastardly crimes and help them in
bringing the culprits to book.........
It was therefore held that Sultan Ahmad accused was not justified
in killing Ali Muhammad.
Custody:
The word 'custody' has occurred in section 46 Cr.P.C..
as also in the definition of 'arrest'. The essence of custody is that
"there should be lack of freedom to move about where and when
one pleases, coupled with a physical power immediately available
to prevent an attempt at breaking the restrictions imposed to
314
distinguish from the power subsequently to punish for the breach
of those restrictions; and if a person is told that he must not go
beyond certain boundaries and he sees or is told that if he did.
physical force would be available to prevent him from doing so,
there would then be no difference in kind between his confinement
or custody and that of a person confined in jail. Thus, an order
confining a person to the limits of his house will be confinement in
custody. (Muhammad Anwar case PLD 1963 Lah. 109; Begum
Nazir Abdul Hamid-PLD 1974 Lah. 7, 16-17).
The person arrested will, after his arrest, be taken to the.
police station which usually has a jail or lock-up or similar police
facility. There he is 'booked', a clerical process by which an
administrative record is made of the arrest. Thus, Art. 167 of the
Police Order, 2002, requires a prescribed daily diary to be
maintained at every police station and names of all complainants,
persons arrested and offences charged, the weapons or property
taken to be recorded therein.
Safeguards as to arrest and detention:
This topic has received a somewhat detailed treatment
under the "Constitutional Criminal Procedure" part of this book
under Article 10 of the Constitution. There, besides discussing the
scope and reach of Article 10 with the aid of corresponding
provisions in the US Constitution and the Indian Constitution, there
is a discussion on "arrest". "custody", "custodial interrogation" and
as to how the constitutional protection provided by Article 10 has
affected sections 60, 61 and 81 Cr.P.C. Reference in that
connection has been made to the Indian case of Ajaib Singh (AIR
1953 SC 10) where the view taken was that the protection given by
Article 22(1) of the Indian Constitution (Article 10 of our
Constitution) applies to arrest without warrants only, and to Bazal
Ahmad (PLD 1957 (WP) Lah. 398), where a different view has
been taken and it has been held that the protection applies both to
arrests with or without warrant. This latter view goes to the validity
of sections 60, 61 and 81 Cr.P.C., for the Constitution prevails over
an ordinary law.
315
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 176
It may be noted here that in the Code of Criminal
Procedure, as re-enacted in India in 1973, the view that the
protection is available even when the arrest is in pursuance of
warrant has been adopted. (Sections 50,55,75 of the India Code of
Criminal Procedure, 1973).
Chapter 6
Remand to custody during Investigation:
Both under Article 10(2) of the Constitution and section
61 Cr.P.C., an arrestee cannot be kept in custody, for more than 24
hours, in the language of Article 10(2). "without the authority of a
Magistrate" and in the language of section 61 Cr.P.C, "in the
absence of a special order of a Magistrate under section 167"
Cr.P.C.
Section 167 Cr.P.C. provides that if the investigation
cannot be completed within 24 hours and there are grounds for
believing that the accusation or information is well founded, the
investigating officer shall forthwith transmit to the nearest
Magistrate a copy of the entries prescribed by section 172 Cr.P.C.
relating to the case and shall at the same time forward the accused
to such Magistrate, who may "from time to time, authorize the
detention of the accused in such custody as such Magistrate thinks
fit". If such Magistrate "has no jurisdiction to try the case or send it
for trial and considers further detention unnecessary, he may order
the accused to be forwarded to a Magistrate having such
jurisdiction". The Magistrate may authorize the detention of the
accused in such custody. police or judicial, for a term not
exceeding 15 days in the whole. Section 167, by its sub-section (5).
makes special provisions for the protection of women.
A remand can be (i) remand to police custody; (ii)
remand to judicial custody and (iii) remand on bail. Here we shall
deal with the first two; remand on bail will be dealt with later.
Section 167 provides for a situation when the
investigation cannot be completed within 24 hours. This section is
in the nature of an exception to section 61 Cr.P.C. which provides
that a police officer shall not detain an arrested person for a longer
period than under all the circumstances of the case is reasonable,
and such period shall not in the absence of a special order of a
Magistrate under section 167 exceed 24 hours. These two sections
contemplate that an investigation is to be completed within 24
hours of the arrest of a person but if the investigation cannot be
completed within that period, then the police officer shall forward
the accused to the nearest Magistrate (not necessarily the trial
Magistrate), along with a copy of the entries in the diary
maintained under section 172 of the Cr.P.C. (Muhammad Siddiq v
Province of Sindh - PLD 1992 Kar. 538). The Magistrate to whom
the accused is so forwarded may authorize detention of the accused
for such custody as such Magistrates thinks fit for a term not
exceeding 15 days in the whole. If the Magistrate is not the trial
Magistrate, and he thinks that further detention is unnecessary_he...
may order the accused to be forwarded to the trial Magistrate.
Remand to police custody and judicial custody - distinction
It will be noticed that the power of the Magistrate to
whom the accused is forwarded under this section is to authorize
the detention of the accused in such custody as the Magistrate
thinks fit. The custody can be police custody or judicial custody
and this is a very important distinction.
The power given by section 167 cannot be exercised by
a Magistrate of 3d class at all; it cannot also be exercised by a
Magistrate of the 2nd class unless he is specially empowered in that
behalf.
Further, the Magistrate authorizing detention in the
custody of police must record his reason for so doing and send a
copy of his order with his reasons for making it to the Sessions
Judge. As was held in Muhammad Siddiq case (PLD 1992 Kar.
538), the Magistrate before whom the accused is produced is
317
316
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 177
expected to put specific questions on all aspects to ensure that the
police does not commit illegal acts.
Instructions which must guide the remand to police
custody are contained in Chapter 11-B of Volume 111 of the High
Court Rules and Orders; in that Chapter will also be found the
principles laid down for the guidance of the Magistrates in the
matter of granting remand. The propositions to be high-lighted in
view of the principles laid down in the High Court Rules and
Orders Volume III and some of the decided cases (inter- alia see
Nazir Ahmad v State-PLD 1978 SC 236; J.C. Shah v Ramswami
- AIR 1969 S.C. 1014; Ghulam Sarwar v State-1984 P. Cr. L. J.
2588 noticed in Khan Asfandyarwali v Federation - PLD 2001
S.C. 607, 608, 609; Muhammad Siddiq v Province of Sind - PLD
1992 Kar. 358; Azmat Ali v State PLD 1999 Pesh. 39) may be
stated as follows:
(1)
(2)
The provisions of sections 61 and 167
Cr.P.C. affect the liberty of a person and
must therefore be strictly construed, i.e.
if there is any doubt, that will be
resolved in favour of the arrested person;
Remands, remands to police custody in
particular, are not to be given as a matter
of routine. This is clear from the fact that
the police officer forwarding the accused

to transmit to the Magistrate a copy of
the entries in the diary maintained under
section 172 Cr.P.C. The object of the

and the presence of the police diary
before him is to enable an independent
judicial authority to apply its mind to the
facts of the case and also to provide to
318

complain as to excesses, if any, of the
police during his detention in their
custody.
It should be obvious from a bare reading
of the provisions of section 167 that the
function of the Magistrate under this
section is a judicial function. He must
record reasons for sending the accused
back to the police custody and to ensure
that the reasons are good reasons, he
must send a copy of his order to the
Sessions Judge.
It necessarily implies from the power to
refuse remand to either custody that

the arrested person should be released on

Chapter 7
Liberty and vigilance
The power to authorize the detention of an arrestee must
be guided by the inspired saying that "the condition upon which
God hath given liberty to man is eternal vigilance which condition
if he break, servitude is at once the consequence of his crime, and
the punishment of his guilt. "(John Philpot Curran, quoted in
Manzoor Ahmad v Malik Yaqoob PLD 1988 Lah. 627, 632).
Vigilance in the context of this power means vigilance not only on
the part of the arrestee but also on the part of the Magistrates and
the Sessions Judges who have been, by these provisions.
constituted the guardians of this "most cherished right" to liberty. It
is, said Justice Bradley in that landmark opinion in Boyd (116 US
616 (1886)) "the duty of courts to be watchful for the constitutional
319
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 178
rights of the citizen and against any stealthy encroachments
thereon. The motto should be obsta principiis", (which means resist
the first approaches or encroachments). The Sessions Judges have
an important supervisory role to play over the Magistrate's remand
power. Under Section 167(3) Cr.P.C. the Magistrate must give
reasons for remand to police custody and sub-section (4) thereof
requires that the order containing such reasons shall be forwarded
to the Sessions Judge. Remand to police custody is a serious matter
and the object is to ensure that the Magistrate applies his judicial
mind and the Sessions Judge keeps a vigilant eye on the exercise of
that power by examining the reasons for remand sent to him under
section 167(4) Cr.P.C.
Chapter 8
Post-arrest investigation: Sections 160 to 162 Cr.P.C.
Post-arrest investigation varies with the fact situation.
There will be little post-arrest investigation where the arrestee has
been caught red-handed. In other cases, investigative activities may
consist of witness interviews, inspection of the scene of occurrence
and taking into possession of things relevant to the crime, search of
the suspect's home.
Post-arrest investigation offers one additional source of
information, namely, the person of the arrestee. If there is a
question of identity, there can be an identification parade or
identification test; that is, the arrestee may be placed in a line-up
where he can be viewed by the witnesses for the purpose of
connecting him with the crime. He can be required to provide
hand-writing or other samples. During the course of investigation,
the Investigating Officer has power under sections 160 and 161
Cr.P.C. to require the attendance of any person who may be
acquainted with the circumstances of the case and may examine
such person orally. Statements made orally under sections 160 and
161 Cr.P.C. may be reduced into writing. No such statement will
be signed by the person making it; nor shall it be, as section 162
Cr.P.C. provides, used for any purpose, at an enquiry or trial in
320
respect of any offence under investigation, except for the purpose
of contradicting such person when he appears as a witness. In other
words, statement of a witness before the police cannot be used as
evidence at the trial; the only way to use it is that when he appears
as witness to testify at the trial, he may be cross-examined to bring
out inconsistencies between his police statement and the statement
at the trial,
In enjoining that "no statement by any person
.......shall, if reduced into writing, be signed by the person making
it", the intention is to provide a statutory safeguard against
improper police practices (Zahiruddin v Emperor - AIR 1947 PC
75; to encourage the free disclosure of information or to protect the
person making the statement from a supposed unreliability of
police testimony as to alleged statements or both (Pakala Narayana
Swami v Emperor AIR 1939 PC 46, 51). Sub-section (2) of this
section provides that "Nothing in this section shall be deemed to
apply to any statement falling within the provisions of Article 46(1)
or to affect the provisions of Article 40 of the Qanoon-e-Shahdat
1984",
Proviso to Section 162(1) stands partly repealed:
The first Proviso to subsection (1) of section 162, in so
far as it provides that "when any witness is called in such inquiry
or trial whose statement has been reduced into writing as aforesaid
(that is, under section 161 Cr.P.C) the court shall, on the request of
the accused, refer to such writing and direct that the accused be
furnished with a copy thereof......." stands impliedly repealed by
sections 241A and 265C Cr.P.C, which provide that in all cases
instituted upon a police report, copies of the statements under
section 161 Cr.P.C. shall be supplied, free of cost to the accused,
not later than seven days before the commencement of the trial.
Copies of such statements "must now be supplied by the State
seven days before the commencement of the trial and it is not
necessary to wait till the witness is called by the prosecution or the
321
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 179
accused asks for them" (Z A Bhutto case PLD 1979 SC 53, para
276 of the Judgment of Anwar-ul-Haq, C.J).
Even an entry in the diary u/s 172 Cr.P.C. may be treated as
statement u/s 161:
By section 161(3) Cr.P.C. where a statement has been
made to the police by a person during investigation, the police
officer, "shall make a separate record of the statement.......
Where however the police officer does not do so, but proceeds to
incorporate it in the case diary kept under section 172 Cr.P.C, the
said statement should be construed as a statement under section
161 Cr.P.C., provided of course it is in substance and essence a
statement of the witness and not merely a statement of the
circumstances ascertained through investigation. Thus, it is, so
wrote Anwar-ul-Haq, CJ. in Z A Bhutto case (Para 278 of his
Judgment):
"the nature of the statement and not the
label given to it which will determine its
real character. The provisions of section
265C are salutary and enacted for the
benefit of the accused, conferring as they
do a valuable right in his favour of his
being apprised of the case set up against
him. This right cannot be taken away or
evaded by allowing the investigating
officer misusing his authority by
incorporating in the case diary the
statements recorded by him during
investigation which though in spirit and
essence fall within the purview of
section 161 Cr.P.C. but are erroneously
or mischievously embodied by him in
the case diaries.......
Chapter 9
Interrogation:
Interrogation of the suspect or the person accused, when
he is in police custody, is an investigative tool for obtaining
evidence, like a search or a blood test. It is a low visibility area and
most of the sins against constitutional and legal rights are
committed during interrogation by investigation agencies.
The power to investigate is implicit in section 161(1)
Cr.P.C: the heading of that section "Examination of witnesses by
police" is misleading, for power, under section 161(1), is to
examine orally any person supposed to be acquainted with the
facts and circumstances of the case". The power to examine is
therefore not limited to witnesses only. The section is drawn in a
general way relating to "any person". That "the words in their
ordinary meaning would include any person though he may
thereafter be accused seems plain. Investigation into crime often
includes the examination of a number of persons none of whom
may or all of whom may be suspected at the time..." (Pakala
Narayana Swami v Emperor AIR 1939 PC 46, 51)
Custodial interrogation means "questioning initiated by
law enforcement officers after a person has been taken into custody
or otherwise deprived of his freedom of action in any significant
way (Chief Justice Warren in Miranda 384 US 436; 16 L Ed 2d
694-1966). The term 'interrogation' refers not only to express
questioning but also to its functional equivalent, "to any words or
actions on the part of the police (other than those normally
attendant to arrest and custody) that the police should know are
reasonably likely to elicit an incriminating response from the
suspect. This latter portion of this definition focuses primarily upon
the perceptions of the suspect, rather than the intent of the
police. A practice that the police should know is reasonably
likely to evoke an incriminating response from a suspect thus
322
323
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 180
amounts to interrogation". (Rhode Island v Innis-446 US 291,64
L Ed 2d 297 (1980).
It was held in Ashcraft (322 US 143; 88 L Ed 1192) that
the detention and questioning of a suspect for a long period of time
say for thirty six hours and even for one hour is "inherently
coercive". As Chief Justice Warren stressed in Miranda, "the
modem practice of in-custody interrogations is psychological
rather than physically oriented...... Interrogations still take place in
privacy. Privacy results in secrecy and this in turn results in a gap
in our knowledge as to what in fact goes on in the interrogation
rooms. Thus, 'coercion' or 'torture" can be physical as
well as psychological, or as was said in Begum Shamim Afridi case
(PLD 1974 Lah. 120) it can be mental as well as physical.
The procedural safeguards deemed necessary to
neutralize the compulsion and pressure inherent in the interrogation
atmosphere and the evils it can bring are now the familiar
"Miranda Warnings". They have already been discussed in the
Constitutional Criminal Procedure part of this book. There, the
relevance and applicability of these safeguards to investigations
and interrogations in Pakistan have also been discussed.
Chapter 10
Searches and Seizures:
To search persons and premises, and to seize
incriminating evidence, as part of the power to investigate, intimate
relationship between searches and seizures and the right against
self-incrimination and the relevance of the law as developed in
other jurisdictions to our jurisprudence, particularly to the right to
privacy as guaranteed by Article 14(1) of the Constitution of
Pakistan, are topics which have already been treated in the
Constitutional Criminal Procedure part of this book. Suffice it to
say here that the protection against unreasonable searches and
seizures is in fact protection against the violation of the privacy of
324
a person's home and property which is guaranteed by the
Constitution of Pakistan, Article 14 the dignity of man and,
subject to law, privacy of home, shall be inviolable - and that the
relationship between this right and the right against self-
incrimination guaranteed by Article 13(a) of the Constitution of
Pakistan is that searches and seizures are almost always made for
the purpose of compelling a man to provide evidence against him.
Under the Code of Criminal Procedure, sections 47, 48,
49 and 50 provide for the search of places and premises for
effecting an arrest. Section 51 authorises the arrester to search the
person of the arrestee. But when the arrestee is a woman, then.
under section 52, the search shall be made by another woman, with
strict regard to decency. The arrester may, under section 53, "take
from the person arrested any offensive weapons which he has about
his person... Under section 94 any court may issue summons or
an officer in charge of a police station may issue a written order, to
the person in whose possession or power a document or thing is
believed to be requiring him to attend and produce it, if such court
or officer considers that the protection of any document or other
thing is necessary or desirable for the purpose of any investigation.
inquiry, trial, or other proceedings. Section 95 CrPC empowers any
Magistrate, High Court or Court of Session to summon letters.
telegrams etc.
Section 96 CrPC provides that when any court has
reason to believe that a person to whom a summons or order under
sections 94 and 95(1) has been or might be addressed, will not or
would not produce such document or thing or where any document
or thing is not known to the court to be in the possession of any
person, or where the court considers that the purposes of any
enquiry, trial or other proceedings under the Code will be served by
a general search or inspection, "it may issue a search warrant and
the person to whom such warrant is directed may search or inspect
in accordance therewith and the provisions hereinafter contained".
Section 97 empowers the court, if it thinks fit, to specify in the
warrant the particular place or part thereof to which only the search
325
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 181
or inspection shall extend and the person charged with the
execution of such warrant shall then search or inspect only the
place or part so specified. Section 98 empowers a Magistrate of the
1st class to authorize by his warrant any police officer to search
houses suspected to contain stolen property, forged documents etc,
Under section 165 CrPC, if the officer incharge of the
police station or a police officer making an investigation, who has
reasonable grounds for believing that "anything necessary for the
purpose of investigation into any offence...
may be found

The general provisions as to searches are contained in

residing in or in charge of the place to be searched, to allow ingress
on the demand of the person or officer executing the warrant and if
ingress is not allowed, to proceed in accordance with section 48
Cr.P.C.. that is, use such force as is mentioned therein.
Section 103 Cr.P.C. applies to all searches under
Chapter VII of the Code of Criminal Procedure. It lays down that
before making a search, the officer or other person shall "call upon
two or more respectable inhabitants of the locality in which the
place to be searched is situate to attend and witness the search and
may issue an order in writing to them to do so". Sub-section (2) of

"The search shall be made in their

witnesses.....
The search witnesses may, subsection (2) of section 103 provides
further, be summoned to give evidence at the trial. The occupant of
the place searched or somebody on his behalf shall always be
permitted to attend the search and be provided with the list
prepared under this section. A person who refuses or neglects to
attend and witness a search under this section commits an offence
against section 187 PPC.
The application of section 103 Cr.P.C. to different fact

In Mushtaq Ahmad, at the time of search, people from
the locality had gathered, yet none of them was associated with the
search and the witnesses to the search were police officials only.
Non-compliance with the requirements of Section 103 Cr.P.C., it
was held. "was not warranted and justified" and the conviction for
the alleged possession of a Kalashnikov and hand grenades was set
aside.
Section 103 Cr.P.C. and Article 40 of Qanun-e-Shahadat
1984 are to be read together. If the accused voluntarily leads to
some discovery, section 103 does not apply. In such a case, the
police officials are as good witnesses as any other person. The
weight to be attached to their evidence is a question of fact (Mir
Ahmed case 1995 SCMR 614)
Constitutional aspects of searches and seizures
We have seen that what is protected by the American 4
Amendment, namely, the right to one's privacy against arbitrary
330
intrusion by the police or other governmental authorities, is
protected by 'dignity of man' and 'privacy of home' rights
guaranteed by Article 14 of the Constitution of Pakistan. It follows
that in order to preserve the Constitution inviolate and in the
interest of integrity of the courts, all laws and governmental actions
must conform to the Constitution, Article 14, or they are void. For
example, the evil of a 'general warrant was that, the arbitrary
power it granted by leaving it to officials conducting the search to
decide who, where, when and what to search, and thereby placing
the liberty and privacy of every man in the hands of the police. In
England. notorious abuse of this power had. by the mid-1700.
resulted in its abolition; and it is well-known that the American 4"
Amendment was, inter-alia, aimed at that. The power under section
96 Cr.P.C to issue a warrant authorizing 'a general search or
inspection' will therefore be hit by Article 14's protection against
privacy.
Then, the court can always be called upon to determine,
in the facts of a case, whether a search and seizure had violated the
right to privacy guaranteed by Article 14 and, if there be a
violation, invite it to hold that the evidence obtained by such
violation is inadmissible. The argument can be that the scheme
underlying the above mentioned provisions of the Code read with
the Article 14's right of privacy is that ostensibly there should be
no search by the police without a warrant issued by a court or
Magistrate and that a search without such warrant, except in cases
of emergency, is prima facie inadmissible. For example under
section 165 CrPC, the power of an investigating officer to search a
place is subject to the conditions that there are reasonable grounds
for believing that something relevant to the offence may be found
in a place and that such thing cannot in his opinion be otherwise
obtained without more delay. Reasons are always for the court, and
absence of "reasonable grounds for believing" will make the search
unreasonable; and the fact that the search can brook delay, shows
that the legislative intention, conformable with the constitutional
protection provided by Article 14, is that only in exigent
circumstances can there be a search and seizure without warrant.
Indeed, both these questions will ultimately be for the court trying
331
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 184
the offence to decide; and if it holds that the evidence sought to be
produced was obtained in violation of the accused's right
guaranteed by Article 14 of the Constitution, the court may in the
performance of its duty to preserve the Constitution inviolate, hold
that the evidence is inadmissible.
Chapter 11
Confession during Investigation:
Besides the evidence collected by the police, such as
statements of witnesses, recovery of incriminatory articles etc, an
accused person may voluntarily offer to confess his guilt during the
course of investigation. The police may record such a confession
but it will not be admissible at the trial, for Articles 38 and 39 of
Qanun-e-Shahadat forbid their admission, the presumption being
that such confessions are involuntary and inherently unreliable.
Under Article 39, "no confession made by any person whilst he is
in the custody of the police unless it be made in the immediate
presence of a Magistrate shall be proved as against such person".
The procedure for the recording of such a confession is provided
by sections 164 and 364 Cr.P.C. Such a confession can be recorded
only by a Magistrate of the 1st class or a specially empowered
Magistrate of the 2nd class. The Magistrate shall ensure that the
confession is made voluntarily, and shall explain to the accused
that he is not bound to make it and that if he does, it may be used as
evidence against him. Such a confession shall be recorded and
signed in the manner provided in Section 364 Cr.P.C, and shall
bear the Magistrate's certificate in terms stated in section 164
Cr.P.C.
and 170 seem to apply to cases in which investigation has been
completed within 24 hours. Under section 169, if the investigating
officer finds that there is no sufficient evidence or reasonable
ground for suspicion to justify the forwarding of the accused to a
Magistrate for an order of remand under section 167, he shall
release the accused on his executing a bond, with or without
sureties, and may direct him to appear, if and when so required.
before the Ilaga Magistrate. But if there is sufficient evidence or
reasonable ground for suspicion to justify the forwarding of the
accused to a Magistrate, the investigating officer shall, as is
provided in section 170, forward the accused to the Ilaqa
Magistrate or if the offence is bailable the investigating officer
shall take security from him to appear before the said Magistrate.
The investigating officer shall, in such cases, also send any weapon
or other articles recovered during investigation to the Magistrate
and also require the complainant and the witnesses to execute a
bond to appear before the Magistrate and "prosecute or give
evidence in the matter of the charge against the accused".
Section 171 Cr.P.C. forbids the complainant or
witnesses to be required to accompany a police officer to the court
or otherwise to be subjected to unnecessary restraint or
inconvenience for their attendance at the trial. But if the
complainant or a witness refuses to attend or to execute a bond
under section 170, then the investigation officer may forward him
in custody to the Magistrate "who may detain him in custody until
he executes such bond or until the hearing of the case is
completed"
Chapter 12
POLICE ACTION UNDER SECTIONS 169 AND 170 Cr.P.C.
Sections 61 and 167 Cr.P.C. relate to the power of the
Magistrates to remand to custody, police or judicial, when
investigation cannot be completed within 24 hours. Sections 169

POLICE REPORT OR CHALLAN UNDER SECTION 173
Cr.P.C.

(even if he 1.

the Public Prosecutor, forward to the Ilaqa Magistrate a police
report in the prescribed form. This is commonly known as the
challan; in the UK and USA the most common titles used for such
a document are the complaint, the information and the indictment.
This is the formal initiation of criminal prosecution by means of a
charging document before a court, a document containing the basic
statement of the charge.
Where the investigation has not been completed within
14 days of the First Information Report under section 154 Cr.P.C.
the section requires an interim report to be filed in the prescribed

report.
A copy of the report filed under this section shall, on his

Opinion of Investigation Officer is not binding on court
What is contained in the report under section 173 as to
the guilt or innocence of an accused person is a mere opinion of the
investigating officer; it is not evidence and is not binding upon the
court (Falak Sher v State - PLD 1967 SC 425, Muhammad Bashir
v SHO-PLD 2007 SC 539,548)
Cancellation of a case:
Cancellation of a case on a report under section 173, it
has been held, is an administrative, and not a judicial, act (Bahadur
v State PLD 1985 SC 62; Mohammad Alam v Secretary - PLD
1987 SC 103). In other words, in cancelling a case on the police
report under section 173 or what is described as cancellation of FIR
in Rule 24.7 of the Police Rules, 1934, the Magistrate acts in
executive and not in his judicial capacity so much so that the order
is not revisable under sections 435, 439 Cr.P.C. This does not.
however, mean that the superior courts are powerless to rectify any
injustice. For example, if the court reaches a positive conclusion
that an order cancelling a case amounts to abuse of the process of
the court within the meaning of section 561A, the High Court may
334
335
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 186
intervene (Arif Ali Khan v State 1993 SCMR 187). Further,
cancellation of a case does not amount to acquittal of the accused
person so as to create res judicata (Waqar-ul-Hassan v State-PLD
1988 Lah. 336; 1988 SCMR 1428). Also, the cancellation of a case
does not render the Magistrate functus officio. He may later lake
cognizance of the same offence on a private complaint (Bahadur v
State PLD 1985 SC 62) and the trial court may summon the
accused who was discharged by the Magistrate on a report under
section 173 (Bahadur v State - PLD 1985 SC 62 and Wagar-ul-
Hassan v State-PLD 1988 Lah. 336).
It is now settled law that though section 173(3) Cr.P.C.
does not say so, yet the power to cancel a case on police report "is
inherent in section 173 read with section 190 of the Code of
Criminal Procedure". (Wazir v The State - PLD 1962 (WP) Lah
405 FB).
It is submitted that as the power to cancel is derived
from section 173(3) Cr.P.C. what the learned Judges intended to
convey by the word 'inherent' is that the power is implied, that is,
the Magistrate has the power to cancel under section 173(3) by
necessary implication.
The law is also now settled that once the Magistrate has
taken cognizance of the offence under section 190 Cr.P.C, there
can be no cancellation of a case on a second report by the police.
What amounts to taking cognizance of the offence "would
generally be a question of fact". As was said in Wazir v the State,
"the police report by itself, when received by the Magistrate, does
not constitute the taking of cognizance"; it would "appear more
sensible if he was supposed to take cognizance by a conscious act
leading to the trial"; it is "reasonable to expect that something more
will be done to show that the Magistrate intends to start the
proceeding". This view of the law seems to have been approved by
the Supreme Court in Muhammad Alam v Addl. Secretary (PLD
1987 SC 103).
336
This view seems to proceed on the basis that the taking
of cognizance by the Magistrate brings an end to the administrative
phase of the criminal process under the Code of Criminal
Procedure.
Does the above view need re-consideration
Does the addition of clause (ma) in section 4(1) of the
Code of Criminal Procedure defining 'Magistrate' to mean "a
Judicial Magistrate", in any way, affect the view in Bahadur and
Muhammad Alam cases referred to above namely that an order of
cancellation of a case is an administrative order and is not revisable
under sections 435 and 439 Cr.P.C? Does this change require a
reconsideration of the view in those cases?
The definition of 'Magistrate' in clause (ma) of section
4(1) Cr.P.C. was inserted in 2001; this was part of the process
giving effect to the mandate in Article 175, clause (3). of the
Constitution that "The Judiciary shall be separated progressively
from the Executive.....
As is well known, before this separation of the
magistracy from the Executive, the Magistrates who tried criminal
cases were part of the Executive. So, when a Magistrate made an
order cancelling a case, he acted in an executive or administrative
capacity in the same way as the police acted. in matters of
investigation, as an agency or instrumentality of the Executive.
Now that the Magistrate has only one capacity, and that is a
judicial capacity, can it be said that a cancellation order continues
to remain immune from being interfered with under sections 435
and 439 Cr.P.C?
In considering this question, it is important to point out
that section 561A Cr.P.C. applies only when the order in question
was made by a court; the power under that section is "to prevent an
abuse of the process of any court or otherwise to secure the ends of
justice" The "ends of justice", it was held in Shahnaz Begum case
(PLD 11971 SC 677, 693). 'necessarily means justice as
337
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 187
administered by the courts and not justice in the abstract sense or
justice administered by agencies other than courts".
Yet, it has been held that the High Court may, under
Section 561A Cr.P.C, interfere, if it reaches a positive conclusion
that an order cancelling a case amounts to abuse of the process of
the court. Here, the order cancelling a case has been treated as a
judicial order an order of court as distinguished from an
administrative order. This may logically lead to the conclusion that
as an order cancelling a case attracts the provisions of section
561A, it ought also to attract the jurisdiction under sections 435
and 439 Cr.P.C.
Magistrate, not Court of Session, can cancel
It is also important to note that the power to cancel a
case, even though it be a case triable exclusively by the Court of
Session, is in the Magistrate. The Court of Session has no such
power.
Intention is speedy investigation and to safeguard liberty
"
The combined effect of the provisions of sections 60, 61,
167, and 173 is that a person charged with the commission of an
offence should not remain in police custody or in judicial lock-up
without trial a moment longer than the period that is absolutely
necessary. The words "whenever any person is arrested and
detained in custody and it appears that the investigation cannot be
completed within a period of 24 hours fixed by section.
61.
in section 167 indicate that the law contemplates
that at least in some cases investigation can be completed within 24
hours. If, however, it is not possible to complete the investigation
within 24 hours, the police can ask for remand under section 167
up to a maximum period of 15 days. If the investigation is not
completed within this period, the accused cannot be remanded to
police custody. He can be sent only to the judicial lock-up. The
intention made clearer by the recently added proviso to sub-section
(1) of section 173 Cr.P.C. is that the investigation must be
completed within fourteen days of the FIR and if this cannot be
done, and a final report under section 173 cannot be filed, then an
interim report must be filed within three days of the expiry of the
period of fourteen days. leaving it to the court, in its judicial
discretion, to commence the trial on the basis of the interim report
or not. The provisions of section 173 are mandatory and must be
strictly complied with (Mumtaz Ahmad v State PLD 2002 SC
590, 596).
Chapter 14
Change or Transfer of Investigation:
Till the investigation stage ends, there may be
investigation by one or more investigating officers within the
hierarchy of the investigation branch under the Police Order, 2002.
Article 18. by its clause (4) of that Order, requires that "All
registered cases shall be investigated by the investigating staff in
the district under the supervision of the head of investigation", but
the Provincial Government may, by a special or general order,
entrust investigation of offences under local or special laws as
defined in the Pakistan Penal Code and punishable with
imprisonment for a term not exceeding three years with or without
any other punishment, to the police station staff. Thus, the Police
Order makes distinction between the investigation staff and the
police station staff; ordinarily, the power to investigate vests in the
investigation staff, but for local or special law offences mentioned
above, the Provincial Government may make a special or general
order authorizing their investigation by the police station staff.
At present, there are two provisions relating to transfer
ar change of investigation, that is, section 22A of the Code of
Criminal Procedure, which was enacted in 2002, and Article 18,
clause (6), of the Police Order 2002.
Before the enactment of section 22A of the Code of
Criminal Procedure, there was, as was pointed out in Muhammad
Bashir v SHO (PLD 2007 S.C. 539, 557, 558) no provision in the
339
338
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 188
Code "which talked of any concept of transfer of investigation of
criminal cases":
"The said Code, as would be evident.
inter alia, from its provisions contained
in sections 156 and 157, thought that it
could trust a police officer of the status
of an officer in charge of a police station
for the purpose and consequently
entrusted him with the said task. But
then realizing that in times to come, the
rising number of criminal cases
registered in a given police station could
make it impossible or at least difficult
for him to investigate all the cases
himself, the framers of the Cr.P.C.,
through sub-section (1) of section 157,
allowed him even to depute his
subordinates to carry out any or some of
the investigation required to be
conducted by him. Generally, the SHO
started to use these provisions of section
157(1) Cr.P.C. more or less like a toy.
He would assign a case to one of his
subordinates in his police station, then
withdraw the investigation from him and
depute another subordinate for the
purpose and this process then continued
with no end. This was not all as the

and who, by virtue of the provisions of

contradictory opinions of different

irreconcilable and also because motives
also started to be attributed to orders
leading to such transfers....
The Supreme Court went on to add:
"Needless to add that such like.
investigation had devastating effects on
the quality of trials that followed. And it
was for these reasons that the superior
courts of the country never approved of
the said so-called transfer of
investigation and always deprecated the
same"
It was in this background that section 22A, sub-section
(6). Cr.P.C. which, in the words of the Supreme Court in
Muhammad Bashir case was "an unwelcome and laboured
deviation of the provisions of section 157(1) of the Cr.P.C" was
enacted and "this hithertofore alien institution of transfer of
investigation got introduced into the system".
341
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 189
Section 22A Cr.P.C, read with section 25, as amended,
also in 2002, provides that an ex officio Justice of the Peace
namely a Sessions Judge and an Additional Sessions Judge so
nominated by the Sessions Judge may issue appropriate directions
to the police authorities concerned on a complaint regarding.
among others,
"(ii) transfer of investigation
from one police officer to another".
While this power to transfer investigation from one
police officer to another seems to be of a quasi-judicial nature, the
power under section 157, sub-section (1). Cr.P.C, which has been
allowed to remain unamended, and the power under Article 18,
clause (6), of the Police Order, seem to be powers of administrative
nature, vesting in the hierarchy of the police.
The crux of Article 18, clause (6), of the Police Order is
that there is now an independent investigation agency in each
district. Clause (6) reads:
"Investigation shall not be changed
except after due deliberation and

with the approval of the Provincial
