We have already commented upon the powers of the ex-
officio Justices of the Peace in the context of section 22A Cr.P.C.
and the powers of the Police under the Police Order. We have
noticed that the superior courts have, for reasons noticed in
Muhammad Bashir case, never approved of the transfer of
investigation from one police officer to another.
It has been held that "Article 18(6) of the Police Order
specifies the only manner in which investigation of a criminal case
can be changed. There is no other law authorizing or empowering
any other police officer or authority to change the investigation of a
criminal case. Any change or transfer of investigation of a criminal
case by any officer or authority other than those mentioned in
Article 18(6) of the Police Order. 2002, is to be void and nullity
(PLD 2005 lah. 470).
The above-noted view does not take into account the
provisions of section 157(1) Cr.P.C. It may well be that Article
18(6) of the Police Order has impliedly repealed section 157(1) in
so far as it empowers the SHO to transfer or change investigation
from one of his subordinates to another. But that question will turn
upon the provisions of Article 143 of the Constitution, and upon
the determination of the question as to which of the two laws, the
Code of Criminal Procedure or the Police Order, will prevail, and
the guidance to be gained from the observations of the Supreme
Court in Muhammad Bashir v SHO.
As regards the power of the ex-officio Justice of the
Peace, it has been held in PLD 2005 Lah. 470 that "if the
complaining person has not yet even applied before the competent
authorities under Article 18(6) of the Police Order, 2002, seeking
change of investigation then his complaint under section 22A(6)
Cr.P.C, is not to be entertained by an ex-officio Justice of the Peace
as no occasion has so far arisen for interference in the matter by an
ex-officio Justice of the Peace". And if the competent authorities
343
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 190
under Article 18(6)..
...have, it was held, "already
attended to the request of the complaining person regarding
transfer of investigation and have not found the case to be a fit case
for transfer of investigation then too an ex-officio Justice of the
Peace cannot interfere in the matter as the competent authorities
have already consciously attended to the matter and there is
nothing left for the ex-officio Justice of the Peace to get activated
or initiated. An ex-officio Justice of the Peace is not to assume the
role of an appellate, revisional or supervisory authority in this
respect. An ex-officio Justice of the Peace, like any judicial or
other authority outside the police hierarchy, should be extremely
slow in directly interfering with the matter of transfer of
investigation and in an appropriate case he may interfere only
where the authorities mentioned in Article 18(6) of the Police
Order, 2002, have already been approached by the complaining
person but such authorities have failed to attend to his grievance
and the application of the complaining person is lying unattended
to Even in such a case, a Justice of the Peace may refuse to
interfere in the matter unless it is established to his satisfaction that
some specific and particular material pieces of evidence had been
missed out by the investigating officer and the same remain to be
collected by the police..... While attending to such a
complaint an ex-officio Justice of the Peace cannot issue a
direction changing the investigation of a criminal case on his
own....
These views proceed on the basis that the spirit
underlying Article 18(6) is to discourage re-investigation (PLD
2005 lah, 1851. and that Article 18(6) of the Police Order and
section 22A Cr.P.C. are constitutionally valid and can stand
together. Their validity or as to which of them prevails does not so
far appear to have been tested on the touchstone of Article 143 of
the Constitution. Assuming that both are valid and of equal status,
they need to be harmonized so that the legislative intent in vesting
the power to change investigations in the ex-officio Justice of the
Peace. the highest judicial officer in the district, is not frustrated.
Chapter 15
Culminating point of Investigation:
We have seen that the basic object of investigation is to
enquire into the allegations of offence and to find out if the
allegations are true or not and thus to ensure that no one is
subjected to the ordeal of trial unless there is good case against
him. To attain that end, there may be more than one investigation
by more than one investigating officer in the police hierarchy.
subject indeed to the provisions of law discussed above. The
question is - is there a culminating point to investigation or is there
no end to it?
To start with section 173 Cr.P.C, it provides, by its sub-
section (1):
3)
"Every investigation under this Chapter
(Chapter XIV, Part V) shall be
completed without unnecessary delay.
and as soon as it is completed, the
officer in charge of the police station
shall, through the Public Prosecutor.
forward to a Magistrate empowered to
take cognizance of the offence on a
police report, a report in the form
by the
prescribed
Provincial
Government........
The words 'a Magistrate empowered to take cognizance of the
offence" have reference to section 190 Cr.P.C. That section is
headed: "Cognizance of offences by Magistrates" and provides.
inter-alia, that a Magistrate of the first class may take cognizance
of any offence....
(b)
upon a report in writing of such facts by
any police officer.
344
345
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 191
The scheme of the Code seems to be that where investigation is not
completed within fourteen days of the FIR, the SHO shall file an
interim police report but after the investigation is completed, there
shall be a final report. This is clear from the words "and as soon as
it (the investigation) is completed, the SHO shall through the
Public Prosecutor, forward to a Magistrate.....
in the form prescribed...
a report
One view therefore can be that the submission of the
challan to the court, through the Public Prosecutor, is the last step
in the investigation process. It is only after the investigation is
completed, that the final police report under section 173 Cr.P.C. is
submitted. But the law, as it now stands, gives a role to the Public
Prosecutor and he, instead of agreeing with the police report and
forwarding it to the Magistrate, may send it back to the police for
something more to be done. (See the discussion under the heading
"Public Prosecutor" in an earlier part of this book). Thus, the
investigation phase may continue till the final police report reaches
the Magistrate through the Public Prosecutor, to enable the
Magistrate to take cognizance of the offence under section 190
Cr.P.C. It was held in the Full Bench case of Wazir v the State
(PLD 1962 (WP) Lah. 405) - a strong Full Bench comprising M.
R. Kayani C.J., Shabir Ahmad and S.A. Mahmood JJ-that.
...the police report by itself, when
received by the Magistrate, does not
constitute the taking of cognizance and it
is reasonable to expect that something
more will be done to show that the
Magistrate intends
start the
proceedings.....".
So, if the Magistrate has not yet taken cognizance of the offence.
and a second police report, as a result of further investigation.
recommending the cancellation of the case is received, the
Magistrate may act upon the second report and cancel the case.
346
On this view, therefore, the culmination point of
investigation by the police is the point at which a competent
Magistrate takes cognizance of the offence under section 190
Cr.P.C. on the police report under section 173 Cr.P.C.
The view taken in Wazir v State was approved by the
Supreme Court in Muhammad Alam v Addl. Secretary (PLD 1987
SC 103).
While decided cases have disapproved, at times in strong
language, the practice of reinvestigation, a clear line separating the
administrative phase from the judicial phase of the criminal justice
system is not discernible. Thus,
(i)
(ii)
in Aftab Ahmad v Hussain Arshad (PLD
1987 SC 13), it was held that subsequent
investigation after submission of first report
under section 173 Cr.P.C. to competent court
is not prohibited; nor is there anything in the
Code to prevent the investigating officer from
in
report
submitting his subsequent
suppression of his earlier report and the
number of investigations into a crime by
Police Officers is not limited by law and when

influential people and favourable reports are

coming to a correct conclusion but have
created more complications for the courts.
347
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 192
(iii)

administration of justice.
Bahadur Khan v Muhammad Azam (2006

law";

Full Bench of the Lahore High Court held:
"We cannot appreciate or approve the
trend of getting a fresh investigation of a
criminal case conducted after submission
of a challan and taking cognizance of the
trial court. In the absence of any
particular material piece of evidence
shown to have been missed out by the
investigating officer and yet to be
collected by the police there can hardly
be any occasion for holding a fresh
investigation at such a stage...
an FIR cannot be cancelled or an
accused person discharged at such a
stage for the reason that after taking of
cognizance of the case by the trial court
the question of the guilt or innocence of
an accused person or the matter of his
release can be determined by the court
and none else".
If we may say with great respect, while this "disapproval" is an
important step in the development of this branch of the law, it is
349
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 193
time that the confusion surrounding it is cleared, and it is held, as
binding law, that the police power to investigate ceases at the point
of time the competent court takes cognizance of the offence. As to
the observation of the Full Bench of the Lahore High Court in
Khizar Hayat case that investigation process may continue where
any material piece of evidence is shown to have been "missed out"
and remains to be collected, this too, it is submitted, should not be
a ground for allowing the process of investigation to continue after
the court has taken cognizance of the offence. The prosecution can
always apply to the court for permission to produce such evidence
under section 540 Cr.P.C.
Chapter 16
Relationship between the Police and the Courts:
From the above survey of the powers of the police to
prevent, detect, and investigate crimes and the role of vigilance that
the courts as guardians of the life and liberty of the citizens are
mandated to play, the position that emerges as to the relationship of
the police and the courts can be stated as follows.
The Magistrate is neither associated with the
investigation nor does he supervise it; yet, the Magistrates and the
Sessions Judges have important statutory functions to perform. The
concerned Magistrate is to be kept informed about the various
stages of investigation. As soon as the first information report is
registered, its copy is to be sent to him. The accused is to be
produced before him within 24 hours of his arrest, the object being
to enable the Magistrate to apply his neutral judicial mind to the
facts of the case at that early stage of the criminal process. With the
help of the police diary, the Magistrate will determine whether to
grant remand to custody, judicial or police, or whether there will be
remand to custody at all. Under Section 344 Cr.P.C. the accused
cannot be remanded to judicial custody for more than 15 days at a
time, and that too, if it appears to the Magistrate that sufficient
evidence has been obtained to raise a suspicion that the accused
may have committed the offence and that further evidence may be
350
obtained by a remand; in other words, as the explanation to section
344 Cr.P.C. says, there must be a reasonable cause for remand.
Thus, at every stage of investigation, the Constitution and the Code
of Criminal Procedure provide safeguards against delays and
violations of the constitutional and statutory rights to life and
liberty of individuals and this enhances the degree of importance of
the role of the courts, the courts of Magistrates in particular, and
their responsibility in the maintenance of the rule of law.
Interference with Investigation:
We have seen that though the District Public Prosecutor
can well be described as the chief law enforcement officer in the
district, yet his functions do not include interference with the police
investigation.
As regards powers of courts, the question assumes an
acute form when the jurisdiction of the courts other than that of the
criminal court whose function is to try the offence is invoked
immediately after the registration of a criminal case with a view to
preventing the investigation of the case by the police, e.g. of the
High Court under Article 199 of the Constitution or of the civil
courts, seeking a declaration that the alleged facts do not constitute
an offence. In Imperial Tobacco case (1980) I All ER 866), the
plaintiffs were tobacco manufacturers. They started a 'spot cash'
advertising scheme and inserted some 260 million 'spot cash' cards
into cigarette packets which were then sold at the same price as
before the scheme started. The Director Public Prosecutions
thought that the scheme was a lottery and was a statutory offence.
The plaintiffs brought an action claiming a declaration that the
scheme was lawful and was not an offence. The Court of Appeal
granted the declaration. The House of Lords reversed holding that
the decision of the Court of Appeal amounted to usurpation by the
civil courts of the functions of the criminal courts; in any case, "the
administration of justice would become chaotic if, after the start of
a prosecution, declarations of innocence could be obtained from the
civil courts".
351
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 194
The law has developed on the same lines in Pakistan. In
Brigadier Imtiaz Ahmad case (1994 SCMR 2142), the petitioner
I was a retired Brigadier and had then worked, on contract, as
Director, Intelligence Bureau. An enquiry was held and fearing that
he would be involved in criminal cases, he brought a petition under
Article 199 seeking various declarations. The petition was
dismissed and it was held that the High Court could not assume the
role of investigator "for the authority to register and investigate a
criminal case in law vests in the police and not in court",
It is well settled that the High Court has no power of
supervision or control either under the Constitution or the Letters
Patent or the Code of Criminal Procedure to interfere in any
manner with the conduct of an investigation already taken in hand
by competent agencies under the law. (Shahnaz Begum case - PLD
1971 SC 677)
The classical words of caution to the courts in the matter
of interference with the police investigation are to be found in the
Privy Council case of Khawaja Nazir Ahmad (AIR 1945 PC 18);
the Privy Council treated such interference with the duties of the
police as a serious matter and observed:
"Just as it is essential that every one
accused of a crime should have free
access to justice so that he may be duly
acquitted if found not guilty of the
offence with which he is charged, so it is
of the utmost importance that the
judiciary should not interfere with the
police in matters which are within their
province and into which the law imposes
upon them the duty of enquiry.......
There is a statutory right on the part of
the police 10. investigate the
circumstances of an alleged cognizable
crime without requiring any authority
352
be,
from the judicial authorities and it would
an unfortunate result if it
should be held possible to interfere with
those statutory rights by an exercise of
the inherent jurisdiction of the court. The
functions of the judiciary and the police
are complementary not overlapping and
the combination of individual liberty
with a due observance of law and order
is only to be obtained by leaving each to
exercise its own function always of
course subject to the right of the court to
intervene in an appropriate case when
moved under section 491 Criminal
Procedure Code to give direction in the
nature of habeas corpus. In such a case
as the present, however, the court's
function begins when a charge is
preferred before it and not until then.
No doubt, if no cognizable
offence is disclosed and still more if no
offence of any kind is disclosed, the
police would have no authority to
undertake an investigation..........
The law laid down in Khawaja Nazir Ahmad case was
applied in Shahnaz Begum (PLD 1971 SC 677)) and again in
Malik Shaukat Ali Dogar v Ghulam Qadir (PLD 1994 SC 281).
In Shahnaz Begum case, the High Court suo motu
assumed jurisdiction (i) to examine if the conduct of the
investigation had been fair and impartial; (ii), whether the ends of
justice required that further investigation of the case should be
entrusted to another officer or court: and (iii) to examine whether
any officer who had taken part in the conduct of investigation, at
any stage, had been guilty of any act of commission or omission.
These questions, it was held, lay outwith the jurisdiction of the
High Court, either under the Constitution, the Letters Patent or the
353
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 195
Code of Criminal Procedure and the High Court had no power of
superintendence, to enable it to interfere in or control the conduct
of investigation by a competent investigation agency.
In Malik Shaukat Ali Dogar case two petitions under
Article 199 of the Constitution were filed in the High Court
seeking registration of criminal cases against Malik Shaukat Ali,
On these petitions, a Judge of the High Court directed not only the
registration of a criminal case, but also directed that its
investigation be conducted by a particular officer and weekly
reports be submitted to the High Court. The Supreme Court held
that this kind of "continued control over the investigation exercised
by the court as in this case was prejudicial to the accused and
detrimental to the faimess of the procedure apart from being
without jurisdiction".
Chapter 17
The role of Public Prosecutor:
We have already discussed the role of the Public
Prosecutor as one of the participants in the criminal justice process.
The importance of the place that he occupies and the role that he is
required by law to play is that he is concemed with the process
both at the administrative and judicial phases. At the administrative
stage, he may have, during investigation, sometimes to act as legal
advisor to the police and then he has the very responsible duty to
ensure not only that no innocent man or woman is prosecuted but
also that no man or woman is prosecuted on insufficient evidence.
At the judicial phase, he is to act as prosecutor, as the
representative of not an ordinary party but of the society and in that
capacity his duty is to uphold a very high standard of faimess and
impartiality.
PART V
ENQUIRIES
The reason why we deal with 'inquiries' here is that
depending upon its nature, an inquiry may belong to the judicial or
the administrative phase.
The expression "enquiry" is defined in section 4(1)(k)
Cr.P.C. to include every enquiry other than trial conducted by a
Magistrate or court.
The definition is not exhaustive; but it does indicate that
there is a distinction between inquiry and trial.
An inquiry may be made by a Magistrate or any other
person; it may be in respect of a matter which is an offence or in
respect of a matter which is not an offence. Examples of inquiries
into a matter which is an offence are provided by sections 159 and
202 Cr.P.C. Examples of inquiries into matters which are not
offences are provided by the proceedings for security for keeping
the peace under section 107 and security for good behaviour under
sections 108, 109 and 111 Cr.P.C. The mode of inquiry into these
matters is provided in section 117 Cr.P.C. and the power of the
Magistrate to order the giving of security is provided in section
118. Proceedings under these sections involve detention in police
custody and provisions of Article 10 of the Constitution and
section 61 etc., of the Code of Criminal Procedure are equally
applicable to them. Other examples are inquiry under section 133
Cr.P.C. for removing a public nuisance and obstruction, inquiry
relating to disputes concerning land under section 145 and inquiry
into suicide etc., under sections 174 and 176. Of them, enquiries
under section 145 Cr.P.C. and sections 174, 176 Cr.P.C. need
special consideration.
354
355
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 196
Inquiries under Section 145
When a Magistrate of the First Class is satisfied from a
police report or other information that a dispute likely to cause a
breach of the peace exists concerning any land or water he may
proceed under Chapter XII, Sections 145 to 148. He shall summon
the parties to the dispute and require them to file written statements
of their respective claims as respects the fact of actual possession
of the subject matter of dispute. If the Magistrate finds that none of
the parties was in possession or he is unable to decide as to which
of them was in actual possession of the subject of dispute, he may
under section 146 attach it until the competent court has
determined the rights of the parties. The object of these
proceedings is to maintain status quo to enable the parties to obtain
a final decision from the civil court. The elements for the
foundation of jurisdiction under this section of which the
Magistrate must be satisfied are (a) that a dispute likely to cause
breach of the peace exists; (b) that the dispute relates to land or
water or boundaries thereof and (c) that such land or water is
situated within the limits of his territorial jurisdiction.
The proceedings under section 145 Cr.P.C. are
subordinate to a decree or order of a civil court in respect of the
property in dispute; the primary concern of the proceedings under
this section being to prevent breach of the peace arising out of a
dispute concerning land or water, these proceedings are not
concerned with the adjudication of the parties' rights in the
property, which is a matter exclusively in the realm of civil courts.
Thus the orders passed by a Magistrate for attachment of the
subject matter of dispute are of a transitory nature. Section 145,
therefore, proceeds on the premises that the Magistrate will cease
to deal with the possession of land or water in dispute as soon as a
civil court is seized of the matter and has passed a decree declaring
the rights of parties or has passed an order regulating the
possession of the subject matter (Shah Muhammad v Haq Nawaz -
PLD 1970 SC 470). Where the possession of the property has been
regulated by civil court even through a temporary injunction, the
matter falls outside the jurisdiction of the Magistrate under Section
145 (Mehr Muhammad Sarwar v State-PLJ 1985 SC 540).
356
Inquiries under Sections 174, 174A, 176
Under section 174 when a police officer receives
information that a person (a) has committed suicide; (b) has been
killed by another person or by accident etc.; or (c) has died under
circumstances raising a reasonable suspicion that some other
person has committed an offence, he shall give intimation of the
fact to the nearest Magistrate and proceed to the spot, make an
investigation and draw up a report as to the cause of death. He shall
then have the dead body medically examined. The police officer is
then to forward his report to the Magistrate concerned for inquest.
All Magistrates of the First Class are empowered to hold inquest
under this section. Under section 176, when a person dies while in
the custody of the Police, a Magistrate of the First Class may hold
an inquiry into the cause of the death and for that purpose he shall
have the powers which he would have in holding an inquiry into an
offence. He shall record the evidence and may make an
examination of the dead body of any person who has been already
interred in order to discover the cause of his death. The Magistrate
may cause the body to be disinterred and examined. By the recently
enacted section 174A Cr.P.C. special provision has been made for
cases in which a person is grievously injured through fire, kerosene
oil, acid etc. The medical officer to whom such a person is
reported, or the SHO to whom such a case is reported, shall give
intimation of the incident to the nearest Magistrate.
The Medical officer shall immediately record the
statement of the injured person; and if the injured is in a position to
make a statement, the Magistrate shall also record his statement.
The object is to ascertain the circumstances and cause of the burn
injuries and to preserve the evidence in the form of the injured
person's statement, which may in some cases serve as dying
declaration. This, it appears, became necessary because of
numerous cases reported in papers of women suffering burn
injuries at the hands of their husbands or their relatives, so that
persons guilty of such crimes are brought to justice,
357
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 197
PART VI
THE JUDICIAL PHASE
Chapter 1
Does the filing of challan raise a presumption of guilt?
The answer is an emphatic 'no'.
The investigation process is a screening process,
whereby the police and the prosecutor, as experts in their fields,
reach an early determination of the probable innocence or guilt of
the persons accused reflected in the police report under section 173
Cr. P. C. Those who are probably innocent are screened out and
those who are probably guilty are sent up for trial.
"Probably guilty" does not mean "presumed to be
guilty". "Presumed to be guilty" is not, and has never been, a rule
of law. The presumption of guilt would mean that the
determination of the police is final, which it is not. If it were final,
there would be no need for trial. It would also mean that the only
object of a trial is to give the accused an opportunity to prove that
he is innocent.
The rule of law is the presumption of innocence which is
the polestar of the criminal process and occupies an important
place in the due process of law. To take an example, a murderer
shoots his victim in the plain view of a large number of people.
When the police arrive, he hands them his gun and says: "I did it
and I am glad". The people who saw the shooting testify to his
guilt. He is arrested. Here it will be absurd to maintain that he is
innocent of the offence. The presumption of innocence here means
that until there has been an adjudication of guilt by a competent
court, "the suspect is to be treated......... as if his guilt is an open
question". It also means that the general burden to prove his guilt is
on the prosecution. (There is an interesting and illuminating
358
discussion on "Due Process Model" and "Crime Control Model" in
the "The Limits of the Criminal Sanction" by Herbert L. Packer
reprinted in "Constitutional Interpretation" by Craig R. Ducar and
Harold W. Chase, 5th ed at p. 673 and we acknowledge our debt of
gratitude to that book).
So, despite the fact that according to police investigation
by however high in that hierarchy, a man is guilty, he will be, for
the purposes of trial, presumed to be innocent, and the general
burden to prove his guilt will remain on the prosecution. For, it
must be remembered, the opinion of the investigating police officer
as to the guilt or innocence of an accused person is inadmissible in..
evidence. (Muhammad Iqbal v Muhammad Akram - 1996 SCMR
908, 918; Muhammad Bashir v SHO-PLD 2007 SC 539, 548).
To quote Lord Denning from Jones (1957) 2 QB 55).
"There is one thing to which everyone in
this country is entitled and that is a fair
trial at which he can put his case
properly before the judge. No
cause is lost until the judge has found it
so; and he cannot find it without a fair
trial".
So, nobody is guilty until the judge has found him so; and the
judge cannot so find without a fair trial.
Chapter 2
TRIAL
The general pro cedure for the trial of offences is
contained in Part VI, titled "Proceedings in Prosecutions", of the
Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898. It is important to mention that
this procedure applies to cases governed by the Code of Criminal
Procedure; as is provided by section 1, subsection (2) of the Code,
".....nothing herein contained shall affect any special or local law
now in force, or any special jurisdiction or power conferred, or any
359
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 198
special form of procedure by any other law for the time being in
force". Section 5 of the Code makes the position clearer. That
section, by its subsection (1), provides that "...All offences under
the Pakistan Penal Code shall be investigated, inquired into, tried,
and otherwise dealt with according to the provisions hereinafter
contained". But as regards offences under other laws, subsection
(2) provides:
Trial, its meaning:
"All offences under any other law shall
be investigated, inquired into, tried and
otherwise dealt with according to the
same provisions (that is, according to the
provisions of the Code of Criminal
Procedure), but subject to any enactment
for the time being in force regulating the
manner or place of investigating.
inquiring into, trying or otherwise
dealing with such offences."
The Code of Criminal Procedure uses the expressions
"try" (e.g. in sections 198(5) and 260) and trial (e.g. in sections
228, 241 and chapter XXII-A), but does not define them. The
definition of "inquiry" in section 4(1), clause (k), of the Code
shows that there is a distinction between an inquiry and trial. In the
Code of Criminal Procedure of 1872, the word 'trial' was defined
as "the proceedings taken in court after a charge has been drawn up
and includes the punishment of the offender". The omission of the
definition in the present Code perhaps manifests an intention that
the expression has no fixed meaning.
Older dictionaries define 'try' as 'to examine' or 'to
examine as a judge', (S. Johnson, "A Dictionary of the English
Language" 1785). In more modern usage the term has various
meanings. For example. 'try' can mean 'to examine or investigate
judicially, to conduct the trial of, or to put to the test by
experiment, investigation or trial". In T. Sheridan's "Dictionary of
the English Language", "try" means "to examine as a Judge; to
bring before a Judicial Tribunal". These definitions were referred
to in Nixon (113 S.Ct.732) (1993), where the provision under
consideration was Art.I, S.3, Clause 6, of the US Constitution.
which provides: "The Senate shall have the sole power to try all
impeachments". It was argued by the petitioner that the word "try"
in that provision "imposes by implication an additional requirement
on the Senate in that the proceedings must be in the nature of a
judicial trial". It was held that "the framers did not intend to
impose additional limitations on the form of the Senate.
proceedings by the use of the word 'try'...
So, the words "try" and "trial" are not terms of art, and
their meaning depends upon the context in which they are used. For
example in Piare Dusadh v Emperor (AIR 1944 FC 1), the section
under consideration was section 4 of the Special Criminal Courts
(Repealed) Ordinance 1943 which purported to deal with cases of
which the trials before special courts had not 'concluded'. The trial
could be said to have concluded when the court pronounced its
judgment or it could be said to have concluded as soon as the case
became ripe for judgment. It was held that the meaning of the
trial largely depends on the context and the scheme of the
enactment in which it occurs. Though the word may sometimes
mean only the recording of evidence it was obvious that in the
context of the Ordinance it comprised all stages including the
imposition of the sentence.
The context and the scheme of the Code of Criminal
Procedure also lead to the conclusion that "trial" under the Code
comprises all stages including the imposition of the sentence. Part
VI of the Code which is titled "Proceedings in Prosecutions"
consists of chapters XV to XXX; they include provisions
prescribing conditions for initiation of criminal proceedings,
provisions for the commencement of proceedings, for summary
trials, for regular trials, and not only provisions for the mode of
taking evidence but also provisions relating to judgments and
imposition of sentences.
360
361
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 199
Object of trial
The memorable words of Crompton J. in O'Connel
(1844) Ir. LR 312) provide perhaps the best statement on the point.
He said:
seks on
"This Court in which we sit is a temple
of justice. The object of all
equally should be the attainment of
justice; now justice is only to be reached
through the ascertainment of the truth
and the instrument which our law
brepresents to us for the ascertainment of
the truth or falsehood of a criminal
charge is by trial... the trial is the
about the truth".
process by which we endeavour to find
The object of the trial therefore must be the attainment of justice
through the ascertainment of truth; in the words of Prime Minister
of England, Benjaman Disraeli, "Justice is truth in action".
The trial has traditionally been viewed as the capstone
(coping, coping stone) of the criminal justice, the 'crown jewel',
that reflects most of the basic elements of the criminal process. It is
not surprising, therefore, that many of the Human and Fundamental
Rights guaranteed by the Written Constitutions and international
charters and treaties relating to the criminal justice process refer
specifically to trial."
A trial thus is a necessary precondition for holding a
person guilty of an offence and for the imposition of a formal
criminal sanction or punishment and is therefore the center-piece of
the criminal process; it is the means and machinery provided by
law for bringing the alleged offender to justice.
What is fairness in a criminal trial
The two-fold aim of criminal justice is that guilt shall
not escape or innocence suffer, (Berger-295 US 78) and the
ultimate object of any procedure is, or ought to be, to ensure a fair
trial according to law. For an accused, fair trial means that he
should have-
E)
ii)
iii)
vi)
full information as to the offence he is
charged with;
the opportunity to be confronted with the
witnesses, which includes the right to be
present at the trial and the right to cross-
examine those who depose against him;
the opportunity to explain the circumstances
disclosed in the evidence against him; and
the opportunity to produce his evidence in
defence, which includes the right to have his
witnesses summoned through the court.
But fairness of a trial is not all one-sided; it requires that those who
are undoubtedly guilty should be convicted as well as those about
whose guilt there is any reasonable doubt should be acquitted.
(Sang-(1979) 2 All ER 1222, 1230).
Chapter 3
Parties to a Criminal Case
'Party' is a technical word having a precise meaning in
legal parlance; it refers to those by or against whom a legal suit is
brought, whether in law or in equity, the party plaintiff or
defendant, whether composed of one or more individuals and
whether natural or legal persons. All others who may be affected
by the suit, indirectly or consequently, are persons interested but
not parties. A party to an action is a person whose name is
designated on record as plaintiff or defendant. The term in general
362
363
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 200
means one having right to control proceedings, to make defence, to
adduce and cross-examine witnesses and to appeal from judgment.
(See Black's Law Dictionary based on some American cases).
While civil law is private law, criminal law is an aspect
of public law in which the State, as the representative of the
society, acts positively to enforce the criminal law. Thus, criminal
cases are brought by the State. A crime is, as an American author
puts it, in theory, a public wrong, a wrong against some victim, to
be sure, but also something that hurts the society which is why the
society, that is the State, takes over the job of punishing. In Fazal
Elahi case (PLD 1953 FC 35), the High Court thought that besides
the Crown (the State) and the accused, there was a third party
namely the society. The Federal Court in disagreeing with that
view, referred to the statement of the law in Halsbury's Laws of
England, namely that "A crime is an unlawful act or default which
is an offence against the public.....
....while a crime is
often also an injury to a private person, it is as an act or default
contrary to the order, peace and well-being of society that a crime
is punishable by the state. Legal punishment is punishment
awarded in a process which is instituted at the suit of the Crown,
standing forward as prosecutor on behalf of the subject on public
grounds".
The Federal Court added:
"When therefore the Crown stands
forward as the prosecutor and asks for
punishment of a criminal before a
court through a prosecutor, the
action is taken on behalf of the State, as
constituted by the people thereof, and it
is in the same sense that the Crown
claims authority to punish a
crime..
The conclusion thus was that a criminal proceeding for the trial of
an accused is a proceeding between the State, representing the
364
society, and the person accused. Some indication of this legal
position is provided by the provisions of Chapter XXII of the Code
of Criminal Procedure, which proceed on the basis that in cases
initiated upon police reports, that is, challan cases, the parties are
the State represented by the Public Prosecutor and the accused and
in complaint cases the parties are the complainant and the accused.
Thus, section 265F provides, by its sub-section (2), that the court
shall ascertain from the Public Prosecutor, or as the case may be,
from the complainant, the names of the witnesses.
In the Anglo-American system of criminal justice
therefore one of the parties is the State, which prosecutes in the
name of the political community, conventionally designated in
England as e.g. Regina v Arthur, in the US, e.g. the People v
Arthur and in Pakistan e.g. State v Zahid.
This has been the legal position in Pakistan, particularly
in cases initiated on police report. Section 265A of the Code of
Criminal Procedure says: "In every trial before a Court of Session
initiated upon a police report (under section 173 Cr.P.C. or other
such provision), the prosecution shall be conducted by the Public
Prosecutor". Similarly, by the recently enacted Provincial Laws,
such as the Punjab Criminal Prosecution Service (Constitution,
Functions and Powers) Act 2006, section 9(1), "The Prosecutors
shall be responsible for the conduct of prosecution on behalf of the
Government". The term 'Government' here is not a happy choice
for it is the State, not the Government, that is a party in a criminal
case.
Thus, there are two parties to a criminal case and; this clearly
envisages adversarial litigation.
Under the Islamic Criminal Justice System
Has the introduction of the Islamic concept of the law of
crimes, and criminal procedure, as regards cases involving offences
against human body such as Qatl and hurt, made any difference? In
Gul Hassan case (PLD 1989 SC 633), certain provisions of the
365
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 201
Pakistan Penal Code, c.g. Sections 299 to 338, and certain
provisions of the Code of Criminal Procedure, e.g. Sections 345,
381, were declared to be repugnant to the Injunctions of Islam
Justice Muhammad Taqi Usmani, a Member of the Shariat
Appellate Bench of the Supreme Court, carried out a comparative
survey of the Anglo-American or Anglo-Saxon Jurisprudence and
the Injunctions of Islam as contained in the Holy Quran and the
Sunnah of the Holy Prophet and pointed out that one fundamental
difference between the two systems is that whereas under the
Anglo-American system an offence is an act against the State only
and the victim or his heirs have nothing to do with it, under the
Quran and the Sunnah and the Islamic Jurisprudence, the offences
of murder and hurt have two elements; first, they are considered as
acts violating the rights of the victim or his heirs, and secondly,
they are acts against the State. In Islam, the first element
predominates. In the words of Shafi-ur-Rehman, J. in the same case
"Under
Islam....
the
Injunctions of
the individual victim
or his heirs retain from the beginning to
the end entire control over the matter
including the crime and the criminal,
They may not report it. They may not
prosecute the offender. They may
abandon prosecution of their free will.
They may pardon the criminal at any
stage before the execution of the
sentence. They may accept monetary or
other compensation to purge the crime
and the criminal. They may compromise.
They may accept Qisas from the
criminal. The State cannot impede, but
must, to its best, assist them in achieving
their object and in appropriately
exercising their rights".
366
Accordingly, necessary changes were made both in the Pakistan
Penal Code and the Code of Criminal Procedure; in the latter.
sections 345 and 333 etc. have been amended so that even murder
is now a compoundable offence and the State cannot now grant
pardon without the consent of the victim or his heirs.
Even before the influence of the Islamic Jurisprudence
and its introduction as part of the criminal procedure, the victim or
his heirs were not rank outsiders. This is sufficiently illustrated by
sections 250 and 544A Cr.P.C. which provide a kind of civil law
remedy in criminal proceedings.
Under section 250 Cr. P. C. when a Magistrate acquits
an accused after trial, and is "of opinion that the
accusation.... ...was false and either frivolous or vexatious,
the Magistrate may by his order of acquittal" call upon the person
upon whose complaint or information the accusation was made to
show cause why he should not pay compensation to the acquitted
accused; and if the Magistrate is so satisfied, he may order such
person to pay compensation to the accused, to the extent of the
amount mentioned in the section.
Section 544A provides that the Court, convicting an
accused of an offence in the commission whereof the death of, or
hurt, injury or mental anguish or psychological damage to any
person is caused, or damage to or loss or destruction of any
property is caused, shall, that is, must, unless for reasons to be
recorded in writing it otherwise directs, order the convict to pay to
the victim or as the case may be the heirs of the victim "such
compensation as the court may determine having regard to the
circumstances of the case". The compensation so ordered to be
paid, if not paid, shall render the convict liable to simple
imprisonment mentioned in the section.
The compensation payable both under section 250 and
section 544A is recoverable as arrears of land revenue, and does
not exempt the person directed to pay compensation from other
civil or criminal liability, but if there is a subsequent civil action in
367
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 202
tort, the civil court shall, in awarding damages, take into account
the amount of compensation pad under section 250 ur section
544A Cr.P.C.
So, the complainant, the victim and his heirs as well as
the acquitted and convicted accused have all to be watchful of their
interests to ensure that they are duly compensated for the loss or
injury suffered by them. This will also serve, in many cases, to
save the parties from another round of litigation in civil courts,
It is plain that if sections 250 and 544A are to fulfill the
object underlying their enactment, the victim, his heirs, the
accused, have all to play an important role. None of them can
therefore afford to be silent spectators at the trial; they have to
vigilantly guard their interest.
It appears, therefore, that in order to be a party to a
criminal case, one has to be designated as a party on record. Thus,
in a criminal case initiated on police report, the parties are the State
on one side and the accused on the other. In a complaint case, the
parties are the complainant on one side and the accused on the
other. An heir or heirs of the deceased person in a murder case and
the person injured in a hurt case may not be necessarily the
complainant. The heirs of the deceased person and the person
injured have, in the new scheme of things, been assigned many an
important role and the matters in which their participation is
required by law must be done in the prescribed way or not at all,
yet, the victims or their heirs are technically not parties to the
proceedings. In cases in which the State is a party, the State has, by
assuming the role of the prosecutor, taken upon itself a double role,
that of the representative of the society and also that of the
representative of the victim or his heirs. The latter role of the
representative of the victim has the great advantage of relieving the
victim and his heirs of the very heavy financial and other burdens
that the prosecution of a criminal case necessarily entails.
Two kinds of trials:
The Code of Criminal Procedure provides for -
(1)
summary trials; and
368
(2)
regular trials.
Chapter 4
Summary trials
Under the English law, crimes are. for procedural
purposes, classified as indictable and summary offences. This
classification broadly reflects a distinction between serious and
minor offences.
Chapter XXII. sections 260 to 265 Cr. P. C.. provide for
the trial of offences summarily by any Magistrate of the First Class
specially empowered in that behalf by the Provincial Government
and any bench of Magistrates invested with powers of a Magistrate
of the First Class specially empowered in this behalf by the
Provincial Govemment. Such a Magistrate or bench of Magistrates
has a discretion, if he or they think fit, to try in a summary way all
or any of the offences mentioned in section 260. Under section
261. the Provincial Government may on the recommendation of the
High Court confer on any bench of Magistrates invested with the
powers of Magistrate of the Second Class or Third Class, power to
try summarily all or any of the offences mentioned in that section.
The object of summary procedure contained in Chapter
XXII is speedy disposal of cases involving cases of comparatively
lesser gravity. Summary trial should be restricted to simple cases; it
should not be resorted to in complicated and serious cases.
Even where a Magistrate exercises the initial discretion
to try a case summarily, he may find, as the case progresses, that
the case is one which should not be so tried. He can then have
resort to the regular procedure provided by Chapter XX.
The procedure applicable to summary cases is the same
as is provided in Chapter XX for regular trials subject to the
following exceptions:-

Place of trial
Chapter XV(A) Cr.P.C., sections 177 to 189, provide for
the place of trial. The general rule is that all crimes are local and a
court's jurisdiction to try a person for an offence depends upon the
crime having been committed within its territorial jurisdiction.
Sections 178 to 187 provide for the determination of the place of
trial. Section 188 permits an offence committed abroad to be tried
in Pakistan and deserves special notice. It provides that-
(i)
(ii)
(iii)
when a citizen of Pakistan commits an offence
at any place without and beyond the limits of
Pakistan: or
when a servant of the State whether a citizen
of Pakistan or not commits an offence in a
tribal area; or
when any person commits an offence on any
ship or aircraft registered in Pakistan
wherever it maybe,
he may be dealt with in respect of such offence as if the offence
had been committed at any place within Pakistan at which he may
be found.
The phrase "dealt with" appears to include all the stages,
administrative and judicial, and appears to mean that the offences
by the abive mentioned persons may be investigated, inquired into
and tried at the place where the accused is found. But "no charge as
to any such offence shall be enquired within Pakistan" unless the
Political Agent if any of the place where the offence was allegedly
committed certifies that the offence ought to be enquired into in
Pakistan and if there is no Political Agent, the Federal Government
grants sanction for such enquiry.
This is an exception to the general rule that all crimes
are local. To the same effect is section 4 PPC. Thus, to enable an
offender who had committed an offence outside Pakistan to be tried
in Pakistan, the law creates a fiction namely that the crime, though
not committed in Pakistan, is fictionally deemed to have been
committed at the place in Pakistan where he is found.

Section 531 Cr.P.C. saves a finding, sentence or order
from being set aside merely on the ground that the trial took place
at the wrong place, unless the error in fact occasioned a failure of
justice.
Cognizance of offences by courts:
Chapter XV(B) Cr.P.C. is titled "Conditions requisite for
initiation of proceedings". This chapter consists of sections 190 to
1998. Besides providing for the cases in which the courts may take
cognizance of offences, it provides also for the cases in which
cognizance cannot be taken without fulfillment of certain
conditions.
Section 190 provides for cognizance of offences by
Magistrates; by its sub-section (1) all Magistrates of the First Class
or any other Magistrate especially empowered by the Provincial
Government on the recommendation of the High Court may take
cognizance of any offence-
(a)
(b)
(c)
upon receiving a complaint of facts which
constitute such offence;
upon a report in writing of such facts made by
any police officer:
upon information received from any person
other than a police officer, or upon his own
knowledge or suspicion that such offence has
been committed which he may try or send to
the Court of Session for trial.
Sub-section (2) of section 190 requires a Magistrate
taking cognizance under sub-section (1) of an offence triable
exclusively by a Court of Session to send the case to the Court of
Session for trial, without recording any evidence. Section 193
provides that a Court of Session shall not take cognizance of an
offence unless the case has been sent to it under section 190(2) Cr.
P.C.
Upon receiving a complaint
This relates to private prosecutions as distinguished from
State prosecutions e.g. those mentioned in clause (b) of section
190, sub-section (1), Cr. P.C.
In Gouriet v Union of Post Office Workers (1977) 3 All
ER 70). Lord Wilberforce recognized the right to bring a private
prosecution as a valuable constitutional safeguard against inertia or
partiality on the part of authority and Lord Diplock desenbed that
right as "a useful constitutional safeguard against capricious.
corrupt or biased failure or refusal of those authorities to prosecute
offenders against the criminal law"
We have seen that under Article 9 of the Constitution,
access to justice is a constitutionally protected right and the right to
initiate private criminal proceedings against criminal offenders is
directly relatable to that right.
There may be a case in which a State functionary has
extended an assurance to an accused person that he will not be
prosecuted. In such a case, a private prosecution may be barred.
Jones v Whalley (2006) 4 All ER 113) is an illustration of such a
case.
The provision in section 190 empowering a Magistrate
to take cognizance of an offence upon receiving a complaint of
facts which constitute such offence is to be read with Chapter XVI
which consists of sections 200 to 203. The expression "complaint"
is defined in section 4(1), clause (h), to mean "the allegations made
orally or in writing to a Magistrate with a view to his taking action
under this Code that some person, whether known or unknown, has
committed an offence, but it does not include the report of a police
officer". Section 200 requires that a Magistrate taking cognizance
of an offence on complaint shall at once examine the complainant
upon cath and the substance of the examination shall be reduced to
writing and shall be signed by the complainant and also by the
373
372
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 205
Magistrate. The proviso to the section provides for cases in which
it is not necessary for the examination of the complainant. Section
201 says that if the complaint has been made in writing to a
Magistrate who is not competent to take cognizance of the case, he
shall return the complaint for presentation to the proper court with
an endorsement to that effect. Section 202 authorizes any court on
receipt of a complaint to postpone the issue of process for
compelling the attendance of the accused person and to enquire
into the case itself or direct an inquiry or investigation to be made
by any Justice of the Peace or by a police officer. A Court of
Session may direct the investigation to be made by a Magistrate
subordinate to it for the purpose of ascertaining the truth or
falsehood of the complaint. Section 203 empowers the court before
whom the complaint is made, or to whom it has been transferred or
sent, to dismiss the complaint if after considering the material
before it, there is in its judgment no sufficient ground for
proceeding. The court shall briefly record its reasons for so doing.
For complaints in Hadood cases, the recently enacted
sections 203A, 203B and 203C provide a special procedure. No
court shall take cognizance of an offence under section 5 of the
Offence of Zina (Enforcement of Hadood) Ordinance, 1979, or in
case of Qazf under section 6 of the Offence of Qazaf (Enforcement
of Hadood) Ordinance, 1979, or of an offence under section 496B
of the Pakistan Penal Code, except on a complaint lodged in a court
of competent jurisdiction. A common feature of all these new
provisions is that the court taking cognizance of the offences
mentioned therein shall at once examine the complainant and the
witnesses produced or required to be produced, reduce the
substance of their examination to writing and have them signed by
the complainant and the witnesses. In cases of Zina and Qazf, the
witnesses must undergo the test of tazkiyah-al-shahood that they
are truthful persons and abstain from major sins, the meaning of
tazkiyah-al-shahood being the mode of enquiry adopted by the
court to satisfy itself as to the credibility of a witness. (See e.g. the
explanation to subsection (2) of Section 203A Cr. P. C. For the
concept of tazkiyah-al-shahood generally please see Sanaullah v
State - PLD 1991 FSC 186). If in the opinion of the court there is
374
sufficient ground for proceeding, the court shall issue summons for
the personal attendance of the accused to face trial; but the court
may for reasons to be recorded dismiss the complaint if, after
considering the statements on oath of the complainant and the
witnesses, there is, in its judgment, no sufficient ground for
proceeding, that is, for summoning the accused.
The combined effect of the provisions of subsections (4)
and (5) of sections 203A, 203B and 203C seems to be to altogether
exclude the police and police investigation in these cases. The
opinion of the court as to the sufficiency of ground for proceeding
further and the judgment of the court that there is no sufficient
ground for proceeding must be based on the statements on cath of
the complainant and the witnesses. For the purpose of proceeding
or not proceeding further, sections 203A, 203B and 203C seem to
be self-contained and it may well be that by necessary implication.
the application of section 202 stands excluded.
Upon a police report
The report contemplated by sub-section (1), clause (b).
of section 190 is the police report (the Challan) under section 173
Cr. P. C.
Upon personal information of the Magistrate
When the Magistrate takes cognizance of an offence
under clause (c) of sub-section (1) of section 190, that is upon
information received from any person other than a police officer or
upon his knowledge or suspicion that such offence has been
committed, the accused person has under section 191 a right to be
informed that he is entitled to have the case tried by another court,
and if the accused objects to his being tried by such Magistrate, the
case shall instead of being tried by such Magistrate, be sent to the
Sessions Judge for transfer to another Magistrate.

Cognizance of offence by Court of Session
Except as otherwise expressly provided by the Code of
Criminal Procedure or by any other law for the time being in force.
no Court of Session can take cognizance of any offence as court of
original jurisdiction unless the case has been sent to it under
section 190, sub-section (3). For example, section 198A Cr. P. C.
provides that a Court of Session "may take cognizance of such
offence, without the accused being committed to it for trial, upon a
complaint in writing made by the Public Prosecutor. The
expression "such offence" has reference to "any offence falling.
under Chapter XVI of the Pakistan Penal Code".
The word 'committed' does not fit in the new scheme of
things, for there are now no commitment proceedings. It must be
read as 'sent'.
Cognizance of offences by High Court
The High Court may take cognizance of an offence in
the manner provided by the Code of Criminal Procedure.
One way of taking cognizance of an offence by the High
Court is to withdraw a case for trial from a subordinate criminal
court to itself under section 526 Cr. P. C. When the High Court so
withdraws a case, it shall observe in such trial the same procedure-
as the subordinate court would have observed if the case had not
been so withdrawn.
Position as to cognizance of offences summed up
Having noticed the relevant provisions of the Code on
"cognizance of offences", the position, as it emerges from decided
cases, may be stated as follows:
The word 'cognizance' is a term of art
implying application of judicial mind to the
facts of a case in order to determine whether
the facts disclosed constitute an offence (Raja
Khushbakhat-ur-Rehman v State 1985
376
(ii)
(iii)
(iv)
SCMR 1314). The expression "take
cognizance of any offence" has to be
understood accordingly.
The occasion for such determination does not
arise in a case under clause (b) of section 190
unless the police submit the report under
Section 173 (Muhammad Nawaz v Noor
Muhammad PLD 1967 Lah. 176, 179). As
was held in Mehr Khan v Yaqub Khan (1981
SCMR 267), in cases under section 190
clauses (a) and (b), the Magistrate cannot take
cognizance unless there is a complete or
incomplete challan, or a complaint is before
the Magistrate.
The court takes cognizance of the case as a
whole not qua only some of the accused found
by the police to be implicated in the case.
Cognizance can be taken even if the offenders
be unknown. On taking cognizance of the
offence, the court acquires jurisdiction over
all the persons involved and not only over
persons against whom the challan is submitted
(Khushbakhat-ur-Rehman case (1985 SCMR
1314).
Under section 190, a Magistrate may take
cognizance of an offence-
a)
for the purpose of trying it himself;
or
b)
for the purpose of sending it to the
Court of Session.
As was held in Mehr Khan v Yaqub Khan
(1981 SCMR 267, 272), the position in view
of abolition of the commitment proceedings
and the consequent changes in section 190,

Once the Magistrate has taken cognizance of

qua a particular accused. The Court of Session
is, therefore, competent to summon a person
whose name occurs in column 2 of the challan
(Khushbakhat-ur-Rehman case 1985 SCMR

even an accused in respect of whom an order
of Magistrate discharging him under section

v State PLD 1988 Lah 336).

Scanned with CamScanner

Page 208
Cases in which prior sanction is required
Ordinarily anyone may prefer a complaint but sections
195 to 199 are exceptions to this general rule (Jagdesh v Joy
Narayan PLD 1963 Dacca 357). Owing to the character of certain
offences as affecting the lawful authority of public servants or
public justice, the right to prosecute has been restricted and the
courts are prohibited from taking cognizance of the offences
mentioned therein unless and until the public servants or the courts
directly concerned or their superiors make the complaint.
Of these sections, section 197 needs to be particularly
noticed. It saved a Judge, a Magistrate or any public servant who
was accused of any offence alleged to have been committed by him
while acting or purporting to act in the discharge of his official
duties from being prosecuted except with the previous sanction of
the authorities mentioned therein.
This section has been declared to be repugnant to the
Injunctions of Islam and, therefore, void (Zafar Awan case - PLD
1992 SC 72), and in terms of Article 203D of the Constitution it
has long ceased to have effect. In the same case namely Federation
of Pakistan v Zafar Awan, section 6(5) of the Pakistan Criminal
Law (Amendment) Act 1958 was also declared to be repugnant to
the Injunctions of Islam. The consequence is that for the offences
mentioned in section 197 prior sanction of the authorities
mentioned therein for prosecuting the offender and for the courts to
take cognizance of those offences is no more necessary.
Processes to procure the attendance of accused persons
The first procedural question concerns the attendance of
the accused at trial. If in custody, the accused is brought to the
count from prison; if on bail, the accused is informed of the time
and date of trial and required to attend.
Chapter XVII Cr.P.C. is titled "Of the commencement of
proceedings before court". It has two sections namely sections 204
and 205. Section 204 provides that if in the opinion of the court
taking cognizance of an offence there is sufficient ground for
proceeding and the case appears to be one in which according to
the 4 column of the Second Schedule to the Code a summons
should issue in the first instance, it shall issue summons for the
attendance of the accused and if the case appears to be one in
which according to that column a warrant should issue in the first
instance, it may issue a warrant, or if it thinks fit, a summons for
causing the accused to be brought or to appear at a certain time
before such court. This section in so far as it relates to cases in
which according to the 4h column of the Second Schedule of the
Code a summons should issue in the first instance, is to be read
with section 90 which empowers the court. for reasons to be
recorded in writing, to issue a warrant for the arrest of the accused
person-
a)
when the court sees reason to believe that the
accused has absconded or will not obey the
summons; or
b)
if the summons had been served and the
accused person failed to appear without
offering any reasonable excuse.
Process to procure attendance generally
As to the processes to procure the attendance of persons.
accused as well as witnesses, the relevant provisions are to be
found in Chapter VI Cr.P.C. titled "Of processes to compel
appearance". That chapter consists of, so far as service of summons
is concerned, of sections 68 to 73, and so far as service of warrants
of arrest is concerned, of sections 75 to 86A.
A duly signed and sealed summons is to be served.
section 69 so provides, on a natural person by delivering or
tendering to him personally a duplicate of the summons, and on a

Scanned with CamScanner

Page 209
body corporate through its secretary etc, or by registered post
When the person summoned cannot by the exercise of due
diligence be found, resort may be had to substituted service, hy, as
is provided in sections 70 and 71, leaving a copy of the summons
with an adult member of his family and obtaining his signature on
the back of the duplicate: if service in these modes is not possible.
the serving officer shall affix a copy of the summons at some
conspicuous part of the ordinary place of residence of the person to

State or a statutory body or company will be effected, as provided
in section 72 Cr.P.C., by sending the summons in duplicate to the
head of the office, who shall cause it to be served on the person
concerned in the manner provided in section 69.
When the person to be served resides outside the court's
territorial jurisdiction, a summons in duplicate shall under section
73 Cr.P.C. go to a Magistrate in whose jurisdiction the person to be
served resides for service upon that person.
A warrant of arrest shall always be in writing, and shall
be duly signed and sealed within the meaning of section 75 Cr.P.C.
It may direct that if the person to be arrested executes a bond with
sufficient sureties for his attendance before the issuing court, he
shall be released on furnishing such security. The serving officer
shall send the security bond to the court. A warrant shall ordinarily
be directed to a police officer, but if its immediate execution is
necessary and no police officer is available, it may be directed to
any other person, even a private person. The warrant shall be an
authority for such officer or person to arrest the named person. A
Magistrate of the First Class may direct a warrant for the arrest of a
non-bailable offence to a landholder or a manager of land within
his territorial jurisdiction.
A warrant of arrest is also an authority, section 82 so
provides, for its execution anywhere in Pakistan. When it is to be
executed beyond the local limits of the issuing court, the executing
police officer shall have it endorsed by a Magistrate or the officer
in charge of a police station within whose limits it is to be
382
executed. This will be sufficient authority to the executing police
officer to execute it within those limits. But if the obtaining of such
endorsement is reasonably believed to prevent the execution of the
warrant, the executing officer may not obtain it.
Under section 83 Cr.P.C. when a warrant is to be
executed outside the issuing court's jurisdiction. "such court may
instead of directing such warrant to a police officer. forward the
same by post or otherwise to any Magistrate or District
Superintendent of Police within the local limits of whose
jurisdiction it is to be executed". Such Magistrate or District
Superintendent of Police "shall endorse his name thereon and if
practicable cause it to be executed in manner hereinbefore provided
within the local limited of his jurisdiction".
Under section 80 Cr.P.C.. the person executing a warrant
must notify its substance to the person to be arrested, and if so
required must show the warrant to him.
When the warrant is executed outside the limits of
issuing court's jurisdiction, then, section 85 Cr.P.C. requires that
"the person arrested shall, unless the court which issued the
warrant is within twenty miles of the place of arrest or is nearer
than the Magistrate or District Superintendent of Police within the
local limits of whose jurisdiction the arrest was made or unless
security is taken under section 76, be taken to such Magistrate or
District Superintendent of Police".
Section 86 provides for the manner in which persons
arrested under sections 83 and 85, that is persons arrested outside
the issuring court's territorial jurisdiction, are to be dealt with. The
Magistrate or the District Superintendent of Police shall if the
person arrested appears to be the person intended by the issuing
court direct his removal in custody to such court. Provided that if
the offence is a bailable offence or the issuing court has under
section 76 endorsed a direction that he be released on furnishing
security or bail, such Magistrate or Superintendent of Police "shall

take such bail or security
which issued the warrant".
, and forward the hond to the court
But if the case is not one falling under the above proviso

and for sufficient reasons, "release the person on interim bail on
such bond or security as the Sessions Judge thinks fit and direct the
person to appear by a specified date before the court which issued

Section 86A Cr.P.C. provides for the manner in which a
person arrested under section 85 Cr.P.C. is to be removed in
custody to a place in the Tribal Areas. Such a person shall be
produced before a Magistrate of the place of arrest and "such
Magistrate in directing the removal shall hear the case in the same
manner and have the same jurisdiction and powers, as nearly as
may be, including the power to order the production of evidence, as
if the person arrested were charged with an offence committed
within the jurisdiction of such Magistrate; and such Magistrate
shall direct the removal of the arrested person in custody if he is
satisfied that the evidence produced before him raises a strong or
probable presumption that the person arrested committed the
offence mentioned in the warrant".
Protection against unlawful arrest:
The above-noted provisions contain some protections
against unlawful arrest. Yet, they fall short of the safeguards
provided by the Constitution, Articles 9 and 10, which have been
dealt with in the Constitutional Criminal Procedure part of this
book. For example, the person arrested must be produced before a
Magistrate within 24 hours of his arrest; this applies equally to
arrests in pursuance of court warrants. As was held in the leading
case on the subject, Manzoor Elahi v Federation of Pakistan (PLD
1975 SC 66), an arrest which is in violation of Article 10 is
unlawful, e.g. if the person arrested is not produced before a
384
Magistrate within 24 hours. Thus production of the arrestec before
a Superintendent of Police will not satisfy the requirements of
Article 10. To this extent, the above-noted provisions are violative
of Article 10 of the Constitution and are void.
Persons arrested in a settled area e.g. Lahore or Karachi
for removal to a tribal area are a category apart and have, in
addition to the benefits of the provisions of section 86 Cr.P.C., e.g.
bail by the Sessions Court of the place of arrest, also the protection
of section 86A, which requires the Magistrate before whom he is
produced to hold an enquiry to examine that the warrant of arrest
issued by an authority in tribal area is not a mere pretext to deprive
him of the protections of the Constitution and ordinary laws of the
land, but there is a genuine strong prima facie case against him to
allow him to be removed to the tribal area. The intention of the
law, in according this special treatment to arrestees to be removed
to tribal areas, is clear. It is to make it doubly sure that such
persons are treated fairly in accordance with the Constitution and
law before they are handed over to the tribal authorities.
Exemption from personal attendance
Section 205 authorizes a Magistrate, when he issues
summons to an accused person, if he sees reason so to do, to
dispense with the personal attendance of the accused and permit
him to appear by his Pleader.
This power to exempt personal appearance applies when
a summons is issued "in the first instance". It does not apply where
a warrant is issued in the first instance. As regards presence of the
accused during the course of trial, that is to say, after the stage of
charge, the relevant provisions are to be found in sections 428, 509.
510, 512 and 540A Cr.P.C., which will be dealt with later.
Other matters
(a)
Supplying copies
After the court has procured the attendance of an
385
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 211
accused person, the first step in the trial of cases, before the
Magistrate as well as before the High Court and the Court of
Session, is the supply of certain statements and documents to the
accused. When the trial is by Magistrate, the statements and
documents required to be supplied to the accused persons are those
mentioned in section 241A and when the trial is before the High
Court and Court of Session, the statements and documents to be
supplied to the accused persons are those mentioned in Section
265C.
It is note-worthy that there are two classes of case triable
before Magistrates, namely, those triable summarily under Chapter
XXII and those triable under Chapter XX. The relevance of this
distinction is that the statements and documents mentioned in
section 241A are to be supplied to the accused persons only in
cases which are tried under Chapter XX, that is, in regular trials.
The statements and documents to be supplied under
sections 241A and 265C are to be supplied free of cost "not less
than seven days before the commencement of the trial",
Included in the copies to be supplied to the accused
person under sections 241A and 265C Cr.P.C. are the statements of
witnesses recorded during investigation under sections 161 and 164
Cr.P.C. A statement recorded by a police officer under section 161.
if reduced into writing, is not to be signed by the person making it:
such a statement cannot be used at any inquiry or trial except for
the purpose of contradicting that person in the witness box in the
manner provided by Article 140 of the Qanun-e-Shahadat Order
1984. A statement of a witness recorded by a Magistrate under
section 164 Cr.P.C. may be recorded in the presence of the accused
and the accused may be given an opportunity of cross-examining
the witness making the statement. Such a statement has to be
recorded in the manner provided in section 364 and is, like a
statement recorded under section 161, a previous statement within
the meaning of Article 140 of the 1984 Order.
Effect of non-supplying copies
Suppose that a statement recorded under section 161 or
164 Cr.P.C. is not supplied to the accused. This will be a
contravention of the provisions of sections 241A and 265C Cr.P.C.
The question is, what is the effect of this contravention? It was held
by the Privy Council in Pulukuri Kotayya v King (74 IA 65) that
the right given to an accused person by section 162 is a very
valuable one and often provides important material for cross-
examination of the prosecution witnesses. "However slender the
material for cross-examination may seem to be, it is difficult to
gauge its possible effect. Minor inconsistencies in his several
statements may not embarrass a truthful witness but may cause an
untruthful witness to prevaricate, and may lead to an ultimate
breakdown of the whole of his evidence......... Their Lordships
would, however, observe that where...........the statements were
never made available to the accused an inference, which is almost
irresistible, arises of prejudice to the accused".
In Faiz Ahmad v State (PLD 1960 SC 8), the
investigating officer had incorporated the substance of the
statement made by the approver in the police diary. At the trial,
when the defence asked for a copy of the statement, it was said that
that was not a statement under section 161 Cr.P.C. and a copy was
not supplied. The appellant was convicted on the basis of the
approver's testimony at the trial supported by some circumstantial
evidence. On appeal to the High Court, when non-supply of the
copy of the approver's statement during investigation was urged as
a ground, a copy of the statement was offered but was refused. The
High Court found that there were two contradictions between the
approver's statement during investigation and the one at the trial
but found an explanation for both. The Supreme Court discussed
the possible courses open to the High Court in such circumstances;
it could order a retrial, or if the irregularity had occasioned a failure
of justice, could recall the approver, supply a copy of his statement
to the defence and direct him to cross-examine the approver or it
could exclude the evidence of the approver from consideration.
386
387
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 212
Section 162 Cr.P.C. stands partly repealed
In Z. A Bhutto case (PLD 1979 SC 53) the question was
as to the effect of the failure of the prosecution to supply to the
accused copies of the statements of two approvers and a witness
recorded by the police during investigation. In order to properly
appreciate the legal position, so observed Anwar-ul-Haq, C.J. (Para
261 of the Judgment), it was necessary to consider the relevant
portions of the provisions of sections 161, 162, 172, 265C and 537
Cr.P.C. and section 145 of the Evidence Act, 1872 (Now Article
140 of Qanun-e-Shahadat). After tracing the legislative history of
some of these provisions, sections 162 and 537 in particular, and
observing that "section 265C (and 241A) Cr.P.C. have brought
significant changes in the law consequent upon the abolition of
commitment proceedings in the trial of serious offences", the
learned Chief Justice noticed that under section 265C Cr.P.C. "in
all cases instituted upon a police report, copies of statements under
section 161 Cr.P.C. shall be supplied free of cost to the accused,
not later than seven days before the commencement of the trial".
This provision, it was held,
"impliedly repeals the provisions of section 162 Cr.P.C.
to the extent that the copies of the statements must now
be supplied by the State seven days before the
commencement of the trial"
and it is not necessary to wait, as the first proviso to subsection (1)
of section 162 Cr.P.C. provides, till the witness is called by the
prosecution or the accused asks for them.
When the statements are in police diaries
In Z A Bhutto case, the statements of the above-named
witnesses were embodied in the case diaries kept under section 172
Cr.P.C., and this raised the question whether they could be treated
as statement under section 161 Cr.P.C. for the purposes of section
265C Cr.P.C. It was held (Para 278 of the Judgment):
388
"Where a statement has been made to
the police by a person during
investigation, the police officer should
record it separately in terms of section
161(3) Cr.P.C. Where, however, he does
not do so, but proceeds to incorporate it
in the case diary, the said statement
should be construed as a statement under
section 161 Cr.P.C. provided of course it
is in substance and essence a statement
of the witness. Thus it is the
nature of the statement and not the label
given to it which will determine its real
character. The provisions of section
265C are salutary and enacted for the
benefit of the accused, conferring as they
do a valuable right in his favour of being
apprised of the case set up against him.
This right cannot be taken away or
evaded by allowing the investigating
officer to misuse his authority by
incorporating in the case diary the
statements recorded by him during
investigation which, though in spirit and
essence fall within the purview of
section 161 Cr.P.C. but are erroneously
or mischievously embodied by him in
the case diaries. This safeguard has
become all the more necessary as
commitment proceedings have been
abolished........ Hence, it is necessary to
construe the provisions of section 265C
(and of section 241) liberally and in the
spirit in which they have been
enacted.......

Accordingly, the statements in question, though incorporated in
police diaries kept under section 172 Cr.P.C., were treated in
essence and substance statements falling under section 161(3)
Cr.P.C; it was held that those statements ought to have been
supplied to the accused persons under section 265C Cr.P.C.

the statement, though incorporated in a police

An inspection note recorded by an investigating officer
on his first visit to the place of occurrence and the note recorded by
him on recoveries made are not substantive evidence; they can be
used only to contradict or discredit the witnesses when they appear
into the witness box (Taj Muhammad v Muhammad Yousaf - PLD
1976 SC 234, 239). The question as to the effect of the failure or
omission to supply their copies to the accused will also, it seems,
fall to be dealt with in accordance with the above-stated principles.
