(b)
Accused's Counsel
the
This important preliminary step before
commencement of the trial is to ensure that the accused's right to
consult and be defended by a legal practitioner of his choice
guaranteed by Article 10 of the Constitution which has been
discussed earlier in the Constitutional Criminal Procedure part of
this book is not denied. This right to be defended by counsel
proceeds on the view that "all but the most gifted and exceptional
defendants are ill-equipped to defend themselves in a criminal
prosecution. A maze of procedures and technicalities which govern
the criminal justice process has long been recognized as demanding
the skills of a trained lawyer to preserve some parity between the
State and the individual so that the defendant can be given a
meaningful chance to tell his side of the story. Giving the
defendant 'his day in court' is of the essence of due process of law"
(Please see "Constitutional Interpretation" by Craig R. Ducat and
Harold W. Chase, 5 ed. p. 629).
Most of the documents supplied to the accused under
sections 241A and 265C Cr.P.C. are technical documents and to
understand them and to make proper use of them there is need for
the assistance of a technical man namely lawyer. Therefore, this is
the most appropriate point of trial at which the court's duty to
ensure, that this fundamental right is not denied, arises.
Besides Article 10 of the Constitution, section 340,
sub-section (1), Cr.P.C. provides for a right to a person accused of
an offence before a criminal court or against whom proceedings are
initiated under the Code to be defended by a pleader.
The accused person must be given a reasonable
opportunity to engage counsel and the counsel engaged must be
given a reasonable opportunity to defend him. It has been held that
where this right is denied, the trial is vitiated and a law which
denies this right is void (Moslimuddin Sikdar v Chief Secretary-
392
PLD 1957 Dacca 101; Mrs. Rowshan Bijaya Shaukat v
Government PLD 1965 Dacca 241).
Counsel for Indigent persons at government expense
Though the Constitution gives to the accused person the
right to consult and be defended by a legal practitioner yet it does
not impose on the State any obligation to provide counsel for the
defence of indigent persons accused of capital offences. But to be
fair to the accused, that is, to place him on an equal footing with
the prosecution, Chapter 24C of High Court Rules and Orders,
Volume IX, provides that accused persons tried for capital offences
should have the assistance of a lawyer. It reads:
Presiding Officer to report whether accused
can afford to engage counsel. If the accused is
unrepresented in a sessions case and cannot afford to
engage a counsel, the Sessions Judge shall make
arrangement to employ a counsel at Government
expense. Counsel in such cases should be appointed well
in time to enable him to study the documents mentioned
in section 265C of the Code of Criminal Procedure.
2.
Counsel for accused to be provided by Sessions
Judge. When the accused is a woman prisoner who is
unable to afford a counsel the presiding officer on an
application made by her shall make arrangements to
employ a counsel at Government expense to defend her
in all offences except those triable in a summary way
under chapter XXII of the Code of Criminal Procedure.
3.
Fees of Counsel. The legal practitioner thus
engaged by the Court trying the case shall receive the
same fees as private practitioners engaged under the note
to rule X (2) of the rules regulating the conduct of
business in the Law Department, and the fees shall be
entered in the same register and drawn in the same
manner as is prescribed for such practitioners".

(c)
hearing
Consultation for, and Fixing dates of
For the expeditious disposal of sessions cases
instructions are to be found in the High Court Rules and Orders,
Vol. 3 chapter 24-B. Sessions Judges should reserve for each
sessions case several days for trial, preferably in consultation with
the prosecutor and the defence counsel. The trial of a sessions case
shall, as a rule, be held from day to day and unless there be
compelling reasons for adjournment, there should be no
adjournment.
Day to day hearing is the rule
The rule that the trial of sessions cases must proceed
from day to day and there should be no adjournment used to be
strictly observed. The result was that the trial invariably concluded
within the days reserved for it; prosecution evidence was recorded.
defence evidence was recorded, arguments were heard and as soon
as the arguments were concluded, the Sessions Judge was able to
pronounce judgment. The advantages of this course are too
apparent to need emphasis. The evidence of the witnesses was
fresh in the mind of the Judge and so was the demeanour of the
witnesses and those are advantages which an appellate court does
not have. Hence the rule that the appellate court would not
ordinarily interfere with the trial court's opinion as to the
credibility of a witness. To strictly comply with this rule the
practice of the Sessions Judges used to be not to take up the trial of
another sessions case till the conclusion of the trial of the case
already in hand. Unfortunately, this rule of day to day hearing is
now observed more in its breach. In the High Court Rules, referred
to above, notice has been taken of this "flagrant disregard of the
day to day hearing rule"; in some cases sessions trials have, after
their commencement, taken months and in some cases years to
conclude. Taking a very serious view of this practice, the High
Court has required:
i)
ii)
explanation to be furnished in monthly
sessions statements of any cases pending over
six months; and
explanation for every case in which trial has
commenced but has not concluded during the
days reserved for them; this explanation shall
mention the date of the commencement of the
trial and reason for each adjournment.
What has been said above about the sessions cases
should apply equally to the trial of cases before the Magistrates.

395
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 216
(d)
Procedure for the trial of complaint and
police cases arising out of the same offence
It has been seen that under section 190, a Magistrate
may take cognizance of an offence (a) upon receiving a complaint;
(b) upon a police report under section 173 Cr.P.C. and (c) upon
information received by the Magistrate. As regards the cases
exclusively triable by the Court of Session, the Magistrate is.
whether it is a complaint case or a police case, to send the case for
trial to the Court of Session without recording any evidence.
Now, in respect of an offence, there may be a police case
only or there may be a complaint case only. But there may be cases
in which out of an offence arise two cases, one being a police case
and the other being a complaint case. For example, the firs
informant in a police case names three persons A, B & C as culprits
of a murder in the FIR. The police after investigation finds that the
offence was committed by A and B only and that C was innocent
of the offence. Dissatisfied with the police investigation, the first
informant or any other heir of the victim may file a complaint
against A. B and C. In this way, there will be two cases before the
court arising out of the same incident.
This is the stage when the court is confronted with the
question how to proceed with the trial of such cases as to cause no
prejudice to either party. The leading authority on this point is Nur
Elahi v State (PLD 1966 SC 708); it was held:
"After considering all aspects of the
matter, we hold that a fair procedure
would be for the learned trial Judge to
take up the complaint case first for trial.
During that case the learned trial Judge
may call the witnesses mentioned in the
police challan, if they were not already
examined, on behalf of the complainant
as court witnesses under section 540 of
the Criminal Procedure Code, so that
396
a
they can be cross-examined by both the
parties. This will enable the court to
have the whole relevant evidence
included in one trial and a decision could
be arrived at after a proper consideration
of the entire material relied on by the
parties. The accused persons would in
addition obviously have the right to
adduce defence evidence if they so
choose. If that trial results in
conviction, it will be for the Public
Prosecutor to consider whether or not he
should withdraw from the prosecution,
with the permission of the court, under
section 494 of the Code of Criminal
Procedure, in police challan case. It
would be easy for him to take such a
decision after the whole evidence has
been thrashed out in the first trial. If the
first case ends in an acquittal, he might
still have to consider whether the police
case has not been so seriously damaged
by what has been brought out in the first
trial, as to justify withdrawal of the
prosecution. Otherwise the second trial
would be allowed to proceed to its
normal conclusion and the parties would
have the advantage of utilizing the
material placed on the record of the
earlier trial, by way of cross-examination
of the relevant witnesses as permitted by
law.
This procedure is being suggested to
avoid a difficulty that might otherwise
confront the complainant. If the police
challan is taken up first for trial, the
complainant would be under a handicap
397
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 217
in so far as he would not be in a position
to cross-examine the witnesses for the
prosecution.
Another difficulty may arise in respect
of conducting the case on behalf of the
complainant in the first trial. Normally,
of course, under the law, the Public
Prosecutor is to be in charge of the case,
even if the trial is based on a private
complaint. The Public Prosecutor,
however, in the special circumstances of
the case, could permit the complainant's
counsel to conduct the proceedings on
his behalf under
his directions.
Alternatively and that may meet the
situation more adequately, Government
in the interest of justice, could notify the
complainant's counsel, as a special
Public Prosecutor, for the conduct of that
case alone. This would ensure full
justice to the complainant and he would
not be left with any sense of grievance".
In that case, Kaikaus J. wrote a dissent; in his view the
two proceedings should be consolidated and there should be a
single hearing so that the whole of the evidence is produced before
the court and then a decision recorded.
The rule in Nur Ellahi does not however lay down an
invariable rule that the complaint case is always to be tried first,
Where the version and the accused are practically the same in both
the complaint and the challan cases, a separate trial may not be
necessary. As was held in Zulfiqar Ali Bhutto v State (PLD 1979
SC 53) there is no necessity for a separate trial of the two cases
when technically speaking there are neither two sets of accused nor
different versions nor any additional evidence is being examined
by the complainant. It was only to avoid prejudice to the
398
complainant that a particular procedure was devised in Nur Ellahi
case but to say that invariably it should be followed even if the
facts are distinguishable is not correct. This view was followed in...
Raja Khushbakht-ur-Rehman v State (1985 SCMR 1314).
The ratio in Nur Ellahi case was considered in
Muhammad Bohra v State (PLD 1989 Lahore 18), where it was
observed: "If I may venture to say, the procedure which
commended itself to Kaikaus J. has this advantage that both the
sets of accused persons will be before the Court, and both will have
the opportunity to cross-examine all the witnesses that are
proposed to be produced in the complaint case and the police
challan case",
In Muhammad Bohra v State, for the murder of one
Barkat Ali, three persons were named as culprits in the F.I.R. They
were Muhammad Bohra. Muhammad Hussain and Muhammad
Ashiq. The last named was killed before trial. As a result of
investigation, the police however found that the above-named three
persons were innocent of the offence and the persons responsible
for killing Barkat were Mansha and Mushi Muhammad.
Accordingly in the final report under section 173 Cr.P.C. the names
of Mansha and Khushi Muhammad were placed in column 3 and
those of Muhammad Bohra and Muhammad Hussain in column 2
of the challan. The first informant filed a private complaint against
Muhammad Bohra, Muhammad Hussain and Muhammad Ashiq. It
was in these facts observed in Muhammad Bohra v State: "Taking
this case as an example, suppose that in the trial of the complaint
case the P.Ws. in the challan case had been called and examined as
court witnesses, and the trial had resulted in the acquittal of the
appellants. It is obvious that in recording the acquittal, the Court
would have considered all the evidence, including the evidence of
the court witnesses, who the sccused persons in the challan case.
Mansha and Khushi Muhammad, had had no opportunity to cross-
examine. As the second trial, that is the trial of the challan case,
I would be by the same Judge. Mansha and Khushi Muhammad
would, not unnaturally, go to their trial with a feeling that probably
399
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 218
their fate has, by the verdict in the complaint case, been already
sealed".
Chapter 6
COMMENCEMENT OF TRIAL
Screening during Judicial Phase
We have already dealt with the screening process during
the administrative phase, that is, by the Public Prosecutor to
safeguard against unwarranted prosecutions.
In America, screening may either be by the "Grand
Jury" to decide whether to indict or it may be by the Magistrate
who must determine at a preliminary hearing whether the
prosecution has a prima facie case there is sufficient evidence
supporting the charge - "the standard test for testing the sufficiency
of the evidence is one of the probable cause, considerably less than
the burden the prosecution must bear in establishing guilt at trial".
The Fifth Amendment to the US Constitution provides
that "no person shall be held to answer for a capital or
otherwise infamous case unless on presentment or indictment of a
Grant Jury". "Infamous offence" has been held to include all felony
offences. Thus, the Fifth Amendment interposes the Grand Jury
between the prosecutor and the prospective defendant. The classic
description of the Grant Jury's function is to be found in Wood v
Georgia (370 US 375 (1962):
"Historically, this body (the Grand Jury) has been
regarded as a primary security to the innocent
against hasty, malicious and oppressive
prosecution; it serves the invaluable function in our
society of standing between the accuser and the
accused, ......to determine whether a charge
is founded upon reason or was dictated by an
intimidating power or by malice and personal ill
will".
A Grand Jury's proceedings may be secret and even in the absence
of the accused.
Though, no such body as a grant jury is recognized in
the laws of Pakistan, yet, it appears that there are provisions in the
Code of Criminal Procedure which are designed to ensure
screening before a man is put to the agony of trial.
Thus, section 190 Cr.P.C., which empowers the
Magistrates of the First Class or any other Magistrate especially
empowered to take cognizance of offences, provides that the
Magistrate 'may take cognizance of an offence upon a complaint.
upon a police report or upon his own information. "May" gives
discretion: the Magistrate may or may not take cognizance. The
discretion here given is "judicial discretion", and requires that the
Magistrate will determine, before taking cognizance, that it will be
lawful to do so. The term 'cognizance' has been held to be a term
of art implying application of judicial mind to the facts of the case
in order to determine whether the facts disclosed do or do not
constitute an offence (Raja Khushbakhat-ur-Rehman -1998
SCMR 1314). Even in cases in which the Magistrate is required to
send the case to the Court of Session for trial, he is not to act as a
mere post office; he is to apply his judicial mind to the facts to
ascertain as to whether the case is really one which is triable
exclusively by the Court of Session or whether it is one which he
can proceed to try himself. Thus, section 204 Cr.P.C. provides that
"if in the opinion of a court taking cognizance of an offence, there
is sufficient ground for proceeding", he may summon the accused.
Existence of "sufficient ground for proceeding" is therefore a
condition precedent for summoning the accused to stand trial. The
Magistrate is thus required to play the neutral role of a judicial
officer to see, at this early stage, that at least a prima facie case - a
case supported by sufficient evidence supporting the charge-exits
to justify the summoning of the accused to undergo the ordeal of
trial.
400
401
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 219
So concerned is the law with protecting the innocent
from the ordeal of trial that in serious cases triable by the Court of
Session or the High Court, section 265-D requires the count, before
framing a formal charge against the accused, to peruse the police
report or the complaint and all other documents and statements
filed by the prosecution and to form an opinion that "there is
ground for proceeding with the trial of the accused".
Open Court
Let her (the truth) and falsehood grapple; who ever saw
the truth put to the worse, in a free and open encounter. (John
Milton in Areopagitica).
said:
In Scott v Scott (1913) AC 417, 463), Lord Atkinson
"The hearing of a case in public may be,
and often is...... painful, humiliating or
deterrent both to parties and witnesses,
and in many cases, those of a criminal
nature, the details may be so indecent as
to tend to injure public morals, but all is
tolerated and endured, because it is felt
that in public trial is to be found, on the
whole, the best security for the pure.
impartial and efficient administration of
justice, the best means of winning for it
public confidence and respect".
The right to a public hearing has been neatly
encapsulated in the Amnesty International Fair Trials Manual,
Chapter 14, as being "an essential safeguard of the fairness and
independence of the judicial process, and means of protecting
public confidence in the justice system". This statement is founded,
among others, upon Article 10 of the Universal Declaration, Article
6(1) of the European Convention and Article XXVI of the
American Declaration. However, open trial means an orderly trial
and not a disorderly one. (Zulfiqar Ali Bhutto case - PLD 1979 SC
53 at p 143); and public trial concept has never been viewed as
imposing a rigid, inflexible straight jacket on the courts and it is
generally conceded that the right to have the general public present
at a trial is subject to some limitations. The trial Judge has
discretion to close to the public, even without the consent of
accused where there is good cause for such action (Z A Bhutto
case, PLD 1979 SC 53 at p 178).
In Ali Nawaz Gardezi (PLD 1963 SC 51, 83) a
complaint case in which the accused, a highly placed bureaucrat,
posted as Commissioner of a Division at the relevant time was tried
for the offence of adultery, the learned trial Judge found no special
features as would have justified departure from the normal rule
enacted by section 352 Cr.P.C. that the hearing of a case should be
in open court. In the opinion of the Supreme Court, "the
circumstances that a higher officer of Government, who also held
military rank, was cited as an accused person, by a private
complainant, and this at a time when the country lay under the
martial law, were compelling considerations that favoured an open
trial so that justice should not only be done, but should manifestly
be seen to be done".
By Section 352, the place in which any criminal court is
held for the purpose of inquiring into or trying any offence is an
open court, to which the public generally may have access, so far
as the same can conveniently contain them. The proviso to this
section empowers the Judge or Magistrate, if he thinks fit, to order
at any stage of inquiry or trial that the public generally or any
particular person shall not have access to, or be or remain in, the
room or building used by the court.
The first part embodies the essential and salutary
principle of administration of justice that justice must not only be
done but should also appear to be done. This necessarily carries
with it the right to an open trial in the full gaze of the public.
including the press. This in tum leads to a healthy, fair and
403
402
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 220
objective administration of justice calculated to promote public
confidence in the court and is conducive to dispel all misgivings
about it (Zulfiqar Ali Bhutto v State - PLD 1979 SC 53; cited in
Khan Isfandyar Wali v Federation of Pakistan - PLD 201 SC 607,
924). The proviso to section 352 shows that the rule is not rigid and
inflexible and it should not be pressed to a breaking point so as to
defeat the very ends of justice. Therefore, the Judge or the
Magistrate has power to forbid access of the public generally or of
any particular person for sufficient reasons in the interest of
administration of justice. In this behalf paragraph 3 of Chapter 1 of
the High Courts Rules and Orders Vol. 3 is also relevant.
This section, however, does not give any right to be tried
at a particular place, and so long as the right to a fair trial is
ensured, the accused may be tried even in jail if that is necessary
for safe administration of justice (State v Islamuddin - 1984
Pakistan Crl. L.J. 273).
Speedy trial and adjournments
This is also the stage for a very important reminder that
the policy of the criminal law is to bring the accused to justice as
speedily as possible, so that if found guilty he is punished ad if
innocent he is acquitted or discharged. This is recognized by the
Constitution, Article 37(d), as one of the Principles of Policy: The
State shall....ensure inexpensive and expeditious justice. The
State can ensure it through its judicial organ, namely, the Judiciary:
as Article 29 of the Constitution enjoins, "it is the responsibility of
the State and of each person performing functions on behalf of an
organ or authority of the State, to act in accordance with those
Principles. As was said in Muhammad Hussain v State
(PLD 1959 (WP) Lah 322, 329) the intention of the law is that a
criminal case must be expeditiously disposed of without
unnecessary delay. Day to day hearing is the rule and adjournment
to a date beyond the day reserved for the trial is an exception. This.
as has been already pointed out, is the object of prior consultation
with the public prosecutor and the defence counsel for fixing dates
of hearing.
This is the point of trial therefore when one must have a
closer look at the provisions of section 344 Cr.P.C. This section
reads:
"344. Power to postpone or adjourn proceedings.... (1)
If, from the absence of a witness, or any other
reasonable cause, it becomes necessary or advisable to
postpone the commencement of, or adjoum any inquiry
or trial, the court may, if it thinks fit, by order in writing,
stating the reasons therefore, from time to time,
postpone or adjourn the same on such terms as it thinks
fit for such time as it considers reasonable, and may by a
warrant remand the accused if in custody:
Remand. Provided that no Magistrate shall remand an
accused person to custody under this section for a term
exceeding fifteen days at a time".
Power to adjourn is judicial discretion
This section empowers the 'court', which term includes
the court of a Magistrate, to postpone the commencement of an
inquiry or trial or to adjourn an inquiry or trial. The power is
discretionary. It must however be remembered that the discretion is
a judicial discretion and that the guidance for the exercise of
discretion is provided by the section itself. There can be
adjournment if, and only if, "from the absence of a witness or other
reasonable cause it becomes necessary or advisable to
.......adjourn any inquiry or trial". That is not all. To prevent
adjournment of cases as a matter of routine, the section requires the
court to record an order in writing, stating the reasons for
adjournment. In a case in which the accused is in custody.
adjournment without reasonable cause is a very serious matter, so
serious indeed, that it may involve violation of the basic principle
of criminal jurisprudence namely expeditious trial and may give
rise to an action for damages against the State.
404
405
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 221
The section provides that adjournment can be made for
absence of a witness or any other reasonable cause. Any cause
other than the absence of a witness may be a cause necessitating or
justifying an adjournment on reasonable grounds. What is a
reasonable ground is a question of fact in each case. The court must
apply its mind to its reasonableness and should not grant an
adjournment mechanically and without good cause. The recording
of reasons is as necessary a condition as the reasonableness of the
cause for which adjournment is granted (Muhammad Hussain v
State-PLD 1959 (WP) Lah 322, 329).
Adjournment for an indefinite period
The power under section 344 is to postpone or adjourn
"from time to time" and "for such time as it considers reasonable".
There was a controversy as to whether the expressions "from time
to time" and "for such time as it considers reasonable" give the
power to adjourn a case sine die, that is, for an indefinite period.
This controversy was set at rest in Shadi Khan v Muhammad
Saleem (PLD 1978 SC 38). It was held that these expressions
should not be given a rigid meaning "for in doing so it would lead
to an impossible situation necessitating the production of a number
of accused in court and thereby causing hindrance to the trial of the
cases. On this view of the matter, there is no occasion for
postponing the commencement of the trial now and again".
Therefore even if the period was not specified still the interregnum
must be regarded as reasonable and a sufficient compliance of the
words "for such time". The result is that cases such as Saif-ur-
Rehman v State (PLD 1978 Lah 314) and Sajjad Hussain v State
(PLD 1978 Lah 922) and the cases relied upon in those cases stand
over-ruled
Shadi Khan v Muhammad Saleem arose out of a
sessions case; that is to say, it concerned the power of the Sessions
Court to adjourn a case sine die. In this behalf, it is significant to
note that while subsection (1) of section 344 uses the general
expression "count", its proviso deals with the power of Magistrates.
Now when an accused is in custody, the question of adjourning a
406
case is closely linked with remanding the accused to jail. That is
why subsection (1), when it gives the power to adjourn, also gives
the power to remand the accused in custody. The combined effect
of subsection (1) of section 344 and its proviso seems to be that
while the Court of Session and a High Court may adjourn a case
for an indefinite period and may also remand an accused to custody.
for an indefinite period or sine die, the power of a Magistrate to
remand an accused to custody is subject to the condition that the
remand shall not exceed 15 days at a time.
Duty of court in case of abuse or delay
It remains to consider the difficult question - what is the
duty of the court in a situation where the prosecution persistently
fails without reasonable cause to produce its evidence and seeks
adjournments unjustifiably? The court may in such a case proceed
to judgment immediately. Justice delayed is justice denied. For the
defence of the accused must suffer by lapse of time and the
prosecution may also suffer likewise. A fair and speedy trial is the
essence and essential of judicial administration in a civilized
country. Protracted proceedings are a mockery of the law and must
be deemed to be an abuse of process of courts. (Muhammad
Hussain v State-PLD 1959 WP Lah 322, 330).
Delaying tactics may amount to abuse of process of court
On abuse of the process of court or process of law, cases
from the English jurisdiction provide an instructive study. The
reason why this power to prevent abuse of process of law or
process of court exists was stated by Lord Denning MR in
Goldsmith v Sperrings Ltd [(1977) 2 All ER 566, 574 cited in Sh.
Muhammad Shafiq v Abdul Hamid-1992 P Cr. LJ 229)]:
"In a civilized society, legal process is the machinery for
keeping order and doing justice. It can be used properly
or it can be abused. It is used properly when it is invoked
for the vindication of men's rights or the enforcement of
just claims. It is abused when it is diverted from its true
407
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 222
course so as to serve extortion or oppression; or to exert
pressure so as to achieve an improper end. When it is so
abused, it is a tort, a wrong known to the law. The
Judges can and will intervene to stop it. They will stay
the legal process, if they can, before any harm is done. If
they cannot stop it in time, and harm is done, they will
give damages against the wrongdoer".
Abuse elaborated
A characteristic case for the exercise of stopping the
proceedings or procceding to judgment immediately occurs where
substantial delay has been caused either by a deliberate act of the
prosecution, for example, some improper or malafide use of the
procedure of the court, or by inefficiency on the part of the
prosecution or even something having gone wrong with the system.
The power of Magistrates to decline to proceed with the case has
been recognized in such cases, though the power has been held to
be "very strictly confined". The power to stop a prosecution, it has
been held, arises only when it is an abuse of the process of the
court. It may be an abuse of process if either (a) prosecution have
manipulated or misused the process of the court so as to deprive the
defendant of the protection provided by the law or to take unfair
advantage of a technicality, or (b) on the balance of probability, the
defendant has been, or will be, prejudiced in the preparation or
conduct of his defence by delay on the part of prosecution which is
unjustifiable. The ultimate object of this discretionary power is to
ensure that there should be a fair trial according to law, which
involves fairness both to the defendant and the prosecution for as
Lord Diplock said in Sang case (1979) 2 All ER 1222, 1230). "The
fairness of a trial is not all one-sided; it requires that those who are
undoubtedly guilty should be convicted as well as that those about
whose guilt there is any reasonable doubt should be acquitted".
Where as a result of the delay the defendant has suffered
considerable hardship, for instance, where the proceedings have
been hanging over his head for a long time, this can be a ground for
stopping the proceedings and to proceed to judgment immediately
408
(See R V Derby Crown Court ex. p. Brooks [(1985) 80 Cr. APP. R.
164].
In the English law, there is power in the court in cases of
miscarriage of justice, to stay the proceedings; its effect is to
terminate the case against the accused.
Adjournment on payment of costs
Instead of refusing adjournment, and taking the extreme
step of proceeding to judgment immediately, the court may adjourn
the case by penalizing the party at fault. The words 'on such terms
as it thinks fit' seem to empower the court to grant adjournment
conditionally on payment of costs. The courts have been exercising
this power (See for example Bishambar v Ramchand AIR 1926
Lah 407; Sh. Abdul Haq v Crown PLD 1955 FC 401, 409 and
Dr. Manzoor Hussain v State, 1969 P Cr. LJ 336) and this should
dispel the notion that costs are a special feature of civil litigation
and have no role to play in criminal cases. Costs are awarded to
compensate the party who suffers by an unnecessary or
unjustifiable adjournment and should therefore not be
disproportionate to the loss suffered; nor should the power be so
exercised as to put obstacles in the way of the accused defending
himself properly (Dr. Manzoor Hussain v State, 1969 P Cr. LJ
336).
Costs awarded under this section are, as section 547 Cr.
P. C. provides, recoverable as fine.
Other cases of sine die adjournment, e.g. pendency of
a civil suit
There are cases in which the court may have to adjourn
the trial of a criminal case pending the decision of a civil suit. A
Magistrate has power under section 249 Cr. P. C. to stop the
proceedings of a criminal case at any stage and "without
pronouncing any judgment either of acquittal or conviction". There
409
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 223
is no such provision in Chapter XXIIA giving a similar power to
the Court of Session. But there can be no doubt that an
adjournment sine die in such cases will be covered by the
expression "any other reasonable cause" in section 344 Cr. P. C.
For example, in Muhammad Akbar v State (PLD 1968 SC 281).
the dispute in a case under sections 411 and 379 PPC pending
before a Magistrate concemed the ownership of a bus. The same
question was also pending decision in a civil suit. The High Court
in exercise of its inherent powers under section 561A stayed the
criminal proceeding. It was held that "normally it is true that
criminal proceedings should not be postponed pending the disposal
of civil litigation connected with the same subject matter but where
it is clear that the criminal liability is dependent upon the result of
the civil litigation or is so intimately connected with it that there is
a danger of grave injustice being done in the case if there be a
conflict of decision......" the criminal proceedings may be stayed."
In Muhammad Azam v Muhammad Iqbal (PLD 1984 SC 95) the
power in the court to adjourn the criminal proceedings under the
Offence of Zina (Enforcement of Hadood) Ordinance 1979 sine die
till the decision of the question of marriage by the Family Court
under the Family Courts Ordinance 1964 was recognized. The
accused had pleaded valid Nikah as his defence against the charge
of Zina-bil-Jabar and as the Family Court had the exclusive
jurisdiction to determine the question of marriage, and the question
of the guilt or innocence of the accused depended upon the
decision of the Family Court, the criminal court, it was held,
"should stay the proceedings and await the result of the contest on
issue of Nikah before the Family Court........
Charge
The first important step in the trial of criminal cases is
the framing of a formal charge. As regards trials before
Magistrates, section 242 provides that "when the accused appears
or is brought before the Magistrate a formal charge shall be framed
relating to the offence of which he is accused and he shall be asked
whether he admits that he has committed the offence with which he
is charged". As regards trials before the High Court and the Court
of Session, section 265D provides that "if, after perusing the police
report, or as the case may be, the complaint, and all other
documents and statements filed by the prosecution, the Court is of
the opinion that there is ground for proceeding with the trial of the
accused it shall frame in writing a charge against the accused".
The provisions as to what is a charge, the form of
charges, their language. joinder of charges and other related
matters are to be found in Chapter XIX, sections 221 to 240
Cr.P.C. We may well pause here to notice some of its provisions to
highlight the place which a charge has in the trial of a criminal
case.
A charge is a statement of the offence, that is, a
description of the offence, and the particulars of the offence, a brief
statement of the essential facts which constitute the offence. The
object of framing a charge is to give reasonable information and
notice as to the matter with which the accused is charged and
which he is called upon to defend. The basic requirement in every
criminal trial is that the charge must be framed so as to give the
accused a fairly reasonable idea as to the case which he is to face,
and the validity of the charge must in each case be determined by
the application of the test viz had the accused a reasonably
sufficient notice of the matter with which he was charged?
(Chittarajan v State - AIR 1963 SC 1696; M. Younis Habib v State
-PLD 2006 SC 155).
This is expressly so provided in Chapter XIX Cr. P.C.
Section 221 says that every charge shall state the offence with
which the accused is charged. If the law which creates the offence
gives it any specific name, the offence may be described in the
charge by that name only. But if the law which creates the offence
does not give it any specific name, so much of the definition of the
offence must be stated as to give the accused notice of the matter
with which he is charged. The law and section of the law against
which the offence is said to have been committed shall be
410
411
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 224
mentioned in the charge. The fact that the charge is made is
equivalent to a statement that every legal condition required by law
to constitute the offence charged was fulfilled in the particular
case. The illustrations to section 221 can be greatly helpful in
understanding these legal requirements. Section 222 requires that
the charge shall contain such particulars as to the time and place of
the alleged offence and the person against whom or the thing in
respect of which it was committed as are reasonably sufficient to
give the accused notice of the matter with which he is charged,
Separate and joint charge
The general rule as enacted in section 233 Cr. P. C. is
that for every distinct offence of which any person is accused there
shall be a separate charge, and every such charge shall be tried
separately. The cases mentioned in sections 234, 235, 236 and 239
Cr. P. C. which sections are exceptions to the general rule enable a
plurality of offences to be dealt with in the same trial (Babulal case
-AIR 1938 P. C. 130). A joint trial is under these provisions by no
means compulsory. Nor can it be said that if several accused
charged for committing the same offence in the same transaction
are tried separately then the trial will irrespective of any question
of prejudice be illegal. The provisions of sections 234 to 239 Cr. P.
C. are merely enabling provisions and do not make it incumbent
upon the criminal courts to hold a joint trial in every case
(Shahadat Khan v Home Secretary - PLD 1969 SC 158; Nadir
Shah v State 1980 SCMR 402). The general rule in section 233
Cr.P.C. is based on a salutary principle that when each charge is
tried separately, there is much less apprehension of prejudice to the
accused as compared to a trial wherein several offences are
combined together (Nadir Shah v State 1980 SCMR 402).
Section 239 enumerates the categories of persons who
may be charged jointly. For example, persons accused of the same
offence committed in the same transaction, and persons accused of
an offence and a person accused of abetment or of an attempt to
commit such offence may be charged and tried jointly. In truth.
there are powerful public reasons why joint offences should be
tried jointly. As was held in R v Hayter (2005) 2 All ER 209, 212)
"while considerations of the avoidance
of delay, costs, and convenience, can be
cited in favour of joint trials this is not
the prime basis of the practice. Instead it
is founded principally on the perception
that a just outcome is more likely to be
established in a joint trial than in
separate trials...... Subject to a judge's
discretion to order otherwise, joint trials
of those involved in a joint criminal case
are in the public interest and are the
norm".
Conviction for offence not charged:
Sections 237 and 238 Cr.P.C. provide for an accused to
be convicted of an offence although he had not been charged with
that offence. Section 237 applies where the accused was charged
with one offence but it appears in evidence that he committed a
different offence and section 238 where a person is charged with an
offence consisting of several particulars, a combination of some
only of which constitutes a complete minor offence and such.
combination is proved, he may be convicted of the minor offence
though he was not charged with it..
Errors in the charges
Sections 225 and 232 need special treatment. Section
225 provides that no error in stating either the offence or the
particulars required in the charge and no omission to state the
offence or those particulars shall be regarded at any stage of the
case as material, unless the accused was in fact misled by such
error or omission and it has occasioned a failure of justice.
413
412
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 225
Illustrations (b). (c), (d) and (e) to this section are instructive and
can be greatly helpful in understanding this provision.
They read:
(b)
(c)
(d)
(e)
A is charged with cheating B, and the manner
in which he cheated B is not set out in the
charge, or is set out incorrectly. A defends
himself, calls witnesses and gives his own
account of the transaction. The court may
infer from this that the omission to set out the
manner of the cheating is not material.
A is charged with cheating B, and the manner
in which he cheated B is not set out in the
charge. There
were many transactions
between A & B, and A had no means of
knowing to which of them the charge referred.
and offered no defence. The Court may infer
from such facts that the omission to set out
the manner of the cheating was, in the case, a
material error.
A is charged with the murder of Khoda
Bakhsh on the 21" January, 1982. In fact, the
murdered person's name was Haider Bakhsh,
and the date of the murder was the 20"
January, 1982. A was never charged with any
murder but one, and had heard the trial which
referred exclusively to the case of Haider
Bakhsh. The Court may infer from these facts
that A was not misled, and that the error in
charge was immaterial.
A was charged with murdering Haider Bakhsh
on the 20 January, 1982 and Khoda Bakhsh
who tried to arrest him for that murder on the

murder of Khoda Baksh. The witnesses
present in his defence were witnesses in the
case of Haider Bakhsh. The Court may infer
from this that A was misled, and that the error
was material.
Error in charge - when may a new trial be ordered
Section 322 enacts that if an appellate or revisional court
is of opinion that any person convicted of an offence was misled in
his defence by the absence of a charge or by any error in the
charge, it shall direct a new trial to be held, upon a charge framed
in whatever manner it thinks fit. In view of these provisions, at one
time, distinction was made between an illegality and irregularity.
The leading case on the subject was Subrahmania Ayyar v King
[(1902) ILR Madras 61, 67] where the appellant had been charged
with no less than 41 acts, extending over a period of two years in
contravention of section 234 Cr.P.C. which prescribes that a person
can only be tried for three offences of the same kind if committed
within a period of two years. It was held that disobedience to an
express provision as to a mode of trial could not be regarded as a
mere irregularity; such a phrase as irregularity' was not
appropriate to the illegality of trying an accused person for many
different offences at the same time and those offences being spread
over a longer period than by law could have been tried together in
one indictment. However this case was later considered in another
Privy Council case (Abdul Rehman case - AIR 1927 PC 44) and it
was held that the bare fact of failure to comply with the mandatory
provisions of a section in that case it was section 360 Cr.P.C.-
unaccompanied by a failure of justice is not enough to viuate the
proceedings which may be cured by sections 535 and 537 Cr. P. C.
However that may be, sections $35 and 537 as amended
in 1964 and 1972 seem to have done away with this distinction and
it seems that even a contravention of section 234 is now a curable
415
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 226
irregularity. The controversy that has raged around the true
meaning of Subrahmania case ought now to have been set at rest.
(Z A Bhutto case, para 176 per Anwar-ul-Haq CJ). Section 535
provides that no finding or sentence shall be deemed invalid merely
on the ground that no charge was framed unless in the opinion of
the court of appeal or revision a failure of justice had in fact been
occasioned thereby. Section 537 provides that no finding or
sentence passed by a court of competent jurisdiction shall be
reversed or altered by an appellate or revisional court on account-
b)
of any error, omission or irregularity in the
complaint, report by police-officer under
section 173, summons, warrant, charge,
proclamation, order, judgment or other
proceedings before or during trial or in any
inquiry or other proceedings under this Code,

of any error, omission or irregularity in the
mode of trial, including any mis-joinder of
charges,
unless such error, omission or irregularity has in fact occasioned a
failure of justice.
As to what may occasion a failure of justice, section 537
itself provides one test. It is that in determining whether any error,
omission or irregularity in any proceeding under this Code has
occasioned a failure of justice, the court shall have regard to the
fact whether the objection could and should have been raised at an
earlier stage in the proceedings. (M. Younis Habib v State - PLD
2006 SC 155).
Effect of admission or denial of charge
After a formal charge has been framed, the accused is to
be called upon to plead guilty or not guilty. When the trial is by a
Magistrate and the accused admits that he has committed the
offence, his admission shall be recorded as nearly as possible in his
own words and if he shows no sufficient cause why he should not
be convicted, the Magistrate may, section 243 Cr. P.C. provides,
convict him accordingly. If the trial is before a High Court or a
Court of Session and the accused pleads guilty, the court shall
record the plea and may, as section 265E provides, in its discretion,
convict him thereon.
It is obvious that the admission by the accused of the
commission of the offence or the admission that he is guilty and
has no defence to make, followed by a conviction thereon, puts an
end to the trial.
But where the accused does not plead guilty or does not
admit the commission of the offence, the hearing of the case
commences. This is the point of the trial where issues such as
double jeopardy and jurisdiction of the court to try etc. may
appropriately be raised.
Pleas such as to jurisdiction and double
jeopardy are preliminary
As to the plea of double jeopardy, the relevant
provisions of law are Article 13 of the Constitution, section 403 Cr.
P. C. and section 26 of the General Clauses Act 1897. These
provisions have been noticed and discussed under Article 13 of the
Constitution in the Constitutional Criminal Procedure part of this
book. Suffice it to say here that these provisions expressly give
effect to the common law rule that a man must not be put twice in
peril for the same offence and that to every prosecution, a plea of
autrefois acquit or autrefois convict is a good defence.
The questions, if raised, will go to the competence of the
court to proceed with the trial of the case. They should ordinarily
be treated as preliminary issues and should be resolved before any
416
417
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 227
further action is taken (Akhtar Ali v Altaf-ur-Rehman-PLD 1963
Lah. 390 FB).
Chapter 7
PROCEDURE FOR TRIALS
We have noticed that under the Code of Criminal
Procedure, trials are of two kinds: (1) summary trials, that is, trials
of minor offences, with which we have already dealt; and (2)
regular trials, that is, trials of serious offences.
Regular trials may be sub-divided into trials by Courts of
Magistrates, and trials by Courts of Session, or High Courts.
Trials by Magistrates:
The procedure for the trial of cases by Magistrates is
provided by Chapter XX, sections 241 to 250A, of the Code of
Criminal Procedure. The provisions of Chapter XX have to be read
with the provisions of Chapter XXIV, which chapter makes
"general provisions as to inquiries and trials".
We have seen that section 241A requires that copies of
certain documents shall be supplied to the accused. We have also
seen what those documents shall be, what the object of supplying
those copies is and what the effect of their non-supply is.
While section 265A Cr.P.C. expressly provides that in
trials before the Court of Session, initiated upon a police report
under section 173 Cr.P.C, the prosecution shall be conducted by
the Public Prosecutor, there is no such provision in the Code of
Criminal Procedure for trials before Magistrates. In the recently
enacted Provincial Laws, e.g. The Punjab Criminal Prosecution
Service (Constitution, Functions and Powers) Act 2006, there are
provisions which require that prosecutions in the Courts of
Magistrates shall also be conducted by the Public Prosecutors. For
example, section 9(1) of the Punjab Act reads:
418
"The Prosecutors shall be responsible for
the conduct of prosecution on behalf of
the Government".
Subject to any constitutional objection under Article 143
of the Constitution, this provision in the Provincial Laws has
modified the provisions of section 495 Cr. P. C. which section.
inter-alia, provides that "any Magistrate inquiring into or trying any
case may permit the prosecution to be conducted by any person
other than an officer of police below the rank to be prescribed by
the Provincial Government in this behalf.........
The need and the occasion for trial arise when, as section
244 Cr. P. C. provides, the accused admits the charge, but the
Magistrate does not convict him, or when he does not admit the
charge and thereby challenges the prosecution to prove it. In these
cases, the Magistrate "shall proceed to hear the complainant, if any.
and take all such evidence as may be produced in support of the
prosecution, and also hear the accused and take all such evidence
as he produces in his defence". Under subsection (2) of section
244, the Magistrate may, if he thinks fit, on the application of the
complainant or accused, issue summons to any witness to attend or
to produce any document or any other thing, and may require that
the witness's reasonable expenses be deposited in court, but when
the offence under trial is punishable with imprisonment exceeding
six months, the accused shall not be required to deposit such
expenses. The power to summon a witness includes the power to
summon a person whose name does not appear in the calendar of
witnesses and even a person whose statement was not recorded
during investigation under section 161 or section 364 Cr.P.C
(Shahbaz Masih v State - 2007 SCMR 1631).
The use of the word 'complainant' in sub-section (2) of
section 244 is not a happy choice. The section applies to trials
initiated both on police reports and private complaints. Obviously.
in cases initiated on police reports, the State is the prosecutor and it
will be on the State's application that the witnesses will be
419
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 228
summoned. This position is correctly reflected in section 265F
subsection (2) Cr. P. C. which reads:
"The court shall ascertain from the
Public Prosecutor or, as the case may be,
from the complainant,
names...
the
Under section 245 Cr. P. C. if on taking the evidence
and examining the accused, the Magistrate finds the accused not
guilty, he "shall record an order of acquittal", and if he finds him
guilty, "pass sentence according to law".
Section 245A Cr. P. C. provides procedure for cases in
which the accused has had a previous conviction but denies that
fact.
Section 247 Cr.P.C. applies to cases initiated on
complaint only; it provides that if on a date of hearing the
complainant does not appear, then the Magistrate shall,
notwithstanding anything hereinbefore contained (in the Code),
acquit the accused unless for some reason he thinks not to do so
and adjourns the hearing. This provision does not apply -
(i)
(ii)
in a case where the complainant is a public
servant, his personal attendance is not
required and the Magistrate dispenses with his
attendance and proceeds with the case; and
in a case where the offence with which the
accused stands charged is either cognizable or
non-compoundable.
Section 248 Cr. P. C. permits the complainant to withdraw the
complaint with the permission of the Magistrate; the withdrawal
shall result in the acquittal of the accused.
Section 250A Cr. P. C. is a special provision applicable
to offences punishable with fine only. The Provincial Government
may authorize a Magistrate to, except for reasons to be recorded in
writing, issue a summons to the accused requiring him either to
appear before him on a specified date in person or by an advocate,
or, if he desires to plead guilty to the charge, without appearing
before the Magistrate, to transmit to the Magistrate before the
specified date, by registered post or through a messenger, the said
plea in writing and the amount of fine specified in the summons or.
if he desires to appear by an advocate through such advocate to
plead guilty to the charge on his behalf and to pay the fine.
The amount of fine to be specified in the summons
"shall not be less than twenty five per cent, nor more than fifty per
cent, of the maximum fine provided for the offence".
Trials before High Courts and Courts of Session:
Section 265A Cr.P.C. enacts that "in every trial before a
Court of Session, initiated upon a police report, the prosecution
shall be conducted by the Public Prosecutor".
The procedure to be followed in trials by the High
Courts and the Courts of Session has been laid down in Chapter
XXII-A, sections 265C to 265N, Cr.P.C.
After the attendance of the accused has been procured,
copies of statements and documents mentioned in section 265C
have been supplied, a charge has been framed under section 265D,
and read over and explained to the accused, he shall, section 265E
so requires, be asked whether he is guilty or has any defence to
make. If the accused pleads guilty, the court shall record the plea
"and may, in its discretion, convict him thereon".
But if the accused does not plead guilty, or if he pleads
guilty but the court, in its discretion, does not convict him on his
plea, the procedure under section 265F Cr.P.C. starts to operate.
420
421
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 229
The court shall summon the witnesses whose names
have been ascertained from the public prosecutor or as the case
may be, the complainant. examine those witnesses, examine the
accused and ask him if he means to produce defence evidence. The
court may summon a person whose name does not occur in the
calendar of witnesses as also a person whose statement was not
recorded during investigation under section 161 or 364 Cr.P.C
(Shahbaz Masih v State - 2007 SCMR 1631). If the accused says
he means to adduce evidence, the court shall call on the accused to
enter on his defence and produce his evidence. For that purpose,
the accused may produce his witnesses or may apply to the court
"to issue any process for compelling the attendance of any witness
or the production of any document or other thing" and the court-
"shall issue process unless it considers
that the application is made for the
purpose of vexation or delay or defeating
the ends of justice. Such ground shall be
recorded by the court in writing".
Chapter XL, sections 503 to 508A, make provisions for
the recording of evidence on commission. Under section 503 Cr.
P.C. if it appears to a Court of Session or the High Court that the
examination of a witness is necessary for the ends of justice and
that the evidence of such witness cannot be procured without an
amount of delay, expense or inconvenience which, under the
circumstances of the case, would be unreasonable, such court may
dispense with such attendance and may issue a commission to a
Magistrate of the First Class of the local area to take evidence of
such witness. Subsections (2A) and (2B) provide for a case in
which the witness resides in a foreign country.
If there be such a witness and the trial Magistrate thinks
that his evidence should be recorded on commission, the
Magistrate shall, under section 506 Cr.P.C., apply to the Sessions
Judge, who "may either issue a commission in the manner
hereinbefore provided or reject the application".
Section 509 Cr.P.C. provides that "the parties to any
in which a commission is issued. may
proceeding
respectively forward any interrogatories in writing which the
Magistrate or court directing the commission may think relevant to
the issue" and the witness shall be examined "upon such
interrogatories".
The evidence recorded in the manner provided in these
provisions shall, section 507(1) Cr.P.C. so enacts, "be read in
evidence in the case by either party, and shall form part of the
record", and under section 507(2). "may also be received in
evidence at any subsequent stage of the case before another court".
Examination of Witnesses - General Provisions:
Mode of recording evidence: In regular trials under
Chapter XX as well as in summary trials under Chapter XXII
Cr.PC. by a Magistrate of the First or Second Class, the Magistrate
shall, section 355 Cr.P.C. so provides, "make a memorandum of
the substance of the evidence of each witness as the examination of
witness proceeds". Such memorandum shall be written and signed
by the Magistrate with his own hand, and shall form part of the
record. If the Magistrate is unable to write the evidence with his
own hand, he shall record the reason of his inability and shall
dictate such memorandum in open court and shall sign the same.
Section 356 Cr.P.C. provides that in trials before the Courts of
Session and in inquiries under Chapter XII (disputes as to
immoveable property) the evidence of each witness shall be taken
down in the language of the court by the Magistrate or Sessions
Judge, or in his presence and hearing and under his personal
direction and superintendence and shall be signed by the
Magistrate or Sessions Judge. In such cases when the evidence is
not taken down by the Magistrate or Sessions Judge, "he shall, as
the examination of each witness proceeds, make a memorandum of
the substance of what such witness deposes; and such
memorandum shall be written and signed by the Magistrate or
Sessions Judge with his own hand. If the Magistrate or
422
423
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 230
Sessions Judge is prevented from making the required
memorandum, he shall record the reason of his inability,
Section 356 also makes provision for cases in which the
evidence is given in any language other than the court language
and section 357 empowers the Provincial Government to direct that
in any district or part of a district or in proceedings before any
Court of Session or before any Magistrate the evidence of each
witness shall, in cases referred to in section 356, be taken down by
the Sessions Judge or Magistrate with his own hand and in his
mother-tongue.
Section 359 Cr.P.C. provides that evidence recorded
under sections 356 and 357 shall not ordinarily be taken down in
the form of question and answer but in the form of a narrative but
the court may, in its discretion, take down or cause to be taken
down any particular question and answer. Under section 360, when
the evidence of each witness is completed, it shall be read over to
him in the presence of the accused or as the case may be, his
counsel, and shall, if necessary be corrected. If the witness denies
the correctness of any part of the evidence when the same is read
over to him, the court may, instead of correcting the evidence.
make a memorandum thereon of the objection made to it by the
witness and shall add such remarks as he thinks necessary. The
object of reading over the evidence to the witness is to obtain an
accurate record of what the witness really meant to say and to give
him an opportunity of correcting the words taken down. It is not to
enable him or his counsel to suggest corrections, or to change his
story. (Abdur Rehman v King - AIR 1927 PC 44; and AIR 1952
SC 214). The witness is entitled to be sure that the evidence has
been read over and the witness has had an opportunity of correcting
the written record. But he is not necessarily entitled to the
opportunity of suggesting corrections (Abdur Rehman v King -
AIR 1927 PC 44).
Demeanour and Credibility of Witness: The trial court
has the great advantage, which the appellate court does not have, of
seeing and observing the witness in the witness box; therefore
424
appreciation of evidence by the trial court is ordinarily given full
weight by the appellate court. And if the appellate court is to take a
different view as to the credibility of a witness from that taken by
the trial court, it must give cogent reasons for so doing. As was
said by Lord Shaw in Clarke v Edinburgh Tramways (1919) SC
HL 35, 36), "when a Judge hears and sees witnesses and makes a
conclusion or inference with regard to what is the weight on
balance of their evidence, that judgment is entitled to great respect
quite irrespective of whether the Judge makes any observation with
regard to credibility or not". This principle was recognized and
applied in Allah Ditta v State (PLD 1958 SC (Pak) 290) State v
Farman Hussain (PLD 1995 SCT, 29), and Muhammad Amir v
Khan Bahadur (PLD 1996 SC 267,273).
Credibility of a witness is not a matter of law; it is a
matter of simple human judgment. The usual aids to belief or
disbelief, so said Cornelius, C.J. in Abdul Razik v State (PLD 1865
SC 151)-
"as to the credibility of a witness are the
appearance of the face of witness as he
makes his statement, the manner in
which he receives a question, considers
his reply and states it, the manner in
which he faces cross examination and
meets objections affecting his veracity
and such other factors by which the
human judgment is assisted".
This is the description of demeanour and all this shows its
importance in credit-worthiness of a witness. That is the reason that
section 363 Cr.P.C. provides that-
"when a Sessions Judge or Magistrate
has recorded the evidence of a witness,
he shall also record such remarks, if any,
as he thinks material respecting the
425
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 231
demeanour of such witness whilst under
examination".
He shall record such remarks about demeanour for his own benefit,
for the benefit of his successor in case he ceases for any reason to
be the trial judge before the stage of judgment and of course for the
benefit of the appellate court.
Court's power to ask questions, call witness etc:
Under section 340 Cr.P.C. a court may, that is, it has
discretion to, at any stage of inquiry, trial or other proceeding.
summon any person as a witness. or examine any person in
attendance, though not summoned as a witness, or recall and re-
examine any person already examined; and the court shall, that is,
it must, "summon and examine or recall or re-examine any such
person if his evidence appears to it essential to the just decision of
the case". Thus, once the court holds that the evidence of such a
person is essential to the just decision of the case, it has no
discretion to refuse to summon or as the case may be, examine,
recall or re-examine such a person (Shahbaz Masih v State-2007
SCMR 1631; Muhammad Azam v Muhammad Iqbal PLD 1984 SC
95, 118, 123).
Article 161 of the Qanun-e-Shahdat 1984 empowers the
judge, in order to discover the truth or to obtain proper proof of
relevant facts, to ask any question he pleases, in any form, at any
time, of any witness or of the parties about any fact relevant or
even irrelevant, and to order the production of any document or
thing. It provides also that the parties shall not be entitled to make
any objection to any such question or order, nor, without the leave
of the court, to cross examine any witness upon any question given
in reply to any such question. This power does not, however,
extend to authorizing any judge to compel any witness to answer
any question or to produce any document which such witness
would be entitled to refuse to answer or to produce under Articles 4
to 14 of the Qanun-e-Shahadat.
The power given by Article 161 is a very wide power
but in exercising it, it should be remembered, first, that there is no
such thing as 'judicial advocacy' and secondly, that it is 'trite law
that a judge's role is to hold the ring fairly between the prosecution
and defence, and this cannot be done properly if the judge enters
into the arena by appearing to take one side or the other. Questions
which might suggest this should be avoided. Often the best course
for a judge is to remain silent until counsel has had opportunity to
deal with the matter (R v Tueget (2002) 2 All ER 872, 888; Jones v
National Coal Board (1957) 2 QB 55). In short, the judge must
not assume the role of a prosecutor or defence counsel and in
elucidating the relevant facts of the case, he must hold the balance
equally between the parties (S.A. Rehman, J. in Ali Nawaz Gardezi
v Lt. Colonel Muhammad Yousaf - PLD 1963 SC 51, 86). But if
the asking of questions is essential to the just decision of the case,
objection such as that the court should not fill gaps in the
prosecution or defence should not deter the court to exercise the
power (Muhammad Azam v Muhammad Iqbal - PLD 1984 SC 95.
123).
The power to proceed under the second part of section
540 Cr.P.C. may be exercised suo motu or on the application of a
party and may be exercised at any stage of the enquiry or trial
(State v Moulvi Muhammad Jamil - PLD 1965 SC 681); it may be
exercised even after both the parties have closed their evidence and
the case has been adjourned for judgment for till then the case is
still pending (Rashid Ahmad v State - PLD 1971 SC 709). What is
for the just decision of the case will depend upon the
circumstances of each case. The object of section 540 is to defend
the interest of justice and not to defeat it (Muhammad Amjad v
State-PLD 2003 SC 704,716).
Thus, the power under section 540 Cr.P.C. and the one
conferred by Article 161 of the Qanun are complementary to each
other and it is not proper to assume any artificial limitation on the
exercise of the court's power under these provisions (Muhammad
Azam v Muhammad Iqbal - PLD 1984 SC 95, 122, 124).
426
427
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 232
Proof of previous conviction or acquittal
Section 265-I Cr.P.C. provides, as does section 245A
Cr.P.C, for cases in which previous conviction is a relevant factor.
Section 511 Cr.P.C. provides for the manner in which a previous
conviction or acquittal may be proved. This is in addition to any
other mode for proving it provided by any other law.
Power of Advocate General to withdraw prosecution
Section 265L Cr.P.C. empowers the Advocate General,
at any stage of any trial before the High Court, "to inform the court
on behalf of the Government that he will not prosecute the accused
upon the charge; and thereupon all proceedings against the accused
shall be stayed, and he shall be discharged of and from the same.
But such discharge shall not amount to an acquittal unless the
presiding Judge otherwise directs".
Preliminary
Chapter 8
CRIMINAL EVIDENCE
The crux of a trial is the presentation of evidence; and
"criminal evidence" means that part of the law of evidence which
governs the process of proof in criminal cases. Thus, the context of
evidence is a trial which means a hearing in a suit or proceeding in
a court or tribunal at which evidence is introduced. The law of
evidence, therefore, is the lex fori, that is, the law of forum or
court.
The principal law of evidence in Pakistan is the Qanun-
e-Shahadat, 1984 (the Qanun). Its ancestor was the Evidence Act,
1872, which codified the common law rules of evidence, lying
scattered in innumerable English decided cases, and applied them
to India. The common law model was adversarial, which was
transported through conquest and colonialism to North America.
428
Australia. Indian sub-continent and significant parts of Africa. In
comparing this adversarial system with the inquisitorial system.
reference is often made to the French model of criminal procedure
which derives originally from Napoleon's Criminal Procedure
Code of 1808 and "still defines the basic contours of French
Criminal Procedure today". The Napoleonic system "was
transported in France's nineteenth and early twentieth century
colonial caravan and implanted in countries as near as Belgium and
the Netherlands and as far afield as Ivory Coast, Cameron, Niger,
Cambodia and Vietnam". (For this information, we gratefully
acknowledge our debt to the book "Criminal Evidence" by Paul
Roberts and Andrian Zuckerman - Oxford pp 42-44).
The avowed object of the enactment of Qanun-e-
Shahadat, 1984, and the repeal of the Evidence Act, 1872, was, as
its preamble says, to "revise, amend and consolidate the law of
evidence so as to bring it in conformity with the Injunctions of
Islam as laid down in the Holy Quran and Sunnah", in compliance
with Article 227, clause (1), of the Constitution. That clause in its
relevant part reads:
"All existing laws shall be brought in
conformity with the Injunctions of Islam
as laid down in the Holy Quran and
Sunnah, in this Part referred to as the
Injunctions of Islam and no law shall be
enacted which is repugnant to such
Injunctions".
Proceedings to which Qanun-e-Shahadat applies:
The law of evidence applies to forensic, as distinguished
from non-forensic, fact-finding process: (The word 'forensic' is
derived from the Roman 'forum' where legal and other business
was transacted and 'forensic' literally means 'pertaining to legal
proceedings), that is fact-finding in legal proceedings. Doctors,
scientists, journalists, detectives and historians are daily engaged in
429
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 233
the collection and evaluation of evidence but the law of evidence
obviously does not apply to their fact-finding process.
Qanun-e-Shahadat applies, as its Article 1. clause (2).
provides, to
1).
(2)
judicial proceedings, in or before any court,
including a court martial:
a tribunal or other authority exercising
judicial or
(i)
(ii)
quasi-judicial powers or jurisdiction,
but does not apply to proceedings before an arbitrator.
To determine the scope of the application of the Qanun-
e-Shahadat, some of the terms used above need to be defined.
Judicial Proceedings
Judicial proceedings' is not defined in the Qanun-e-
Shahadat; it is defined in the Code of Criminal Procedure, section
4(1)(m), but not exhaustively; under that section. judicial
proceedings includes any proceeding in the course of which
evidence is or may be legally taken on oath. For one, that definition
is for the purposes of the Code only. Secondly, it being not
exhaustive, it leaves its ordinary meaning or if it has acquired a
technical meaning, that meaning, intact.
In its dictionary meaning, judicial proceeding" is a
generic term for proceedings relating to, practiced in, or proceeding
from, a court of justice; a proceeding in a legally constituted court.
(See Black's Law Dictionary). The word judicial has two
meanings; it may refer to the discharge of duties exercisable_by_a_
judge or it may refer to administrative duties which need not be
performed in court, but in respect of which it is necessary to bring
to bear a judicial mind, that is a mind to determine what is fair and
just in respect of the matters under consideration (Fauj Din v
Akhtar Mehmood-PLD 1988 Lah. 352).
430
Court
The term 'court' is defined in the Qanun-e-Shahadat.
Article 2(a), but again not exhaustively; it includes all Judges and
Magistrates and all persons, except arbitrators, legally authorized to
take evidence. That takes us to the ordinary or technical, if any,
meaning of the term.
Clause (2) of Article 1 of the Qanun-e-Shahadat also
uses the term 'tribunal' but does not define it.
There is a wide variety of courts; so there is of tribunals.
While every court is a tribunal, the converse is not true, that is,
every tribunal is not necessarily a court. "There are many tribunals
which are not courts despite the fact that they are charged with
certain matters and have features in common with courts".
(Viscount Dilhorne in Attorney General v BBC - (1980) 3 All ER
161; also see Zahoor Elahi v State
Muhammad Gul J. who said: ".
term which includes a court and
interchangeably").
PLD 1977 SC 273. 357 per
.... tribunal is a generic
often these terms are used
The distinction is between courts of law, which exercise
the judicial power of the State-Courts of Judicature, that is, courts
of law which form part of the judicial system of the country and
courts or tribunals which are to resolve problems arising in the
course of administration.
There are many tribunals with the label "court' attached
to them, which have many of the trappings of a court or which are
required to act judicially, yet they are not courts of law in the
above-stated sense. Thus, a tribunal is not a court of law merely
because-
(1)
it is called a court; or
(2)
(3)
800
it performs its functions sitting in public; or
it has power to administer oath and hear
evidence on oath.
431
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 234
Nor is it the test that the tribunal or body in question is
required to act judicially, that is to say, with such fairness and
impartiality as characterize proceedings in courts of justice that
being a duty common to all state or public power. (Bahadur v State
-PLD 1985 SC 62, 68).
Thus,
(i)
(ii)
(iii)
(iv)
in AG v BBC (1980) 3 All ER 161, the
question was whether the local valuation court
established under the (English) Local
Government Act 1948 was a court exercising
the Judicial Power of the State. It was held
that that court was not a court of law
exercising the Judicial Power of the State; it
was established to exercise administrative
