Courts Martial, as distinguished from Martial Law
Courts mean courts established under the Army, Navy or Air Force
Acts to deal with matters relating to the armed forces personnel.
Martial Law Courts refer to courts established by the Commander
of the Army which has conquered an enemy's territory and
imposes martial law. (Muhammad Nawaz case PLD 1951 FC
73).
Quasi-Judicial:
"Quasi is a Latin word; it means as if; almost as it were;
analogous to. This term is used in legal phraseology to indicate that
one subject resembles another with which it is compared, in certain
characteristics, but there are intrinsic and material differences
between them. 'Quasi-judicial' is a term applied to the action,
discretion etc of public administrative officers or bodies; and a
'quasi-judicial act means a judicial act performed by one not a
judge. (These definitions have been gratefully borrowed from
Black's Law Dictionary).
In Engineers Workers Union v Devanayagam (1967) 2
All ER 367, Lord Guest and Lord Devlin discussed the term
'quasi-judicial' with reference to the concept of "Judicial Power":
"It is true that Judicial Power' can be
entrusted to someone who is not a
judicial officer and the person so
432
433
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 235
entrusted is then generally spoken of as
acting quasi-judicially".
In the words of Chief Justice Muhammad Monir in Tariq
Transport (PLD 1958 SC (Pak) 437)-
"The word 'quasi' as prefixed to the word
judicial' may either indicate that the
tribunal is not acting
administratively or that it is acting in a
purely
manner in which a judicial tribunal is
expected to act".
Court and tribunal:
Article 1, clause (2), of the Qanun, uses both the term
'court' and the term 'tribunal'. The idea is to distinguish between
the courts of law exercising the Judicial Power of the State and
tribunals which have been established for other purposes, c.g.
administrative and legislative purposes. We have seen, that though
the two terms are often used interchangeably, yet every court is a
tribunal but every tribunal is not a court. (See AG v BBC, per
Visconnt Dilhomme and Zahoor Elahi v State, per Muhammad Gul
J.).
The term 'court' is defined in Article 2(a) of the Qanun;
the definition is not exhaustive. It includes all Judges and
Magistrates and all persons, except arbitrators, legally authorized to
take evidence. This has reference to Judges and Magistrates
appointed by the State to exercise the Judicial Power of the State in
civil, criminal, commercial matters, that is all matters concerning
the life, liberty and property of its citizens.
Arbitrator:
We have seen that under Article 1, clause (2), the
Quanun-e-Shahadat, 1984, does not apply to arbitrators. Also,
under Article 2(a), the term 'court' does not include arbitrators.
434
The reason is the distinction between the state-appointed
functionaries to exercise the legislative, executive and judicial
powers of the State and the privately appointed functionaries. For
example, the Judicial Power of the State is exercised by the courts
established in accordance with Article 175 through Judges and
Magistrates appointed by the State. An arbitrator is appointed by
the parties to the dispute and not by the State. Hence he is not a
court.
Evidence:
In discussing the Constitutional Criminal Procedure in
an earlier part of this book, we have noticed the development of the
constitutional rule in America namely that all evidence obtained in.
violation of the Constitution is inadmissible. The rationale of that
exclusionary rule of evidence is two-fold (1) exclusion of such
evidence is the only effective means of protecting the constitutional
rights and preserving the Constitution inviolate; (2) the interest in
judicial integrity requires that the courts should not be parties to a
constitutional violation. We have argued that in view of the
similarity of the provisions guaranteeing such rights as right
against self-incrimination, right to counsel and right to privacy in
the two constitutions, the American Constitution and the
Constitution of Pakistan, there is no linguistic difficulty in adopting
in Pakistan the law as it has developed in America and that that
law, particularly the exclusionary rule, ought to be applied here.
There is, thus, a constitutional law of evidence; its
predominant position was brought into sharp focus in a recent
English case - A v Secretary of State for Home (2006) 2 AC 221).
where, as a result of the enactment of the Human Rights Act 1998.
legislative provisions are now liable to be declared incompatible
with the European Convention Rights. The question in that case
was whether a tribunal was entitled to rely on evidence obtained by
agents of a foreign government by means of torture. The evidence
was held inadmissible. One of the Law Lords said:
435
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 236
"It trivializes the issue....
....to treat
it as an argument about the law of
evidence. The issue is one of the
constitutional principle, whether
evidence obtained by torturing another
human being may lawfully be admitted
against a party to a proceeding in a
British court. irrespective of where, or
by whom, or on whose authority, the
torture was inflicted. To that question I
would give a very clear negative
answer".
The word 'evidence' is defined in the Qanun, Article
2(1), clause (c), to include-
(i)
(ii)
all statements which the court permits or
requires to be made before it by witnesses in
relation to matters of fact under inquiry; such
statements are called oral evidence; and
all documents produced for the inspection of
the court; such documents are called
documentary evidence.
In short, 'evidence' includes oral and documentary evidence.
It falls to be observed that in the Evidence Act, 1872, the
definition of 'evidence' used both the expressions 'means and
includes', not a very elegant drafting device, yet, it served the
purpose of expressing the legislative intent, namely, that the
definition was exhaustive. The reason why the word 'means' was
omitted in clause (c) of Article 4(1) of the Qanun is not apparent
and is difficult to conceive. However, that may be, it appears that
the definition is as exhaustive as it was in the 1872 Act; it was so
treated in Jameel Ahmad v Saifuddin (PLD 1994 SC 501, 504).
436
As Monir, in his great work on "The Law of Evidence".
says, there is nothing technical or legal about 'evidence'; in its
original sense, it signifies the state of being evident, plain or
apparent.
Evidence is information. The Arabic word for evidence
is Shahadat, the root word being Shahd. As was observed in
Rashida Patel case (PLD 1989 FSC 95, 109), information based
upon one's observations and knowledge is Shahadat (evidence).
Thus, what is merely conjecture or guess or surmise is not
evidence. In technical terms, evidence in Islam means true
information about a thing or event provided to the court.
Shahadat', so says, Fida Muhammad Khan, J, in Rashida Patel is
one of the pillars supporting the system of Adl (justice) in Islam.
As Professor Edward M. Morgan of the Harvard Law
School in his Foreword to the American Law Institute's Model
Code of Evidence has observed, a Code of Evidence is designed to
make a trial a rational proceeding for the settlement of a dispute
between the litigants. Thus, when A asserts that an event occurred
in a certain way but B, his adversary, asserts that it occurred in
altogether a different way, the court's function is one of "truth-
finding" through the medium of witnesses, documents etc. Wills on
"Circumstantial Evidence", 7th ed. p 2, thinks that 'evidence'
denotes 'the means by which any alleged matter of fact, the truth of
which is submitted to investigation, is established or disproved".
The law of evidence comprises the legal rules regulating those
means.
In Jameel Ahmed v Saifuddin (PLD 1994 SC 501, 504),
Monir's well known work on the Law of Evidence was referred to
with approval to determine the meaning of 'evidence' in Article
2(1), clause (c). Monir referred to Stephen, according to whom -
"the word "evidence" as generally employed is
ambiguous: (a) it sometimes means the words uttered
and things exhibited by witnesses before a Court of
437
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 237
Justice: (b) at other times, it means the facts proved to
exist by those words or things and regarded as the
groundwork of inferences as to other facts not so proved;
(c) again it is sometimes used as meaning to assert that a
particular fact is relevant to the matter under enquiry".
In the opinion of Monir, "the word in this Act (now the Qanun) is
used in the sense of the first clause. As thus used, it signifies only
the instruments by means of which relevant facts are brought
before the court (viz witnesses and documents) and by means of
which the court is convinced of those facts".
The Supreme Court held:
"Evidence is a comprehensive word
which includes statements of witnesses,
parties and documents which are
produced in a court or judicial forum to
prove or disprove the case".
The law of evidence in Pakistan has not kept up with the
changing times as it has in some jurisdictions e.g. UK and USA.
Yet there is no denying that it has come a very long way from the
so-called 'pure justice' practices to the civilizing hand of the
modern law; from the barbaric myths of the 'dark past' to the
scientific methods of the enlightened age; from "that popular sport
known as jumping to conclusions") to the informed decision-
making, that is, informed by evidence, regulated by law, the
ultimate object being the promotion of legitimacy of adjudication.
Evidence and Proof:
'Evidence' and 'proof are sometimes used
synonymously but they are not the same thing. This is clearly
demonstrated by the definitions of the words "proved" and
'disproved' in clauses (4) and (5) respectively of Article 2 of the
Qanun;
"(4) A fact is said to be proved when, after considering
the matters before it, the court either believes it to exist.
or considers its existence so probable that a prudent man
ought, under the circumstances of the particular case, to
act upon the supposition that it exists.
(5) A fact is said to be disproved when, after
considering the matters before it. the court either
believes that it does not exist, or considers its non-
existence so probable that a prudent man ought, under
the circumstances of the particular case, to act upon the
supposition that it does not exist".
We shall return to these definitions when discussing the concept of
"Standard of Proof". For the purposes of the distinction between
'proof and 'evidence', it is to be noted that in these definitions, the
word used is matters' and not evidence: they say, "after
considering the matters before it", and not "after considering the
evidence before it". "Matters" is obviously wider than 'evidence':
matters includes 'evidence' and 'evidence' means oral and
documentary evidence. As was said by Muhammad Afzal Zullah J.
in State v Habibur Rehman (PLD 1983 SC 286). "matters" carries a
wider connotation; wider than 'evidence', its statements and the
documents. The learned Judge referred to Monir's Law of
Evidence, where the learned author says: "The court is, therefore,
not bound to look for its findings on the 'evidence' alone as is
defined in the Evidence Act but has to see to the high probability
regarding the existence or non-existence of a fact after considering
the matters before it
Included in 'matters", besides 'evidence' are -
1)
presumptions, e.g. presumptions as
documents under Articles 90 to 100, and
presumptions as to existence of certain facts
under Article 129 of the Qanan;
to
438
439
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 238
2)
3)
4)
facts of which the court will take judicial
notice under Articles 11 and 112 of The
Qanun;
inspection of spot or place of incident by the court;
remarks
demeanour of witnesses. e.g.
recorded by a Sessions Judge or a Magistrate,
when recording the evidence of a witness,
respecting the demeanour of such witness
while under examination, under section 363
Cr.P.C.
Thus, if we read the definition of 'evidence' in Article 2(1), clause
(c), and that of "proof" in clauses (4) and (5) of that Article,
together, as we must, it becomes plain that "evidence" is a species
of proof through the medium of witnesses and documents.
So, proof is the result of a consideration of the matters
before the court, and as evidence is one of those matters, evidence
differs from proof as cause from effect, for strictly proof marks the
effect of evidence, and other matters
Burden of Proof;
The expressions 'burden of proof has several meanings.
but there is an agreement among the authorities that it has two
primary meanings:
i)
the legal burden of proof; and
ii)
the evidential burden of proof.
Legal burden of proof:
'Legal burden of proof, also called 'onus of proof.
'onus probandi' or 'probative burden' (as it was called in the
House of Lords case, DPP v Morgan (1976) AC 182) means the
burden of persuasion, an obligation to persuade the court, to a
specified standard of proof [generally speaking. proof_on_balance
of probabilities in civil cases, and proof beyond reasonable doubt,
in criminal cases; see Lord Pearson's speech in Nimmo v
Alexander Cowan and sons (1967) 3 All ER 187); also see
Zakaulla v Muhammad Aslam-1991 SCMR 2126] that the fact in
issue (which is a question of substantive law and the parties'
pleadings e.g. statement of facts in a challan or in a private
complaint in a criminal case) is true. There may be several facts in
issue in a case and the legal burden of proof of different issues may
be on one party or the other. In short, it is the obligation to prove
your case according to the applicable standard. It is the ultimate
burden of proof which if placed by statute upon the prosecution is
discharged on proof beyond reasonable doubt and if placed upon
the accused is discharged on balance of probabilities. (Lord Ackner
in R v Hunt-(1987) 1 All ER 1, 19).
Evidential burden of proof:
It is a misnomer to describe evidential burden as a
burden of proof. As Lord Bingham said in Sheldrake v DPP (2005)
1 All ER 237, 243)-
"An evidential burden is not a burden of
proof. It is a burder of raising, on the
evidence in the case, an issue as to the
matter in question fit for consideration
by the tribunal of fact. If an issue is
properly raised, it is for the prosecutor to
prove, beyond reasonable doubt, that
that ground of exoneration does not avail
the defendant".
440
441
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 239
An evidential burden, so said Lord Ackner in R v Hunt (1987) 1
All ER 1, 18), is-
"an obligation to establish through
evidence from the prosecution and/or
evidence from the defence that there is
material which raises such a defence, so
that it becomes a live issue in the case".
Though, evidential burden may not be a burden of proof,
yet, the question whether a statutory burden is or is not a burden of
proof in the strict sense and whether it is merely an evidential
burden, assumes importance when the statutory provision in
question is tested on the touchstone of the right to be presumed
innocent, such as the one under Article 6(2) of European
Convention and the one under the 'due process clause' of the
American Constitution. Some of the relevant cases will be
discussed below.
Burden of proof in criminal cases:
The governing principle of the English Criminal Law,
memorably affirmed by Viscount Sankey LC in Woolmington v
DDP (1935) AC 462, 481: (1935) All ER 1, 8) is that the onus lies
upon the prosecution in a criminal trial to prove all the elements of
the offence with which the accused is charged. This principle has
been regarded as supremely important but not as absolute. Viscount
Sankey in Woolmington acknowledged the authority of
M'Naghten's case (1843-60) All ER 229) which had definitely and
exceptionally placed an onus on the accused to establish a defence
of insanity. He further acknowledged that his statement of principle
was 'subject also to any statutory exception'. (Lord Bingham in
Sheldrake v DDP-(2005) 1 All ER 237, 244).
The Woolmington case was concerned with the
constituent elements of the crime of murder. The facts were
unusual. The appellant went to his mother-in-law's house where his
442
wife, following a quarrel with him, had gone to stay. He went there
to persuade her to return but he killed her with a shot from a gun
which he had fastened with a wire under his coat. He claimed that
he had carried the gun with a view to threatening to commit suicide
and that as he tried to use it for this purpose it went off accidentally
and killed his wife. In the classic words of Viscount Sankey LC:
"If it is proved that the conscious act of
the prisoner killed a man and nothing
else appears in the case, there is
evidence upon which the jury may, not
must, find him guilty of murder. It is
difficult to conceive so bare and meager
a case, but that does not mean that the
is
the
not still on
..it is not till
prosecution...
onus
the end of the evidence that a verdict can
properly be found and that at the end of
the evidence it is not for the prisoner to
establish his innocence but for the
prosecution to establish his guilt. Just as
there is evidence on behalf of the
prosecution, so there may be evidence
on behalf of the prisoner which may
cause a doubt as to his guilt. In either
case, he is entitled to the benefit of the
doubt. But while the prosecution must
prove the guilt of the prisoner, there is
no such burden laid on the prisoner to
prove his innocence and it is sufficient
for him to raise a doubt as to his guilt; he
is not bound to satisfy the jury of his
innocence.
443
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 240
Throughout the web of the English
criminal law one golden thread is always
to be seen that it is the duty of the
prosecution to prove the prisoner's guilt
subject to what I have already said as to
the defence of insanity and subject also
to any statutory exception. If, at the end
of and on the whole of the case, there is
a reasonable doubt, created by the
evidence given by either the prosecution
or the prisoner, as to whether the
prisoner killed the deceased with a
malicious intention, the prosecution has
not made out the case and the prisoner is
entitled to an acquittal. No matter what
the charge or where the trial, the
principle that the prosecution must prove
the guilt of the prisoner is part of the
common law of England and no attempt
to whittle it down can be
entertained...
As was held in R v Edwards (1974) 2 All ER 1085), there are
according to Woolmington two exceptions to the fundamental rule
of the English criminal law that the prosecution must prove every
element of the alleged offence. The first relates to insanity and the
second to those cases in which a statute expressly imposes a burden
of proof upon an accused. Woolmington was not concerned to
consider the nature of a statutory defence or on whom the burden
of proving it might lie; it did not lay down a rule that the burden of
proving a statutory defence only lay on the defendant if the statute
specifically so provided. (Lord Griffith in R'v Hunt (1987) ! All
ER 1, 7, 10).
Cases in which the burden is placed on the defendant
and not, as ordinarily in criminal proceedings, on the prosecutor.
are called cases of 'reverse burden'. (Lord Bingham in Sheldrake v
DPP-(2005) | All ER 237, 243).
In R v Edwards (1974) 2 All ER 1085), the defendant
was accused of selling by retail intoxicating liquor without holding
a justices' license authorizing such a sale contrary to section
160(1)(b) of the Licensing Act 1964, and the question was whether
the section placed the burden of proof, by necessary implication.
upon the defendant that he held the necessary license, and was that
burden legal or evidential only. Lawton LJ held that there was a
line of authority establishing -
"that over the centuries the common law,
as a result of experience and the need to
ensure that justice is done both to the
community and to defendants, has
evolved an exception to the fundamental
rule of our criminal law that the
prosecution must prove every element of
the offence charged. The exception, like
so much else in the common law, was
hammered out on the anvil of pleading.
It is limited to offences arising under
enactments which prohibit the doing of
an act save in specified circumstances or
by persons of specified classes or with
specified qualifications or with the
license or permission of specified
authorities.......... In our judgment
its application does not depend upon
either the fact or the presumption that
the defendant has peculiar knowledge
enabling him to prove the positive of any
negative averment
The conclusion reached was that-
444
445
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 241
"Two consequences follow from the
view we have taken as to the evolution
and nature of this exception. First, as it
comes into operation upon an enactment,
being construed in a particular way,
there is no need for the prosecution to
prove a prima facie case of lack of
excuse, qualification or the like; and
secondly, what shifts is the onus: it is for
the defendant to prove that he was
entitled to do the prohibited act. What
rests on him is the legal or as it is
sometimes called the persuasive burden
of proof. It is not the evidential burden",
R v Edwards was approved in the House of Lords
decision in R v Hunt (1987) 1 All ER 1, 11). In Hunt, as in
Edwards, the legislature had made no express provision as to the
burden of proof, and the court had to construe the relevant
provision to find on whom the legal burden was intended to lie.
Lord Ackner said:
"It is of course axiomatic that a statute
may impose on the accused the burden
of proof of a particular defence to a
statutory offence and may do so either
expressly or by necessary implication.
Whichever method Parliament uses it
has created a 'statutory exception' and
there is no difference in the quality or
status of such an exception....
In rejecting, the contention that the burden in such cases should be
an evidential burden only, Lord Ackner (at pp 18, 19) gave the
following reasons:
and
"(i) It is accepted that, when Parliament
by express words provides that the proof
of the excuse shall lie on the accused,
the legal burden of proof, that is to say.
the ultimate burden of proof, is placed
on the defendant and that is discharged
on the balance of probabilities. It cannot
logically follow that if, ex hypothesi,
Parliament has, by necessary
implication, placed the burden on the
accused the weight of that burden would
be quite different. (ii) The hypothesis is
that by necessary implication Parliament
has provided in a statute that proof of a
particular exculpatory matter shall lie on
the accused. However, the discharge of
an evidential burden proves nothing: it
merely raises an issue. Accordingly, the
mere raising of an issue by the defence
would not satisfy the obligation which
Parliament has imposed.....
In Sheldrake v DPP (2005) 1 All ER 237, two
provisions, (i) section 5(2) of the (English) Road Traffic Act, 1988,
(ii) section 11(1) of the (English) Terrorism Act, 2000,
were under consideration. Both imposed the burden of proof on the
accused and the question was whether having regard to the
presumption of innocence in Article 6(2) of the European
Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental
Freedoms, 1950, as set out in the (English) Human Rights Act,
1998, those provisions should be read down so as to hold that the
burden was not the legal burden of proof but evidential burden
only. In other words, the legal burden of proof infringed the
presumption of innocence right of the accused. It was held that as
regard the burden under section 5(2) of the Road Traffic Act, the
burden was a legal burden of proof to be discharged on balance of
probabilities, but that the one under the Terrorism Act was an
evidential burden only. To quote Lord Bingham:

"The right to a fair trial has long been

Presumption of Innocence
As to what does the principle of the presumption of innocence
require, reference was made to another European Court case.
Barbera v Spain (1989) 11 EH RR 360, 387) -
"Paragraph 2 embodies the principle of
the presumption of innocence. It
requires, inter alia, that when carrying
out their duties, the members of a court
should not start with the preconceived
idea that the accused has committed the
offence charged; the burden of proof is
on the prosecution, and any doubt should
benefit the accused. It also follows that it
is for the prosecution to inform the
accused of the case that will be made
against him, so that he may prepare and
present his defence accordingly, and to
adduce evidence sufficient to convict
him".
We have seen in the Constitutional Criminal Procedure
Part of this book that the US Supreme Court has described the
'presumption of innocence as the bedrock axiomatic and
elementary principle whose enforcement lies at the foundation of
the administration of justice. (See, among others, Re Winship
449
448
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 243
397 US 358-1970); the burden of proof, it was held, lies on the
prosecution to prove its case beyond a reasonable doubt.
As in the UK and the USA, the governing principle in
Pakistan also is that the accused is presumed to be innocent and
that the onus lies upon the prosecution to prove all the elements of
the offence with which the accused is charged. This principle is
supremely important but is not an absolute principle. (See, among
others, Ghulam Muhammad v State 1980 P Cri J 1039; State v
Farman-PLD 1995 SC 1. 11; Abdul Mateen case - PLD 2006 SC
538).
In Safdar Ali v Crown (PLD 1953 FC 93) Shahabuddin
J. held that-
"It is the main principle of criminal law
that an accused person must be
presumed to be innocent unless and until
it is established by the prosecution
beyond reasonable doubt that he or she,
as the case may be, is guilty".
Provisions in the Qanun:
The provisions bearing on "burden of proof are to be
found in Chapter IX, Articles 117 to 129, of the Qanun.
Article 117, clause (2), defines the "burden of proof":
"When a person is bound to prove the
existence of any fact, it is said that the
burden of proof lies on that person".
Articles 117(1), 118 and 119 enact, as Monir in his "Law of
Evidence" observes different aspects of the same rule as to on
whom the burden of proof lies.
450
By Article 117(1)-
"Whoever desires any court to give
judgment as to any legal right or liability
dependent on the existence of facts
which he asserts, must prove that those
facts exist".
This is well explained by illustration (a) to Article 117. A desires a
court to give judgment that B should be punished for a crime which
A asserts B has committed; A must prove that B has committed the
crime.
The reference in Article 117 to "legal right or liability"
is obviously a reference to the substantive law, that is, the rights
and liabilities including criminal liabilities created by the
substantive law.
Thus, under Article 117, burden of proof means the
obligation to persuade as a matter of (i) substantive law, that is to
say, the ingredients of the offence under the law which defines and
punishes it, must be established, and (ii) the pleadings, in a
criminal case for example the facts alleged in the challan or the
complaint.
In the words of Comelius J. in Safdar Ali. "it is
undeniable that finally the burden lies upon the prosecution to
prove each ingredient of the offence charged", and "the burden of
the general issue is on the prosecution from beginning to end
..". Thus, the onus to prove the guilt of an accused is
always on the prosecution because the accused is presumed to be
innocent. (State v Farman PLD 1995 SC 1. 11: Rab Nawaz v
State-PLD 1994 SC 858).
Now, since the burden of proof, as in the above
illustration, is on A, he must lead evidence as to the facts alleged
by him to prove that B committed the alleged offence. It is plain
451
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 244
that if he leads no evidence at all, he must fail. This is the principle
enacted by Article 118:
"The burden of proof in a suit or proceeding lies on that
person who would fail if no evidence at all were given
on either side",
The word 'proceeding' includes criminal proceeding and
the word 'liability' includes criminal liability; the rule therefore
applies both to civil and criminal cases.
Article 119 puts the same idea as is embodied in Article
117(1) in another way: "The burden of proof as to any particular
fact lies on that person who wishes the court to believe in its
existence, unless it is provided by any law that the proof of that fact
lies on any particular person". This applies equally to the
prosecutor and the person accused. The two illustrations to this
Article exemplify this position. (a) A prosecutes B for theft and
wishes the court to believe that B admitted the theft to C. The onus
to prove the admission is on A. Otherwise too, as a prosecutor, the
burden to prove that B committed the theft is on A and one piece of
prosecution evidence can be the confession of B. (b) B wishes the
court to believe that at the time of an incident he was elsewhere,
that is, so far away from the place of the incident that he could not
possibly participate in the incident. This is what is called plea of
alibi, and its burden is obviously upon B.
When the statutory burden is on accused:
In cases of 'reverse burden' (reverse because the burden
is placed on the defendant and not, as ordinarily in criminal
proceedings, on the prosecutor - see Sheldrake, p 243, per Lord
Bingham), the statutory burden of proof may be placed upon the
defendant expressly or by necessary implication, that being a
matter of interpretation of the provision in question. As was held in
Edwards (1974) 2 All ER 1085; approved in Hunt (1987) 1 All ER
1. both being cases of burden of proof by necessary implication]
452
"whichever method Parliament uses, it has created a statutory
exception and there is no difference in the quality or status of such
an exception.......".
Unlike America, and the countries governed by the
European Convention. 'presumption of innocence" has not been
accorded a constitutional status in Pakistan, and it has been held
(See Khan Asfandyar Wali v Federation - PLD 2001 SC) that the
placing of burden of proof in certain cases upon the accused is not
violative of any provision of the Constitution. Even when the right
to be presumed innocent appears on its face to be an absolute
requirement, it has been held that it does not prohibit rules which
transfer the burden to the accused to establish a defence, provided
the overall burden of proof remains on the prosecution, nor does it
necessarily prohibit presumptions of law or fact provided these are
within reasonable limits. (Brown v Scott (2001) 2 All ER 97.
105).
Article 121 of the Qanun (which is an exact reproduction
of section 105 of the Evidence Act, 1872), is a general statutory
provision expressly placing the burden of proof upon the accused.
It reads:
"When a person is accused of any
offence, the burden of proving the
existence of circumstances bringing the
case within any of the General
Exceptions in the Pakistan Penal
Code.or within any special
exception or proviso contained in any
other part of the same Code, or in any
law defining the offence, is upon him.
and the court shall presume the absence
of such circumstances".
Chapter IV of the Pakistan Penal Code comprising
sections 76 to 106, contains the General Exceptions within the
453
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 245
meaning of Article 121 of the Qanun. Of them, Articles 82 and 83
create exceptions in favour of children. Article 84 is an exception
regarding a person of unsound mind, the leading case on this
subject being M'Naghten (1843-60) All ER 229), and sections 96
to 106 which provide for the right of private defence in its various
forms. Section 96 reads:
"Nothing is an offence which is done in
the exercise of the right of private
defence".
The leading case on this subject is Safdar Ali v Crown
(PLD 1953 FC 93) in which Safdar Ali was accused of murder; he
had, during the course of the incident, received a serious knife
injury in the thigh and had pleaded that he had caused injuries to
the deceased man in self defence. Before the Federal Court
reference was made to section 105 of the Evidence Act, 1872, (now
Article 121 of the Qanun) read with the definitions of 'proved" and
'not proved", and to the Woolmington case and the question was
what was the burden of proof on the accused under section 105
(Article 121). Chief Justice Abdul Rashid, in his short concurring
note, encapsulated the law in the following words:
the decision in the case of
Woolmington v Director of Public
Prosecutions is in no way inconsistent
with the provisions of section 105 of the
Evidence Act. In a criminal case it is the
duty of the court to review the entire
evidence that has been produced by the
prosecution and the defence. If, after an
examination of the whole evidence, the
court is of opinion that there is a
reasonable possibility that the defence
put forward by the accused might be
true, it is clear that such a view reacts on
the whole prosecution case. In these
circumstances, the accused is entitled to
the benefit of doubt, not as a matter of
grace, but as of right, because the
prosecution has not proved its case
beyond reasonable doubt".
In the opinion of the learned Chief Justice, "section
105......has been enacted in order to make it clear that it is not the
duty of the prosecution to examine all possible defenses that might
be taken on behalf of the accused and to prove that none of those
defenses would be of any assistance to him. The principles laid
down in Woolmington's case are applicable with full force in spite
of the provisions of section 105.....
Cornelius J. in his detailed judgment, felt satisfied that
"in cases like the present, there is no material difference between
the application of the standard of proof required under Pakistan
Law and that which underlies the rule of 'reasonable doubt' which
obtains in the English Courts. It is undeniable that finally the
burden lies upon the prosecution to prove each ingredient of the
offence charged, i.e. to support each ingredient by such evidence as
would justify action by a prudent man, on the basis that such
ingredient is established. He went on to say:
"I do not see any appreciable
difference between this duty, and the
duty of proving each ingredient beyond
'reasonable doubt". If then an accused
person is able to establish by evidence.
or if the prosecution evidence presents
such features as go to establish the
existence of a reasonable doubt
regarding an essential ingredient of the
offence charged, such as the requisite
intention in a case of murder, then the
prosecution must necessarily fail. Such
intention may, of course, be established
454
455.
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 246
by proof of circumstances surrounding
an evident act of cruelty causing death
and need not necessarily be proved by
direct evidence. Yet, it must be admitted
that where the only credible evidence of
11 direct nature. relevant to the
determination of intention is furnished
by the accused person himself, who
adduces acts in avoidance of the charge
of murder, it requires very strong
circumstances indeed of a
sufficient to exclude the possibility of
the defence plea being true in order to
provide the preponderance of probability
necessary for a prudent man to act on the
footing that the accused's act was
performed with the sole intention of
killing, or of causing a necessarily fatal
injury.
nature
It is, of course, not possible to arrive at
any conclusion that the accused person
acted as he alleged he did, on a
consideration of his statement alone. It is
necessary to place his evidence
alongside all the other evidence and
circumstances appearing in the case, and
only then can a court be in a position to
weigh the testimony and the
probabilities with the requisite degree of
thoroughness before reaching its
conclusion. The process by which the
court at the close of the case assesses the
evidence and circumstances in relation
to the charges preferred by the
prosecution is precisely similar. Clearly,
as necessary to place the defence version
and its supporting evidence and
circumstances in juxtaposition to the
prosecution case for the proper
estimation of the extent to which the
charge may be held to have been proved,
as it is to examine the prosecution case
side by side with the defence case in
reaching a decision on the accused's
special pleading........
Safdar Ali was followed, among others, in Nadeem-ul-Haq v State
(1985 SCMR 510), Rab Nawaz v State (PLD 1994 SC 858), which
was a case under a Hadd Law namely Prohibition (Enforcement of
Hadd) Order, 1979 and Abdul Haque v State (PLD 1996 SC I); it
was applied and explained in State v Mushtaq Ahmad (PLD 1973
SC 418). In Mushtaq Ahmad, the accused had not specifically
raised the plea of self-defence; he did not admit the causing of the
stab wound to the deceased. Referring to Safdar Ali case and the
case of Muhammad Aslam v Crown (PLD 1953 FC 115),
Muhammad Gul J. speaking for the court, observed that-
"in both cases the pleas of self-defence
were not only specifically raised but
evidence was also led in support thereof
though such evidence was found, in each
case, to be inadequate to bring the cases
under the general exception. It was in
that context that the learned Judges of
the Federal Court laid down the rule that
in a criminal case even if the plea of
self-defence has failed, nevertheless the
court was bound to take into account all
the facts appearing on the record
including the evidence led for the
defence with a view to finding out
456
457
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 247
whether as a result of such review the
prosecution case has been affected with
a reasonable doubt, in which case the
accused will be entitled to its benefit".
To the question "whether on the facts of the instant case
a foundation was laid for application of the rule in Safdar Ali's
case", the answer, it was held, must be in the negative:
"As pointed out already the respondent
did not specifically raise a plea of self-
defence, nor did he produce any
evidence in his defence. Therefore, the
possibility of any 'reaction on the
prosecution case is excluded altogether".
Burden on accused under Special Laws:
There are a number of special laws placing the burden of
proof of some facts on, or raising a presumption against, the
accused; prominent among them are the anti-corruption laws in
which receipt of tainted money by the accused shifts the burden on
him to explain how he received the money. A respectable body of
case-law has accumulated round those laws, (See for example.
Muhammad Siddiq v State 1977 SCMR 503; Ghulam Ali v State
- PLD 1963 (WP) Kar. 582; Ghulam Muhammad v State = 1980 P
Cri J 1039). In Khan Asfandyar Wali v Federation (PLD 2001 SC
607), the law in question was the National Accountability Bureau
Ordinance, 1999, which placed the burden of certain facts upon the
person accused. In Sikandar A. Karim case (1995 SCMR 387),
section 156 of the Customs Act, 1969, provided that where goods
specified in clause (s) of section 2 of the Act were seized in the
belief that an act to defraud the Government of any duty was
committed, the burden to prove that no such act was committed
was on the accused. The accused was held to discharge the initial
burden of showing that the goods were neither smuggled nor was
458
their possession unlawful. The overall burden to prove that the
accused was guilty remained on the prosecution.
Burden to prove facts especially within one's knowledge:
Article 122 of the Qanun provides;
"When any fact is especially within the
knowledge of any person, the burden of
proving that fact is upon him".
We have, in considering the rule enacted in Article 121, noticed R
v Edwards in which the defendant was convicted of selling by
retail intoxicating liquor without holding a justices license
authorizing such a sale. The statutory prohibition of acts, otherwise
than under license granted by government, was a commonplace of
life during the war years 1939 to 1945. The question as to who was
to prove lack of license has been answered as follows. If on its true
construction an enactment prohibits the doing of an act in specified
circumstances, the accused must, by way of exception to the
fundamental rule of the criminal law that the prosecutor must
establish every element of the offence charged, prove the existence
of the specified circumstances. For example, if the charge is that a
person was selling sugar without license, where license was
necessary, the burden to prove that he had the license is on the
accused and not on the prosecution. Or, as the illustration (b) to
Article 122 reads:
"A is charged with traveling on a
railway without a ticket. The burden of
proving that he had a ticket is on him".
But this rule is not based on the premise of special or
peculiar knowledge of the accused. "There is not, and never has
been, a general rule that the mere fact that a matter lies peculiarly
within the knowledge of the defendant is sufficient to cast the onus
on him. If there was any such rule, anyone charged with doing an
459
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 248
unlawful act with a specified intent would find himself having to
prove his innocence because if there ever was a matter which could
be said to be peculiarly within a person's knowledge it is the state
of his own mind". (Lawton LJ in R v Edwards (1974) 2 All ER
1085).
Right to begin:
In one sense, 'burden of proof also means introducing
evidence. This depends on the allocation of the burden of proof.
The right to begin is in the party who bears the burden of proof. In
criminal cases, as for example under sections 244 and 265F of the
Code of Criminal Procedure, the right to begin is in the
prosecution, because, as we have seen, the burden to prove the guilt
of the accused is on the prosecution.
Standard of proof:
Though the expression 'standard of proof has not been
used in the Qanun, there is no doubt that it is laid down in its
Article 2, clauses (4) and (5), in the definitions of the expressions
"proved' and 'not proved' respectively.
While burden of proof is the burden of persuasion,
standard of proof is the degree or measure of persuasion required
of the party on whom the burden of proof lies. For a trier of fact,
the question is that, in view of the nature of the issue before him,
how convinced he must be to be convinced that the fact in question
is proved. He will ask himself the question: how sure should I be
before I decide the case in favour of one party or the other? The
appropriate confidence level depends on what is at stake in the
proceedings. ("Criminal Evidence" by Paul Roberts and Andrian
Zuckerman, p 351).
"Standard of proof is also known as "quantum of
proof. For example, (1) the Hadood Laws prescribe the number
of witnesses required to prove offences punishable with Hadood
460
punishments: (2) Article 17(2)(a) of the Qanun, requires that "in
matters pertaining to financial or future obligations, if reduced to
writing, the instrument shall be attested by two men, or one man
and two women, so that one may remind the other, if necessary.
and evidence shall be led accordingly"; and (iii) Article 79 of the
Qanun lays down that "if a documents is required by law to be
attested, it shall not be used as evidence until two attesting
witnesses at least have been called for the purpose of proving its
execution, if there be two attesting witnesses alive and subject to
the process of the court and capable of giving evidence"
Required standard of proof:
The law may require different standards of proof or
persuasion in different fact-situations. For example, Article 23 of
the Qanun provides that where there is "reasonable ground to
believe" that two or more persons have conspired, then anything
said or done by one of such persons is a relevant fact. Section 497
Cr. P. C. provides that a person shall not be released on bail if there
appear "reasonable grounds for believing" that he has been guilty
of an offence punishable with death etc. These expressions
"reasonable ground to believe" and "reasonable grounds for
believing" mean that there exists a prima facie case. (See Niamat
Singh v State ILR 2 All 25 and other cases considered in Z A
Bhutto case PLD 1979 SC 53, paras 106 to 115 in the judgment of
the Chief Justice). They do not mean, as we shall see, the same
thing as the expression "believes it to exist" in Article 2, clauses
(4) and (5), of the Qanun.
In laying down the standard of proof, the Qanun in its
Article 2, clauses (4) and (5), does not prescribe one standard of
proof for criminal cases and another for civil cases. What it says is.
to quote from clause (4), that -
A fact is said to be proved when, after considering the
matters before it, the court either -
461
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 249
(i)
(ii)
believes it to exist; or
considers its existence so probable that a
prudent man ought, under the circumstances
of the particular case, to act upon the
supposition that it exits.
This definition and the definition of 'not proved' in clause (5)
visualize two kinds of cases:
(i)
(ii)
Cases in which the matters before the court
induce in its mind an absolute, almost
mathematical certainty - a belief that the fact

But

"If it is proved that the conscious act of

And in the American case of Re Winship (397 US 358; 25 L. Ed 2d

in a judicial proceeding in which

earlier event, the fact-finder cannot
acquire unassailable accurate knowledge
of what happened.....".
Therefore, if the evidence is not of such a quality as to induce
absolute certainty, then the law, as laid down in clauses (4) and (5)
of Article 2, allows the court to decide on probabilities - the court
may, after considering the matters before it, consider the existence
of the fact in question so probable that a prudent man ought to act
on the supposition that it exists. Here, the court is the spokesman of
an ordinary prudent man. The test is whether an ordinary prudent
man will, on the material before him, hold the disputed fact proved.
That is why in the Anglo-American system, the questions of fact
are left to the jury, a panel of layman, not lawyers.
As was said by Muhammad Afzal Zullah J. in State v
Habibur Rehman (PLD 1983 SC 280, 289):
"Circumstantial deduction reaching
"probability is a mental cognition which
leads to 'supposition" regarding
existence of a fact. This the law permits
as an alternative to positive 'belief in its
existence. Probability is not lower than
likelihood which is higher than a mere
possibility a surmise to distinguish a
462
463

Page 250
probability from conjecture and even
possibility........
In the words of Justice Harlan in Re Winship, if the fact-finder
cannot acquire "unassailably accurate knowledge of what
happened", then-
all that the fact-finder can
acquire is a belief of what probably
happened. The intensity of this belief-
the degree to which a fact-finder is
convinced that a given act actually
occurred can, of course, vary. In this
regard, a standard of proof represents an
attempt to instruct the fact-finder
concerning the degree of confidence our
society thinks he should have in the
correctness of factual conclusion for a
particular type of adjudication".
Although, the definitions of 'proved' and 'not proved' govern both
the criminal and civil cases, and the law of evidence does not lay
down one standard for one type of cases and a different standard
for another type, yet, the courts have evolved two basic standards:

(2)

standard of proof beyond a reasonable doubt.

Standard required in civil and criminal cases:
In general, in ordinary civil cases, the required standard
of proof is preponderance of probabilities, and in criminal cases it
is proof beyond a reasonable doubt. (Muhammad Ibrahim v
Muhammkad Sharif 1980 CLC 296: Zakaullah Khan v
Muhammad Aslam-1991 SCMR 2126).
The reason for different standards of proof in civil as
opposed to criminal litigation was explained in Re Winship (397
US 358; 25 L Ed 2d 368) by Justice Harlan as follows:
"In a civil suit between two private
parties for money damages, for example.
we view it as no more serious in general
for there to be an erroneous verdict in
the plaintiff's favour. A preponderance
of the evidence standard therefore seems
peculiarly appropriate for, as explained
most sensibly, it simply requires the trier
of fact 'to believe that the existence of a
fact is more probable than its non-
existence before he may find in favour
of the party who has the burden to
persuade the Judge of the fact's
existence.

Page 251
In a criminal case, on the other hand, we
do not view the social disutility of

innocent

someone who is guilty..
In this context, I view the requirement of
proof beyond a reasonable doubt in a
criminal case as bottomed on
fundamental value determination of our
society that it is far worse to convict an
innocent man than to let a guilty man go
free.........
The rule is not absolute:
The above statement is subject to the qualification that
there is no absolute standard in either case. We have seen that
when the law places a legal burden of proof upon a person accused
of a criminal offence, the burden upon him is to be discharged by
preponderance rule as opposed to the burden of proof beyond a
reasonable doubt upon the prosecution. (See e.g. Safdar Ali (PLD
1953 SC 53): Hunt -(1987) 1 All ER 1; and Sheldrake - (2005) 1
All ER 237). Then, in a civil case of divorce on ground of cruelty
(Bater v Bater (1950) 2 All ER 458), as also on ground of
adultery (Preston-Jones (1951) 1 All ER 124), the burden of
proof is beyond a reasonable doubt. In Rashid Ahmad v President
(PLD 1994 SC 36, 45). proceedings which entailed disqualification
from being elected as a member of an Assembly were proceedings
of civil nature, yet the benefit of doubt rule, was applied.
Meanings of the two standards:
We have already noticed the American case of Re
Winship, which declared:
"Lest there remain any doubt about the
constitutional stature of the reasonable -
doubt standard, we explicitly hold that
Due Process Clause protects the accused
against conviction except upon proof
beyond a reasonable doubt of every fact
necessary to constitute the crime with
which he is charged".
That case, as we have noticed, also explained the reasons for the
two different standards and in the process their meanings.
In Miller v Minister of Pensions (1947) 2 All ER 372.
Lord Denning, in explaining the preponderance standard, observed:
"If at the end of the case the evidence
turns the scale definitely one way or the
other, the tribunal must decide
accordingly. This means that the case
must be decided in favour of the man
unless the evidence against him reaches
the same degree of cogency as is
required to discharge a burden in a civil
case. That degree is well settled. If must
carry a reasonable degree of probability
but not so high as is required in a
criminal case. If the evidence is such that
the tribunal can say: "we think it more
probable than not" the burden is
discharged, but if the probabilities are
equal, it is not".
Thus, the balance of probability standard requires the party who
has the burden to show that it is more likely than not that his case is
true. The court, so to say. puts the evidence of one side in one scale
of justice and the evidence of the other, in the other scale of justice,
and sees which way the balance tilts.
466
467
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 252
"Beyond reasonable doubt" is a time-honoured phrase
as was noticed in Re Winship by Justice Brennan. "it is now
accepted in common law jurisdictions as the measure of persuasion
by which the prosecution must convince the trier of fact of all the
essential elements of guilt; it is a prime instrument for reducing the
risk of convictions resting on factual error...... a person accused
of a crime........ would be at a severe disadvantage, a disadvantage
amounting to a lack of fundamental fairness, if he could be
adjudged guilty and imprisoned for years on the strength of the
same evidence as would suffice in a civil case". As we have seen, it
was explained and reinforced in Viscount Sankey's most famous
and frequently quoted golden thread passage in the English
Criminal Jurisprudence in Woolmington (followed in Safdar Ali
which passage is often referred by the English lawyers as shorthand
for the burden and standard of proof in criminal proceedings.
Yet, there is no universally agreed definition of "beyond
reasonable doubt". As the authors of the American Jurisprudence
point out, the courts at one time defined it in terms of "important
life decision", "the proof be so convincing that an ordinary person
would be willing to make the most important decisions in his or her
own life", and by equating it to a moral certainty. In Sandoval v
California (1994) it was said that it is that state of the case which,
after the entire comparison and consideration of entire evidence
leave the minds of the jurors in that they cannot say they feel an
abiding conviction, to a moral certainty, of the truth of the charge.
In England, in one case - Rv Yap Chuan Chin (1976) 63 Cr. App.
R 7), the judge defined a reasonable doubt as one "for which you
could give reasons if you were asked"; the Court of Appeal
disapproved it. So despaired was Lord Goddard CJ of an exact
definition of the phrase that he suggested in R v Summers (1952)
36, Cr. App.R.14; (1952) I AIIER 1059) that the phrase should be
abandoned altogether. And in Khawaja (1984) AC 74) where the
question was whether proof beyond reasonable doubt or proof on
balance of probabilities was the appropriate standard in
applications for habeas corpus, Lord Scarman said:
M
I have come to the
conclusion that the choice between the
two standards is not of any great
moment. It is largely a matter of
words".
The question at the end of the day is that a case is either proved or
not proved in accordance with the standard appropriate to the case
before the court. As was said in an Australian case - Rajfek (1965)
112 CLR 517)-
"The difference between the criminal
standard of proof and the civil standard
of proof is no matter of words. It is a
matter of critical substance..........
And Dixon CJ said in another Australian case - Dawson (1961)
106 CLR 1)-
"it is a mistake to depart from the time-
honoured formula. It is, I think, used by
ordinary people and understood well
enough by the average man in the
community....".
"Beyond reasonable doubt" is not the only phrase or
expression in law which is insusceptible of an exact definition.
There are many other such expressions such as negligence. It is a
fallacy to think, so said Lord Reid in Ridge v Baldwin - (1963) 2
All ER 66, 71) in which the phrase under consideration was
"natural justice", that because something cannot be cut and dried or
nicely weighed or measured therefore it does not exist.
We think that a fairly good idea of the meaning of the
phrase can be had from Lord Denning's following observations in
Miller v Minister of Pensions (1947) 2 All ER 372) -
468
469
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 253
"It need not reach certainty, but it must
carry a high degree of probability. Proof
beyond reasonable doubt does not mean
proof beyond the shadow of a doubt. The
law would fail to protect the community
if it admitted fanciful possibilities to
deflect the course of justice. If the
evidence is so strong against a man as to
leave only a remote possibility in his
favour which can be dismissed with the
sentence: 'of course it is possible, but
not in the least probable', the case is
proved beyond reasonable doubt, but
nothing short of that will suffice".
The following two cases decided by the Supreme Court of Pakistan
shed considerable light on the subject.
In State v Mushtaq Ahmad (PLD 1973 SC 418, 430).
Muhammad Gul J. said:
"Law allows to persons accused of
criminal offences the benefit of
'reasonable and not of imaginary
doubts. What is a reasonable doubt is not
a question of law; it is essentially a
question of human judgment by a
prudent person to be formed in each
case, in the light of day to day
experience in life, after taking into
account fully all the facts and
circumstances appearing on the record. It
is anti-thesis of haphazard approach.or
reaching fitful decision in a case".
470
In State v Manzoor Ahmad (PLD 1966 SC 664, 680), a

"It is also equally well settled that the
circumstances sought to be relied upon
must have been established beyond all
doubt. But this only means reasonable
doubt i.e. doubt such as would assail a
reasonable mind and not any and every
kind of doubt and much less a doubt
conjured up by pre-conceived
notions..
That the difference between the preponderance standard and
reasonable doubt standard is one of "critical substance" may be
illustrated by the following cases.
In Re Winship, a 12-year-old boy was charged with
stealing money, and was tried under a statute which prescribed the
standard of preponderance of evidence. The trial judge made an
order placing the juvenile in a training school, subject to
confinement for six years. In doing so, the trial judge
acknowledged that if he were to apply the reasonable doubt
standard, the evidence might not establish guilt. The question was
whether proof beyond a reasonable doubt was among the
"essentials of due process and fair treatment". The Court of Appeal
confirmed the order suggesting that there is, in any event, only a
"tenuous difference" between the reasonable doubt and
preponderance standards. In the US Supreme Court, Justice
Brennan rejected the suggestion:
"The suggestion is singularly
unpersuasive. In this very case, the trial
Judge's ability to distinguish between
the two standards enabled him to make a
finding of guilt that he conceded he
471
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 254
might not have made under the standard
of proof beyond a reasonable doubt.
Indeed, the trial judge's action evidences
the accuracy of the observation of
commentators that 'the preponderance
test is susceptible
misinterpretation that it calls on the trier
10 the
of fact merely to perform an abstract
weighing of the evidence in order to
determine which side has produced the
greater quantum, without regard to its

In the same case, Justice Harlan referred to Wigmore's famous
book on Evidence 3 ed (1940), who, in discussing the various
attempts by courts to define how convinced one must be to be

no one has yet invented or discovered a mode of measurement for

"We have before us a case where the

There is then the recent American case of O.J. Simpson

the murder of his wife and another. The trial took about eleven

months, and resulted in a verdict of not guilty. On the same facts,
Simpson was sued for damages and the civil action resulted in a
verdict against him and he was held liable to pay heavy damages.
For our purposes, it is sufficient to say that it was the difference in
the standard of proof that made the difference.
THE PRINCIPLE OF BEST EVIDENCE
The principle of "best evidence' is well-established in
English Common Law, it was, as we shall see, implicit in the
Evidence Act, 1872, and is implicit in its successor - the Qanun-e-
Shahadat, 1984. It requires that the best available evidence of
which the case is susceptible should always be presented. (Murarka
(1978) I SCC 109 and Janki Narayan (2003) 2 SCC 91). It finds
expression, so far as oral evidence is concerned, in Article 71 of the
Qanun-e-Shahadat Order, 1984: "Oral evidence must, in all cases
whatever, be direct......" and so far as documentary evidence is
concerned, in Article 75: "Documents must be proved by primary
evidence except in the cases hereinafter mentioned"; "hereinafter
means Article 76, which enumerates the cases in which instead of
primary evidence, secondary evidence may be given. Primary
evidence, so says Article 73, means the document itself produced
for the inspection of the court.
In elaboration of this general principle, Article 71 goes
on to provide that if oral evidence-
(i)
(ii)
(iii)
refers to a fact which could be seen, it must be
the evidence of a witness who says he saw it;
refers to a fact which could be heard, it must
be the evidence of a witness who says he
heard it;
refers to a fact which could be perceived by
any other sense or in any other manner, it
must be the evidence of a witness who says he
perceived it with that sense or in that manner.
473
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 255
(iv)
refers to an opinion or to the grounds on
which that opinion is held, it must be the
evidence of the person who holds that opinion
on those grounds.
The word 'direct' is used, in the law of evidence, in two senses;
one, in contrast to indirect, or hearsay, and the other, in contrast to
circumstantial.
Here, in Article 71, it has been used in the first sense,
that is, in contrast to indirect or hearsay.
The word 'must' emphasizes the mandatory nature of
the rule: Oral evidence must be direct; it must not be indirect or
hearsay. By necessary implication, therefore, indirect or hearsay
oral evidence is excluded; it is not admissible.
In Article 71 of Qanun-e-Shahadat, 1984 (as in its
predecessor provision viz section 60 of the Evidence Act, 1872),
the expression "direct evidence", so observed Monir in his
"invaluable treatise" on the Law of Evidence, 1974 Edition V.I, p.
690 (quoted in Z.. A. Bhutto v State - PLD 1979 SC 53, in para 62),
has been used in the sense of 'original' evidence as distinguished
from 'hearsay evidence. According to Monir, section 60 of the
1872 Act and Article 71 of the Qanun-e-Shahadat enact the general
English rule that "hearsay' is no evidence.
As regards oral evidence referred to at (i), (ii) and (iii)
above, the underlying notion is that a witness should speak only of
facts which he has perceived with one of his five senses. Indeed,
there are exceptions which will be noticed later.
Hearsay
The starting point for the consideration of the hearsay
rule is that the rule presupposes that the evidence in question is
relevant to the fact in issue. If the evidence is irrelevant, it is
inadmissible for that reason. That will obviate the necessity to ask
whether the evidence is hearsay.
The word 'hearsay' was not used in the Evidence Act.
1872; it has not been used in the Qanun-e-Shahadat, 1984 either.
This avoidance to use it seems to be deliberate. The reason is that it
has no exhaustive definition and any definition can, therefore, be
misleading.
It is difficult, said Lord Reid in Myers v Director of
Public Prosecutions, (1965) AC 1001:(1964) I All ER 877) "to
make any general statement about the law of hearsay
evidence which is entirely accurate". As we shall see, in the recent
leading case on the common law hearsay, R v Kearley ((1992) 2
AC 228; (1992) 2 All ER 345)). a decision by a 3:2 majority, one
point of divergence between the majority and the minority of the
Law Lords was whether the evidence in question was hearsay or
not. The majority thought it was and the minority, that it was not.
In simple language, hearsay evidence means evidence at
second hand; anything that is not based on the personal or first-
hand knowledge of the witness. The courts are not to hear second-
hand stories; they must have Zaid's story out of his own mouth, not
Umer's account of what Zaid had to say. Thus, if A gives evidence
that B killed C, and when asked how he knew it, he says, he saw it.
the evidence is admissible, because it is direct evidence of what the
witness perceived with his own unaided senses. But if the witness
replies: "so and so told me", this is hearsay and is inadmissible to
prove its truth.
The distinction between direct and hearsay evidence,
said Anwar-ul-Haq CJ. in Z. A. Bhutto case "is best illustrated by
Wigmore on Evidence, 3rd Edition, Volume V, section 1361".
According to the learned author-
"when a witness A on the stand testified,
'B told me that event X occurred', his
testimony may be regarded in two ways:
475
474
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 256
of
(1) he may be regarded as asserting the
event upon his own credit i.e. as a fact to
be believed because he asserts that he
knows it. But when it thus appears that
his assertion is not based on personal
observation of event X his testimony to
that extent is rejected, because he is not
qualified by proper sources
knowledge to speak to it. (2)
suppose in order to
But
obviate that
objection that we regard A as not
making any assertion about event X (of
which he has no personal knowledge)
but as testifying to the utterance in his
hearing of B's statement as to event X.
To this, A is clearly qualified to testify,
so that no objection can arise on that
score".
In Charles Dicken's "Pickwick Papers". Sam's evidence called for
the Judge's ruling on its admissibility. He admitted that he was in
Pickwick's service:
"Little to do, and plenty to get, 1
suppose", asked Sergeant Buzfuz, with
jocularity:
"Oh, quite enough to get, Sir, as the
soldier said when they ordered him three
hundred and fifty lashes," replied Sam.
"You must not tell me what the soldier
or any other man said, Sir," intercepted
the Judge, "it is not evidence".
Because the precise scope of the rule against hearsay is.
so said Lord Ackner in Kearley, a matter of controversy, there are a
variety of formulations of the rule. In Cross on Evidence (7th ed.
1990. p 42), the rule was thus stated:
"an assertion other than one made by a
witness while giving oral evidence in the
proceedings is inadmissible as evidence
of any act asserted".
This formulation was approved by the House of Lords in R v Sharp
(1988) 1 All ER 65, 68) and was relied on in Kearley.
The best way of understanding the concept of hearsay is
to see how the rule has been applied in decided cases.
R v Gibson (1887) 18 QBD 537) is an example of
classic hearsay. The accused was charged with malicious
wounding, by throwing a stone at the complainant, in the street
where the accused's house was situated. In the evidence, the
complainant stated that just after he had been hit by the stone, a
woman pointed to the door of the accused's house and said: "The
person who threw the stone went in there'. Shortly afterwards the
accused was arrested from that house. He was convicted by the trial
Judge. Lord Coleridge CJ in Court of Appeal held:
I am of opinion that the true
principle which governs the present case
is that it is the duty of the Judge in
criminal trials to take care that the
verdict... is not founded upon any
evidence except that which the law
allows. Here evidence which was at law
inadmissible was allowed to go to the
jury".
Note that the evidence was not described as hearsay; the
reason is that it was well-understood that this was hearsay and
therefore inadmissible.
476
477
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 257
In Mst. Atkia Begum v Mohammad Ibrahim (AIR 1916
PC 25), which was a suit for restitution of marriage, and in which
the question of fact was whether the appellant, Atkia, was of age
the date of her alleged marriage, which took place at Mecca, and if
so, was the marriage with her consent. According to the Islamic
Law, "a girl becomes a major on the happening of either of two
events; first, the completion of her fifteenth year and second, on
her attaining a state of puberty at an earlier period".
Their Lordships insisted upon 'legal evidence' because-
"it appears to their Lordships that
hearsay evidence-in some cases indeed
mere gossip, wholly inadmissible in its
nature was admitted and treated as
substantive proof of the fact related or
discussed".
They referred to two instances, "one so coarse as to be almost
incredible and the other such a travesty of legitimate methods of
proof as to be comical".
The first was where a witness to the Nikah, Bashir
Ahmad by name, "having taken upon himself to state, in answer to
a question that he knew the appellant to be of age by certain
signs of puberty recognized by Mohammedan Law. When asked
how he knew this, he replied: "through her father". It is difficult to
believe that the girl's father can even have bestowed this
confidence upon the witness; but even if he had done so, the
repetition of what the father said was no evidence whatever of the
substantive fact of the girl's puberty".
The other instance was furnished by the evidence, taken
on commission at Mecca, of one of the witnesses of the plaintiff in
the suit. "After being examined by the person appearing for the
defendant, he was re-examined by the person appearing for the
plaintiff and was asked: Did you hear from anybody that Atkia
Begum was of age? And he replied: I heard it from my wife who
478
heard from the mother of Atkia Begum........ The point is that the
deposition appears to have been read in evidence as it stood.
without any objection having been made to this undoubted
hearsay".
The evil consequences of the admission of such
evidence, their Lordships went on to say, as this is, are-
"not merely that it prolongs litigation
and increases its costs, but that it may
unconsciously be regarded by judicial
minds as corroboration of some piece of
evidence legally admissible and thereby
obtain from the latter quite undue weight
and significance".
The rationale of the rule was stated by Lord Normand in
Taper v R (1952) AC 480, 486):
"It (hearsay) is not the best evidence and
it is not delivered an oath. The
truthfulness and accuracy of the person
whose words are spoken to by another
witness cannot be tested by cross-
examination and the light that his
demeanor would throw on his testimony
is lost".
According to Wigmore on Evidence, vol.5, section 1420, the
hearsay rule is based on the assumption-
sources of
"that many possible
inaccuracy and untrustworthiness which
may be underneath the bare untested
assertion of a witness can best be
brought to light and exposed, if they
exist, by the test of cross-examination".
479
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 258
A small quantity of amphetamine was recovered from his flat,
In Kearley, the accused was charged with drug-dealing
which he shared with his wife and another man, but not in
sufficient quantity to raise the inference that the accused was a
dealer. The accused was arrested and taken to the police station but
the police party remained there for several hours during which time
they intercepted ten telephone calls in which the callers asked to
speak to the accused and asked for drugs. In addition, seven
persons called at the flat asking for the accused and seeking to buy
drugs. At the trial, the prosecution was unable or unwilling to call
the telephone callers or visitors to the flat as witnesses to prove the
charge of drug-dealing; instead, the prosecution proposed to call
the police officials who had intercepted the calls or received the
visitors to prove as a fact that they were customers from which it
could be inferred that the accused was dealing in drugs. The
defence objected that the evidence of the police officials was
hearsay and inadmissible. The Judge overruled the objection and
the accused was convicted. His appeal was dismissed by the Court
of Appeal, but on appeal to the House of Lords, the conviction was,
by a 3:2 majority, set aside, for it was based on the hearsay and
inadmissible evidence of the police officials. As Lord Ackner put
it:
"What is sought to be done is to use the
oral assertion, even though it may be an
implied assertion, as evidence of the
truth of the proposition asserted. That
the proposition is asserted by way of
necessary implication rather than
expressly cannot, to my mind, make any
difference. The object of tendering the
evidence would be to establish the truth
of what is contained in the statement.
This is precisely what the rule
prohibits....
Lord Griffiths and Lord Browne - Wilkinson, in their dissenting
speeches, emphasized the common sense view of the evidence; in
480
their opinion, the police officials' evidence was evidence of the
conduct of the callers, recounted at first-hand, by them. In the
words of Lord Griffiths-
"Unless compelled to do so by authority
I should be most unwilling to hold that
such evidence should be withheld........
In my view the criminal law of evidence
should be developed along common
sense lines readily comprehensible to the
men and women who comprise the jury
and bear the responsibility for the major
decisions in criminal cases. I believe that
most layman if told that the criminal law
of evidence forbade them even to
consider such evidence........ would
reply, then the law is an ass'......
Lord Griffiths went on to say:
"It is hardly surprising that the jury
convicted the appellant for as a matter of
common sense it is difficult to think of
much more convincing evidence of his
activity as a drug dealer than customers
constantly ringing his house to buy drugs
and a stream of customers beating a path
to his door for the same purpose.....
The requests for drugs made by the
callers were not hearsay as generally
understood, namely an out-of-court
narrative description of facts which have
to be proved in evidence. The callers
were neither describing the appellant as
a drug dealer nor stating their opinion
that he was a drug dealer. They were
calling him up to visit him as customers.
481
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 259
a fact revealed by the words they used in
requesting drugs from him".
The risk of wrongful convictions based on unreliable hearsay
evidence is another strong reason for the exclusion of such
evidence.
Hearsay in America:
Hearsay rule exists in one form or another in all
American jurisdictions, but cases on hearsay have generally been
considered with reference to the Sixth Amendment "Confrontation
Clause":-
"In all criminal prosecutions, the
accused shall enjoy the right....... to be
confronted with the witnesses against
him".
The accused's right to confrontation "has been traced historically
through medieval jurisprudence into Roman and other ancient
systems of justice". (Frank R. Herrmann and Browlow M. Speer in
their Article in (1994) 34 Virginia Journal of International Law.
481, cited by Paul Roberts and Adrian Zuckerman in their
"Criminal Evidence" p 668). As was noticed by the Chief Justice
delivering the opinion of the Court in White v Illinois (116 L Ed 2d
848 (1992), the confrontation clause's "limited purpose is to
prevent a particular abuse common in 16th and 17th century
England, prosecuting a defendant through the presentation of
exparte affidavits, without the affiants ever being produced at
trial". In 16 Century England, magistrates interrogated the
prisoner, accomplices and others prior to trial. These interrogations
"were intended only for the information of the courts. The prisoner
had no right to be, and probably never was, present". At the trial
itself "proof was usually given by reading depositions, confessions,
letters and the like" and this occasioned frequent demands by the
prisoner to have his 'accusers' i.e. the witnesses against him,
brought before him face to face." (J. Stephen "A History of
482
the Criminal Law of England 221. (1883) cited in White). In that
connection is "none more frequently retold than the infamous
denial of a right of confrontation to Sir Walter Raleigh". Raleigh
was convicted of treason and executed in 1603 on the basis of an
out-of-court testimony secured from his alleged accomplice, Lord
Cobham. Raleigh, it seems, did not ask to cross-examine Cobham,
or even to have him questioned in court by judges, but only that he
be produced. 'Let Cobham be here, let him speak it. Call my
accuser before my face and I have done". The judges were
apparently fearful that the mere sight of Raleigh would induce
Cobham to change his story and Raleigh's demand to have
Cobham produced face-to-face was denied. (For this statement of
the case, we are indebted to the book "Criminal Evidence" p 668
referred to above). Apparently, so observed the learned Chief
Justice in White,
"in response to such abuses, a common
law right of confrontation began to
develop in England during the late 16
and early 17th Centuries. Justice Story
believed that the Sixth Amendment
codified some of this common
law.
Under the rules of evidence currently applicable in the
different States of America, most hearsay testimony is not
admissible, but there are exceptions; the rationale of many common
law exceptions as also of exceptions under the Confrontation
Clause are primarily based upon a guarantee of reliability or
trustworthiness intended "to ensure the truthfulness of the admitted
statement and to compensate for the fact that a party would not
have the opportunity to test its veracity by cross-examining the
declarant".
In Bourjaily v US (483 US 171: 97 L Ed 2d 144 -
(1987)), Clarence Greathouse, an informant working for the
Federal Bureau of Investigation, arranged to sell a kilogram of
cocaine to Lonardo, who agreed that he would find individuals to
483
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 260
distribute the drug. When the sale became imminent, Lonardo
stated in a tape recorded telephone conversation that he had a
gentleman friend who had some questions to ask about the cocaine,
In a subsequent telephone call, Greathouse spoke to the 'friend'
about the quality of the drug and the price. Greathouse then spoke
again with Lonardo and the two arranged the details of the
purchase. They agreed that the sale would take place in a
designated hotel parking lot, and Lonardo would transfer the drug
from Greathouse's car to the 'friend' who would be waiting in the
parking lot in his own car. Greathouse proceeded with the
transaction as planned, and FBI agents arrested Lonardo and
Bourjaily, the petitioner, immediately after Lonardo placed the
cocaine into the petitioner's car. In the petitioner's car, the police
found over 20000 Dollars in cash.
The petitioner was charged with conspiring to distribute
cocaine and its possession with intent to distribute. The prosecution
introduced Lonardo's telephone statements regarding the
participation of the 'friend' in the transaction. At the trial, Lonardo
exercised his right not to testify. The petitioner argued that
Lonardo's unavailability rendered the telephone talk hearsay and
its admission unconstitutional under the Confrontation Clause.
Rejecting this argument, Chief Justice Rehnquist, speaking for the
Court held:
"While a literal interpretation of the
confrontation clause could bar the use of
any out-of-court statements when the
declarant is unavailable, this court has
rejected that view as 'unintended and too
extreme....... Rather, we have
attempted to harmonize the goal of the
clause with a societal interest in
accurate fact-finding, which may require
consideration
out-of-court
statements..."
484
of
The argument was rejected and the conviction was
upheld. This case provides an interesting contrast with the English
case of Kearley, where also a part of the evidence rejected as
hearsay comprised telephone calls.
In White v Illinois (116 L Ed 2d 848 (1992)), the
application of the confrontation clause to hearsay was considered
in another setting-witness statements made by the alleged child
victim of a sex offence. Speaking for the Court, the Chief Justice
said:
We have consistently sought to
steer a middle course that recognizes that
hearsay rules and the confrontation
clause are generally designed to protect
similar values and stem from the same
roots......
The preference for live testimony in the
case of statements....... is because of
the importance of cross-examination,
'the greatest legal engine invented for
the discovery of truth'. Thus courts have
adopted the general rule prohibiting the
receipt of hearsay evidence. But where
professed hearsay has sufficient
guarantee of reliability to come within a
firmly rooted exception to the hearsay
rule, the confrontation clause is
satisfied".
After referring to the history of the rule, and the previous
discussions, the learned Chief Justice went on to say -
