"Ever since Ohio v Roberts (448 US 56-
1980), the Court has interpreted the
Confrontation Clause to mean that
hearsay may be admitted only under a
485
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 261
firmly rooted exception, or if it otherwise
bears particularized guarantees of
trustworthiness'. This analysis implies
that the Confrontation Clause bars only
unreliable hearsay..
...Reliability is
more properly a due process concern.
There is no reason to strain the text of the
Confrontation Clause to provide criminal
defendants with a protection that due
process already provides them".
Purpose determines admissibility:
The general rule is not that hearsay evidence is always
inadmissible. Depending upon the purpose for which it is offered
as evidence, it may be hearsay and inadmissible or it may not be
hearsay and therefore admissible. This distinction is well-settled.
Wigmore on Evidence (3d ed, V.6, page 178) puts the
matter clearly in this way:
"The prohibition of the hearsay rule,
then, does not apply to all words or
utterances merely as such. If this
fundamental principle is clearly realized,
its application is a comparatively simple
matter. The hearsay rule excludes extra-
judicial utterances only when offered for
a special purpose, namely, as assertions
to evidence the truth of the matter.
asserted".
The rule has been stated to the same effect by the Privy Council in
Subramanian (1956) I WLR 965). The accused was charged with
being in possession of ammunition. His defence was that he was
acting under duress, and he sought to give evidence of what had
been said to him by terrorists. The trial judge excluded this
evidence as hearsay and the accused was convicted, but the Privy
486
Council held that the evidence was admissible, and quashed his
conviction. Delivering the opinion of the Board, Mr. De Silva held:
"In ruling out peremptorily the evidence
of conversation between the terrorists
and the appellant the trial judge was in
error. Evidence of a statement made to a
witness by a person who is not himself
called as a witness may or may not be
hearsay. It is hearsay and inadmissible
when the object of the evidence is to.
establish the truth of what is contained in
the statement. It is not hearsay and is
admissible when it is proposed to
establish by evidence, not the truth of the
statement, but the fact that it was
made.........
In that case, it was held, "statements could have been
made to the appellant by the terrorists, which, whether frue or not,
if they had been believed by the appellant, might reasonably have
induced in him an apprehension of instant death if he failed to
conform to their wishes".
In Mawaz Khan v R (1967) AC 454; (1967) 1 All ER
80), the Privy Council accepted the generality of the proposition
maintained by the text writers, like Wigmore, and the above
statement of the rule in Subramanian.
A simple example of the rule has been given by P.B.
Carter in his "Cases and Statutes on Evidence", at p 319: Whereas
a witness's testimony that X told him that he had seen Y steal
would be inadmissible to show that Y had committed theft, the
hearsay rule would not preclude its admissibility to show that X
had uttered a defamatory statement about Y. In the latter case the
statement is said to constitute 'original' evidence rather than
hearsay: again it is sometimes said to be 'circumstantially
relevant.
487
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 262
Oral evidence as to an opinion and its grounds; If the oral
evidence refers to an opinion or to the grounds on which that
opinion is held, the evidence to be direct must be the evidence of
the person who holds that opinion on that ground. But an expert
opinion expressed in any treatise commonly offered for sale, and
the grounds on which such opinions are held, may be proved by
production of such treatises if the author is dead or has become
incapable of giving evidence, or cannot be called as a witness
without an amount of delay or expense which the court regards as
unreasonable.
Hearsay in cases other than oral evidence: The hearsay rule is.
by no means, limited to the spoken word or oral evidence. Thus, in
Chandersekara v R [(1937) AC 220]. the complainant was
prevented from speaking because her throat had been cut, but she
managed to indicate using hand-signals that the accused was her
assassin. The Privy Council held that such non-verbal assertions
were within the rule against hearsay.
The best evidence rule namely that the best evidence in
the possession or power of the party must be produced applies
equally to documentary evidence. What the best evidence is in a
particular case depends upon its circumstances. Generally
speaking, the original document is the best evidence; but
circumstances may arise in which secondary evidence of the
contents may be given. (Macdonnel (1852) 138 ER 742). Similarly,
the hearsay rule has been extended to statements in documents and
to writings on objects provided of course that the statement or
writing is adduced as evidence of its truth.
This is enacted in Article 75 of the Qanun-c-Shahadat,
which requires that the contents of documents must be proved by
primary evidence, that is, original document, unless a case for
secondary evidence has been made out. Indeed, what is an original
document is a separate question; as we shall see, modern
technological devices have changed many a concept.
The rule of "primary evidence" necessarily involves the
exclusion of hearsay evidence.
In Patel v Comptroller of Customs [(1966) AC 356).
(1965) 3 All ER 593] the accused was convicted of falsely
declaring to customs officials that the country of original of the
five bags of imported seed was India, when in fact the seed came
from Morocco. The prosecution proved the seed's country of origin
at trial by removing its outer packing to reveal inner bags marked
with the legend 'produce of Morocco. The Privy Council held that
the markings were hearsay and should have been excluded. The
words 'produce of Morocco' were being adduced to prove that the
seed really was the produce of Morocco. Yet the bag itself could
not vouch, by direct evidence, for the authenticity of this assertion.
As Lord Hudson said:
"Nothing here is known of which and by
whom the markings on the bags were
affixed, and no evidence was called to
prove any fact which tended to show that
the goods in question in fact came from
Morocco".
What the prosecution needed was the testimony of a witness who
personally could speak of the origin of the seed. Without such
testimony, the prosecution was merely relying on second hand
assertions from an unknown source, that is, hearsay evidence. The
conviction was set aside.
Myers v Director Public Prosecutions (1965) AC 1001;
(1964)! All ER 877) is another example of the application of the
hearsay rule to documentary evidence.
The only way to prove the contents of a document is by
producing the criginal document or by secondary evidence where
secondary evidence is admissible. This is what Article 72 of the
Qanun-e-Shahadat 1984 provides:
488
489
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 263
"The contents of documents may be
proved either by primary or by
secondary evidence".
One of the modes of secondary evidence under Article
74 of the Qanun-e-Shahadat is "oral accounts of the contents of a
document given by some person who has himself seen it".
In Ma Mi (AIR 1927 PC 15), it was held that "seen it"
here means 'read it'; therefore evidence of an illiterate person who
gave evidence that he had heard the document in question read to
him was hearsay and inadmissible evidence.
Exceptions: We have seen that "as a general rule hearsay evidence
is not admissible and in order to justify its reception authority must
be found within some existing established exceptions to this rule"
(Mayer case); and where the law has been codified, as in Pakistan,
the authority must be found in the codified law, e.g. the Qanun-e-
Shahadat, 1984.
Need to reform the hearsay rule:
We have referred to the observations of Lord Griffiths
(dissenting) in R v Kearley, namely that "most laymen if told that
the criminal law of evidence forbade them even to consider such
evidence as we are debating in this appeal", would reply: "Then the
law is an ass". He went on to observe that "The hearsay rule was
created by our judicial predecessors", and suggested that in order
that the law of evidence should develop "along common sense
lines" readily comprehensible to the common men and women, and
to prevent it, so to say, from being as asinine as that, "the Judges of
today should accept the responsibility of reviewing and adapting
the rules of evidence to serve present day society".
In England, there had been widespread criticism of the
hearsay exclusionary rule with the result that the law has been
modernized and changed both as regards civil and criminal cases.
in civil cases by the Civil Evidence Act, 1968, and in criminal
cases by the Criminal Justice Act, 2003, Chapter 2 of Part II.
sections 114 to 136. Section 114(1) of the 2003 Act provides for
the admissibility of 'hearsay evidence' by saying that-
"In criminal proceedings a statement not
made in oral evidence in the proceedings
is admissible of any matter stated"
if that statement falls within the categories mentioned in that
section. One of the categories is a statement about which-
"the court is satisfied that it is in the
interest of justice for it to be
admissible".
Thus, the law as it is reflected in section 114(1)(d) of the English
Act of 2003 now is that the Judges have an overriding residual
discretion to admit any oral or documentary hearsay evidence in
the interest of justice. Thus, in England, the law as reflected in
Kearley has been replaced by this statutory law.
In America, the hearsay rule has, as we have seen, its
basis in the Constitution's Confrontation Clause, and the common
law general principle that hearsay evidence is not admissible has
not been followed strictly; the constitutional law as developed by
the US Supreme Court seems to be that "the Confrontation Clause
bars only unreliable hearsay". In other words, the test is reliability.
In that behalf, the English case, R v Kearley, and the
American case, Bourjaily v US. provide a very interesting contrast.
Both were drug cases; in both a very important piece of evidence.
upon which the prosecution relied, consisted of telephone calls or
conversation, but whereas in the English case that evidence was
excluded, in the American case it was held admissible.
In Pakistan, and perhaps also in India, the old common
law 'rule against hearsay' is being followed. It has not undergone
any change either at the hands of the Judges or the Legislature. The
491
490
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 264
only change, if it can be so described, is the one introduced in
Article 71, third proviso. That Article enacts the general rule that
oral evidence must be direct, excluding by necessary implication,
the admission of hearsay evidence. The third proviso reads:
"Provided further that if a witness is
dead or cannot be found or has become
incapable of giving evidence or his
attendance cannot be procured without
an amount of delay or expense which
under the circumstances of the case the
court regards as unreasonable, a party
shall have the right to produce shahada
ala al shahadah, by which a witness can
appoint two witnesses to depose on his
behalf, except in the case of Hadd".
It is obvious that the proviso has a limited application. It cannot
apply to a witness who is dead, or who cannot be found or who has
become incapable of giving evidence; it can apply to a witness
whose attendance cannot be procured without undue delay or
expense only.
As we have sought to demonstrate, there seems to be no
doubt that the English Common Law hearsay rule needs to be
modernized and changed "along commonsense lines". The
common law of England is not the common law of Pakistan. In any
case, it was a judge-made law; we have seen that the common law
rule has been changed, in England, by legislation and in America,
by Judges. There is no reason why we should continue to follow
the English Common Law, which even the English follow no more.
If the Legislature does not intervene, then, it is submitted, the
Judges "should accept the responsibility of reviewing and adapting
the rules of evidence to serve present day society". Whether the
reform is legislative or judge-made, it cannot be over-stressed that
the reform, in at least criminal cases, in such a way that the law
operates fairly both to the prosecution and the accused, is long
over-due. The requirements of fairness, we should think, will be
492
amply satisfied whether we adopt the American constitutional law
or the English statutory law.
SOME SALIENT FEATURES OF CRIMINAL EVIDENCE
False in one thing, false in everything:
The principle embodied in the Latin maxim-Falsus in
uno falsus in omnibus - which means false in one thing. false in
everything, was at one time applied to criminal cases (See, for
example, the Privy Council case of Muhammad Fiaz Baksh v The
Queen PLD 1959 P.C. 24). But this principle has not been
followed in Pakistan. The rule that has been applied since the case
of Ghulam Muhammad v Crown (PLD 1951 Lah 66) is that where
it is found that a witness has falsely implicated one accused person.
ordinarily he would not be relied upon with regard to the other
accused. But if the testimony of such a witness is corroborated by
very strong and independent circumstances regarding others, then
reliance might be placed on the witness for convicting the other
accused. What the courts do now is to separate the grain from the
chaff (Ghulam Sikandar v Mumraze Khan-PLD 1985 SC 11. 23).
It is interesting to note that in Ghulam Sikandar v Mumraze (PLD
1985 SC 11, 23) the principle of Islamic jurisprudence that when a
witness has been found false as regards one accused, his credibility
is irretrievably shaken was noticed and it was observed that the rule
of separating the grain from the chaff will perhaps undergo a
change when considered in the light of the Islamic Jurisprudence.
The rule propounded in Ghulam Muhammad v Crown has been
followed in a number of cases; Tuwaib Khan v State (PLD 1970
SC 13); State v Mushtaq Ahmad (PLD 1973 SC 418); Muhammad
Nawaz v State (1984 SCMR 190) and Feroz Khan v Fateh Khan
(1991 SCMR 2220) are some of those cases.
The rule thus is that
"Where for an offence of murder, the
evidence of the prosecution witnesses is
wholly rejected as unreliable so far as
most of the accused are concerned, it is
493
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 265
not safe to rely upon the evidence of the
same witnesses for the purpose of
convicting the remaining accused in the
case for that offence in the absence of
confirmatory circumstances"
Muhammad and Sher v Crown
PLD
(See
1954 FC 84; cited in Muhammad Akhtar
v State-PLD 1957 SC 297).
Suspect evidence which needs corroboration:
Ocular evidence may be classified into three categories,
first, wholly reliable, secondly, wholly unreliable; and thirdly,
partly reliable and partly unreliable.
In the first category, conviction may safely be based on
uncorroborated testimony. In the second category, even the
strongest corroborative evidence may not rehabilitate such
evidence. In the third category, conviction cannot be recorded
unless such evidence is corroborated by other oral or circumstantial
evidence (Muhammad Iqbal v Muhammad Akram 1996 SCMR
908).
In the English cases (See for example Junior Reid v R
(1993) 4 All ER 95), the third category is described as suspect
evidence. As has been said in Junior Reid case, "judicial
experience has established that there are certain categories of
evidence which are, by their very nature, potentially unreliable and
in respect of which, in order to avoid the serious danger of wrong
conviction, special warmings and directions have to be given to
juries".
In other words, suspect evidence is that evidence which
cannot, consistently with the safe dispensation of criminal justice,
be acted upon without corroboration.
Concept of corroboration:
There is no magic or artificiality about the rule of
judicial practice concerning corroboration; nor is the word
"corroboration" a technical term of art. It is a dictionary word
bearing its dictionary meaning which by itself means no more than
evidence tending to confirm other evidence (Lord Hailsham L. C.
in DPP v Kilbourne (1973) I All ER 440). "When in ordinary
affairs of life, one is doubtful whether or not to believe a particular
statement, one naturally looks to see whether it fits in with other
statements or circumstances relating to the particular matter; the
better it fits in the more one is inclined to believe it. The doubted
statement is corroborated to a greater or lesser extent by the other
statements or circumstances with which it fits in (Lord Reid in DPP
Kilbourne (1973) 1 All ER 440; also see Irshad Ahmad v State -
1990 P Cr. LJ 374, 383).
To give or to require corroboration, a witness must be
believed without doubt. This means that unless a witness's
evidence in intrinsically credible, he can neither afford
corroboration nor be thought to require it. In such cases a witness's
evidence is rejected before the question of corroboration arises
(Boardman v DPP (1975) 60 Criminal Appeal Reports 165, 183,
per Lord Hailsham). To illustrate it by an example, suppose that
'A' an interested witness gives evidence that he saw 'B' killing
'C'. The court does not believe the claim of 'A' that he saw the
killing taking place. This is a case in which A's evidence is
rejected before the question of corroboration arises.
Thus, the tainted evidence of a witness must satisfy what-
in Indian and Pakistani cases is called a double test; first, whether
his evidence is reliable, that is, probable and natural. If the answer
to this question is in the negative, that is the end of the matter, and.
no occasion for the application of the second test, namely whether
it has received sufficient corroboration, will arise. (Muhammad
Bashir case-PLD 1967 SC 447, applied in Z. A Bhutto case - PLD
1979 SC 53, para 424 per Anwar-ul-Haq, C.J).
494
495
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 266
Categories of suspect evidence include the following:
i)
Evidence of interested witnesses
In criminal law, the expression 'interested witness' has
acquired a technical meaning. Mere friendship or relationship with
the deceased or the victim does not make a witness an interested
witness. An interested witness is a person who has a motive to
falsely implicate the accused. In one of the leading case on the
point namely Niaz v Sate (PLD 1960 SC 387), it was held:
"Whenever interested persons claiming
to be eye-witnesses of an occurrence
charge persons against whom they have
some motive for false implication, with
the commission of the offence, the first
question to be considered is whether in
fact they saw the occurrence and were in
a position to identify the culprits. If there
be no reason to doubt that they in fact
witnessed the occurrence and were in a
position to identify the offenders, the
further question arises as to whether they
can be relied upon for convicting the
accused without corroboration. In cases
where such interested witnesses charge
one person only with the commission of
the offence, or where the number of
persons whom they name does not
exceed that which appears from
independent evidence or from
circumstances not open to doubt to be
the true number of culprits, their
evidence may, in the absence of
anything making it unsafe to do so, be
accepted without corroboration, for
substitution is a thing of rare occurrence
and cannot be assumed, and he who sets
496
up the plea of substitution has to lay the
foundation for it. But if the court finds
that the number mentioned by interested
persons may have been exaggerated their
word cannot be made the basis of
conviction and the court will have to
look for some additional circumstance
which corroborates their testimony".
Elaborating upon these observations in Nazir and others
y The State (PLD 1962 SC 269), it was held:
"There may be an interested witness
whom the court regards as incapable of
falsely implicating an innocent person.
But he will be an exceptional witness
and, so far as an ordinary interested
witness is concerned, it cannot be said
that it is safe to rely upon his testimony
in respect of every person against whom
he deposes. In order, therefore, to be
satisfied that no innocent persons are
being implicated along with the guilty.
the court will in the case of an ordinary
interested witness look for some
circumstance that gives sufficient
support to his statement so as to create
that degree of probability which can be
made the basis of conviction. This is
what is meant by saying that the
statement of an interested witness
ordinarily needs corroboration".
These principles were re-affirmed and applied in Talib Husain v
State (PLJ 2009 SC 483).
The principle to be gleaned from decided cases may be
summed up as follows. In the case of an ordinary interested
497
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 267
witness, as in the case of any other witness, the first question the
court must ask is whether he had seen the incident taking place and
was in a position to identify the culprit. In other words, the Court
must first decide if the evidence of a witness is intrinsically
credible. Only if the answer be in the affirmative, can the question
of corroboration of an ordinary interested witness arise. For, it is
not the purpose of corroboration to give validity or credence to
evidence which is intrinsically incredible (Irshad Ahmad v The
State 1990 PCr.L.J. 374, 385). This may be illustrated by an
example. Suppose that "K" appears as an eye witness and testifies
to having seen an incident of murder taking place. There is,
however, evidence to show that 'K' was at the time of the incident
lodged in a jail, and it was therefore impossible for him to be
present at the time and place of occurrence. Assuredly, no amount
of corroborative evidence would make his testimony, that the
accused was the person whom he had seen firing the fatal shot,
make his evidence credible.
This does not mean that the mere disinterestedness of a
witness in the sense referred to above is sufficient to hold that he is
a truthful witness. If the principle be that a disinterested witness is
always to be relied upon even if his evidence is unreasonable,
improbable and implausible, it would lead to very dangerous
consequences (Muhammad Rafique v The State 1997 SCMR 412;
Furman Ullah v Qadeem Khan 2001 SCMR 1474).
ii)
Evidence of identity
Recent judicial experience in England has established
that the identification evidence is one of the categories of suspect
evidence. This was brought in sharp focus by two much publicized
cases of Dougherty and Virag where miscarriage of justice was
established despite the apparent strength of the identification
evidence. Miscarriage of criminal justice, affecting as it does the
life and liberty of person, being a very serious matter and the
country being England, there was great public concern. That
concern found expression first in the Eleventh Report of the
Criminal Revision Committee, published in 1972, which was
498
followed by the appointment of a Committee under the
chairmanship of Lord Devlin to consider identification evidence in
criminal cases. In the light of recommendations of that Committee.
Lord Widgery, Cl, giving the judgement of the Court of Appeal in
R v Turnbull (1976) 3 All ER 549) laid down the guidelines which
are, by now, well known and consistently applied in England and
in a number of Commonwealth countries (See for example, the
Privy Council decisions in Scott v Queen (1989) AC 1242: Junior
Reid v Queen (1990) I AC 363). This trend of judicial authority in
England was noticed in the leading judgment in Muhammad
Arshad v State (PLD 1995 SC 475) and the principles were stated
as follows: The evidence of visual identification is one of the
categories of suspect evidence and that ordinarily it is not safe to
convict on the basis of such evidence without corroboration.
Indeed, in exceptional circumstances, that is, where the evidence of
visual identification is of exceptionally good quality, such as.
where the offender was known to the witness, there was sufficient
light, the witness had had an unobstructed view of the offender and
there was a dialogue between the witness and the offender, the
evidence may be acted upon. It was observed that there was no
reason why we should not benefit from the "accumulated judicial
experience" in England. If anything, the need for caution here is
greater than in England. The other two learned Judges, however.
agreed with the conclusion, but referring to the decision in State v
Farman Hussain (PLD 1995 SC 1) preferred to follow the views in
that case. In that case, in the majority judgment authored by Ajmal
Mian, J, reference was made to two cases namely Lal Pasand v
State (PLD 1981 SC 142) and Abdul Sattar v State (1981 SCMR
678). In the first it was emphasized that "although the witness was
an honest witness the dangers of errors in identification are so great
that it would not be safe to base a conviction on the evidence
of a solitary eye witness if the witness has only had a fleeting
glimpse of the assailants....." and in the second, the question was
whether the evidence of the prosecution witnesses who were
admittedly complete strangers to the accused persons should be
acted upon. In that behalf, reference was made to observations in
an earlier case viz. Ramzan v Emperor (AIR 1929 Sindh 149)
namely that the "recognition of a dacoit or other offender by a
499
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 268
person who has not previously seen him is, I think, a form of
evidence which has always to be taken with a considerable amount
of caution because mistakes are always possible in such cases"
The learned Judges agreed with these observations and held that
"evidence of the identification of strangers must always be
scrutinized very carefully", In State v Farman Hussain. Ajmal
Mian, J. had no "cavil with the proposition of law propounded in
the above reports". He made distinction "between a case in which
witness has had only a fleeting glimpse of the accused who
happened to be stranger and a witness who had known the accused
previously or who had met the accused several times. In the former
case, the court insists upon having proper identification parade
whereas in the latter case, the identification parade can be
dispensed with as witness can identify the accused even in the
court". State v Farman Hussain (PLD 1995 SC 1), it may be noted,
belonged to the second category of cases.
To establish the identity of the culprits, the police often
have resort to identification parade or identification test. There is
no legal requirement that such a parade or test should be held and
whether any identification parade was warranted would depend
upon the facts of each case. Where an identification parade is held,
its value is that of corroborative evidence but the mere fact that a
witness is able to pick out an accused person from among the
crowd does not prove that he had identified that accused person
having taken part in the crime. It might merely mean that the
witness happens to know that accused person. The principal
evidence of identification is the evidence of a witness given in
court as to how and under what circumstances he came to pick out
a particular accused person and the details of the part that accused
took in the crime in question. Thus, the proceedings of the
identification parade where the accused were picked out without
describing the roles played by them in the crime have no
evidentiary value and cannot be relied (Mehmood Ahmad v State
1995 SCMR 127). Then, the value of the fact of identification at a
parade would depend upon the surrounding circumstances. The
court must he satisfied, and the burden to satisfy is upon the
prosecution, that the accused had not been shown to the witness
before the parade and the fact that the parade was held after
considerable unexplained delay would militate against the
identification (Sajjad Ali Shah J, in State v Farman Hussain PLD
1995 SC 1, 131
Evidence of a child witness
A child witness is an example of a case in which the
question both of competence and credibility can arise. Under
Article 3 of the Qanun, a child witness is a competent witness
provided the court considers that he is not prevented from
understanding the questions put to him or from giving rational
answers to those questions. Where the court had, by questioning
the child concerned, fully satisfied itself that the child witness was
capable of understanding the questions put to him and of giving
rational answers to those questions, he is not only a competent
witness but his evidence can also be acted upon (Abdullah Shah v
State 1968 SCMR 852: State v Farman Hussain PLD 1995 SC 1.
21).
But the evidence of children is suspect evidence because
"although old enough to understand the nature of an oath and thus
competent to give sworn evidence, may yet be so young that their
comprehension of events and of questions put to them, or their
power of expression, may be imperfect". However, it seems that
quality is what matters in the end and for that purpose the views of
the trial court who had seen the child witness in the witness box
both as to the competence and the credibility of a child witness will
carry considerable weight (This seems to be the ratio of majority
judgment in State v Farman Hussain PLD 1995 SC 1).
iv)
Evidence of an accomplice
The term 'accomplice has not been defined in the
Qanun and is, therefore, presumed to have been used in its ordinary
sense. Yet, some indication of its meaning is provided by section
337 Cr.P.C. It means "a guilty associate or partner in crime. or.
who in some way or the other, whether before, during or after the
500
301
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 269
commission of the offence, is consciously connected with the
offence in question, or who makes admissions of facts showing that
he had a conscious hand in the offence.....
.... In other words,
50
an accomplice is a particeps criminis, who is consciously
connected with the criminal act done by his confederate, that he on
account of the presence of the necessary mens rea, and his
participation in the crime in some way or the other can be tried
along with that confederate actually perpetrating the
crime..... (Bagu v Emperor - AIR 1925 PC 130; Mahadeo
v Emperor AIR 1936 PC 242: Z A Bhutto case - PLD 1979 SC
53. paras 408-410, per Anwar-ul-Haq CJ). Whether a person is or
is not an accomplice depends on the facts of each particular case,
considered in connection with the nature of the crime. The burden
of showing that a witness is an accomplice lies ordinarily upon the
party alleging it (Z A Bhutto case, para 411 of Anwar-ul-Haq CJ's
judgment).
By Article 16 of the Qanun, an accomplice is a
competent witness against an accused person except in the case of
an offence punishable with 'hadd' and a conviction is not illegal
merely because it proceeds upon the uncorroborated testimony of
an accomplice.
Article 16 is to be read with Article 129, illustration (b),
of the Qanun. The latter provides that "the court may presume the
existence of any fact which it thinks likely to have happened,
regard being had to the common course of natural events, human
conduct and public and private business, in their relation to the
facts of the particular case". Illustration (b) to that Article reads:
"That an accomplice is unworthy of
credit unless he is corroborated in
material particulars".
The rule in Article 129, illustration (b), is based on the
ground that "an accomplice, with a purpose of his own to serve.
such as the hope of lenient punishment, may well tend, when
giving evidence for the prosecution, to suggest that the entirety or
the majority of the blame for the crime should fall upon the
accused rather upon himself (These observations are from Junior
Reid R (1993) 4 All ER 95). As was said in Ishaq v Crown
(PLD 1954 FC 335, 343), an accomplice is a moral wretch who not
only publicly boasts of his own part in the crime............but who,
prompted by a mean desire to save his skin, shamelessly betrays his
companions in the dock and who has no scruples either in
exaggerating their part in the crime or in substituting in a well
thought-out narrative a completely innocent man.
The effect of the provisions of Article 16 as it stood
before 31.8.1993 read with Article 129 illustration (b) of the Qanun
was that "though by virtue of illustration (b) of Article 129 of the
Qanun, the court may presume that the testimony of an accomplice
is unworthy of credit unless it is corroborated in material
particulars but the court may convict an accused person on the
hasis of the sole testimony of an accomplice in view of the
language employed in the above Article 16 of the Qanun except in
case of an offence punishable with Hadd. We may observe that in
practice the courts, as a rule of prudence while considering section
133 of the late Act (Evidence Act 1972) had been insisting to have
the testimony of an accomplice or approver corroborated in
material particulars keeping in view illustration (b) of section 114
thereof (Federation of Pakistan v Muhammad Shafi Muhammadi.
1994 SCMR 932; relying upon Abdul Qadir v State PLD 1956
SC (Pak) 407; Dr. Muhammad Bashir v State - PLD 1971 SC 447).
Reference in the above-cited case to offences punishable
with Hadd is reference to offences punishable under the Offences
against Property (Enforcement of Hadood) Ordinance. 1979, the
Offence of Zina (Enforcement of Hadood) Ordinance. 1979, the
Offence of Qazf (Enforcement of Hadd) Ordinance, 1979, and the
Prohibition (Enforcement of Hadd) Order, 1979.
In Federation of Pakistan v Muhammad Shafi
Muhammadi (1994 SCMR 932), the question before the Appellate
Shariat Bench of the Supreme Court was whether Article 16 of the
Qanun was in conformity with the Injunctions of Islam. It was held
503
502
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 270
that there is a distinction between an offence punishable with Hadd
or Qisas on the one hand and an offence which entails 'taazir' only.
In the former case, the State cannot deviate as to the type or nature
of evidence which is required for recording a conviction in terms of
the Holy Quran and Sunnah but in the latter case, the State
provides the punishment and, therefore, the State can also lay down
the type and nature of evidence for warranting conviction. So in the
case of offences entailing punishment of Hadd and Qisas, even the
State cannot provide that the testimony of an accomplice or an
approver will be admissible. However, in case of an offence
punishable with 'taazir, the State may provide that the testimony
of an accomplice or an approver is admissible in evidence and can
furnish basis for conviction subject to corroboration or otherwise as
the facts of the case warrant. The conclusion reached, therefore,
was that "the evidence of an accomplice is not admissible at all in
case of an offence punishable with Hadd and Qisas. However, in
case of an offence punishable with 'taazir' his testimony is
admissible and can furnish the basis for conviction provided it is
corroborated in material particulars. However, in exceptional cases.
for the reasons to be recorded by the court, his testimony may be
acted upon as sufficient for warranting recording of conviction".
This decision of the Supreme Court directed that Article
16 be "amended accordingly by 31.8.1993, failing which the said
provision will become void and shall be of no effect to the extent
stated above".
The position that emerges as a result of the reading
together of the provisions of Article 16 and Article 129 illustration
(b) of the Qanun in the light of the decision of the Supreme Court
in Shafi Muhammadi case and the provisions of the amended
section 338 Cr.P.C. may be summed up as follows:
An accomplice is not a competent witness
against an accused person in the case of an
offence-
b)
punishable with Hadd; and
punishable with Qisas;
its consequence being that the evidence of an accomplice in these
cases is not admissible at all.
ii)
An accomplice is a competent witness in other
cases, that is, cases other than those involving
offences punishable with 'Hadd" and "Qisas
and though a conviction is not illegal merely
because it proceeds upon the uncorroborated
testimony of an accomplice, yet the rule of
prudence which has hardened into a rule of
law is that the testimony of an accomplice
cannot be acted upon unless it is corroborated
in material particulars by independent
evidence.
iii) Though an accomplice is a competent witness in
cases covered by (ii) above, yet he cannot be
tendered pardon under Chapter XXIII Cr.P.C.
in the case of an offence relating to 'hurt' or
'qatal' without the permission of the victim or
as the case may be of the heirs of the victim.
Real Evidence:
Real evidence in the legal sense means material physical
matters such as a body, wound, finger print or a bloodstain.
For example, the discovery of a body provides the best
evidence of the death of the victim, of his identity and generally the
means by which he was killed.
Effect of dead body not found
There is a firm and salutary rule that no one shall be
convicted of murder when the body of the alleged victim has not
504
505
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 271
been found, unless there is circumstantial evidence of such weight
that it can lead to no other reasonable conclusion than that the
person for whose murder the accused is being tried is dead. It is a
salutary rule because there have been instances where persons have
been hanged for the murder of someone who subsequently turned
up alive and well. As we have seen, the, the high sounding maxim
that 'let justice be done, though the heavens should fall' owes its
origin to the man for whose murder the accused was sentenced to
death coming forward himself alive and well. (See Part I, chapter 1
ante of this book.)
Lord Goddard CJ said in R v Onufrejezyk (1955) 1 All
ER 247) "...........there is apparently no reported case in English
law where a man has been convicted of murder when there has
been no trace of the body at all. But it is equally clear that the fact
of death, like any other fact, can be proved by circumstantial
evidence, that is to say, evidence of facts which lead to one
conclusion, provided that the jury are satisfied and are warned that
it must lead to one conclusion only".
Medical, chemical examination etc.
The evidence as to a body, or a wound, nature of injuries
etc., is provided by postmortem examination and medico legal
examination. In this connection, reference is invited to sections 509
and 510 of the Criminal Procedure Code and the instructions
contained in Chapters 18(A) and 18(B) of the High Court Rules
and Orders Vol. III. Section 509 provides for the deposition of
medical witnesses and section 510 provides for the reports of
chemical examiner and serologist etc. While ordinarily a medical
officer who had carried out the postmortem examination or medico
legal examination should appear in court to testify to that fact,
unless, of course his deposition had been taken and attested by a
Magistrate in the presence of the accused or taken on commission,
section 510 makes the reports under the hands of a chemical
examiner, assistant chemical examiner to government, serelogist.
finger print expert or fire arm expert appointed by the government
upon any matter or thing duly submitted to him for examination
506
and analysis, per se admissible without the need of calling him as a
witness.
Post-mortem of female body
The Supreme court has in a recent case (Muhammad
Iqbal v Muhammad Akram - 1996 SCMR 908, 919) taken a very
serious view of dead bodies of females being subjected to post-
mortem examination by male doctors, and issued instruction that
such examination should be conducted by female doctors.
Medical evidence as corroboration
Medical evidence by itself does not establish the identity
of the culprits (Mehmood Ahmad v State-1995 SCMR 127, 133).
It can be used as corroborative evidence "but only to the extent of
nature and number of injuries" (State v Muhammad Sharif - 1995
SCMR 635, 647)
Direct and Circumstantial Evidence:
Under Article 18 of the Qanun, evidence may be given
in a proceeding of the existence or non-existence of facts in issue
and such other facts as are declared by the Qanun to be relevant.
Direct evidence is that which goes expressly to the very
point in question and which, if believed, proves the point in
question without aid from inference or reasoning. For example, the
testimony of an eye-witness of a murder is direct evidence.
Circumstantial evidence, on the other hand, does not prove the
point in question directly but establishes it only by inference. Thus
if A is tried for the murder of B, evidence of the fact that A had a
motive to murder B and that at the time B was murdered, A, with a
drawn sword, was seen going towards the place where B was
murdered and shortly afterwards was seen returning from the place
with his clothes stained with blood would be circumstantial
evidence.
507
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 272
1
"Direct evidence" as used here, that is, as opposed to
circumstantial evidence, is not the same thing as "direct evidence"
as used in Article 71 of the Qanun. In Article 71, the term direct
evidence is used as opposed to hearsay evidence and not as
opposed to circumstantial evidence. Therefore, in the sense in
which this term is used in Article 71, circumstantial evidence must
always be direct ie, the facts from which the existence of the fact,
in issue is to be inferred must he proved by direct and not by
hearsay evidence (See Monir in his invaluable Treatise on the Law
of Evidence, 1974 ed., p 690. cited with approval in Z A Bhutto
case-PLD 1979 SC 53. para 62, per Anwar-ul-Haq CJ).
'Circumstantial evidence' is evidence of facts from
which, taken with all other evidence, a reasonable inference is a
fact directly in issue. It works by cumulatively, in geometrical
progression, eliminating other possibilities (DPP v Kilbourne
(1973) AC 729, 752 = (1973) 1 All ER 440, 462; 1990 PCrLJ 374).
As evidence of a fact in issue, it is ordinarily produced when direct
evidence is not available. An example is an unwitnessed crime.
It is well established that when all the evidence is
circumstantial it is necessary that cumulatively its effect should be
to exclude any reasonable hypothesis of the innocence of the
accused. In other words the chain of circumstances established
against the accused person should raise a strong probability that he
is guilty of the offence charged (Allah Ditta v State - PLD 1958
SC (Pak) 290, 293, 298; Muhammad Nazir Hossain v State - 1969
SCMR 388; Mst. Sairan v State - PLD 1970 SC 56).
Before the guilt of the accused can be inferred merely
from inculpatory circumstances, those circumstances must be
found to be incompatible with the innocence of the accused and
incapable of explanation upon any reasonable hypothesis other than
that of his guilt. It is also equally well established that the
circumstances sought to be relied upon must have been established
beyond a doubt. But this only means a reasonable doubt, that is, a
doubt such as to assail a reasonable mind and not any and every
kind of doubt and much less a doubt conjured up by pre-conceived
508
notions but once the circumstances have been found to be so
established they may well furnish a better basis for decision than
any other kind of evidence (Hamoodur Rehman J. in State v
Manzoor Ahmed - PLD 1966 SC 664, 680).
In other words, if circumstantial evidence of this quality
is produced, then there can be no better evidence than this
evidence. For it must be remembered that witnesses can make
mistakes, forget or lie. Therefore, it is no derogation of evidence to
that it is circumstantial (Hewart L.CJ. in (1828) 21 Cr. A. 20
cited in State v Manzoor Ahmad - PLD 1966 SC 664, 680).
F.L.R. as evidence in contrast to police statements during
investigation and police diaries:
say
We have seen that in cognizable cases ordinarily the law
is set in motion, that is to say, the process of investigation begins,
when a report under section 154 Cr.P.C. commonly known as the
First Information Report is lodged. Such a report is to be recorded
as intimation of the commission of a cognizable offence and not as
a prayer for redress for personal wrong or injury suffered. For the
report may be made by any person, eg. a Lumbardar or a
Chowkidar or a member of the public who has gained knowledge
in any manner howsoever of the commission of a cognizable
offence. The further pursuit of the matter by the police is an
activity of the State (Muhammad Ashiq v Allah Bakhsh - PLD
1957 SC (Pak) 293). The First Information Report is supposed to
contain a narration of the way the incident took place; it is not
supposed to contain minute details, particularly when it is made by
a person who had not seen the incident taking place (Liaqat Ali v
State 1981 SCMR 1130).
F.I.R. after investigation
But when a statement is recorded by the police after
investigation, it is not the First Information Report and cannot be
so used under section 154 Cr.P.C. In other words, a
509
so-called
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 273
F.I.R. recorded after investigation is inadmissible in evidence
(Nasim Akhtar v State PLD 1968 Lah 841). In that case, it is a
statement before the police during investigation within the meaning
of section 162 Cr.P.C. and can be used only for the purpose
mentioned therein namely for contradicting the witness in the
manner provided by Article 140 of the Qanun.
F.I.R. at a place other than police station
As a rule, a First Information Report recorded at a place
other than the police station may raise an inference that it was
recorded after preliminary investigation had commenced and
would not therefore be admissible in evidence (Muhammad Hanif
v State - PLD 1977 Lah. 1253: Lakhmir v State - PLD 1968
Quetta 7: Ghulam Qadir v State - PLD 1967 Peshawar 269).
Use of F.I.R.
As an F.I.R. recorded under section 154 Cr.P.C. is not a
statement during investigation. it can be used as corroboration
under Article 153 of the Qanun. In any case, it is a previous
Statement for the purposes of Article 140 thereof (A. Nagesia v
Bihar State AIR 1966 SC 119). A prompt FIR eliminates the
possibility of fabrication (Khalil Ahmad v State 1975 SCMR
442); similarly delay in making it, if reasonably explained, does not
affect the prosecution case adversely (Ismail v. State 1976 SCMR
135: Hamid Khan v State - PLJ 1980 SC 519 and Mst. Siani v
State PLD 1984 FSC 121). Delay in making the FIR can assume
importance, for it "can be attributed to consultation, taking
instructions and calculatedly preparing report..
(Mehmood Ahmad v State-1995 SCMR 127, 131).
F.I.R. by culprit
The first information of an offence may have been given
by the culprit himself, and it may contain a confession of his guilt.
In that case, the question of admissibility of the First Information
Report arises. This turns on the provisions of Articles 38 and 39 of
510
the Qanun. Article 38 forbids proof of a confession made to a
police officer and Article 39 forbids proof of a confession made by
any person while in police custody. The preponderance of judicial
opinion seems to be that a first information report if it contains a
confession of the accused is inadmissible in evidence (Muhammad
Saleh v State - PLD 1965 SC 366 and A. Nagesia v Bihar State-
AIR 1966 SC 119). But the prohibition is against using a
confession against the accused person and not using it in favour of
the accused person (State v Ghandal - PLD 1960 Peshawar 137:
Salman Shah v Ayub-PLD 1971 SC 751).
Statement before Magistrates during investigation
As regards a statement of a witness recorded by a
Magistrate under section 164 Cr.P.C., the court has a discretion to
treat it as evidence if (a) it was made in the presence of the accused
and he had notice of it and was given an opportunity of cross-
examining the witness and (b) if the witness is produced and
examined at the trial. (Sections 244A and 265J Cr.P.C)
Statement of a Dying Man - Dying declaration:
Such statements are relevant and admissible under
Article 46 of the Qanun-e-Shahdat, which makes statements,
written or verbal, relevant facts made by a person who is dead.....
when the statement is made by the person as to the cause of his
death or as to any of the circumstances of the transaction which
resulted in his death in cases in which the cause of that person's
death comes into question. Such statements are relevant whether
the person who made them was or was not at the time when they
were made under expectation of death and whatever may be the
nature of the proceeding in which the cause of death comes into
question. This is an exception to the general rule against hearsay
evidence.
The expression "any of the circumstances of the
transaction which resulted in his death" is wider in scope than the
expression "the cause of his death". Similarly the words "resulted
511
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 274
in his death" do not mean caused his death. In other words, the
intention clearly is to make admissible not only the statement
dealing directly with the cause of death but also a statement as to
any of the circumstances. Thus, the statement of a deceased person
is admissible not only in regard to the cause of his death, but also
in regard to any of the circumstances of the transaction which
resulted in his death and this would include the circumstances in
which his companion may have been done to death in the course of
the same transaction, provided the case is one in which the cause of
the death of the maker of the statement comes into question
(Muhammad Aslam v State PLD 1978 SC 298, 311, 312).
Dying declaration as basis of conviction
There is a respectable body of judicial literature on the
evidential value of a dying declaration, and on whether such a
declaration can form a safe basis for conviction without
corroboration. From the guidance to be gained from decided cases,
the position seems to emerge as follows. A dying declaration when
it falls under Article 46(1) of the Qanun becomes evidence. Neither
that Article nor any other provision of the Qanun says that a
conviction cannot be based on a dying declaration. It can therefore
be said that a conviction can be based solely on a dying
declaration, particularly because it is presumed to be true on the
ground that a statement made by a person under expectation of
death is treated as a substitute for oath on the religious view that no
man who is immediately going into the presence of his Maker will
do so with a lie on his lips (Reg v Osman (1881) 15 Cox C.C. 1.
3). As has been said, such a declaration is made in extremity "when
the party is at the point of death, and when every hope of this world
is gone; when every motive of falsehood is silenced and the mind is
induced by the most powerful considerations to speak the truth
(Eyre C.B. in R v Woodcock - 1 Leach C.C. 500, quoted in Zarif v
State PLD 1977 SC 612, 617). But the deceased man might not
have been a man of unquestionable integrity; or as was said in
Bakhsheesh Singh v Emperor (AIR 1925 Lah 549) family feuds
and enmities do not die with death. However that may be, the
evidence of dying declaration is a weaker type of evidence than the
512
evidence hy a witness in the witness box and therefore as a rule of
as distinct from a rule of law, a close scrutiny of the
prudence.
dying declaration like the statements of interested witnesses
becomes absolutely necessary. A dying declaration can be
challenged on any ground on which the evidence of a witness can
be challenged. For example, it can be challenged on the ground of
enmity and also on the ground that the deceased was not a very
honest man. Then a person can make an honest mistake about the
identity of the person who attacked him and if he has implicated
the wrong person, his cross-examination may help to bring out the
truth. But this is not possible in the case of a dying declaration.
although the possibility of an error in identification is far greater.
Thus, though a conviction can be based on a dying declaration, yet
as the burden of proving the guilt of the accused is on the
prosecution, it will be for the prosecution to prove that the author
of the dying declaration was a man of unquestionable integrity and
if the prosecution discharges this burden, a conviction can be based
on a dying declaration subject to the further condition that evidence
about the dying declaration recorded and deposed to by a judicial
officer is generally considered to be more reliable than a dying
declaration recorded and deposed to by the police or by a relative
of the deceased (Abdul Razik v State PLD 1965 SC 151: Towaib
Khan v State PLD 1970 SC 13: Zarif v State PLD 1977 SC
612).
To sum up, if the court is satisfied that the dying man
was able to identify the assailant, that there was no background of
enmity, that there was no chance of tutoring the dead man and his
having acted under the influence of another and that the dying man
was fully conscious and in possession of his senses when he made
the statement, the court may act upon the dying statement (These
principles are deducible from the judgment in Muhammad Aslam v
State PLD 1978 SC 298). In one word, to accept a dying
declaration without considering the surrounding circumstances
would be totally inconsistent with the safe administration of
criminal justice (Cornelius CJ in Abdul Razik v State - PLD 1965
SC 151. 155)
513
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 275
The modern approach to dying declarations seems to be
that the acceptance of a dying man's statement depends on its
probative value, that is, on whether it inspires confidence as to its
truthfulness (See among others Ratten v The Queen (1971) 3 All
ER 801 and Mills v Queen (1995) I WLR 511).
It is well settled that the provisions of section 164
Cr.P.C. do not in any way affect the admissibility of a statement
made by a person, if it falls within the terms of Article 46(1) of the
Qanun. To be admissible under that Article, it is not necessary that
such statements must necessarily have been recorded and much
less recorded in accordance with the provisions contained in
Chapter XXV Cr.P.C. Also, dying declarations are admissible even
if made orally (Allah Bakhsh v Crown PLD 1951 FC 111, followed
in Muhammad Aslam v State - PLD 1978 SC 298, 309).
Confession Evidence:
Confession is a species of admission. An admission is a
statement, oral or documentary, which suggests any inference as to
any fact in issue or relevant fact and which is made by any of the
persons or under the circumstances mentioned in Articles 31 to 45
of the Qanun.
The term 'confession' has not been defined in the
Qanun; it was not defined in the Evidence Act, 1872 either. The
term was defined in Pakala Narayana Swami v Emperor (AIR 1939
PC 47) by Lord Atkin, who said:
"As the point was argued however and
as there seems to have been some
discussion in the Indian courts on the
matter it may be useful to state that
no statement that contains self-
exculpatory matter can amount to a
confession, if the exculpatory statement
is of some fact which if true would
negative the offence alleged to be
514
confessed. Moreover, a confession must
either admit in terms the offence or at
any rate substantially all the facts which
constitute the offence. An admission of a
gravely incriminating fact, even a
conclusively incriminating fact is not of
itself a confession e.g. an admission that
the accused is the owner of and was in
recent possession of the knife or revolver
which caused a death with
explanation of any other man's
possession.

Some confusion, so noted Lord Atkin, "appears to have been
caused by the definition of confession in Article 22 of Stephen's
Digest of the Law of Evidence which defines a confession as an
admission made at any time by a person charged with a crime
stating or suggesting the inference that he committed that crime. If
the surrounding articles are examined it will be apparent that the
learned author after dealing with admissions generally is applying
himself to admissions in criminal cases, and for this purpose
defines confession so as to cover all such admissions in order to
have a general term for use in the three following articles.
confession secured by inducement, made upon oath, made under a
promise of.......". The definition is not, so held Lord Atkin.
"contained in the Evidence Act, 1872;
and in that Act it would not be consistent
with the natural use of language to
construe confession as a statement by an
accused suggesting the inference that he
committed the crime".
Lord Atkin's definition in Pakala has been followed in
Pakistan (See, among others. Liaqat Bahadur v State - PLD 1987
FSC 43, 49; Z A Bhutto case - PLD 1979 SC 53, paras 123, 124,
125 of Anwar-ul-Haq C.J's judgment).
515
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 276
To the argument raised by the prosecution that a
statement, partly inculpatory and partly exculpatory, can also be
used under section 30 of the Evidence Act, 1872 (now Article 43 of
the Qanun). Anwar-ul-Haq CJ., in Z A Bhutto case, referred to the
cases relied upon by the Prosecutor and observed that "A perusal of
the facts and observations appearing in these cases, however, does
not fully support the learned Special Public Prosecutor, as there is
no departure from the basic definition as given by the Privy
Council in the case of Pakala......... He went on to hold:
"The principle underlying the section
(section 30 of the 1872 Act) is that the
consequences of self-implication in an
offence afford some sort of guarantee for
the truth of the statement and when the
maker of such statement also implicates
another prisoner, it is very difficult, if
not practically impossible, to require the
court to exclude
that statement
altogether from its mind when it comes
to consider the case against the other
accused. An admission by an accused
person of his own guilt affords some sort
of sanction in support of the truth of his
confession against others as well as
himself. These considerations however
do not apply when the question is
whether statement partly inculpatory and
partly exculpatory should be used
against the maker thereof. In his case,
even if the statement does not amount to
a confession in the full sense of the term,
it could still be used as admission
against him".
If we may say with great respect, such a statement, even
though it does not amount to confession, can be used, so far as its
inculpatory part is concerned, against the maker, only if the
516
statement is not read as a whole; that is, by separating the
inculpatory part from the exculpatory part. This will be against the
well settled principle that such statements must be read as a whole.
However that may be, in view of the fact that the right
against self incrimination is now a constitutionally guaranteed
right, a change in the definition of 'confession' is inevitable. We
have seen that in Miranda (384 US 436 -1966) where the US
Supreme Court was dealing with the protections guaranteed by the
Fifth Amendment (right against self-incrimination) and the Sixth
Amendment (right to counsel), Chief Justice Earl Warren had said
that-
"No distinction can be drawn
between statements which are direct
confessions and statements which
amount to 'admissions' of part or all of
an offence. The privilege against self
incrimination protects the individual
from being compelled to incriminate
himself in any manner, it does not
distinguish degrees of incrimination.
Similarly, for precisely the same reason,
no distinction may be drawn between
inculpatory statements and statements
alleged to be merely exculpatory...... In
fact, statements merely intended to be
exculpatory by the defendant are often
used to impeach his testimony at trial or
to demonstrate untruths in the statement
given under interrogation and thus to
prove guilt by implication. These
statements are incriminating in any
meaningful sense of the word and may
not be used without the full warnings
and effective waiver required for any
other statement...."
517
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 277
And as if the British Parliament were anticipating the Human
Rights Act, 1998. it, by section 82(1) of the Police and Criminal
Evidence Act 1984 (known as PACE), defined the word confession
to mean-
"Any statement wholly or partly adverse
to the person who made it".
Under that section, an adverse statement can be in words or
conduct, such as a nod or holding up one's hand, and the court will
direct the jury to consider the confession, that is the mixed
statement as a whole to decide where the truth his.
It is, therefore, time to redefine the term 'confession".
preferably by legislation; but as the definition in Pakala was judge-
made, the Judges can also assume that responsibility.
Section 162, by its subsection (1), Cr.P.C, prohibits the
use of a statement, made by a witness or an accused, to a police
officer in the course of investigation for any purpose at any inquiry
or trial in respect of any offence under investigation, except to
contradict a witness called for the prosecution in the manner
provided by Article 190 of the Qanun. However, nothing in section
162 shall, subsection (2) thereof enacts, "be deemed to apply to any
statement falling within the provisions of section 46, clause (1) of
the Qanun, or to affect the provisions of Article 40 of the Qanun".
The words "or to affect the provisions of section 27" (now Article
40 of the Qanun) were added in 1941, perhaps in the light of the
Privy Council's observations in Pakala (AIR 1939 PC 46) made in
answer to the contention that section 162, as it then stood, had the
effect of repealing section 27 (now Article 40 of the Qanun); said
Lord Atkin:
"It is obvious that the two sections
(section 162 Cr.P.C. and section 27 of
the Evidence Act) can in some
circumstances stand together. Section
162 is confined to statements made to a
518
an
police officer in course of
investigation. Section 25 (now Article
38) covers a confession made to a police
officer before any investigation has
begun or otherwise not in the course of
an investigation. Section 27 (now Article
40 of the Qanun) seems to be intended to
be a proviso to section 26 which
includes any statement made by a person
whilst in custody of the police and
appears to apply to such statements to
whomsoever made e.g. to a fellow
prisoner, a doctor or a visitor. Such
statements are not covered by section
162. Whether to give to section 162 the
plain meaning of the words is to leave
the statement still inadmissible even
though a discovery of fact is made such
as is contemplated by section 27 it does
not seem necessary to decide".
The effect of the addition of the words "or to affect the provisions
of section 27" seems to be to save section 27 (now Article 40 of the
Qanun) so that a statement covered by section 162 Cr.P.C. if it
leads to some discovery, is now provable. As was held in Stat v
Deoman (AIR 1960 SC 1125, 1129)-
"Section 162 Cr.P.C, also enacts a rule
of evidence. This section in so far as it is
material for purposes of this case.
prohibits, but not so as to affect the
admissibility of information to the extent
permissible under section 27 of the
Evidence Act, use of statements by any
person to a police officer in the course of
an investigation under Chapter 14 of the
Code in any inquiry or trial in which
such person is charged for an offence
519
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 278
under investigation at the time when the
statement was made".
It is to be noted that section 27, as it stood in the 1872 Act, began
with the word 'Provided'; hence the observation in Pakala that
section 27 was a proviso to section 26. In the Qanun, Article 39 is a
reproduction of section 26, but in Article 40 (previous section 27)
the word "Provided" has been deleted.
Voluntariness is the test:
The well known rule, peculiar to English Law and its
derivative systems, said Lord Hailsham in Director of Public
Prosecution v Ping Lin (1975) 3 All ER 175), is that to be
admissible, confessions, however convincing, must be voluntary in
the sense that the prosecution must prove, and prove beyond
reasonable doubt, in the classic words of Lord Sumner in Ibrahim v
The King (1914) AC 599.609:
"that it has not been obtained from him
by fear of prejudice or hope or
advantage exercised (excited) or held out
by a person in authority".
Article 37 of the Qanun enacts this rule expressly, and
Articles 38 and 39 of the Qanun enact this rule impliedly, for they
proceed on the supposition that the police of our country is not to
be trusted and that confessions made to them or even to any other
person by an accused in police custody are not therefore to be
treated as voluntary.
In Muhammad Amjad v Sate (PLD 2003 SC 704, 717).
Nazim Hussain Siddiqui J. said:
"Articles 37, 38 and 39 of Qanun-e-
Shahadat, 1984, corresponding to
sections 24, 25 and 26 of the Evidence
Act are relevant to determine the criteria
520
as to which statement could be treated as
confession. In criminal cases great
responsibility rests upon the courts to
determine if the confession is voluntary
and true or is lacking within the scope of
either term 'voluntary' and 'true'. If the
confession directly or indirectly is the
result of inducement, threat or promise
from a person in authority, it would be
treated as not voluntary. Voluntary and
true are two different terms related with
confession and each of them has its own
significance. A confession, which is
voluntary, is admissible even though it
may be incorrect in its contents. As
against above, a confession which is not
I voluntary is not admissible though it
may be true, whether a confession is
voluntary and true is a question of fact
and is to be determined keeping in view
the attending circumstances of each case.
Voluntariness of confession and of being
true are totally distinct Voluntarily
relates to its admissibility while its truth
is looked into for the purpose of
assessing its value. Therefore, for
proving confession it shall be both
voluntary and true".
Lest the words "for proving confession it shall be both
voluntary and true" in the above statement of the law are
misunderstood, the statement must be read as a whole and so read,
as we understand it, it means that voluntariness is the test of
admissibility and if the confession is voluntary, and, therefore,
admissible, the court will then determine whether it is true. If it is
both voluntary and true, then it is proof against its maker. If the
confession is not voluntary, the confession is inadmissible and the
question of determining its truth would not arise.
521
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 279
Article 41 saves a confession hit by Article 37, if it was
made after "the impression caused by any such inducement, threat
or promise has, in the opinion of the court, been fully removed".
Such a confession will be treated to have been made voluntarily.
All about Article 40 of the Qanun:
Article 40 reads:
"How much of information received from accused
may be proved: When any fact is deposed to as
discovered in consequence of information received from
a person accused of an offence in the custody of a police
officer so much of such information whether it amounts
to confession or not, as relates distinctly to the fact
thereby discovered, may be proved".
According to the Privy Council in Palukuri Kotayya v King (AIR
1947 PC 67) section 27 of the 1872 Act was "not artistically
worded". We have seen that section began with the word
'Provided. Article 40 has laid to sleep at least one controversy,
namely, whether it is a proviso to Article 39 of the Qanun (Article
26 of the Act). There is, however, no doubt that the rule in Article
40 is an exception to the rule enacted in Article 39; that Article
begins with the words "subject to Article 40", which indicates the
legislative intent that Article 40 is by way of exception to Article
39. Thus, a confession made by any person in police custody
cannot be proved unless:
(i)
(ii)
it is, as Article 39 itself provides, made in the
immediate presence of a Magistrate; or
when, as Article 40 says, a fact is deposed to
as discovered in consequence of information
received from the accused in police custody.
Rationale and Scope:
One of the best statements of the scope and rationale of
Article 40 (section 27 of 1872 Act) if we may say with respect is to
be found in Palukuri. In that case, the accused were charged with
murder. Some of them made statements to the police, when
arrested, that the spear "with which I stabbed I hid in a particular
place". As a result of that statement, the spear was recovered. The
High Court, relying upon the statement with which I stabbed.
convicted the accused. The Privy Council observed that section 27
provided an exception to the prohibition imposed by section 26-
"and enables certain statements made by
a person in police custody to be proved.
The condition necessary to bring the
section into operation is that the
discovery of a fact in consequence of
information received from a person
accused of any office in the custody of a
police officer must be deposed to and
thereupon so much of the information as
relates distinctly to the fact thereby
discovered may be proved.
The section seems to be based
on the view that if a fact is actually
of
discovered in consequence
information given, some guarantee is
afforded thereby that the information
was true, and accordingly can be safely
allowed to be given in evidence, but
clearly the extent of the information
admissible must depend on the 'exact
nature of the fact discovered to which
such information is required to relate.
Normally the section is brought into
operation when a person in police
custody produces from some place of
522
523
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 280
concealment some object, such as a dead
body, weapon or ornaments, said to be
connected with the crime of which the
informant is accused. Mr. Megow for the
Crown has argued that in such a case the
fact discovered is the physical object
produced, and that any information
which relates distinctly to that object can
be proved. On this view information
given by a person that the body
produced is that of a person murdered by
him, that the weapon produced is the one
used by him in the commission of
murder, or that the ornaments produced
were stolen in a dacoity, would all be
admissible. If this be the effect of section
27, little substance would remain in the
ban imposed by the two preceding
sections on confessions made to the
police by persons in police custody. That
ban was presumably inspired by the fear
of the legislature that a person under
police influence might be induced to
confess by the exercise of undue
pressure. But if all that is required to lift
the ban be the inclusion in the
confession information relating to an
object subsequently produced, it seems
reasonable to suppose that the persuasive
power of the police will prove equal to
the occasion, and that in practice the ban
will lose its effect. It is fallacious to treat
the fact 'discovered" within the section
as equivalent to the object produced; the
fact discovered embraces the place from
which the object is produced and the
knowledge of the accused as to this, and
the information given must relate
524
distinctly to this fact. Information as to
past user, or the past history, of the
object produced is not related to its
discovery in the setting in which it is
discovered. Information supplied by a
person in custody that 'I will produce a
knife in the roof of my house' does not
lead to the discovery of a knife; knives
were discovered many years ago. It leads
to the discovery of the fact that a knife is
concealed in the house of the informant
to his knowledge, and if the knife is
proved to have been used in the
commission of the offence, the fact
discovered is very relevant. But if to the
statement the words be added 'with
which I stabbed A', these words are
inadmissible since they do not relate to
the discovery of the knife in the house of
the information".
Article 40 is subject to the constitutional right against
self-incrimination:
This topic has been discussed in the Constitutional
Criminal Procedure Part of this book, with reference to the
American 5 Amendment and Article 13(b) of the Constitution of
Pakistan; they guarantee the right against self-incrimination; in the
words of Article 13(b) of the Pakistan Constitution, no person
"shall, when accused of an offence, be compelled to be a witness
against himself. It is sufficient to say here that the main object of
interrogation by the police of a suspect in custody, is to get
information relating to the crime under investigation. Even if the
suspect does not confess, in the technical sense given to
'confession' in Puluka, his interrogation might yield important
clues to the mystery. Article 13(b)of the Constitution does not use
the word 'confession'; it is enough to bring the case within the
prohibition of Article 13(b) that the accused was compelled to be a
525
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 281
witness against himself. And to determine 'compulsion', the fact
that he was in police custody, that the interrogation leading to the
discovery of an incriminating article was made in the oppressive.
suffocating and humiliating atmosphere of the police station will
all be weighed in the scale.
In a recent English case, Lam Chi-Ming. (1991) AC
212) the accused made a confession to murder which was obtained
by oppression. Part of the confession disclosed that the knife used
in the murder was at a particular place. The discovery of the knife
was held to be inadmissible on the ground that it was against self-
incrimination rule.
In that connection it is well to recall the American
exclusionary rule, discussed in the Constitutional Criminal
Procedure part of this book, namely that evidence obtained in
violation of the Constitution is inadmissible in evidence.
Confession made under promise of secrecy or deception:
If a confession is otherwise relevant, it does not, Article
42 so enacts, "become irrelevant merely because it was made under
a promise of secrecy, or in consequence of a deception practiced on
the accused for the purpose of obtaining it, or when he was drunk
or because it was made in answer to questions which he need not
have answered, whatever may have been the form of the questions,
or because he was not warned that he was not bound to make such
confession, and that evidence of it might be given against him".
This provision "shall not apply to the trial of cases under
the laws relating to enforcement of Hadood"; but we also wonder if
this Article can stand scrutiny under Article 13(b) of the
Constitution. Some of the cases noticed under the American 5
Amendment in the Constitutional Criminal Procedure Part of this
book will shed some light on the constitutional validity of this
Article.
526
Contrast Article 42 with Article 36 of the Qanun. The
latter provides that-
"In civil cases no admission is relevant.
if it is made either upon an express
condition that evidence of it is not to be
given or under circumstances from
which the court can infer that the parties
agreed together that evidence of it
should not be given".
But "nothing in this Article shall be taken to exempt any advocate
from giving evidence of any matter of which he may be compelled
to give evidence under Article 9". The reference here to Article 9
of the Qanun is to cases covered by the proviso to Article 9.
Effect of confession against its maker and others;
Section 30 of the Evidence Act, 1872 read:
"When more persons than one are being
tried jointly for the same offence and
confession made by one of such persons
affecting himself and some other of such
persons is proved, the court may take
into consideration such confession as
against such other person as well as
against the person who makes such
confession".
Section 30 of the 1872 Act was considered by the Privy
Council in Bhuboni Sahu v King (PLD 1949 PC 90), and it was
held that-
"Confession of a co-accused is
obviously evidence of a very weak type.
It does not indeed come within the
definition of 'evidence' contained in
527
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 282
section 3 (of the Act). It is not required
to be given on oath, nor in the presence
of the accused, and it cannot be tested by
cross-examination. It is much weaker
type of evidence than the evidence of an
approver which is not subject to any of
these infirmities. Section 30, however,
provides that the court may take the
confession into consideration and
thereby no doubt makes it evidence on
which the court may act; but the section
does not say that the confession is to
amount to proof. Clearly there must be
other evidence. The confession is only
one element in the consideration of all
the facts proved in the case; it can be put
in the scale and weighed with the other
evidence. The -confession of a co
accused can be used only in support of
other evidence and cannot be the
foundation of a conviction".
These observations were highlighted and followed in the majority
judgment of the Supreme Court in Z A Bhutto case (PLD 1979 SC
53, para 129 of Chief Justice Anwar-ul-Haq's judgment).
It appears that it was in the light of these observations
that Article 43 of the Qanun was drafted. It reads:
"When more persons than one are being tried jointly for
the same offence and a confession made by one of such
persons is proved-
(a)
(b)
such confession shall be proof
against the person making it; and
the court may take into
consideration such confession as
circumstantial evidence against
such other person",
The position under Article 43 now seems to be that if a confession
is otherwise relevant and admissible, it is proof against its maker,
o that it can be the foundation of his conviction without
corroboration. But as regards its use against a co-accused, it can be
taken into consideration as 'circumstantial evidence' against him.
Artistically, the expression "circumstantial evidence" is not a
happy choice; the intention seems to have been that such a
confession may be used against a co-accused as 'corroborative
evidence'.
Judicial confession:
A confession is judicial confession if it is made during
investigation and is recorded under section 164 Cr.P.C (Qazi
Pervaiz Iqbal v State - PLD 1976 Kar. 583, cited with approval in
Z A Bhutto case, PLD 1979 SC 53, para 127 of Chief Justice
Anwar-ul Haq's judgment); and if judicial confession' means
confession before a judicial officer, then a confession made before
the court during trial, e.g. under section 342 Cr.P.C. may also be
treated as "judicial confession'.
A statement or confession made in the course of any
investigation may be recorded by a Magistrate under section 164
Cr.P.C. Only a Magistrate of the Ist Class and a Magistrate of the
2nd Class specially empowered in that behalf by the Provincial
Government is competent to record a statement or confession made
to him in the course of any investigation or at any time afterwards
before the commencement of the inquiry or trial.
The subject of confessions recorded under section 164
read with section 364 Cr.P.C. has been admirably encapsulated in
Chapter 13 of the High Court Rules and Orders Vol. III. The object
of recording a confession in accordance with section 164 read with
section 364 Cr.P.C. is to provide a method of securing a reliable
record of statements or confessions made during the course of
529
528
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 283
police investigation which can be used if necessary during the trial.
Under Article 91 of the Qanun, a court is bound to presume that a
statement of confession of an accused person taken in according
