with law and purporting to be signed by any Judge or Magistrate is
genuine and that the certificate or note as to the circumstances
under which it was taken are true and that such statement of
confession was duly taken. The words "taken in accordance with
law" in Article 91 are very important and it is essential that in
recording a statement or confession under section 164 Cr.P.C. the
provisions of that section are strictly followed. The evidential value
of a confession depends upon its voluntary character and the
precision with which it is reproduced and the safeguards provided
in section 164 are meant to secure this end. These safeguards are of
great importance, as confessions are often retracted at a later stage
and it becomes necessary for the court to ascertain whether the
alleged confession was actually and voluntarily made. The mere
fact that a confession is retracted does not render it inadmissible in
evidence, but the court has to scrutinize any such confession with
the utmost care and accept it with the greatest caution. These
considerations and tendency of the police, now judicially
recognized, to direct their attention to securing a confession.
especially in unwitnessed incidents, should serve to show how
serious is the responsibility entrusted to the Magistrates under
section 164 Cr.P.C. (Queen v Babu Lal ILR 6 All. 509, cited in
Naqeebulla v State-PLD 1978 SC 21, 33).
Oral evidence of such a confession cannot be allowed,
for the rule "which applies is that where a power is given to do a
certain thing in a certain way the thing must be done in that way or
not at all (Nazir Ahmad v King - AIR 1936 PC 253, cited in
Muhammad Aslam case-PLD 1978 SC 298, 309).
It should be mentioned here that Chapter 13 of the High
Court Rules and Orders Vol. III does two things:
i)
states the law on the subject of confessions.
and
530
ii)
gives instructions as to how Magistrates
should proceed with the recording of
confessions and how to deal with the
confessing accused persons after they have
made the confession.
As regards the instructions, it has been held that they are
merely directory in their nature. "The sole object and the dominant
purpose behind all these instructions........is that they (Magistrates)
must always make a real and earnest endeavour to ensure that the
confessions of the accused recorded by them are free and voluntary
and are not caused by any inducement, threat or promise". In
recording a confession, "the Magistrate must always apply himself
fully, diligently and in all seriousness as a matter of solemn duty to
this task entrusted to him under the law. He cannot be casual and
remiss or act mechanically in the enquiries made from the accused
before recording his confession. He should endeavour to place him
at ease, dispel all or any of the lurking fears inducing hope or
promise from his mind to enable him if he so chooses, to make of
his own volition and absolutely free and voluntary statement
according to the best dictates of his own inner conscience. The
Magistrate before proceeding to record the confession must fully
assure himself and satisfy his own judicial conscience about it"
(Naqeebullah v State PLD 1978 SC 21, 30).
Retracted Confession
When a confession is retracted at the trial, the rule of
caution universally applied is that it should not be acted upon
unless corroborated in material particulars by reliable evidence
(Nadir Hussain v the Crown 1969 SCMR 442; Dhani Bakhsh v
State PLD 1975 SC 187). In Dhani Bakhsh case (PLD 1975 SC
187), it was held to be well established "that a retracted judicial
confession is seldom made the basis of conviction without being
materially corroborated and even if a confession is proved to have
been voluntarily made it must further be established that it was
true. For the purpose of establishing its truth it is necessary to
examine the confession and compare it with the rest of the
531
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 284
prosecution evidence and the probabilities of the case (Naqeebullah
v State PLD 1978 SC 21, 32).
To be read as a whole
It is also well-settled that a confession must be read as a
whole (Riaz Hussain Shah v State - PLD 1995 SC 336, 341)
Extra-judicial confession
Extra judicial confession is a confession before any
person other than a Magistrate. Evidence of extra judicial
confession alone without any corroboration is not sufficient to
maintain a conviction (Ahmad Hasan v State-2001 SCMR 505
and Zia-ur-Rehman v State-2001 SCMR 1405)
Motive Evidence:
Motive has two distinct but related meanings. In the first
sense, it means an emotion prompting an act. In the second sense it
means intention or purpose. It is in the first sense that it is used in
criminal cases. Motive is the emotion that gives rise to the intention
(Muhammad Ishaq v State - 1992 PCL 2059) For example.
motive for murder may be jealousy, fear, hatred, desire for money,
perverted lust or even, as in so called mercy killings, compassion
or love (Reg y Hyam (1975) AC 55, 73 HLS
Under Article 21 of the Qanon, "Any fact is relevant
which shows or constitutes a motive or preparation for any fact in
issue or relevant fact"
Motive evidence is not only relevant but also, as was
held in Abdur Rashid case (PLD 1975 SC 2271, often helpful to the
investigating agency as well as the court. Its importance, however,
depends on the facts and circumstances of each case. For the
police, it steers and determines the course of investigation. Its
established existence and strong nature proved by reliable evidence
when put in the scales along with the ocular and other evidence
832
does often tend to set at rest some lurking suspicions and satisfy
the judicial conscience. Of course, there may be cases where even
the strongest motive may be wholly inept owing to absence or
weakness of direct evidence. Conversely, the weakness of motive
or even its conspicuous absence might not be helpful to the accused
against whom unimpeachable ocular evidence is available. As has
often been said, proof of motive loses importance if there be strong
evidence to prove that the crime was committed by the person
accused (Muhammad Ilyas v State - PLD 1967 SC 443, 447)
Motive precedes action. It is principally a kind of
circumstantial evidence. By itself it neither proves nor disproves
any assertion conclusively (Moazam Shah v Mohsin Shah PLD
2001 SC 458, 463). It is evidence of the background or history
relevant to the offence.
In ordinary human conduct where killing takes place by
design, it is not without a motive strong or weak. This is not to say
that murders are not committed wantonly without any motive
whatsoever. Motiveless murders do occur owing to mad or reckless
acts of inhuman nature. Sometimes a motive lies mysteriously
hidden in the mind of the killer with no means to dig it on the
surface. But it may be stated as a rule of prudence in judging
human conduct that where a motive is alleged by prosecution
which is found to be false, it becomes all the more necessary to
scrutinize the credentials of the witnesses who by their evidence
direct or indirect speak about the guilt of an accused person on the
premises of a false motive (Habibullah v State PLD 1969 SC 127).
Motive of crime may not be known or it may not have
been discovered. The rule, therefore, is that the prosecution is not
obliged to set up or prove a motive; but just as presence of motive
can greatly strengthen the case for the prosecution so its absence
can weaken it (Reg. v Sharmpal Singh (1962) AC 188, 197).
Although the prosecution does not have to prove motive.
evidence of motive is always admissible in order to show that it is
more probable that the accused committed the offence charged.
533
1
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 285
Previous enmity is a double edged weapon and cuts both
ways. If enmity is considered as sufficient motive for the
commission of an offence, it can also be considered as sufficient
motive for false implication (State v Muhammad Sharif - 1995
SCMR 635, 647).
Chapter 9
EXAMINATION OF THE ACCUSED
Under section 342 Cr.P.C.
Section 342 Cr.P.C. provides that for the purpose of
enabling him to explain any circumstances appearing in the
evidence against him, the court may at any stage of an inquiry or
trial without previously warning the accused put such questions to
him as the court considers necessary, and shall for the purpose
aforesaid question him generally on the case after the witnesses for
the prosecution have been examined and before he is called on for
his defence. The answers given by the accused may be taken into
consideration in such an inquiry or trial and put in evidence for and
against him in any other inquiry or trial.
Sub-section (4) of section 342 provides: "Except as
provided by sub-section (2) of section 340, no oath shall be
administered to the accused".
It will be noticed that section 342 Cr.P.C. has two parts:
the first empowers the court to put any question it considers
necessary at any stage of an inquiry or trial: this is a discretionary
power, under the second part the court shall, that is to say, it is
mandatory for the court, for the purpose of enabling the accused to
explain any circumstances appearing in the evidence against him,
to question him generally.
The whole object of section 342 Cr.P.C. is to provide an
opportunity to the accused to explain the circumstances which are
relied upon by the prosecution as established in the case against
him (Amin-ul-Haque v Crown PLD 1952 FC 63, 70). Section
342 Cr.P.C. aims at bringing to the notice of the accused such
points of evidence as are likely to influence the mind of the court to
draw adverse inference against him and to give him chance if he so
desires to offer his version or to explain circumstances appearing in
evidence against him (Shabbir Ahmad v the State - PLD 1995 SC
343, 347). The object is not to cross-examine the accused or to
resort to unduly detailed examination which savours of cross-
examination, nor is it to fill up gaps in the prosecution case (Abdul
Wahab v Crown PLD 1955 FC 88; Jamal v State - PLD 1960
WP Lah 1192, 1195). In other words, the judicial questioning
should not become inquisitorial (Mohyuddin v Emperor - AIR
1925 Pat. 414).
The requirement of section 342 Cr.P.C. is to put all the
circumstances appearing in the evidence against the accused so that
he has opportunity to explain them. An omnibus question such as
"you have heard the evidence, what is your defence" would hardly
meet this requirement (Abdul Wahab x Crown PLD 1955 FC 88,
91).
Statement of accused must be read as a whole
It is well settled that the statement of an accused under
section 342 Cr.P.C. has to be read in its entirety. It is to be accepted
or rejected as a whole. It is not permissible to accept the
inculpatory part to corroborate the prosecution evidence and reject
the exculpatory part (See among others Shabbir Ahmad v State
PLD 1995 SC 343). This assumes importance where the accused
makes his statement admitting the commission of the offence
simultaneously raising a plea constituting his defence. In such a
case, the court will not accept the inclupatory portion and reject the
exculpatory one (Shabbir Ahmad v State PLD 1995 SC 343).
534
535
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 286
Effect of non-compliance with the provisions of section 342:
One view is that, when the prosecution relies upon a fact
as evidence against the accused, but that fact is not put to the
accused in his examination under the second part of section 342,
sub-section (1) Cr.P.C., and he is thereby deprived of an
opportunity to explain it, this should deprive the fact of its
evidentiary value with the result that it should be excluded from the
court's consideration. (S.M.K. Alvi v Crown PLD 1953 FC 189;
Abdul Salam Molla-PLD 1955 FC 129; Munawar Ahmad v State
- PLD 1956 SC (Pak) 300; Dwarkanath v Emperor - AIR 1939 PC
124). The other view is that ultimately the question may turn on
whether the non-compliance was an error or omission within the
meaning of section 537 Cr.P.C. and had resulted in miscarriage or
failure of justice; (Abdul Wahab v Crown PLD 1955 FC 88; M.
Sonafar Ali v State -1969 SCMR 461: Saleh Muhammad v State -
1971 SCMR 260; Allah Dad v State PLD 1978 SC 1) so that the
non-compliance will not result in vitiating the trial or in the
exclusion of the particular piece of evidence unless it had caused
prejudice to the case of the accused. After considering a large
number of cases for and against the above-stated two views.
Anwar-ul-Haq CJ noticed in Z A Bhutto case (PLD 1979 SC 53,
para 175) the "trend of the more recent decisions of the Privy
Council and indeed of later-day criminal jurisprudence in England
as well as in India" and observed that:
"The swing of the pendulum has been
away from technicality, and greater
endeavour has been made to regard the
substance rather than the shadow and to
administer justice fairly and impartially
as it should be administered, fair to the
accused, fair to the State and fair to the
vast mass of the people for whose
protection penal laws are made and
administered".
The conclusion reached (paras 181 and 182 of Anwar-ul-Haq CJ's
judgment) was as follows:
error
or
"It will be seen that in determining
whether an omission.
irregularity in the conduct of the trial
(including the failure to put some pieces
of evidence to the accused under section
342 Cr.P.C), using the phrase so as to
embrace all aspects thereof, has vitiated
the trial in any manner, the court must
look to the substance and not to
technicalities and if the accused had a
fair trial and has not been prejudiced in
his defence, then the error, omission or
irregularity would stand cured under the
provisions of section 537 of the Code.
And as the distinction between an
illegality and irregularity is, to borrow
the words of Sir John Beaumont of the
Privy Council in AIR 1947 PC 67, only
one of degree rather than of kind,
nothing turns on this distinction for the
purposes of the application of this
curative section".
If an accused files a written statement in his defence,
that does not abrogate the duty of the court, under section 342
Cr.P.C., to ask him to explain the incriminating circumstances
appearing in the evidence; but where the accused refuses to answer
questions saying that he had said all that he had to say in his
written statement, it will be useless for the court to persist with the
detailed questioning (Rameshan v Emperor AIR 1936 Nagpur
147). In State v Zia-ur-Rehman (PLD 1973 SC 49) the Supreme
Court noticed that the accused had refused to participate in the
proceedings saying that they did not recognize the court or its
proceedings; it did not, it was held, "lie in their mouths now to
complain that they had been deprived of any valuable right..........
536
537
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 287
Section 342 Cr.P.C. and Article 43 of the Qanun:
We have already considered Article 43 of the Qanun. Its
relationship with section 342 and also with a statement on oath
under section 340 Cr.P.C. is that in statements under these sections,
an accused person, who is being jointly tried with another, may
make a confession, implicating himself and his co-accused but the
co-accused has had no opportunity to explain or rebut that
statement. Under Article 43 of the Qanun, the confession of one
accused against his co-accused may be taken into consideration.
The question is whether such a confession can be taken into
consideration against a co-accused who had had no opportunity to
explain or rebut it. This question was considered by Muhammad
Haleem J. in Qazi Pervaiz Iqbal v State (PLD 1976 Kar. 583):
"Upon a consideration of the authorities
we are inclined to hold that section 30.
Evidence Act (now Article 43 of the
Qanun) does not specify the form the
confession may take........ Section
30 provides an exception to the rule that
an admission can only be used against its
maker under section 21 of the Evidence
Act (Article 34 of the Qanun).
Therefore, in construing section 30 of
the Evidence Act regard must be had to
the fact that the confession which is
sought to be used against the co-accused,
like any other piece of prosecution
evidence, must be proved before the
prosecution closes its side so as to
provide an opportunity to the accused to
rebut it. This being the minimum of a
fair trial, the keyword 'proved must
have relation to the stage of the trial
otherwise it cannot be used in evidence
against him. Concluding, therefore, the
538
implication cannot be on the meaning of
the word 'proved' in section 3 of the
Evidence Act (now Article 2(1)(4) of the
Qanun)".
This statement of the law was approved in Z A Bhutto case (see
para 127 of Anwar-ul-Haq CJ's judgment) in which the statement
under section 342 Cr.P.C. of Z A Bhutto accused was recorded
first: thereafter, statements of his co-accused, containing
confessions implicating themselves and Z A Bhutto accused, were
recorded. As Z A Bhutto had had no opportunity to explain and
rebut those confessional statements in so far as they implicated Z A
Bhutto, they were, as regards Z A Bhutto, excluded from
consideration.
But if the confession, judicial or extra-judicial, by one
accused against his co-accused, is proved in the prosecution
evidence and the same is put to the co-accused in his statement
under section 342 Cr.P.C. thereby affording him opportunity to
explain it, it can be taken into consideration against the co-accused
(ZA Bhutto case, para 132 of Anwar-ul-Haq CJ's judgment).
Connotation of "any circumstances appearing in the evidence
against him"
A confession of an accused person against his co-
accused may, under Article 43 of the Qanun, be "taken into
consideration". As was held by the Privy Council in Bhuboni Sahu
v King (PLD 1949 PC 90) "it does not come within the definition
of evidence contained in section 3 (of the Evidence Act, 1872)".
Yet, as we have seen above, in order to be used against the co-
accused, it must be put to him in his statement under section 342
Cr.P.C. Then, suppose that during the course of the trial, the trial
judge inspects the scene of occurrence and records
"memorandum of any relevant facts observed at such inspection"
under section 539 Cr.P.C. This too is not, strictly speaking,
'evidence'. Yet, it cannot be doubted that any observation by the
trial judge which has a bearing on the guilt of the accused is a
539
a
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 288
circumstance which must be put to him to enable him to explain it
before it can be used against him.
In the context of section 342 Cr.P.C., therefore, the word
'evidence' in the phrase "any circumstances appearing in the
evidence against him" does not seem to be confined to what it is
defined to mean in Article 2, clause (1)(c) of the Qanun.
Effect of failure to answer
The accused does not, subsection (2) of section 342 so
provides, render himself liable to punishment by refusing to
answer questions so put to him or by giving false answers to them
but the court may draw such inference from such refusal or answer
as it thinks just.
Manner of recording accused's statement
The examination of the accused under section 342
Cr.P.C. has to be recorded in the manner provided in section 364
Cr.P.C. The whole of such examination, including every question
put to him and every answer given by him, shall be recorded in full
and such record shall be shown or read to him, or if necessary,
interpreted to him so that he can explain or add to his answers. The
statement shall then be signed by the Magistrate or the Judge, who
shall certify under his own hand that the examination was taken in
his presence and hearing and that the record contains a full and true
account of the statement made by the accused.
Chapter 10
THE ACCUSED ENTERS ON HIS DEFENCE
In trials before Magistrates under Chapter XX Cr.P.C..
section 244, if the Magistrate does not convict the accused on his
admission, or when the accused denies the charge, "the Magistrate
shall proceed to hear the complainant, if any, and take all such
evidence as may be produced in support of the prosecution and also
540
hear the accused and take all such evidence as he produces in his
defence".
In trials before the High Courts and Courts of Session
under Chapter XXIIA, section 265F Cr.P.C., if the accused does
not plead guilty or if the accused pleads guilty but the court does
not convict him on his plea, "the court shall proceed to hear the
complainant, if any, and take all such evidence as may be produced
in support of the prosecution.......". When the examination of
witnesses for the prosecution and the examination, if any, of the
accused are concluded, the accused shall be asked whether he
means to adduce evidence. Under sub-section (5) of section 265F.
if the accused puts in any written statement, the court shall file it
with the record. Subsection (6) of that section reads:
"If the accused, or any one of several
accused, says that he means to adduce
evidence, the court shall call on the
accused to enter on his defence and
produce his evidence".
While section 244 says that after the prosecution
evidence, the Magistrate shall also hear the accused", section 265F
says "when the examination of the witnesses for the prosecution"
and "the examination of the accused" are concluded, they mean the
same thing; they mean in the words of section 342 Cr.P.C. that the
accused shall be questioned generally on the case "for the purpose
of enabling the accused to explain any circumstances appearing in
the evidence against him".
Also, section 244 Cr.P.C. does not require the
Magistrate to call upon the accused to enter upon his defence, yet
the requirement that the Magistrate shall "take all such evidence as
he produces in his defence" means the same thing.
Thus, at the end of the accused's examination under
section 342 Cr.P.C, the court of the Magistrate may put two
questions to the accused, first, whether he would give evidence on
541
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 289
oath in disproof of the charges made against him and, two, whether
he would adduce evidence in defence. The accused may not
himself enter into the witness box to give evidence on oath, but that
will not deprive him of the right to lead evidence in his defence.
Accused's right to testify
Section 340 Cr.P.C., by its sub-section(2), requires that
an accused person shall, if he does not plead guilty, give evidence
on oath in disproof of the charges or allegations made against him
or any person charged or tried together with him at the same trial.
But the proviso to subsection (2) says that the accused shall not be
asked and if asked shall not be required to answer any question
tending to show that he has committed or been convicted of any
offence other than the offence with which he is charged or for
which he is being tried, or is of bad character, unless the case falls
in one of the categories mentioned in the proviso.
The question whether an accused has a right to testify as
his own witness has a long history and it is not necessary to weary
the reader with its narration. As was said by Chief Justice Appleton
in a case from American jurisdiction (State v Cleaves - 59 ME.
298 (1871), "the defendant in criminal cases is either innocent or
guilty. If innocent he has every inducement to state the facts which
would exonerate him. The truth would be his protection. But the
defendant having the opportunity to contradict or explain the
inculpative facts proved against him, may decline to avail himself
of the opportunity thus afforded him by the law. His declining to
avail himself of the privilege of testifying is an existent and
obvious fact. It is a fact patent in the case. The Jury cannot avoid
perceiving it. Why should they not regard it as a fact of more or
less weight in determining the guilt or innocence of the guilt......
(Also see Muhammad Ishaq v State-1992 PCr.L.J. 2059, 2077).
It has always been recognized that the right of the
accused to testify was given to help the innocent. Indeed, it made
life more difficult for the guilty. Gradually, however, it seems that
the force of an inference from not testifying came to be considered
542
the equivalent of compelling the accused to furnish or give
evidence against himself and, therefore, repugnant to the self-
incrimination guarantee of the American Fifth Amendment (Addie
Dean Griffin v State 380 US 609; noted in Muhammad Ishaq v
State-1992 P Cr.L.J. 2059, 2077, 2078).
Section 340 Cr.P.C. was first amended by the Law
Reforms Ordinance 1972; it was provided that the accused may
give evidence on oath in disproof of the charges or allegations
made against him..............but-
(i)
(ii)
he could not be called as a witness except on
his own request; and
his failure to give evidence was not to be
made the subject of any comment by the
prosecution or give rise to any presumption
against him or any person charged or tried
together with him at the same trial.
This produced the result that the accused had the option
of either making an unsworn statement under section 342 Cr.P.C.
on which he could not be cross-examined or of giving evidence on
oath and submitting himself for cross-examination. Section 340 as
it stands now was amended in 1985. The present section uses the
word 'shall' and requires that the accused "shall if he does not
plead guilty give evidence on oath in disproof of the charges or
allegations made against him..........". There was a divergence of
judicial opinion on the effect of section 340(2) Cr.P.C. when
considered with reference to the fundamental right guaranteed by
Article 13 of the Constitution. The controversy seems to have been
set at rest in Mst. Amir Khatoon v Faiz Ahmad (PLD 1991 SC
787). In that case, the section was considered in its historical
setting, in the light of section 5 of the Oaths Act 1873, which
provides that "nothing herein contained shall render it lawful to
administer, in a criminal proceeding, oath or affirmation to the
accused person" and Article 13 of the Constitution, which reads:
543
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 290
"No person
a)
b)
shall, when accused of an offence, be
compelled to be a witness against himself".
The right guaranteed by Article 13 is the right not to be
compelled to be a witness against himself, it is also known as the
right of silence. This right has been discussed in the Constitutional
Criminal Procedure part of this book. The question raised in Amir
Khatoon v Faiz Ahmad was whether section 340, subsection (2)
Cr.P.C had changed the basic principle of criminal jurisprudence
namely that the prosecution shall prove its case and the accused
would not be burdened with the proof of his innocence and as to
what is the import, effect and implication of section 340 on the
right of an accused as guaranteed by Article 13 paragraph (b) of the
Constitution. It was held that the view that on the strength of these
provisions the accused can be compelled to make a statement on
oath and that on his failure to do so he can be sent to prison or that
adverse inference can be drawn against him is not correct.
Of some relevance to the question are the observations
in Shah Wali v State (PLD 1993 SC 32). That was a case under the
Prohibition (Enforcement of Hadd) Order 1979, Heroin was
recovered from the front passenger seat of a car occupied by the
two accused persons. The accused were content to deny the
recovery. The courts below found them guilty. The plea before the
Supreme Court was that the prosecution had failed to prove
exclusive possession of the heroin by either of the two accused
persons. It was held that "under the present constitutional and
juridical set up in Pakistan the old notion so called of the
entitlement of an accused person to tell a lie and divert the court in
wrong channels of inquiry cannot be accepted, particularly when
the amended law provides abundant opportunity and scope for the
accused to make deposition as a witness and also to state the truth
in that capacity. While accepting all benefits from the court to
follow the presumption of innocence till proved guilty, the accused
cannot be absolved of his duty to help the court to discover the
544
truth if need be by appearing as a witness for himself and divulging
the truth. If this culture of criminal litigation gets evolved in true
spirit of the present legal, constitutional, juridical and Islamic
ethos, new avenues of protection of the accused interest would
open...
Comments as to the implications of the ratio in Amir
Khatoon v Faiz Ahmad (PLD 1991 SC 787) were made in
Muhammad Ishaq v State (1992 P Cr.L.J. 2059, 2075) and as the
law is developed on a case to case basis, those comments and the
observations in Shah Wali v State (PLD 1993 SC 32) can be
helpful in a future case. As has been noticed in Muhammad Ishaq
case, the provision that an accused shall not be compelled to be a
witness against himself, is, to borrow from an American case
noticed there, like the rain descending upon the innocent and guilty
alike. In England, the law had not developed on the same lines as
in Pakistan. As the Privy Council said in Haw (1981) 3 All ER 14),
a case from Singapore, English Law has always recognized the
right of the deciders of fact in a criminal trial to draw inferences
from the failure of a defendant to exercise his right to give
evidence and thereby to submit himself to cross-examination. It
would in any event be hopeless to expect jurors or judges, as
reasonable men, from doing so.
Defence Evidence
It has been seen that one of the questions to be put to the
accused under section 342 Cr.P.C. is whether he means to adduce
evidence in his defence. What the accused does in answer to such a
question is to state his defence plea and to state also whether he
means or does not mean to adduce defence evidence. If he says that
he means to adduce defence evidence, he may ask the court to
summon a witness for examination or for the production of any
document or thing and the court shall summon the witness, unless
it considers that the object of the application is vexation or delay or
defeating the ends of justice. The defence plea may be a total
denial. For example, the accused may set up a plea of alibi which
means that at the time of occurrence, he was at a place other than
545
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 291
the place of occurrence and his presence elsewhere is essentially
inconsistent with his presence at the time and place of occurrence
and, therefore, with his participation in the crime. Or, the accused
may plead one of the general exceptions contained in Chapter IV,
sections 76 to 106 PPC or a special exception, if any.
Though the burden of establishing guilt is on the
prosecution, yet the court must also consider the evidence for the
defence, which may have one of the three results: it may convince
it of the innocence of the accused, or it may cause it to doubt, in
which case the accused is entitled to an acquittal; or it may and
sometimes does strengthen the case for the prosecution (Bullard v
Queen (1957) AC 635, 645 PC; noticed and relied upon in
Muhammad Ishaq Khan v State (1992) P.Crl.LJ. 2059, 2075).
Thus in Muhammad Ishaque Khan v State (1992 P.Crl.L.J. 2059),
the accused had taken the plea of self-defence which, it was found,
made great demand upon one's sense of credulity and the defence
evidence, by its inherent improbabilities, was held to lend strength
to prosecution's case.
When the burden is on accused:
There are then cases in which the law places the burden
of proof of a particular fact on the accused. As has been seen under
the heading "Burden of Proof" in an earlier part of this book, the
burden on the accused in all such cases is not as heavy as on the
prosecution; he is not required to prove beyond a reasonable doubt,
and may discharge the burden on the balance of probabilities.
Chapter 11
ARGUMENTS
In trials before the High Courts and Courts of Session,
after the evidence of the prosecution, examination of the accused,
and evidence of the accused, have concluded, the court hears
arguments. Section 265G Cr.P.C. provides that in cases where the
accused, or any one of several accused, does not adduce evidence
in his defence, the court shall, on the close of the prosecution case
546
and examination of the accused, call upon the prosecutor to sum up
his case. After the prosecutor has done so, the accused shall make a
reply. Where the accused or any of the several accused examines
evidence in his defence, the court shall, on the close of the defence
evidence, call upon the accused to sum up the case. After he has
done so, the prosecutor shall make a reply.
There is no such provision in Chapter XX which governs
the trial of cases by Magistrates. Despite the absence of an express
provision to that effect in Chapter XX, the practice is, and it is a
salutary practice more in accord with the principle of fairness, that
arguments are heard by the courts of Magistrates also. As the
matter concerns the right of hearing, the courts proceed on the
principle that absence of an express provision does not mean the
absence of power to do a thing which is necessary for a just
decision of the case.
Chapter 12
ORDERS INCLUDING ORDER OF ACQUITTAL THAT
MAY BE NECESSARY TO BE MADE DURING TRIAL
After the court has heard final arguments, the stage has
reached for the final judgment of acquittal or conviction but during
the course of trial also, the court has power to make various orders.
including an order of acquittal. They include the following:
Cases which the Magistrate cannot, or does not want to, hear
Section 346 Cr.P.C. provides that if in the course of an
inquiry or trial before a Magistrate, the evidence appears to him to
warrant a presumption that the case is one which should be tried or
sent for trial to the Court of Session or the High Court or to some
other Magistrate, he shall stay proceedings and submit the case
with a brief report to the Sessions Judge or to such other Magistrate
having jurisdiction as the Sessions Judge directs. This may involve
547
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 292
a case in which the evidence discloses that the Magistrate lacks
territorial jurisdiction, or a case which is triable exclusively by a
Special Magistrate. Section 347 provides for a case when it appears
to the Magistrate at any stage of the proceedings that the case is
one which ought to be tried by the Court of Session, in which case
he shall send the case to the Court of Session. A case in which the
Magistrate finds from the evidence that the offence should be
punished with a sentence which is beyond his power to inflict, is
one of the categories which falls within this section. Section 348
makes provision for a case in which on account of a previous
conviction under Chapter XII or XVII PPC, the Magistrate thinks
that the case should be tried by the Court of Session or High Court.
In such a case he may send the case to the Court of Session or High
Court. Section 349 provides among others for the procedure when
a Magistrate of the 2nd class or 3 class finds that the accused is
guilty and that he ought to receive a punishment different in kind or
more severe than that which he is empowered to inflict. This
section requires a Magistrate to record his opinion and to submit
his proceedings and forward the accused to a Magistrate of the 1"
Class specially empowered by the Provincial Government.
Orders of acquittal etc. during the trial
There are situations in which the court may not proceed
to final judgment and may have to record an order of acquittal
during the course of the trial.
Thus,
i)
ii)
under section 247, when the court has taken
cognizance on a complaint and the
complainant does not appear on the day
appointed for the appearance of the accused or
on a subsequent date of hearing, the
Magistrate may acquit the accused unless for
some reason he thinks it proper to adjourn the
hearing to some other date;
section 248 provides that if a complainant at
any time before a final order satisfies the
iii)
Magistrate that there are sufficient grounds
for permitting him to withdraw his complaint.
the Magistrate may permit him to do so and
"shall thereupon acquit the accused";
sections 249-A and 265-K Cr.P.C. empower
the court to acquit an accused at any stage of
the trial if, after hearing the prosecutor and the
accused and for reasons to be recorded, it
considers that the charge is groundless or that
there is no probability of the accused being
convicted of any offence. That the charge is
groundless may mean that there is not even a
prima facie case against the accused, or that
the facts do not disclose the commission of
any offence or do not constitute the offence
with which the accused is charged. The other
ground is that there is no probability of the
accused being convicted of any offence. Cases
in which the prosecution fails to adduce its
evidence resulting in inexcusable or
unconscionable delay may fall in this
category. For this, the reader is referred to the
discussion under
heading
"Commencement of trial" in a preceding part
of this book, which deals with the provisions
of section 344 Cr.P.C. The power under this
section may be exercised at any stage and
even without recording evidence (Badar-ud-
Din v Mehr Ahmad Raza PLD 1993 SC 399).
The rationale is that if the facts of the case do
not disclose the commission of an offence, the
accused should not suffer the ordeal of trial.

Chapter 13
Composition etc. of offences:
Section 345 provides for the compounding of offences.
It provides by its subsection (1) that the offences punishable under
the sections of the Pakistan Penal Code "specified in the first two
columns of the table next following may be compounded by the
persons mentioned in the third column of that table", and
punishable under the sections of the Pakistan Penal Code specified
"in the first two columns of the table next following may, with the
permission of the court..........be compounded by the persons
mentioned in the third column of that table". Included in the table
under subsection (2) of section 345 Cr.P.C. are offences as grave as
murder, grievous hurt. This is a departure from the rule of the
Anglo-Saxon Jurisprudence; to quote from "Salmond on
Jurisprudence",
"A crime
is an act deemed by
law to be harmful to the society in
general, even though its immediate
victim is an individual. Murder injures
primarily the particular victim, but its
blatant disregard of human life puts it
beyond a matter of mere compensation
between the murderer and the victim's
family".
This change by way of amendments of section 345
Cr.P.C. enlarging the category of compoundable offences, and
some other sections of the Code of Criminal Procedure, e.g.
sections 337 and 338, as also the amendments of some of the
provisions of the Pakistan Penal Code to which we shall presently
advert, is the direct result of the Supreme Court's decision in
Pakistan v Gul Hasan Khan (PLD 1989 SC 633), a decision under
Article 203D read with Article 203F of the Constitution of
Pakistan, declaring certain provisions of the Pakistan Penal Code
and the Code of Criminal Procedure "repugnant to the Injunctions
550
of Islam as laid down in the Holy Quran and the Sunnah of the
Holy Prophet........
are
offences which
Besides enumerating the
compoundable and the persons in whom vests the right to
compound each of those offences, section 345 provides further-
(i)
(ii)
(iii)
(iv)
(v)

Siyah Kari offence under the Pakistan Penal
Code may be waived or compounded subject
to such condition as the court may deem fit to
impose with the consent of the parties;
by its subsection (3), that the abetment of or
attempt to commit a compoundable offence
may be compounded in the same manner as
the offence itself;
by its subsection (4). that if the person
competent to compound is an idiot, under the
age of 18, or a lunatic, the offence may be
compounded by "any person competent to
contract on his behalf with the permission of

by its subsections (5) and (6), that in an

be with the leave of the court; and
by its subsection (6), that the composition of
an offence under this section shall have the
effect of an acquittal of the accused.
Subsection (7) of section 345 enacts that-
"No offence shall be compounded except as provided by
this section".

Sections 337 to 339A which relate to tendering of

heirs of the victim,
Section 311 PPC reads:
"Notwithstanding anything contained in
section 309 or section 310, where all the walis
do not waive or compound the right of gisas
.or if the principle of fasad-fil-arz........is
attracted, the court, having regard to the facts
and circumstances of the case, punish an
offender against whom the right of qisas has
been waived or compounded with death,
imprisonment for life or imprisonment of
either description for a term which may
extend to fourteen years as taazi".
The term "fasad-fil-arz" has been defined in the Explanation to
section 311 PPC to include the past conduct of the offender, or
whether he has any previous convictions, or the brutal or shocking
manner in which the offence has been committed which is
outrageous to the public conscience or if the offender is considered
a potential danger to the community or if the offence has been
committed in the name or on the pretext of honour.
Composition in Hadd and Taazir cases-distinction:
The distinction may well be illustrated with reference to
cases under section 302 PPC. Whoever commits qatl-i-amd is
punishable -
(3)
with death as qisas, provided proof as
provided in section 304 PPC is given; or
553
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 295
(b)
with death or imprisonment for life as taazir,
if proof under section 304 PPC is not
available.
Section 345, subsection (2), Cr.P.C. provides that the offence of
qatl-i-amd punishable under section 302 may be compounded by
the heirs of the victim.
In Khan Muhammad State (2005 SCMR 599), it was
held that sections 209, 310 and 311 PPC apply to qatl-i-amd
punishable with death as qisas that is, under section 302, clause (a)
PPC and "the sentence of death, liable to qisas, has been made
compoundable even if the offence has not been compounded by all
the legal heirs or otherwise, subject to the provisions of sections
309, 310, 311 PPC". But as far as the offence of qatl-i-amd liable
to death by taazir is concerned. (that is, the one falling under
section 302, clause (b)] it has been made compoundable by
enacting section 345(2) Cr.P.C. which says that if all the legal heirs
have compounded the offence, the court is empowered to accord
permission to ensure that the parties may bury their
hatchets..
Thus, for the composition of an offence against section
302(b)PPC, all the heirs of the victim must join in the composition,
but the joining of all the heirs is not necessary for the composition
of offences against section 302(a) PPC. Earlier the same view had
been taken in Muhammad Aslam v Shaukat Ali (1997 SCMR
1307).
Composition where one of the Walls dies leaving
his/her own heirs:
In Ahmad Nawaz v State (PLD 2007 Lah. 121), M, an
unmarried man was murdered. His heirs were his mother B, and his
father A. A died after the incident of murder, and was survived by
children from other wives. The question was whether the children
of A had become walis of M. This turned on the interpretation of
section 305 PPC which provides that in case of qatl, the wali shall
554
be the heirs of the victim according to his personal law. It was held
that section 305-
"clearly states that in case of a qatl, the
wali shall be the heirs of the victim...
And the said provisions do not
contemplate that the heirs of heir of the
victim shall also be wali of the
victim..........
Accordingly, the heirs of A were not the walis of M for the purpose
of composition.
Chapter 14
JUDGMENT AND SENTENCING
Some general observations
(a)
Definition of judgment
The expression judgment" has not been defined in the
Code of Criminal Procedure and is, therefore, to be understood in
its ordinary signification, namely, where a written judgment is
required by law, the document which for the reasons stated therein
concludes the trial and disposes of the proceedings (Munir CJ in
Malik Feroz Khan Noon case - PLD 1958 SC (Pak) 333, 348). In
England, judgment is equivalent to a judgment of conviction or
acquittal and is distinct from other orders in a criminal case, and in
the Code also, it means a judgment of conviction or acquittal. Thus,
neither under the English law nor under the Code, the term
"judgment" in a criminal case includes an interlocutory order
(Horiram Singh v Emperor AIR 1939 FC 43, 48 per Sulaiman J). It
follows that interlocutory orders including bail orders are not
judgments (Gulzar Hasan Shah v Ghulam Murtaza - PLD 1970 SC
335).
555
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 296
To believe a witness reasons to be given
When credibility is a factor it is not ordinarily sufficient
to say that you accept the evidence of witness "A" and reject that
of witness "B". Reasons must be given, that being of the essence of
a judicial pronouncement as distinguished from an administrative
order.
Disparaging or condemnatory remarks
Sometimes it becomes necessary to censure or pass
disparaging or condemnatory remarks against a party or witness.
The judge is competent to do so on the principle that when a person
is examined as a witness, he has the right to give his own version
and the party calling him has an occasion to rehabilitate his credit
by putting him questions in re-examination but the exercise of this
power must be marked with judicial self-restraint. The reason is
that disparaging remarks in a judgment, whether they amount to
verdict or not, imputing crime, moral delinquency or improper
conduct to a person are a constant source of weariness and
irritation to him. They lower him in the public estimation and haunt
him like a specter for life, invariably visiting him whenever he
enters the premises of a court of justice as a witness or a party.
Being fraught with such serious consequences they should only be
made where any hesitation or reluctance in making them would
impede the ends of justice. Persons making or publishing such
remarks, whether true or not, are not liable for libel or for
defamation because in the former.case they are protected by
common law and in the latter by statute the reason being that unless
judges had the power to make bold and fearless comments on the
evidence given before them they would not be able to effectively
discharge their functions. These two conflicting considerations
must always be present to the mind of a judge whenever he is
called upon to criticize the character and conduct of a person (In
the matter of Mr. Hameed-ud-Din PLD 1950 Lah 34, 41 cited
with approval in Malik Feroz Khan Noon case - PLD 1958 SC
(Pak) 333, 359).
556
NO
It is also within the province of the power and duty of an
appellate court or revisional court to comment upon the judgment
or mode of trial adopted by a lower court judge. The degree of
sharpness that can be permitted in the comment would be
determined by the gravity of the irregularity or the injury resulting
there from. For, in all circumstances, the criticism offered would of
necessity fall within the requirements of the dispensation of justice.
But a judge should devote more than ordinary care to the
ascertainment of the facts on which his censure is to be founded for
"it is imperative that the criticism offered should not only be well
informed, but also that it should be well intentioned in a strictly
judicial sense". These are necessary conditions of anything said by
way of reproof or admonition in a solemn judicial pronouncement.
Any criticism directly diminishes the capacity of the judge, who is
criticized, to do justice in matters coming before him. Equally it
affects the standing of the court of which he is an integral part
(This statement of law is based upon the judgment of S. A.
Rehman, J, in Ali Nawaz v Muhammad Yousaf - PLD 1963 SC 51.
81, 82).
Delivery, language etc., of judgment
Chapter XXVI, sections 366 to 373 Cr.P.C. provide for
the mode of delivery of judgment. language of judgment and
contents of judgment etc.
By the trial court
The judgment in every trial in any criminal court of
original jurisdiction shall, so provides section 366 Cr.P.C, be
pronounced or its substance shall be explained in open court either
immediately after the termination of the trial or at some subsequent
time of which notice shall be given to the parties or their pleaders
in the language of the court or in some other language which the
accused or his pleader understands. The whole of the judgment
557
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 297
shall be read out by the presiding judge if he is requested so to do
by either of the parties; the accused shall if in custody be brought
up and if not in custody be required by the court to attend to hear
judgment except where his personal attendance has been dispensed
with and the sentence is one of fine only or he is acquitted in either
of which cases it may be delivered in the presence of his pleader.
Section 367 requires that every judgment shall be
written by the Judge or Magistrate or from his dictation in the
language of the court or in English. The judgment shall contain-
the points for determination;
i)
ii)
iii)
the decision thereon, that is to say, the
findings recorded on all the charges; and
reasons for the decision.
It shall be dated and signed by the Judge or Magistrate in
open court at the time of pronouncing it and where it is not in the
hand-writing of the Judge or Magistrate, every page of such
judgment shall be signed by him. A judgment shall specify the
offence of which and the section of the PPC or other law under
which the accused is convicted and the punishment to which he is
sentenced. Where the judgment is under the Pakistan Penal Code
and it is doubtful under which of two sections or under which two
parts of the same section of that Code, the offence falls, the court
shall distinctly express the same and pass judgment in the
alternative. If it is a judgment of acquittal, it shall state the offence
of which the accused is acquitted and direct that he be set at liberty.
If the accused is convicted of an offence punishable with death and
the court sentences him to any punishment other than death. the
court shall in its judgment state the reason why the sentence of
death was not passed.
Under section 368, when a person is sentenced to death,
the sentence shall direct that he be hanged by the neck till he is
dead.
Except as otherwise provided in the Code or any other
law for the time being in force, no court, when it has signed its
judgment, shall alter or review the same, except to correct a clerical
error. This is so provided by section 369 Cr.P.C.
Sections 366, 367 and 369 must be read together, with
the result that the 'Judgment" which is referred to in section 369
means a judgment which has been delivered, that is to say.
pronounced, in accordance with section 366. Delivering judgment
means pronouncing judgment (Amin Sharif v Syeda Khatoon -
PLD 1962 SC 97, 101). Thus, a verbal or oral announcement of
acquittal without writing and signing the judgment is a nullity, and
despite such announcement, the case was held to be pending
(Mehboob Ali v Qamar Ali 1972 SCMR 109); similarly a mere
writing and signing of a judgment of acquittal without pronouncing
it was also held to be of no legal erfect (Amin Sharif v Syeda
Khatoon PLD 1962 SC 97). Prohibition as to alteration becomes
operative only after it has been signed, and a judgment delivered
orally, without any note in writing duly signed by the judge, can be
altered (Rukan Din v Hafiz-ud-Din - PLD 1962 (WP) Lah. 161).
Under section 371, in every case where the accused is
convicted, a copy of the judgment shall be given to him at the time
of pronouncing the judgment free of cost. This does not apply to
cases tried summarily or where the accused is convicted of an
offence under any law other than the Pakistan Penal Code. When
the accused is sentenced to death by a Sessions Judge, such judge
shall inform him of the period within which if he wishes to appeal,
his appeal should be preferred. In cases tried by the Court of
Session, the court shall forward a copy of its finding or sentence to
the officer-in-charge of prosecution in the district.
558
559
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 298
Failure to sign the judgment when
pronounced-consequences:
What are the consequences when a judgment is
pronounced but is not signed by the trial court at the time of its
pronouncement as is required by section 367 Cr.P.C? Of course,
when a judgment has not been written and signed by the trial judge
or magistrate at the time of its pronouncement, its copy will not be
supplied to the convict as required by section 371 Cr.P.C. The
courts seem to have treated such an error or defect as a procedural
irregularity not affecting the merits of the case or the jurisdiction of
the court, unless it has occasioned a failure of justice.
This question arose in Firm Gokal Chand y Firm Nand
Ram (AIR 1938 PC 292), with reference to the corresponding
similar provisions in the Code of Civil Procedure. Lord Wright
speaking for the Privy Council observed:
"The rule (Order 41 CPC) does not say
that if its requirements are not complied
the judgment shall be a nullity. So
startling a result would need clear and
precise words. Indeed the rule does not
even state any definite time in which it
be fulfilled. The time is left to be defined
by what is reasonable. The rule from its
very nature is not intended to affect the
rights of the parties to a judgment. It is
intended to secure certainty in the
ascertainment of what the judgment was.
It is a rule which judges do so comply
with for that object. No doubt in practice
judges do so comply as it is their duty to
do. But accidents may happen. A judge
may die after giving judgment but before
he has a reasonable opportunity to sign
it. The court must have inherent
jurisdiction to supply such a defect. The
case of a judge who has gone on leave
before signing the judgment may call for
more comments, but even so the
inconvenience of the court and the
interest of the litigants must prevail. The
defect is merely an irregularity".
This case was followed by the Supreme Court of India in Iqbal
Ismail v State (AIR 1974 SC 1880) in which the question turned on
the provisions of sections 366 and 367 Cr.P.C, and was: can a
convicted person be said to be lawfully imprisoned if at the time of
his conviction the trial judge dictates the judgment but does not
sign the same because of its having not been transcribed? The
petitioner (it was a habeas corpus petition) was convicted under
sections 392 and 397 of the Penal Code and sentenced to 7 years in
prison. The judgment was pronounced on May 12, 1972, and its
copy was not supplied to the petitioner till February 19, 1973. This,
it was noted, was a "rather depressing state of affairs"; yet, the
defect was to be considered with reference to section 537 Cr.P.C.
which provided, inter alia, that no finding, sentence, or order
passed by a court of competent jurisdiction would be reversed or
altered on appeal or revision on account of any error, omission, or
irregularity... unless such error, omission, or irregularity had
in fact occasioned a failure of justice. It was held that the failure to
write and sign the judgment at the time of its pronouncement was a
procedural irregularity and that in the facts of the case, it had not
occasioned a failure of justice.
Confirmation of death sentence by High Court:
Chapter XXVII, sections 374 to 379, of the Code of
Criminal Procedure provide for submission of sentences for
confirmation. Sections 374 and 375 provide that when the Court of
Session passes the sentence of death, the proceedings shall be
submitted to the High Court and the sentence shall not be executed
unless it is confirmed by the High Court. If the High Court thinks
that further inquiry should be made into or additional evidence
taken upon any point bearing upon the guilt or innocence of the
561
560
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 299
convicted person it may make such inquiry or take such evidence
itself or direct it to be made or taken by the Court of Session. When
the inquiry is not made and the evidence is not taken by the High
Court, the result of such inquiry and the evidence shall be certified
to the High Court. The High Court, under section 376, may-
b)
confirm the sentence or pass any other
sentence warranted by law; or
may annul the conviction and convict the
accused of any offence of which the Sessions
Court might have convicted him, or order a
new trial on the same or any other charge, or
may acquit the accused person.
But no order of confirmation shall be made under this
section until the period allowed for an appeal has expired or if an
appeal is presented within such period, until such appeal is
disposed of. Section 377 requires that the confirmation of the death
sentence or any new sentence or order passed by the High Court
shall be made, passed and signed by at least two judges. When a
difference of opinion arises, the case shall be laid before another
judge and such judge after such hearing as he thinks fit shall
deliver his opinion and the judgment or order shall follow such
opinion. A copy of the order of the High Court in cases submitted
for confirmation shall without delay be sent to the Court of
Session.
Judgment of acquittal and question of compensation:
It has been seen that under section 367 Cr.P.C., if it is a
judgment of acquittal, it shall state the offence of which the
accused is acquitted, and direct that he be set at liberty.
In passing a judgment of acquittal, the provisions of
section 250 Cr.P.C. have to be kept in mind. That section provides
that if in any case instituted upon complaint or upon information
562
given to a police officer or to a Magistrate, the Magistrate acquits
the accused and is of opinion that the accusation against him was
false and either frivolous or vexatious, he may by his order of
acquittal call upon the informant or the complainant, as the case
may be, to show cause why he should not pay compensation to
such accused. The Magistrate shall record and consider any cause
which such complainant or informant may show and if he is
satisfied that the accusation was false and either frivolous or
vexatious, may, for reasons to be recorded, direct that
compensation to such amount not exceeding Rs.25.000/-, or if the
Magistrate is a Magistrate of 3 class, not exceeding Rs.2500/- as
he may determine, be paid by such complainant or informant to the
accused. The compensation payable under this section is
recoverable as arrears of land revenue. Further, this payment of
compensation will not exempt the complainant or the informant
from any civil or criminal liability. However, such compensation
shall be taken into consideration in any subsequent civil suit
relating to the same matter. Such an order is to be treated as an
appealable order, as if it were an order of conviction.
Convicting and sentencing - difference:
Conviction and sentence are two different things.
Conviction means to find guilty of an offence. Sentence is the
punishment awarded to a person convicted in a criminal trial.
Conviction is followed by sentence (Abdul Kabir v State 1990
PSC 1081). Only when a person has been found guilty of an
offence can the question of sentencing him arise. (This statement in
the author's book "Access to Justice in Pakistan" has been cited
with approval in the recent case of Shah Hussain v State PLD 2009
SC 460, 491). An order or judgment which merely says, e.g., that
the accused is sentenced to such and such imprisonment is not a
correct order or judgment. The correct order will be to say that the
accused is guilty and convicted of such and such offence and is
sentenced to such and such punishment.
563
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 300
Sentencing:
It is the requirement of fairness that the individual
knows not only what behaviour will be illegal but also what
punishment and penalty may be imposed for such behaviour. This
concept is reflected in the legal maxims Nullum Crimen Sine Lege
and Nulla Poena Sine Lege; the latter simply means that there shall
be 'no crime without punishment'. The prescribed punishment is,
therefore, an integral part of the crime.
We have seen in the Constitutional Criminal Procedure
part of this book that there are a number of constitutional
protections afforded to persons accused of crime during pre-trial
and trial phases. Only two of the protections are relevant to
punishment namely the protection against retrospective punishment
guaranteed by Article 13 of the Constitution and in a way, Article
14 thereof, in so far as it ensures inviolability of the dignity of man
in matters of punishment.
There can be no doubt that the consequences of a
sentence are of the highest importance; if too short, or of the wrong
type, it can deprive the law of its effectiveness and if too severe, it
can reinforce the criminal tendencies of the defendant. In America,
Congress enacted the Sentencing Reform Act of 1984; it classified
federal criminal offences and designated the sentencing range,
stated the purposes to be served by any sentence, established a
commission to promulgate guidelines, required judges to give
reasons for sentencing and for departing from the guidelines.
By the U.S. Amendment VIII, there is a prohibition
against excessive fines and cruel and unusual punishments. On the
question of unusual and cruel punishment, the Supreme Court has
upheld the death penalty, reasoning that-
"the Eighth Amendment's meaning must
be drawn from evolving standards of
decency: that although punishments
must not be excessive in form or severity
and must respect human dignity, the
564
legislature need not select the least
severe sanction available; that capital
punishment could be justified on
retributive and deterrent theories and
that a sentencing authority could impose
a death sentence if properly guided by
statutory standards" (Gregg v Georgia -
428 US 153-1976).
Some of the cases under the Due Process Clause make useful
reading. In Lockett v Ohio (438 US 586-1976), the contention
was that the death sentence awarded to the petitioner was invalid
because the statute under which it was imposed did not permit the
sentencing judge to consider, as mitigating factors, her character.
prior record, age, lack of specific intent to cause death. The
Supreme Court began by "recognizing that the concept of
individualized sentencing in criminal cases generally, although not
constitutionally required, has long been accepted in this country.
Consistent with that concept, sentencing judges have taken a wide
range of factors into account.... And where sentencing
discretion is granted, it generally has been agreed that the
sentencing judge's possession of-the fullest information possible
concerning the defendant's life and characteristics is highly
relevant, if not essential, to the selection of an appropriate
sentence". Although Legislatures remained free to decide how
much discretion in sentencing should be reposed in the judge or
jury in non-capital cases, as regards capital cases, Chief Justice
Burger in his opinion referred to Woodson, where it was held:
"in capital cases the fundamental respect
for humanity underlying the Eighth
Amendment...........requires
consideration of the character and record
of the individual offender and the
circumstances of the particular offence
as a constitutional indispensable part of
the process of inflicting the penalty of
death".

This declaration rested "on the predicate that the penalty of death is

"the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments
(the latter is Due Process Clause) require
that the sentencer, in all but the rarest
kind of capital case, not be precluded
from considering as a mitigating factor
any aspect of a defendant's character or
record and any of the circumstances of
the offence that the defendant proffers as

the established practice of individualized

profoundly different from all other
penalties, we cannot avoid the

decision is essential in capital cases. The
need for treating each defendant in a
capital case with that degree of respect
due the uniqueness of the individual is
far more important than in non-capital
cases.......
In Specht v Patterson (386 US 605-1967), the sentence could be

There is, in Pakistan, no statutory guidance available to

The cases from the American jurisdiction mentioned above can
hopefully provide some guidance. In that connection the
philosophy of the classical and positivist schools of criminology is
worth noticing. The classical school philosophy is largely
expressed in the notion that "the punishment should fit the crime"
and the positivist school theory shifts attention from the crime to
the criminal; it is that "the punishment should fit the criminal".
With this was born the idea that rehabilitation of the offender
should be the objective. Obviously, these two philosophies cannot
operate at the some time, and a compromise has to be struck. As
has been said in "Criminal Justice System" by Professors Hazel B.
Kerper and Jerold H. Israel, 2d ed., p 93-
"A statutorily prescribed maximum
punishment for the crime would be set
consistently with the classical viewpoint,
according to the harm done. However,
when it came to sentencing the
individual offender, consideration would
be given for the need to achieve
rehabilitation.
When discretion given to the court is so wide-ranging, as well as
so unguided and unfettered, one is reminded of what US Attorney
General (later Justice of the Supreme Court) Robert H. Jackson
said:
"It is obviously repugnant to one's sense
of justice that the judgment meted out to
an offender should be dependent in large
part on a purely fortuitous circumstance,
namely, the personality of the particular
judge before whom the case happens to
come for disposition".
An example is cases in which for an offence of killing under grave
and sudden provocation, under the old section 304 PPC, one judge
would impose the sentence of six months, another life
imprisonment.
No statute contains, and this is as true of PPC. a general
statement of the aims and objects which the sentencer should seek
to achieve, or is expressed in terms of the different theories,
although there may be references to "protection of the public' or
'prevention of crime" etc. However that may be, the concept of
punishment for homicide and the like offences as recognized in
Islam is relatable to none of the western theories. "It is manifold
wherein the main consideration is the fulfillment of God's will.
This, in turn, is conducive to the improvement, reformation and
preservation of good society. Regarding the citizens, while on the
one hand it serves as strong deterrent for the criminal, on the other,
