Page 303
expiation, which when fulfilled, qualify him for God's mercy.
it acts on his soul as a measure of repentance, reformation and
individual is not considered as an outsider. He, the criminal and the
Higher social goals are also achieved. In this behalf, the aggrieved
society all suffer on account of crime; when the aggrieved is
compensated, society also stands benefited. When the criminal
earns pardon from the aggrieved that too serves God's purpose.
wherein Divine attribute of mercy is involved, as also, picty' and
taqva' for the individuals. Thus looked at, the society gains, the
aggrieved individual is not ignored and the criminal's option for
reform is not stifled" (Muhammad Afzal Zullah, J. in Muhammad
Bashir v State PLD 1982 SC 139, 144).
Proportionality:
To put it in simple terms, the primary object is to fix a
sentence proportionate to the offender's culpability; this is
described as the tariff system (See Cross on "The English
Sentencing System 2d ed p.146). The doctrine of proportionality
requires a nexus between the punishment and the defendant's
blame-worthiness. The heart of the retribution rationale is that a
criminal sentence must be directly related to the personal
culpability of the criminal offender (See South Carolina v Gathers
-104 Ed 2d 876, in which these views have been expressed and
reiterated). As has been said, you cannot use a sledge-hammer to
crack a nut.
The doctrine of proportionality has been recognized in
England. For example, in R v Cunningham (1993) 2 All ER 15.
18), it has been held that the sentence must be commensurate with
the seriousness of the offence. It has been recognized also in
Pakistan (See inter alia, Zafar v State 1999 SCMR 2028 reiterated
in Muhammad Ilyas v Muhammad Sufian - PLD 2001 SC 465,
474; Farooq Ahmed Khan Leghari v Federation PLD 1999 SC 57,
192),
Judgment of conviction and question of compensation:
Under section 544A Cr.P.C. when a person is convicted
of an offence in the commission whereof death, or hurt, injury or
mental anguish or psychological damage to any person is caused or
damage to or loss or destruction of any property is caused, the
court shall, when convicting such person, unless for reasons to be
recorded in writing it otherwise directs, order the person convicted
to pay to the heirs of the person whose death has been caused, or to
the person hurt or injured or to the person to whom mental anguish
or psychological damage has been caused, or to the owner of the
property damaged, lost or destroyed, as the case may be, such
compensation as the court may determine having regard to the
circumstances of the case. The compensation payable under this
section is recoverable as arrears of land revenue and the court has
also power to order further that in default of payment or recovery.
the person ordered to pay such compensation shall suffer
imprisonment for a period not exceeding six moths or if it be a
court of the Magistrate of the 3rd class for a period not exceeding
30 days.
In addition to any sentence for the offence of which the
accused has been convicted, the provisions of section 250 Cr.P.C.
subsections (2B), (2C), (3) and (4) also apply to the payment of
compensation under this section.
For the purpose of determining compensation, the court
may, at the penultimate stage of the case, conduct an inquiry as to
what compensation should be awarded for the 'power to conduct
inquiry must be regarded as incidental or ancillary to the main
power exercisable under section 544A (State v Rab Nawaz - PLD
1974 SC 87, 99).
On some sentences under PPC:
As section 53 PPC says, imprisonment is of two
descriptions namely, rigorous that is with hard labour, and simple,
There are offences in the PPC which are punishable witn
570
571
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 304
imprisonment as well as fine. The usual formula adopted is to
provide the maximum term of imprisonment by saying, for
example, "which may extend to three years". Where the sentence is
death or life imprisonment, the rule is that death is the normal
penalty and life imprisonment is an exception (Noor Muhammad y
State 1999 SCMR 2722). As has been seen, by section 367,
subsection (5), if the accused is convicted of an offence punishable
with death and the court sentences him to life imprisonment, the
court must state the reasons why the sentence of death was not
passed. Where the sentence of fine is mandatory, the usual formula
adopted is to say that the offence shall be punished with
imprisonment and fine. Where the sentence of fine is in the
discretion of the court, the normal drafting formula in the PPC is to
say that the person convicted "shall also be liable to fine' (Koro v
State PLD 1963 Kar 256, Shamroz Khan v Muhammad Amir-
PLD 1978 SC 89).
For some offences imprisonment may be simple, for
some, both simple and rigorous and for some, rigorous only. When
an offence is punishable with imprisonment which may be of either
description, it is competent to the court under section 60 PPC to
direct "that such imprisonment shall be wholly rigorous, or that
such imprisonment shall oe wholly simple or that any part of such
imprisonment shall be rigorous and the rest simple".
Solitary confinement:
Rigorous imprisonment may, in the discretion of the
sentencing court, become solitary confinement. Section 73 PPC
empowers the court when passing the sentence of rigorous
imprisonment to order that the convict shall be kept in solitary
confinement for any portion or portions of the imprisonment to
which he is sentenced, subject to the limits mentioned in that
section and section 74 PPC. Solitary confinement means isolation
of the prisoner from human intercourse and society; it may lead to
a morbid state of mind in the convict and does frequently lead to
mental derangement. In view of its cruel nature and the
consequences that it may produce in the prisoner concerned, it has
572
been abandoned in the United Kingdom and it is no more
awardable as a punishment in that jurisdiction.
Solitary confinement is a serious deprivation (Saifuddin
v Federation of Pakistan PLD 1977 Lah. 1174; on this point also
see Begum Shamim Afridi v Province of Punjab PLD 1974 Lah.
120); it is an exceptional punishment and must be confined to most
exceptional circumstances such as in the case of a person guilty of
unparalleled atrocity or brutality (See AIR 1949 Mad. 386 and
Ramanjulu v State - AIR 1947 Mad. 381).
In this connection it is well to recall to mind the
provisions of Article 14 of the Constitution which inter alia
guarantees the dignity of man. This is one of the few fundamental
rights which are absolute in nature, and of which a person cannot
be deprived at all. There may, therefore, be a question as to the
constitutional validity of section 73. But apart from the question of
its constitutional validity, there can be no question that the power is
an exceptional power and must, therefore, be confined to
exceptional circumstances.
Probation of Offenders Ordinance 1960
It is important for the sentencing court to always have
before it the provisions of the Probation of Offenders Ordinance
1960 (the Ordinance). That Ordinance authorizes the courts
mentioned in section 3 thereof namely, the High Court, the Court
of Session and the Court of Magistrate of the first class to exercise
powers under this Ordinance. Under section 5 of the Ordinance the
court by which -
a)
a male person is convicted of any of the
offences mentioned therein, or
b)
any female person is convicted of any offence
other than an offence punishable with death
573
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 305
if it is of opinion, having regard to the circumstances, including the
nature of the offence and the character of the offender that it is
sentencing the person at once, to make a probation order, that is to
expedient to do so, for reasons to be recorded in writing, instead of
say, an order requiring him or her to be under the supervision of a
probation officer for such period not being less than one year or
more than 3 years as may be specified in the order.
Section 4 of the Ordinance applies where the offender is
not a previous convict of an offence punishable with imprisonment
for more than two years, and the court is of the opinion having
regard to the age, character, antecedents or physical or mental
condition of the offender and the nature of the offence or any
extenuating circumstances attending the commission of the
offence, that it is inexpedient to inflict punishment and that a
probation order is not appropriate, it may, after recording its
reasons, make an order discharging him after admonition, or if the
court thinks fit, it may make an order discharging him subject to
the condition that he executes a bond with or without sureties for
committing no offence and being of good behaviour during the
specified period. These powers may under section 8 also be
exercised by the court of appeal or revision.
The court to remain within its power
It is well to remember that for what is the punishment
for a particular offence, the section of the law which creates that
offence must be referred to; the punishment awardable for a
particular offence is one thing, and the punishment that the court
trying the offence is competent to award is another. Suppose that a
Magistrate of the First Class is trying an offence against section
406 PPC which is punishable with imprisonment of either
description for a term which may extend to seven years. But
because the offence is punishable with seven years' imprisonment
does not mean that the Magistrate is competent to sentence the
offender to seven years in prison. If he does so, he will exceed his
power and the sentence will be without jurisdiction.
Death Sentence
Where death is the only punishment, the court has no
discretion. Where death or life imprisonment is the sentence for the
offence, the court has a discretion and the doctrine of
proportionality should guide it. As has been seen, the normal
punishment in such a case is death. "This is to be awarded as a
matter of course except where the court finds some mitigating
circumstances which may warrant imposition of lesser sentence
namely imprisonment for life" (Noor Muhammad v State - 1999
SCMR 2722). The Supreme Court has, in recent years, taken
strong notice of "a kind of inhibition or hesitancy on the part of the
trial courts in awarding the normal penalty of death" and "of a
marked tendency....to find a laboured pretext to alter the
sentence of death to life imprisonment" (Muhammad Sharif v
Muhammad Javed PLD 1976 SC 452; relied and followed in
Muhammad Ilyas v Muhammad Sufian - PLD 2001 SC 265), and
also that "the people are losing faith in the dispensation of criminal
justice. It has accordingly been held in Muhammad Ilyas
v Muhammad Sufian (PLD 2001 SC 465, 473), and this is to a
large extent a departure from the views expressed in some previous
cases, that "no extenuating or mitigating circumstances such as
extreme youth, grave and sudden provocation or question of family
honour are available.... ..". This was a case in which murder
was said to have been committed under the influence of accused's
father; in Moazam Sheh v Mohsin Shah (PLD 2001 SC 458)
absence of immediate motive for commission of offence was used
in the High Court to reduce death to life imprisonment.
Aggravating and mitigating circumstances
Previous conviction is in some cases statutorily
recognized as an aggravating circumstance. Section 75 PPC
provides that if a person had been convicted of an offence
punishable under chapter XII or XVII thereof and sentenced to a
term of imprisonment of three years or more is again convicted of
an offence under those chapters he shall be liable to the enhanced
sentence of life imprisonment or imprisonment of ten years.
574
575
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 306
Under section 382C Cr.P.C. raising a scandalous or
frivolous plea in defence by the accused may be taken into
consideration and can be an aggravating circumstance.
Then, prevalence of a particular kind of offence, such as
abduction for ransom, is a circumstance which might require
severer punishment (R v Cunningham (1993) 2 All ER 15; State v
Farman Hussain-PLD 1995 SC 1).
Whether a circumstance is or is not an aggravating or
mitigating circumstance is a question to be determined on the facts
of cach case.
Offence for which maximum sentence is prescribed:
Where a maximum sentence of imprisonment or fine is
prescribed by using such expressions as "which may extend to
three yeas or with fine", the intention is to give discretion to the
sentencer and thereby to allow him room to maneuver so as to
impose the maximum in the worst kind of case.
Consecutive and concurrent sentences:
Section 35 Cr.P.C. provides for the sentences to run
concurrently or consecutively. When a person is convicted at one
trial of two or more offences, the court may, subject to the
provisions of section 71 PPC, sentence him for such offences to the
several punishments prescribed therefore which such court is
competent to inflict; such punishments when consisting of
imprisonment to commence the one after the expiration of the other
in such order as the court may direct, unless the court directs that
such punishment shall run concurrently. In other words, sentences
for two or more offences are to run consecutively, unless the court
directs that they shall run concurrently.
In case of consecutive sentences it is not necessary for
the court by reason only for the aggregate punishment for the
several offences being in excess of the punishment which it is
competent to inflict on conviction of a single offence, to send the
offender for trial before a higher court. [Sub-section (2) of Section
35). This is subject to the provise to sub-section (2) of section 35,
which provides that-
a)
b)
in no case shall such person be sentenced to
imprisonment for a longer period than 14
years;
if the case is tried by a Magistrate the
aggregate punishment shall not exceed twice
the amount of punishment which he is, in the
exercise of his ordinary jurisdiction.
competent to inflict.
Section 71 PPC which finds mention in sub-section (1)
of section 35 Cr.P.C. provides for the limits of punishment of an
offence made up of several offences. It enacts that where any thing
which is an offence is made up of parts, any of which parts is itself
an offence, the offender shall not be punished with the
imprisonment of more than one of such offences, unless it be so
expressly provided. It provides further that where any thing is an
offence falling within two or more separate definitions of any law
in force for the time being by which offences are defined or
punished, or, where several acts, of which one or more than one
would by itself or themselves constitute an offence. constitute.
when combined, a different offence, the offender shall not be
punished with a more severe punishment than the court which tries
him could award for any one of such offence.
Section 397 Cr.P.C. is also relevant in this context. That
section applies where a person already undergoing a sentence of
imprisonment is sentenced to imprisonment and provides that such
imprisonment shall commence at the expiration of the
imprisonment to which he has already been previously sentenced,
unless the court directs that the subsequent sentence shall run
concurrently with such previous sentence. The proviso to this

Scanned with CamScanner

Page 307
section makes an exception; it is that where a person who has been
committed to prison under section 123 Cr.P.C. in default of
furnishing security is, while undergoing such imprisonment,
sentenced to imprisonment for an offence committed prior to the
making of such order, the latter sentence shall commence
immediately.
Proviso to section 35(2) governs sentences passed
by Magistrates only:
It is now settled that-
(I)
(2)
the proviso (a) in sub-section (2) is a proviso
to sub-section (2) only and it is not a proviso
to sub-section (1) of section 35; and
sub-section (2), and its proviso (a), of section
35 of Cr.P.C. applies to the sentences passed
by courts of Magistrates and Assistant
Sessions Judges only; it does not apply to the
sentences passed by the High Courts and the
Sessions Judges and Addl. Sessions Judges.
(Bashir v State-PLD 1991 SC 1145).
Consequently, the decisions in cases such as Javed
Sheikh v State, (1985 SCMR 153) Jumma Khan v State, (1986
SCMR 1573), Muhammad Ittefaq v The State, (1986 SCMR 1627)
and Khanzaman v State, (1987 SCMR 1382), which applied.
section 35, sub-section (2), to sentences passed by Sessions Judges,
were not correctly decided. They were expressly over-ruled in
Bashir v State. The facts of one of the cases dealt with in Bashir v
State are sufficient to illustrate the point. Four persons were tried of
offences under sections 302, 326, 324 read with section 34 PPC.
They were all convicted of these offences by the trial court. Their
convictions were maintained by the High Court and then by the
Supreme Court. Thus, they stood convicted under section 302 read
with section 34 PPC and sentenced to life imprisonment, and under
section 326 read with section 34 and sentenced to 3 years' RI. The
578
Supreme Court while reducing the sentence of Bashir to life
imprisonment had maintained his sentence of imprisonment which
had been ordered to run consecutively and the sentence of fine. The
contention was that the consecutive running of his sentences was in
violation of proviso (a) to subsection (2) of section 35 Cr.P.C. The
contention was repelled and it was held that the proviso to sub-
section (2) of section 35 did not apply to sentences passed by the
Court of Session and the sentences were, therefore, lawful.
In the recent case of Shah Hussain v State (PLD 2009
SC 460), the petitioner was sentenced to 10 years' RI and
imprisonment for life on two counts. His sentences were ordered to
run consecutively. The aggregate sentence of the petitioner, so
observed the Supreme Court, "would thus come to sixty years.
which is contrary to the provisions of section 35 Cr.P.C. Proviso
(a) of section 35 prohibits the giving of consecutive sentences in
one trial beyond the period of 14 years". This issue, it was
observed further, was examined in Javed Sheikh v State (1985
SCMR SC 153).
It appears that the attention of the Supreme Court, in
Shah Hussain case, was not invited to the later case of Bashir v
State (PLD 1991 SC 1145), which case had expressly overruled
Javed Sheikh v State and other cases on the subject. As we have
noticed above, in Bashir v State, it was held that sub-section (2) of
section 35 applies to sentences passed by Magistrates and Assistant
Sessions Judges only; it does not apply to the sentences passed by
the Court of Session.
The sentences in Shah Hussain case were passed by the
Court of Session and according to the decision in Bashir v State
those sentences were not hit by section 35, sub-section (2). As
Bashir v State was not referred to or considered in Shah Hussain
case, it cannot, it is submitted, be said to have been overruled.

Sentence of fine:
There may be provisions which express a sum of money
to which a fine may extend; or, there may be previsions where no
sum of money is expressed to which a fine may extend. For
offences under the Pakistan Penal Code section 63 provides that
where no sum is expressed to which a fine may extend the amount
of fine to which the offender is liable is unlimited, but shall not be
excessive. The discretion in such cases is therefore subject to the
limitation that the court shall, while imposing the sentence of fine,
take account of the circumstances of the case including the
financial position of the offender, and see that the fine is not
excessive, that is, disproportionate to the offence committed.
When death is, by executive order, changed to
life imprisonment, Sections 35 and 397 do not apply.
It sometimes happens that death sentence awarded by
the court is subsequently, by an executive order, commuted into
life imprisonment. To such a situation neither section 35(1) nor
section 397 Cr.P.C. in terms applies, and the court cannot pass any
order with regard to its being concurrent or otherwise. In the
absence of any provision directly applicable to the case, the
sentence so commuted shall run concurrently and not
consecutively. (Bashir v State-PLD 1991 SC 1145, 1162).
For purposes of appeal, aggregate of consecutive
sentences is one sentence.
For the purpose of appeal the aggregate of consecutive
sentences passed under section 35 Cr.P.C. in case of conviction for
several offences at one trial shall be deemed to be a single
sentence.
The court may make preventive order when
passing a sentence:
Section 106 Cr.P.C. empowers the courts mentioned
therein to make, while recording conviction for offences stated
therein, orders of a preventive nature. If such a court is of the
opinion that the convict should execute a bond for keeping the
peace, it may, in addition to passing the sentence order him to
execute such a bond proportionate to his means for keeping the
peace for a period not exceeding three years. Similarly, under
section 565 Cr.P.C., if a person was convicted of any of the
offences mentioned therein and sentenced to three years or more in
prison and is again convicted and sentenced for any of such
offences, the court recording the conviction and sentence may also
order that his residence and any change of or absence from such
residence after release be notified as provided in section 565 for a
term not exceeding five years from the date of the expiration of
such sentence.
This power under sections 106 and 565 Cr.P.C. may also
be exercised by the appellate court.
Where sentence is imprisonment or fine:
Where the sentence prescribed for the offence is
imprisonment or fine, the court has discretion either to send the
convict to prison or to be content with imposing a sentence of fine
only. In such a case, the first question that the court should ask
itself is whether the convict should go to prison or not.
In imposing a sentence of fine again the gravity of
offence has to be kept in mind. In determining the amount of fine,
the court will also keep in mind the convict's capacity to pay; for to
impose fine beyond his capacity will make the discretion to impose
fine ineffectual; that does not however mean that a wealthy man
must pay heavy fine. In his case as also in the case of any other
person, the fine imposed must have relation to the gravity of the
580
581
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 309
offence. Thus, while incapacity to pay is a mitigating circumstance,
the main consideration is the gravity of the offence.
Period of detention during trial-section 382B Cr.P.C.
Section 382B provides: "Where a court decides to pass a
sentence of imprisonment on an accused for an offence, it shall
take into consideration the period, if any, during which such an
accused was detained in custody for such offence".
When this section was originally enacted the word "may"
was used; which meant the court had discretion to take or not to
take into consideration the pre-sentence period spent in detention.
The word 'shall' was substituted for the word 'may' by Ordinance
LXXI of 1979.
The rationale behind section 382B is the legislative
realization that -
"an accused person is entitled to be put
to trial or released on bail. If he is not to
be released on bail, he must be put to
trial. If for any reason the State is unable
to put him up for trial it is only fair that
during the period he is detained to await
his trial that period is taken into
consideration in computing the sentence
of imprisonment given to him. Another
point to be noted is that the provision
occurs in a criminal statute which
requires strict construction as far as it
imposes restrictions and punishments.
Beneficial provisions need to be
construed liberally. These are axiomatic
principles". (Qadir v State PLD 1991 SC
1065 cited in Javed Iqbal v State 1998
SCMR 1539 and again in the very recent
582
case Shah Hussain y State PLD 2009
SC 460).
After referring to the above noted cases and the fact that it was the
"hue and cry of the convict prisoners" that ultimately led to the
enactment of section 382B. Chief Justice Iftikhar Muhammad
Chaudhry, speaking for a six-Judge Bench in the very recent case
of Shah Hussain v State (PLD 2009 SC 460) observed:
"This was a new era in the area of
criminal law, which dealt with the
liberty of a person. Prior to it the time
spent by the convicts in custody for the
same offence would not be accounted for
in any way. Having waited for the
conclusion of their trials for months, and
in many cases for years together they
would re-enter the jail to serve out the
sentence imposed upon them. The
enactment of section 382B brought a
complete shift in the approach of the
court towards the issue of pre-sentence
period of a convict".
The learned Chief Justice went on to say:
The pre-sentence custody period
certainly called for a rational treatment.
which it got in the shape of section
382B"
The stage for the application of this section is when the
court decides to pass a sentence of imprisonment. This is the stage
when the court asks the crucial question: what length of sentence
shall be regarded as appropriate. When the court has asked and
answered that question then it shall take into consideration the
period during which the accused has remained detained in custody
for such offence during the trial. This is a beneficial provision and
583
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 310
has been liberally construed in favour of the accused. It has been
held that after the court decides to pass a sentence of imprisonment
on an accused, it shall, in the absence of special circumstances
disentitling the accused to have the sentence of imprisonment
reduced by the period spent in jail during the trial, exercise its
discretion in favour of the accused by ordering that that period
shall be counted towards his sentence of imprisonment or that the
sentence of imprisonment shall be treated as reduced by that
period. This may involve a balancing exercise between the public
and the private interests and also the consideration of such other
factors as the conduct of the accused, his antecedents, nature of the
offence etc. Indeed, the court will use its good sense in determining
the circumstances in which the discretion will not be exercised in
favour of the accused. But as the discretion is a judicial discretion.
the order of the court must show that the pre-sentence period has
been taken into consideration and if the court thinks that the
sentence should not be reduced by the period spent in prison during
the trial, the court must give reasons for so thinking. This is
necessary, among others, because (i) the court's discretion is liable
to be set right by the court of appeal and (ii) if justice is to be seen
to be done, the discretion which falls to be exercised by different
judges in different cases must manifest a reasonable consistency as
between one case and another (Muhammad Rafiq v State 1995
SCMR 1525; Mukhtiar-ud-Din v State 1997 SCMR 55 and
Ghulam Murtaza v State PLD 1998 S.C. 152).
The general practice is to make an order saying that the
accused shall or shall not have the benefit of section 382B. This
practice should be discouraged. The sentencing court must apply its
judicial mind to the facts of the case and give reasons for the order
that the accused is or is not entitled to have his sentence reduced by
the period spent in detention during the trial. The proper order to
make is to say that the sentence will be reduced by the period spent
in jail during the trial. (Fazal Karim J. in Muhammkad Rafiq v
State-1995 SCMR 1525).
The very recent landmark judgment in Shah Hussain v
State (PLD 2009 SC 460) considers questions under section 382B
584
for the first time as questions of public importance relating to the
enforcement of Fundamental Rights guaranteed by Articles 9 and
25 of the Constitution of Pakistan and sets many a controversy
surrounding that section at rest. Chief Justice Iftikhar Muhammad
Chaudhry speaking for a six-Judge Bench, revisited the provisions
of that section, and after a wide-ranging survey of almost the entire
body of case-law, including Javed Iqbal v State (1998 SCMR
1539), Muhammad Saleem v State (1996 PCr.LJ 1598), Ramzan v
State (PLD 1992 SC 11). Mukhtiar-ud-Din v State (1997 SCMR
55), Muhammad Rafiq v State (1995 SCMR 1525), Aamir v State
(2002 YLR 1902), Ghulam Murtaza v State (PLD 1998 SC 152).
Qadir v State (PLD 1991 SC 1065), held:
1. After the use of the word 'shall' for the word 'may' in
section 382B Cr.P.C., at the time of passing the
sentence, it is mandatory for the trial court (and when
the occasion arises, for the appellate and revisional
court) to take into consideration the pre-sentence
custody period in the light of the following principles:
(i)
(ii)
Ordinarily, in the absence of
special circumstances disentitling
the accused to have his sentence of
imprisonment reduced by the
period spent in jail during or before
trial, the court shall exercise its
discretion in favour of the accused:
to do so will promote the policy
and objects underlying section
382B.
The pre-sentence period spent in
jail was not spent in vain; nor can
such period be ignored on the
pretext that it was not so spent by
way of punishment. That will be a
play on the meaning of
'punishment'. Detention in jail is
deprivation of the very valuable
585
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 311
Fundamental Right of liberty
guaranteed by Article 9 of the
Constitution and that is certainly
punishment. The Article 9 right to
life and liberty is also available to
prisoners.
2. The refusal to take into consideration the pre-sentence
custody period at the time of passing the sentence is
illegal inasmuch as if the court sentences a convict to
imprisonment for life which is the alternate but
maximum sentence for the offence of murder, but does
not make allowance for the pre-sentence custody period,
it would be punishing the convict - prisoner with
imprisonment for life plus the pre-sentence custody
period, that is to say, more than the maximum legal
punishment.
3. The practical effect of reducing the sentence to the
extent of pre-sentence custody period, particularly the
way it is done in Pakistan, is that the sentence takes
effect from the date of the arrest of the convict in
connection with the offence for which he is sentenced.
" conviction follows proof of guilt of the convict,
which is relatable to the time of the commission of the
offence. Only its finding is reached on a subsequent
date. On proof of guilt, the presumption of innocence is
displaced and the convict is considered guilty of the
offence from the very inception i.e. from the date of
commission of the offence".
4. The under-trial prisoners, or criminal prisoners,
particularly those who are later convicted of the offence
in connection with which they were incarcerated, sooner
or later, join the ranks of convicted criminal prisoners. It
is discriminatory not to treat them at par with their co-
prisoners living in the same or similar premises, may be
under the same very roof. They are equal before law and
586
are entitled to equal protection of law under Article 25
of the Constitution. "The classification of criminal
prisoners and convicted criminal prisoners qua the
admissibility of remissions granted by any authority
where the court has passed an order granting the benefit
of section 382B Cr.P.C. does not meet the test of
'intelligent differentia' laid down in 1 A Sharwani v
Government of Pakistan (1991 SCMR 1041)".
5. The cases of convict - prisoners who are expressly
debarred under any law from the benefit of section 382B
Cr.P.C. stand on a different footing. For example, where
section 382B Cr.P.C. itself is not applicable, no
remission of the pre-sentence custody period can be
allowed to the prisoner in question".
Section 382B applies where a sentence of death has been
reduced to life imprisonment by the appellate court (Ramzan v
State PLD1992 SC II); Shah Hussain v State PLD 2009 SC 460).
It also applies where the sentence is life imprisonment. (Bashir v
State PLD 1991 SC 1145 and Qadir v State-PLD 1991 SC 1065).
Remissions and section 382B:
In Bashir v State (PLD 1991 SC 1145) it was held that
section 382B does not apply when the death sentence is reduced to
life imprisonment by an executive order, e.g. under Article 45 of
the Constitution, or Chapter XXIX of the Code of Criminal
Procedure. In Haji Abdul Ali case (PLD 2005 SC 163) Abdul Ali
was arrested on 24.7.1994 under section 302 PPC, but was, on trial,
acquitted by the Sessions Judge. On appeal, the High Court set
aside the acquittal, convicted him under section 302(b) PPC and
sentenced him to life imprisonment. "The benefit, as it is
commonly referred to of section 382B Cr.P.C. was extended to
him". Remissions granted by various authorities from time to time
including the remissions of the pre-sentence custody period were
recorded in his history ticket. This granting of remissions was
challenged before the High Court, and the High Court held that the
587
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 312
petitioner was not entitled to the remissions of his sentences for the
period prior to his conviction. In the Supreme Court, it was held:
the conviction and sentence of
an accused could not be made to run
from the date prior to the date of
conviction by a competent court
although in certain eventualities the
execution of sentence of a convict could
be postponed. Ordinarily a conviction
commences from the time it is passed. A
criminal court does not posses any
power to make a sentence to precede the
conviction. In other words, the
conviction and sentence cannot be ante-
dated........
As has been seen above, this view has not been approved in the
recent case of Shah Hussain v State. Therefore Haji Abdul Ali case
and the Human Rights case No.4115 if 2007 (PLD 2007 SC 71)
which followed Haji Abdul Ali case have ceased to be good law.
The law as laid down in Shah Hussain case now is that-
-
"The convict prisoners who are
granted the benefit of section 382B
Cr.P.C. shall be entitled to remissions
granted by any authority in their pre-
sentence detention or during their pre-
sentence detention in connection with
such offence. However, the same shall
not be available to the convicts of
offences under the National
Accountability Bureau Ordinance, 1999,
Anti-Terrorism Act, 1997, the offence of
Karo Kari etc. where the law itself
prohibits the same".
Orders relating to property subject matter of offence:
Section 517 Cr.P.C. provides that at the conclusion of
the enquiry or trial the court may make such order as it thinks fit
for the disposal by destruction, confiscation or delivery to any
person claiming to be entitled to possession thereof or otherwise of
any property or document regarding which any offence appears to
have been committed or which has been used for the commission
of any offence. Such an order is not to be carried out, except where
the property is subject to speedy and natural decay, for one month
or if an appeal has been filed till the disposal of the appeal. Section
519 provides for compensation to an innocent purchaser for value
of a thing subject matter of an offence.
Under section 522 Cr.P.C. the court has power, while
convicting a person of an offence of cheating, forgery etc., to direct
that the person dispossessed of any immovable property be restored
to the possession of the same. Such an order will be subject to the
right or interest that a person may be able to establish in a civil suit.
Section 522A Cr.P.C. empowers the court convicting a
person of an offence of criminal misappropriation of property or
criminal breach of trust or cheating etc., to direct that the person
dispossessed of any moveable property as a result of the
commission of such an offence be restored to its possession. This
order is also subject to the decision in a civil suit that may be
brought by any person to establish his right or interest in the
property.

PART VII
Appeals, Revisions, Review, Inherent Powers
Chapter 1
Appeals
General observations on right of appeal
It appears necessary to preface the provisions of the
Code of Criminal Procedure providing for appeals as contained in
Part VII thereof with the following general observations:
1.
An appeal does not exist in the nature of things; a right
of appeal from a decision of any tribunal or court must be given by
express provision. It must, therefore, be shown to exist before the
higher forum can claim to exercise it (See among others Hussain
Bakhsh v Settlement Commissioner PLD 1970 SC 1; Re - Racal
Communications Limited (1980) 2 All ER 634; Habib Bank v State
1993 SCMR 1583). Thus, if no appeal is provided by the
Constitution or law against the determination of a court or tribunal,
its decision is final (Rahim Shah v Chief Election Commissioner
PLD 1973 SC 24, 36).
provides:
Section 404 Cr.P.C. recognizes this principle; it
"No appeal shall lie from any judgment
or order of a criminal court except as
provided for by this Code or by any
other law for the time being in force".
The Code of Criminal Procedure itself provides
examples of cases in which no appeal lies. They are being deall
with below.
2.
Appellate jurisdiction, as distinguished from original
jurisdiction, is the jurisdiction of a higher court to review the final,
and in some cases interim judgment, order or decree of an inferior
court on the record made in the inferior court and to affirm, reverse
or modify such order, judgment or decree,
3.
Proceedings in appeal are a continuation of the original
proceeding where cause is reheard (Jamal Shah v Election
Commissioner PLD SC 1, 50). Rehearing is a technical expression
which does little more than entitle the appellate court to review the
facts as at the date when the appeal is reheard (Calvin v Carr -
(1979) 2 All ER 440).
4.
From the proposition that an appeal is a continuation of
the original proceeding, it follows that an appellate court would in
the absence of a contrary provision in the statute conferring the
appellate jurisdiction cannot claim higher and larger jurisdiction
than the original court and that an appellate authority exercises the
same powers as the original authority had under the relevant
enactment (Sabir Shah v Shad Muhammad Khan PLD 1995 SC.66.
143, 212; Rab Nawaz v State PLD 1994 SC 858, 866). Also, the
appellate court has ordinarily no power to pass an order on any
ground on the basis of which the original court could not have
proceeded under the relevant enactment (M.M. Isphahani Ltd. v
Muhammad Sultan - PLD 1961 SC 76).
5.
The scope and ambit of the appellate jurisdiction
depends upon the provisions of the law conferring the appellate
jurisdiction. Where the provisions conferring the appellate
jurisdiction are general and are not qualified by any limitation, the
appellate authority may set aside the order appealed against in its
entirety or may grant even partial relief depending upon the facts of
a particular case (Sindh Employees of the Social Security v
Adamjee Cotton Mills PLD 1975 SC 32).
Non-Appealable orders under Cr.P.C.
It has been seen that under section 404, no appeal lies
from any judgment or order of a criminal court except as provided
for by the Code or by any other law for the time being in force. The

Section 413 Cr.P.C. is subject to Article 185
of the Constitution:
Article 185 of the Constitution provides, by clause (2)
thereof, for cases in which an appeal to the Supreme Court lies as
of right, and by its clause (3), for cases not covered by clause (2).
but in which the Supreme Court may grant leave to appeal. For
example, an appeal lies, under sub-clause (c) of clause (2) of
Article 185, as of right against an order of a High Court "if the
High Court has imposed any punishment on any person for
contempt of the High Court". So, despite the provisions of section
413 which say that there shall be "no appeal by a convicted person
in cases in which a High Court passes a sentence of imprisonment
not exceeding six months or fine not exceeding two hundred rupees
only", an appeal, in a case covered by sub-clause (c) of clause (2)
of Article 185 of the Constitution, shall lie, as of right, to the
Supreme Court. Similarly, whatever the sentence of imprisonment
or fine awarded by the High Court, the Supreme Court may, in its
discretion, and despite the provisions of section 413 Cr.P.C.. grant
leave to appeal.
Scope of appeal-when accused pleaded guilty
Where an accused pleaded guilty and was convicted and
sentenced by a High Court, a Court of Session or a Magistrate of
the 1 Class on such plea, there is no appeal except as to the extent
or legality of the sentence.

Under section 420 Cr.P.C, a petition for appeal by a

Grounds of appeal
Under section 418.Cr.P.C. an appeal lies on a matter of
fact as well as a matter of law and severity of sentence is for the
purpose of this section a matter of law.
As an appeal lies both on a question of fact and a
question of law, this does away with the distinction, which assumes
importance in civil cases, between a question of law and a question
of fact.
When an appeal lies on a question of fact as well as on a
question of law, it means that the appellate court may interfere with
the order of the court below both on the ground that the decision of
the court below is wrong on a question of law and on the ground
that it is wrong on a question of fact.
Summary dismissal of appeal
When the petition of appeal is properly before the
appellate court, it shall pursue it and if it considers after affording
the appellate or his counsel a reasonable opportunity of being heard
in support of it, that there is no sufficient ground for interfering, it
may dismiss the appeal summarily. The court may do so after
summoning the record of the court below or without summoning it.
The words 'may dismiss the appeal summarily' can be
said to give discretion. But the discretion must be exercised like
any other judicial discretion to secure due and efficient
administration of justice and to inspire confidence in the mind of
596
the accused persons that their case has been treated with due care
and caution by the appellate court'. There may be cases which are
so clear and simple that nothing whatever can be urged in defence;
in such cases the appellate court may dismiss the appeal summarily
without giving reasons. But in cases which raise complicated
questions of fact and law an order of summary dismissal must
indicate in brief the reasons which led the court to reach the
conclusion that there was insufficient ground for interference
(Khalil v Crown PLD 1953 FC 133).
When the appeal is admitted for hearing
If the appeal is not dismissed summarily, the appellate
court shall, section 422 Cr.P.C. so ordains, give notice to the
appellant or his pleader and to the Public Prosecutor of the time
and place at which such appeal will be heard; and where the appeal
is under section 411A, subsection (2), or section 417 (that is, it is
an appeal against an order of acquittal) the appellate court shall
cause notice to be given to the accused.
The appellate court shall then send for the record of the
case (if it is not already there) and after perusing it and hearing the
appellant or his pleader, if he appears, and the Public Prosecutor, if
he appears, or in appeals against acquittal, the accused, if he
appears, shall, if it thinks that additional evidence is necessary.
record its reasons and may either take such evidence itself or direct
it to be taken by a Magistrate or when the appellate court is a High
Court, by a Court of Session, or a Magistrate. Such additional
evidence shall, section 423(1) and section 428 Cr.P.C. so provide.
ordinarily be taken in the presence of the accused or his pleader
and shall be certified to the appellate court. The appellate court
shall then proceed to dispose of the appeal.
As we shall see, there is no power in the appellate court
to dismiss an appeal under section 423 Cr.P.C. in default of
appearance. An appeal once admitted must be decided on its
merits.

Some important principles governing appellate powers
From the provisions of chapter XXXI, and its various
sections relating to appeals and from the decided cases the
following general principles emerge:
i)
Section 423 Cr.P.C. is, as regards the powers
of the appellate courts, self-contained and
exhaustive; that is to say, the appellate courts.
have only those powers as are expressly
conferred on them by that section or some
other provisions of law. They have no power
independently of them (9 Crl. L. J. 553; Zamir
Qasim v Emperor - AIR 1944 All 137, 141).
Thus-
a)
b)
there is under section 423 Cr.P.C.
no power to enhance a sentence
(Muhammad Aslam v State - PLD
1959 SC (Pak) 119);
an appeal under section 423 cannot
be dismissed in default of
appearance and the absence of the
appellant or his pleader does not
relieve the court of its duty of
perusing the record and disposing
of the appeal on merits giving
599
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 318
ii)

iii)
iv)
v)
reasons in support of the judgment
(Muhammad Ashiq Faqir v State
PLD 1970 SC 177; Asif Ali v State
PLD 1971 SC 223: Muhammad
Bakhsh v State 1986 SCMR 59).
The primary duty of the appellate court as
indicated by subsection (1) of section 423
Cr.P.C. is to consider the record before it and
to decide whether there is sufficient ground
for interfering. In considering that question,
what the court has to decide is whether there
has been a failure of justice in the sense that a
guilty man has been acquitted or an innocent
man has been convicted (Abdul Rahim v
Emperor AIR 1946 PC 82).
The words "after perusing such record"
manifest the intention that the proceedings in
appeal are a continuation of the original
proceedings where a cause is reheard. The
record will include the record of evidence
prepared under section 428 Cr.P.C.
The requirement of hearing the appellant or
his pleader is not of a merely directory
character. Just as a conviction following a
trial cannot stand if there has been a refusal to
hear the counsel for the accused so an
appellate order cannot stand where there has
been a refusal to hear the appellant's counsel.
Appellant or his counsel is entitled as of right
to be heard (Galos Hirad v King - AIR 1944
PC 93).
But the fact that the appellant or his counsel is
entitled as of right to be heard does not mean
that the appellant or his counsel may or may
600
not appear; nor is it a license to him to appear
or not to appear at will. This intention is made
clear by using the expression "if he appears".
Provided the appellant or his counsel has been
afforded an opportunity to be heard, the fact
that the appellant or his counsel does not avail
of the opportunity does not deprive the court
of its power to proceed to judgment (Asif Ali
v State PLD 1971 SC 223). Indeed, in doing
so, it must peruse the record and give reasons
for its conclusions.
When may the appellate court reverse a finding of fact
The principles which guide an appellate authority in
deciding whether to reverse the trial court on a question of fact,
were laid down by the Privy Council in Prem Singh v Deb Singh
(PLD 1947 PC 293). They are:
1.
2.
3.
Where a question of fact has been tried by a
Judge without a Jury and there is no question
of misdirection of himself by the Judge an
appellate court which is disposed to come to a
different conclusion on the printed evidence
should not do so unless it is satisfied that any
advantage enjoyed by the trial Judge by
reason of having seen and heard the witnesses
could not be sufficient to explain or justify the
trial Judge's conclusion.
The appellate court may take the view that
without having seen and heard the witnesses.
it is not in a position to come to any
satisfactory conclusion on the printed
evidence.
The appellate court either because the reasons
given by the trial Judge are not satisfactory or
601
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 319
because it unmistakably
so appears from the
evidence, may be satisfied that he had not
taken proper advantage of his having seen and
heard the witnesses and the matter will then
become at large for the appellate court.
Governing principles in acquittal appeals:
There was at one time difference of opinion in the
several Indian High Courts as to the scope of the appellate courts
power to reverse an order of acquittal on a matter of fact. That
controversy was set at rest by the Privy Council in Sheo Swarup v
King (AIR 1934 PC 227); it was held that sections 417, 418 and
423 give to the High Court full power to review at large the
evidence upon which the acquittal was founded and to reach the
conclusion that the order of acquittal should be reversed. There is
no limitation upon that power. But in exercising that power and
before reaching its conclusions upon fact, the High Court will
always give proper weight and consideration to such matters as-
i)
ii)
iii)
113)
the views of the trial court as to the credibility
of a witness;
the presumption of innocence in favour of the
accused, a presumption certainly not
weakened by the fact that he has been
acquitted at the trial;
the right of the accused to the benefit of any
reasonable doubt;
the slowness of an appellate court in
disturbing a finding of fact arrived at by a
Judge who had the advantage of seeing the
witnesses.
These principles were reaffirmed by the Privy Council in Noor
Muhammad case (AIR 1945 PC 151), and have been adopted and
602
followed in Pakistan (See for example Abdul Majid case -
1964 SC 422).
Right to withdraw the appeal:
PLD
So far as an appeal by a convicted person is concerned,
he is as much at liberty to withdraw it as he was at liberty to file it
and in such cases the obvious duty of the appellate court is to
dismiss the appeal. If, however, the appellate court considers that
an order or finding should be set aside or a retrial ordered or the
sentence enhanced, the proper course for it is to act on the
revisional side. This is on the principle that an appeal is the
creation of statute and a convicted person is not bound to appeal.
There is, therefore, no general principle which stands in the way of
his withdrawing the appeal. If he can accept the finding and the
sentence by electing not to appeal, there is no reason why the mere
fact of his having filed an appeal should, in the absence of a
principle akin to estoppel, be considered to be a bar to his
subsequently waiving the right (Muhammad Aslam v State PLD
1959 SC (Pak) 119). Cases taking the contrary view such as Crown
v Ghulam Muhammad (ILR (1942) 23 Lah 241 F.B) should.
therefore, be taken to stand over-ruled.
Death of accused - its effect on appeal:
Under section 431 Cr.P.C. an appeal against acquittal
under section 411A(2) or section 417 finally abates on the death of
the accused and every other appeal under Chapter XXXI, except an
appeal from a sentence of fine, finally abates on the death of the
appellant.
Delivery of Judgment by appellate court:
Section 424 Cr.P.C. provides that the rules contained in
Chapter XXVI Cr.P.C. as to the judgment of a criminal court of
original jurisdiction apply, so far as may be practicable, to the
judgment of any appellate court other than a High Court, and the
preceding discussion may, in that behalf, be referred to.
603
15
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 320
As regards the judgments by the High Court, Rules and
Order of the High Court, Volume V, Chapter 4-H, are relevant.
Appeal to Supreme Court:
The Constitution itself provides for appeals to the
Supreme Court. Under Article 185, clause (2), of the Constitution,
in so far as relevant, an appeal shall lie to the Supreme Court from
any judgment, final order or sentence of a High Court-
(a)
(b)
(c)
(d)
if the High Court has on appeal reversed an
order of acquittal of an accused person and
sentenced him to death or imprisonment for
life; or on revision, has enhanced a sentence
to a sentence as aforesaid;
if the High Court has withdrawn for trial
before itself any case from any subordinate
court and has in such trial convicted the
accused person and sentenced him as
aforesaid;
if the High Court has imposed any
punishment on any person for contempt of the
High Court; or
if the High Court certifies that the case
involves a substantial question of law as to the
interpretation of the Constitution.
An appeal to the Supreme Court in other cases is not as a
matter of right; such an appeal lies, as clause (3) of Article 185
provides, only if the Supreme Court grants leave to appeal.
Under Article 187(1) of the Constitution, the Supreme
Court has power to issue such directions and orders, enforceable
throughout Pakistan as may be necessary for doing complete
justice in any pending case or matter.
604
Preliminary observations
Chapter 2
REVISIONS
While an appeal is a continuation of the original
proceedings and if it is given by statute, ordinarily it carries with it
the right of oral hearing, a revision is simply an examination of the
matter for the purpose of seeing the propriety and legality of the
orders of the subordinate and inferior authorities and it does not
carry the same incidents as are peculiar to appeal. Also, a revision
is not, like an appeal, a matter of right (Adnan Afzal v Sher Afzal
PLD 1969 SC 187, 193).
The extent of a revisional jurisdiction depends upon the
statute conferring it. The classical and the most well known
revisional jurisdictions are those conferred by the Code of Civil
Procedure 1908, by its section 115, and by the Code of Criminal
Procedure 1989, by its sections 435, 439 and 439A. It is not
necessary to compare the two jurisdictions; suffice it to say that the
scope of the revisional powers under sections 435, 439, 439A
Cr.P.C. is much wider. Under those sections, the High Court and
the Sessions Court can, not only, consider the legality but also the
correctness and even the propriety of any sentence or order of an
inferior court as also the regularity of the proceedings of such a
court. In other words, it can, not only go into the evidence and.
reverse the finding of fact, but can even consider the propriety of
an order or the propriety of adopting a particular procedure (Abdul
Rehman Bajwa v Sultan PLD 1981 SC 522).
Revisional powers are generally discretionary powers.
Section 439 Cr.P.C. expressly says that the High Court "may in its
discretion" exercise all or any of its revisional powers and as
regards the Sessions Judges, section 439A expresses the same
intention by using the word 'may'.
605
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 321
Revisional powers under Code of Criminal Procedure:
Section 435 to 440 of Chapter XXXII Cr.P.C. deal with
the revisional powers of the High Court and the Court of Session.
These sections must be read together.
Under section 435 Cr.P.C., the High Court or any
Sessions Judge may call for and examine the record of any
proceeding before any inferior criminal court within its territorial
jurisdiction for the purposes of being satisfied as to the correctness,
legality or propriety of any finding, sentence or order recorded or
passed, and as to the regularity of any proceedings of such inferior
court. When calling for such record, the High Court, or as the case
may be, the Sessions Judge, may suspend the execution of any
sentence and may release the accused on bail or on his own bond
pending examination of the record.
Under section 438, an Additional Sessions Judge may
exercise all the powers of a Sessions Judge under Chapter XXXII
in respect of any case which may be transferred to him by or under
any general or special order of the Sessions Judge.
The expression "inferior criminal court" seems to have
been used in order to avoid the use of 'subordinate which
expression had been used in the predecessor section namely section
295 of the Criminal Procedure Code 1872. The expression "inferior
criminal court" refers to a court of which the High Court or the
Sessions Judge proceeding under section 435 is the appellate court.,
From this it follows that there may be inferiority without
subordination but there cannot be subordination without inferiority
(Muhammad Hafeez v State PLD 1981 SC 352, 355). In Abdul
Hafeez v State (PLD 1981 SC 352), the question was whether a
Drug Court established under the Drugs Act 1976 was a criminal
court inferior to the High Court and whether the High court was
competent to hear a revision petition against that court's order. The
High Court was, in respect of the orders of the Drug Court, the
appellate court and it was held that it was, for the purposes of
section 435 Cr.P.C., an inferior criminal court.
The explanation to section 435 says that all Magistrates
shall be deemed to be inferior to the Sessions Judge for the
purposes of section 435.
Thus, the courts of Sessions Judges, Additional Sessions
Judges and the courts of Magistrates are all criminal courts inferior
to the High Court and all Magistrates are criminal courts inferior to
the Court of Session.
It will be noticed that section 435 Cr.P.C. by itself gives
no power to set right errors, illegalities or irregularities. The
machinery for sc doing is provided by sections 436 to 440 Cr.P.C.
By section 439A, the Sessions Judge has the same
powers of revision, as regards the orders or proceedings of
Magistrates, as the High Court has under section 439 Cr.P.C.
Thus, the power of revision of the High Court and the
Court of Session, as regards the orders and proceedings of
Magistrates, is concurrent power. The general principle is that
where two courts have concurrent jurisdiction and one of such
courts happens to be a superior court to which an appeal lies from
the other court of concurrent jurisdiction then the superior court
will not normally entertain an application for revision which the
applicant could have made to the other court, in this case the Court
of Session (Muhammad Yasin Khan v State 1983 PCLJ 27:
Muhammad Ehsan v State PLD 1968 Lah. 451; Muhammad
Farooq v Riaz Ehsan Khan PLD 1960 Kar. 42: Ghulam
Muhammad Jafar v Crown-PLD 1952 Bal. 25).
Revision against orders under Sections 203, 204(3)
and 119 Cr.P.C:
On examining any record under section 435, or
otherwise, the High Court or Sessions Judge may order further
inquiry-
606
607
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 322
(a)
(b)
into any complaint which has been dismissed
under section 203 or section 204 subsection
(3) Cr.P.C;
into any proceeding in which order of
discharge or release has been made under
section 119 Cr.P.C.
Powers of revision of High Courts and Sessions Courts
in other cases:
Where the record of any inferior criminal court has been
called by itself or which otherwise comes to its notice, the High
Court or the Court of Session may, in its discretion, exercise any of
the powers conferred on a court of appeal by sections 423, 426, 427
and 428 Cr.P.C. In one important respect, the revisional power is
wider, namely, the revisional court may, but the appellate court
may not. enhance the sentence.

and Sessions Court:
The revisional power of the High Court and the Court of
Session is subject to the following restrictions:
i)

for the offence which in the opinion of such

Magistrate of 1" class;
under subsection (4) of section 439 Cr.P.C.
the revisional court cannot convert a finding

where an appeal lies and no appeal is brought

revision lies against appealable orders or
judgments;
under subsection (4)(b) of section 439 Cr.P.C.
no further revision lies to the High Court
against an order of the Court of Session made
in the exercise of its revisional jurisdiction
under section 439A Cr.P.C.
Right of hearing before the revisional court:
No party has, section 440 Cr.P.C. so provides, any right
to be heard either personally or by pleader before any revisional
court. To this general rule there are the following exceptions:
i)
ii)
Section 439(2) provides that no order can be
made to the prejudice of the accused unless he
has had an opportunity of being heard either
personally or by pleader in his own defence.
The court may, if it thinks fit, hear any party
either personally or by pleader. In other
words, the revisional court has a discretion to
afford hearing to the parties.
When a convicted person has been given an opportunity under
subsection (2) of section 439, of showing cause why his sentence
should not be enhanced, he is entitled also to show cause against
his conviction.
As we have seen in the Constitutional Criminal
Procedure part of this book, hearing includes the right of hearing
608

Scanned with CamScanner

Page 323
by counsel. Therefore, if a petitioner wants to be heard through
counsel, his right to do so will be respected.
Chapter 3
Review
Like an appeal and revision, power to review is a statutory power
and must be expressly conferred by law, and unless it is so
conferred, no court or authority can exercise it.
Section 369 CrPC provides:
"Save as otherwise provided by this
Code or by any other law for the time
being in force, or in the case of a High
Court by the Letters Patent of such High
Court, no court, when it has signed its
judgment, shall alter or review the same
except to correct a clerical error".
Thus, unless there is a provision in the Code or any other law,
expressly conferring the power, a judgment on a criminal case once
signed by the court which had delivered it, cannot be altered or
reviewed by that court except to correct a clerical error. A clerical
error may be corrected by the court suo motu or on the application
of a party. In truth, the power to correct a clerical error is not.
strictly speaking, a power of review. It is a power to correct
mistakes "due to human forgetfulness and not involving a mental
process of reasoning in the application of any law or the facts
already proved or admitted." (Muhammad Tufail v Abdul Ghafoor
-PLD 1958 SC(Pak) 201, 205).
There are two well-recognized exceptions, vouched by
high and respectable authority to the general rule that power to
review does not exist unless it is expressly conferred by law,
namely-
(1) a court has inherent jurisdiction to set aside a judgment
or order which it had delivered without jurisdiction
(Kofi Forfi v Seifah- (1958) 1 All ER 289); and
(2) a court or authority has the power to review an order or
judgment obtained by fraud. (Ali iqtidar v Custodian -
PLD 1964 Lah. 274; Chief Election Commissioner v
Muhammad Fazil - PLD 1975 SC 331). The reason is
that a fraud vitiates the most solemn proceedings.
(Muhammd Fazil case.)
Chapter 4
Inherent powers of the High Court:
Section 561A of the Code of Criminal Procedure reads:
"Saving of inherent power of High Court: Nothing in
this Code shall be deemed to limit or affect the inherent
power of the High Court to make such order as may be
deemed necessary to give effect to any order under this
Code, or to prevent abuse of the process of any court or
otherwise to secure the ends of justice".
This section was enacted in 1923. At that time, the concept of
'inherent jurisdiction' was well-known. As was observed by Fazal
Karim J. in Sardar Ali v State (PLD 1987 Lah. 633)-
"The concept of inherent jurisdiction is a
concept of the law of England, where
there is no written constitution. There,
most of the jurisdiction which the courts
exercise, including the supervisory
jurisdiction of the High Court to issue
writs, is inherent jurisdiction. It appears
therefore that section 561A was enacted
under the influence of the English
(common) law".
610
611
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 324
Section 561A is, as was noticed in Sardar Ali case, "one
of the most frequently invoked as also one of the most debated
provisions of the Code of Criminal Procedure. Therefore, since its
enactment in the year 1923, there has naturally grown a large and
respectable body of case-law around it".
To the many controversies that have bedeviled the
discussion of section 561A, two more, and both are serious, must
needs be added. They are about the constitutional validity of this
section; and its justification for continued existence.
Whatever be the position in England, in a country
governed by a written constitution, as Pakistan is, a court has only
such jurisdiction as is conferred on it by the constitution or statute
law. Article 175. clause (2) of the Constitution of Pakistan
expressly so provides:
"No court shall have any jurisidicition
save as is or may be conferred on it by
the Constitution or by or under any law".
As was pointed out in Sardar Ali case, the question is that if the
only source of jurisdiction be the Constitution and the statute law,
and if no court has any jurisdiction other than the jurisdiction
expressly conferred on it by the Constitution or the law, then can a
court claim to have inherent jurisdiction. In other words, the
question is whether the assumption which was the basis of section
561A when it was enacted in the year 1923 is still valid in view of
Article 175 of the Constitution?
This question was not finally decided in Sardar Ali case;
yet, the matter is, it was observed, not wholly destitute of judicial
authority. Reference was in that behalf made to Sind Employees
Social Security v Adamjee Cotton Mills (PLD 1975 SC 32) and
Shahnaz Begum case (PLD 1971 SC 677, 687). In the first, it was
expressly ruled that the claim to inherent jurisdiction is no longer
tenable in view of Article 175(2) of the Constitution, and in the
second, it was held that so far as the High Courts are concerned,
they have no powers other than those conferred upon them by the
Constitution or by any law.
One way to save section 561A Cr.P.C. from invalidity is
to read "inherent power" in that section in the sense of ancillary or
incidental. "Inherent powers" and "incidental and ancillary power"
are not to be confused the one with the other. When a statute grants
power or jurisdiction, it also impliedly grants powers which are
reasonably incidental or ancillary to the main jurisidiciton and the
fact that there is no express provision in the statute enabling the
court to exercise such powers does not negative their existence.
(Commissioner Khairpur Division v Ali Sher Sarki, PLD 1971 SC
242, citing Maxwell on the Interpretation of Statutes, 1962 ed). On
the other hand, what is inherent is an inseparable incident of a thing
or an institution in which it inheres. (Adamjee Cotton Mills case-
PLD 1975 SC 32, 36). As has been said by I. H. Jacob, the source
of inherent jurisdiction of the court is derived from its nature as a
court of law. (See Current Legal Problems 1970 at p 23). Yet, as
was demonstrated in Sardar Ali case the expressions 'inherent
power' and 'incidental or ancillary power' are frequently used
interchangeably. It is therefore reasonably possible, as was
suggested in Sardar Ali case, to read 'inherent' in section 561A
Cr.P.C. in the sense of ancillary or incidental.
Some well-settled propositions:
Some well settled propositions of law to be gleaned from
cases decided by the courts may be stated as follows:
1.
Section 561A does not confer inherent
jurisdiction upon the High Court. It does not
confer any powers but only indicates that
there is a power to make such orders as may
be necessary for the purposes mentioned
therein. (Mardan Shah v Sattara - PLD 1954
Lah. 87; Sardar Ali v State, PLD 1987 Lah.
633,642).
612
613
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 325
2.
3.
The inherent jurisdiction given by section
561A is not an alterative or an additional
jurisdiction. Nor has it given increased powers
to the High Court. It is a jurisdiction
preserved in the interest of justice to redress
grievances for which no other procedure is
available or has been provided by the Code of
Criminal Procedure itself. (Emperor v
Khawaja Nazir Ahmed - AIR 1945 PC 18, 22
and Ghulam Muhammad v Muzammil Khan-
PLD 1967 SC 317). What is preserved by
section 561A is the power "to meet a lacuna
in the Criminal Procedure Code in
extraordinary cases" and not to vest the High
Courts with powers to make any order that
they are pleased to consider to be in the
interest of justice. These powers are as much
controlled by principles and precedents as are
any express statutory powers. (Ghulam
Muhammad case, at p 324).
The power under section 561A can certainly
not be so utilized as to interrupt or divert the
ordinary course of criminal procedure; it is
generally accepted that the inherent
jurisdiction should not normally be invoked
where another remedy is available. (Ghulam
Muhamad case; also Khawaja Fazal Karim v
State PLD 1976 SC 461; A. Habib Ahmed
case PLD 1992 SC 353). Thus, the High
Court would not normally exercise its power
to quash criminal proceedings under section
561A unless the trial court's power under
section 249A or 265K, as the case may be, has
first been invoked. Incidentally, these
provisions are "of the same nature and in a
way akin to and co-related with quashment of
proceedings as envisaged under section 561A
614
Cr.P.C." (Asif Ali Zardari case-1994 SCMR
798). Nor would the remedy under section
561A be available, where the remedy of
revision under section sections 435 and 439
Cr.P.C., a much wider power, is available.
(Muhammad Samee Ullah Khan case PLD
1963 SC 237).
4.
i)
ii)
The inherent powers which section 561A
saves are-
power to make an order that is
necessary to give effect to any
order of the court; this is obviously
in the nature of ancillary or
incidental power. (Sardar Ali case,
P 646);
power to prevent abuse of process
of any court or otherwise to secure
the ends of justice. The word
"abuse' is a strong word. It can only
be in a rare case that the High
Court would deem it appropriate to
act so as to place an alleged offence
outside the operation of the
criminal law, on incidental
grounds, such as that of delay or for
any reasons other than reasons
going to the question whether the
allegation is sufficient to constitute
an accusation of an offence in law.
To quash a judicial proceeding in
order to ensure the ends of justice
would involve a finding that if
permitted to continue the
proceeding would defeat the ends
of justice or would either operate or
615
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 326
perpetuate an injustice. To find an
abuse, it would be necessary to see
in the proceedings a perversion of
the purpose of the law such as to
cause harassment to an innocent
party, to bring about undue delay
etc. (M. S. Khawaja v State - PLD
1965 SC 287).
The words 'justice' in the phrase "ends of
justice", it was held in Shahnaz Begum case
(PLD 1971 SC 677). necessarily means
justice as administered by the courts and not
justice in the abstract sense of justice
administered by other agencies.
The words "otherwise to secure the ends of
justice" also have to be read subject to the
well-known nositur a sociis nule namely that
when two or more words which are
susceptible of analogous meaning are coupled
together, they are understood to be used in
their cognate sense. (Sardar Ali case, p 646-
7). As was said in Shahnaz Begum case (at p
693), these words have to be read along with
the earlier objects mentioned in this section
and must have some co-relation with them;
they must have reference to the purposes
which the judicial process is intended to
secure "(also sec M. S. Khawaja v State
- PLD 1965 SC 287).
5.
As the words "ends of justice" have
reference to the purposes which the
judicial process is intended to secure, "it
is difficult to include actions of the
investigation agencies within the scope
of judicial process". In other words,
616
6.
actions during the investigation stage of
an offence are not amenable to the
jurisdiction under section 561A Cr.P.C.
(Emperor v Khawaja Nazir Ahmed
AIR 1945 PC 18; M.S. Khawaja case;
also Sardar Ali case at page 647).
The power under section 561A is not in
the nature of, or as wide as, the power of
revision or appeal. An order within
jurisdiction cannot be described as an
abuse of the process of the court. There
is a trite saying that the power to decide
includes the power to decide wrong as
well as right (Lord Hobson in Malkarjun
v Narhari (1900) 23 Bom. 337 PC; A.
Habib Ahmed case - PLD 1992 SC 353.
362). A wrong decision cannot therefore
engage the power under section 561A
Cr.P.C.
A proposal for Law Reform:
Apart from the constitutional validity of section 561A
Cr.P.C., a more vital question is as to the justification and need for
the continued existence of that section.
Criminal justice system in Pakistan is known to be a
system of too many remedies. There are the statutory remedies of
appeal and revision. Then there are sections 249A and 265K
Cr.P.C., which, as we have seen, are of the same nature "and in a
way akin to and co-related with the quashment of proceedings as
envisaged under section 561A Cr.P.C." (Asif Ali Zardari case-
1994 SCMR 798, cited in Muhammad Khalid Mukhtar v State-
PLD 1997 SC 275). More remedies, particularly those which
interrupt or divert the ordinary course of criminal procedure
provided in the procedural statutes, must necessarily occasion more
delays in the decision of the criminal cases. A. Habib Ahmed case
617
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 327
(PLD 1992 SC 353) provides a striking example. There it was
noticed by Muhammad Afzal Zullah CJ that if the High Court had
allowed the trial court, without interrupting the normal course of
the case, to proceed with it, then "in that eventuality it would have
taken few weeks or at the most few months, while in the present
situation where the normal course has been deflected by the High
Court the time that has already been consumed is about four years.
Such like inherent and consequential elements in the interference
by the High Court, as has been demonstrated in this very case", so
held the learned Chief Justice, "instead of advancing the cause of
justice sometimes prove counter productive".
A. Habib Ahmed case was a case under Article 199 of
the Constitution, but the ratio of that case, it is submitted, applies
equally, if not more forcefully, to cases under section 561A Cr.P.C.
Be that as it may, now that Article 199 of the
Constitution provides a speedier and higher remedy to do justice
and to prevent abuse of the process of the court, there seems to be
hardly any need or justification for a provision like section 561A to
remain on the statute book. This provision, we reckon, cannot
conceivably provide a more efficacious remedy, in a proper case,
than the constitutional remedy under Article 199.
repealed.
We propose therefore that section 561A may be.

PART VIII
MISCELLANEOUS
Chapter 1
SPECIAL PROCEEDINGS UNDER THE CODE OF
CRIMINAL PROCEDURE AND OTHER LAWS
Relating to lunatics
Two questions can arise as to a person of unsound mind:
i)
ii)
whether he was at the time of the offence
alleged to have been committed by him, by
reason of unsoundness of mind, incapable of
knowing the nature of the act or that he was
doing what was either wrong or contrary to
law; and
whether the accused is of unsound mind at the
time of trial or inquiry.
As regards the first question, section 84 PPC says:
"Nothing is an offence which is done by a person who, at the time
of doing it, by reason of unsoundness of mind, is incapable of
knowing the nature of the act, or that he is doing what is either
wrong or contrary to law". Under sections 469 and 470 Cr.P.C., if
the Court of Magistrate or the Court of Session or the High Court
finds that the accused was of unsound mind at the time of the
commission of the offence, it shall acquit him upon that ground but
the finding shall state specifically whether he had committed the
act or not.
As regards cases falling under the second category.
namely whether the accused is of unsound mind at the time of the
inquiry or trial, sections 464 and 465 Cr.P.C. require the court of
the Magistrate, the Court of Session or as the case may be, the
High Court, to try the fact of such unsoundness and if it is satisfied
of the fact, it shall record a finding to that effect and shall postpone
619
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 328
further proceedings in the case. The court may release such person
on bail, or if it is a case in which in the opinion of the court bail
should not be taken or sufficient sureties are not given, the court
shall order the accused to be detained in safe custody in such place
and manner as it may think fit and shall report the action taken to
the Provincial Government, Section 466 Cr.P.C. provides that no
order for the detention of the accused in a lunatic asylum shall be
made otherwise than in accordance with such rules as the
Provincial Government have made under the Lunacy Act 1912,
Indeed, if the accused is subsequently found to be capable of
making his defence then section 468 Cr.P.C. permits the inquiry or
trial to proceed.

of justice
Chapter XXXV, sections 476 to 487 Cr.P.C., make

The offences mentioned in clause (b) of subsection (1)

It has been seen that under Chapter XXII, section 262

b)

if the court is the High Court, a Court of

or a District Court, it may pass any sentence

The procedure for a case in which the court considers

Section 480 Cr.P.C. provides for summary trial of cases

(omission to produce document by a person legally bound to

But if the court thinks that for the reasons stated in

Section 484 Cr.P.C. empowers the court to discharge the

Under section 486 Cr.P.C. appeals against convictions in

Section 487 Cr.P.C. emphasizes that the provisions of

committed before himself or in contempt of his authority or is
brought under his notice as such Judge or Magistrate in the course
of judicial proceedings.
