Cr.P.C.
Remedy in the nature of Habeas Corpus under
There are three provisions in the Code of Criminal
Procedure providing for a remedy in the nature of habeas corpus.
They are sections 100, 491 and 552.
Under section 100 if a Magistrate of the first class has
reason to believe that any person is confined under such
circumstances that the confinement amounts to an offence, he may
issue a search warrant and the person to whom such warrant is
directed may search for the person so confined; and such search
shall be made in accordance therewith, and the person, if found,
shall be immediately taken before a Magistrate, who shall make
such order as in the circumstances of the case seems proper.
Under section 552, a Session Judge may, upon
complaint on oath of the abduction or unlawful detention of a
woman or of a female child under the age of 16 years for any
unlawful purpose, may make an order for the immediate restoration
623
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 330
of such woman to her liberty, or of such female child to her
husband, parent or other person having the lawful charge of such
child and may compel compliance with such order using such force
as may be necessary.
Section 491 Cr.P.C. empowers the High Court,
whenever it thinks fit, to direct, among others, that -
a)
b)
a person within its territorial limits be brought
up before it to be dealt with according to law;
a person illegally or improperly detained in
public or private custody within such limits be
set at liberty.
This section does not apply to persons detained under
any law providing for preventive detention. -
The High Court may from time to time frame rules to
regulate the procedure for cases to be deal with under this section,
These provisions are in addition to Article 184(3) and
Article 199, clause (1)(b)(i) of the Constitution.
By subsection (1A) of section 491, which has been
recently inserted by Ordinance VIII of 2002, the High Court may
delegate its powers under section 491, subsection (1), to a Sessions
Judge or an Additional Sessions Judge to be exercised within the
territorial limits of a Sessions Division.
Scope of power under section 491
There is no authority in law authorizing an adult woman
to be detained in Dar-ul-Aman against her will (Noor Hussain v
Superintendent Dar-ul-Aman PLD 1988 Lah 333). Where the court
finds that the person brought before it was not being illegally or
improperly detained, the question is what order can be passed
regarding the custody of that person under section 491. If the
624
person is a minor, the court may make over his custody to his
guardian which will be dealing with him in accordance with law
but if the person is major the only jurisdiction which the court can
exercise is to set him at liberty whether illegally or improperly
detained in public or private custody or not. The court may "set at
liberty" but cannot restore status quo ante against the wishes of the
person brought before it. Such a course will lead to curtailment of
liberty for which there is no warrant under section 491 nor can such
an order be made under section 561-A Cr.P.C. as it cannot be said
that allowing the person freedom of movement is an abuse of the
process of the court (Muhammad Rafiq v Abdul Ghafoor - PLD
1972 SC 6).
The right conferred by these provisions, concerned as it
is with the liberty of citizen, is the "most cherished right", and if
the court is satisfied that the custody is illegal, the order that must
necessarily and inevitably follow is that the person in custody be
set at liberty (Noor Hussain v Superintendent Dar-ul-Aman - PLD
1988 Lah 333).
Chapter 2
HADOOD LAWS
The Offences against Property (Enforcement of Hadood)
Ordinance 1979, the Offence of Zina (Enforcement of Hadood)
Order 1979, the Offence of Qazf (Enforcement of Hadood)
Ordinance 1979, and the Prohibition (Enforcement of Hadd)
Ordinance 1979, are the Hadood laws here under consideration.
These laws codify and in the process modify the existing laws on
the subjects dealt with by them. In the language of Article 227 of
the Constitution they bring the existing criminal law on the
subjects in conformity with the Injunctions of Islam as laid down in
the Holy Quran and Sunnah.
"Hadd' in Islam is the name of that punishment which is
fixed by the Holy Quran or the Sunnah of the Holy Prophet. It is
enforceable as a right of God and is liable to be changed neither by
625
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 331
the legislature nor by the courts (Hazoor Baksh v Federation - PLD
1981 FSC 145, 224).
One special feature of these Hadood laws is that they are
a combination of substantive and procedure laws; that is to say,
they create offences, provide for their punishment with Hadood
sentences and also provide for the forums for, and mode of trial of,
those offences. For example, section 3 of the Offences against
Property (Enforcement of Hadood) Ordinance 1979 and section 19
of the Offence of Qazf Ordinance 1979 impliedly repeal the
substantive law on the subject in the PPC, and other laws by saying
that "the provisions of this Ordinance shall have effect
notwithstanding anything contained in any other law for the time
being in force" and the Offence of Zina Ordinance, 1979, contains
an express repeal clause in section 19, subsection (3), which
provides that section 366, section 372, section 373, section 375,
section 376, section. 493, section 497 and section 498 of the PPC
shall stand repealed. The Prohibition Order contains no such
express repeal clause but it is obvious that it has also the effect of
impliedly repealing the provisions on the subject in other laws.
Each of these laws provides for two kinds of offence,
namely offences punishable with 'Hadd' and ofences punishable
with Taazir. The expression 'Hadd' or 'Hafood' means the
punishment ordained by the Holy Quran or the Sunnah and the
expression 'Taazir' means any punishment other than Hadd. The
cases which are punishable with "Taazir' are those which are either
not liable to be punished with 'Hadd' or for which the required
proof is not available. The distinction is important for it
emphasizes that on account of the severity of the punishment for
offences liable to 'Hadd', a higher and severer standard of proof is
needed. If that proof is not available, then the offender is liable to
ordinary punishment prescribed by the Legislature. These Hadood
laws are self-contained codes in the sense that they provide both
Tor 'Hadd' punishments and "Taazir' punishments.
As regards the procedure, the fact that offences
punishable with 'Hadd' require special proof has already been
noted. What remains to be stated is that for the proof of offences
626
liable to 'Hadd' sentences, the witnesses testifying before the court
have also to undergo the test of Tazkiya Al-Shuhood namely an
inquiry by the court to satisfy itself as to the credibility of the
witness that is to say that he is a truthful person and abstains from
major sins. Further if the accused is a Muslim, the eye witnesses
must be Muslims but if the accused is a non-Muslim, the eye
witnesses may be non-Muslims.
In the context of the Hadood laws, the requirement of
enquiry as to the witness's credibility has great importance. For the
purposes of that enquiry, mere statement of the witness. and
questions put to him, are not sufficient. For no one who has
deposed or who has come to depose for the prosecution in a case of
Hadd will be willingly disclosing that he has some defects of
character or that he is not a truthful person". Therefore, there is
need for the matter of the credibility of the witness to be referred to
one or more than one Muzakki (a referee who gives evidence about
the truthfulness of the witness). The Muzakki's evidence must be
recorded in the presence of the accused (Ghulam Ali v State - PLD
1986 SC 741,755).
The Code of Criminal Procedure 1898 applies to the trial
of cases under these Hadood laws, except to the extent that special
procedure has been provided.
These laws also provide for the presiding officers
competent to try these offences. The presiding officers of these
courts must be Muslims except in cases where the accused is a non-
Muslim.
Chapter 3
JUVENILES INVOLVED IN CRIMINAL LITIGATION
The law on juvenile persons involved in criminal
litigation is now contained in Juvenile Justice System Ordinance
2000 (the Ordinance). This Ordinance, unlike an Ordinance
promulgated under the Constitution, is a permanent primary
legislation, and as its section 14 says, its provisions are in addition
627
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 332
to and not in derogation of any other law for the time being in

This law provides for the protection of children involved
in criminal litigation, their rehabilitation in society, reorganization
of juvenile courts and matters connected therewith and incidental
thereto. Section 2 of this Ordinance defines certain expressions
such as "borstal institution', 'child', 'guardian', and 'probation
officer'. The expression 'child', means a person who at the time of
the commission of the offence had not attained the age of 18 years.
If a question arises as to whether a person is a child for the
purposes of the Ordinance, the Juvenile Court shall under section 7
make an inquiry and record its finding.
The definition of the expression 'minor' in section 299
PPC is the same. Under section 299 PPC 'minor' means a person
who is not an adult, and "adult" means a person who has attained
the age of 18 years,
The expressions 'guardian' means a parent or a person
who has actual care of the child and includes such relative who is
willing to bear the responsibility of the child; 'offence' means an
offence punishable under any law for the time being in force and
'probation officer' means a person appointed under the Probation
of Offenders Ordinance 1960 or such person as the Provincial
Government may appoint to perform the functions of probation
officer under the Ordinance.
Under section 3 of the Ordinance every child who is
accused of the commission of an offence or is a victim of an
offence has the right of legal assistance at State expense.
The Provincial Government has power, under section

Jurisdiction of juvenile court
The juvenile court established under this Ordinance has
exclusive jurisdiction to try cases in which a child is accused of the
commission of an offence. The juvenile court shall decide the case
within 4 moths of taking cognizance of an offence. This is so
provided by sub-sections (3) & (6) of section 4 of the Ordinance.
Notwithstanding anything contained in section 239
Cr.P.C.. or any other law for the time being in force, no child shall
be charged with or tried for an offence together with an adult.
Where a child is charged with the commission of an offence along
with an adult, (which expression means a person who has attained
the age of 18 years), the court shall direct separate trial of the child.
The procedure to be followed by the juvenile court is the
procedure provided for in the Code of Criminal Procedure as
modified and supplemented by the provisions of the Ordinance, for
example, by the provisions of section 6, section 8 and section 10.
Section 6 empowers the juvenile court to control and restrict the
entry of persons in the court when a juvenile is being tried or as to
when the presence of a child accused may be dispensed with:
section 8 empowers the court to prohibit the publication of the
court proceedings and section 10 provides for the arrest and bail of

A child convicted and in case of acquittal the Provincial

PART XI
POWER TO PARDON, REMIT, SUSPEND SENTENCES
Under the Constitution
(i)
Under Article 45 of the Constitution,
"The President shall have power to grant
pardon, reprieve and respite, and to remit,
suspend or commute any sentence passed by
any court, tribunal or other authority"
The power to grant pardon, remission etc. is an
executive power and Article 45 of the Constitution expressly
recognizes it. Though the power is expressed to vest in the
President, yet, as Article 48(1) of the Constitution requires, it is to
be exercised on the advice of the Cabinet or the Prime Minister.
In Sakina Bibi v Federation of Pakistan (PLD 1992 Lah.
99), it was held that in view of Article 2A of the Constitution, the
power to grant pardon, reprieve etc. under Article 45 in Hadood
cases was, to that extent, repugnant to the Injunctions of Islam and
therefore void. This view was not approved by the Supreme Court
in Hakim Khan case (PLD 1992 SC 595) and the position remains
that the President continues to have the power to grant pardon.
reprieve etc. under Article 45 of the Constitution even in Hadood
cases.
We shall presently notice the provisions of Chapter
XXIX of the Code of Criminal Procedure. Suffice it to say here
that those provisions are subject to Article 45 of the Constitution.
with the result that to the extent of any inconsistency between
Article 45 of the Constitution and the provisions of Chapter XXIX
of the Code, the provisions of Chapter XXIX will be void. This
question fell directly for consideration in Abdul Malik v State
(PLD 2006 SC 365) and it was held that the newly amended
sections 401, 402, 402A, 402B and 402C Cr.P.C. (the amendments
630
631
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 334
probably gave effect to the decision of the Federal Shariat Court in
Habib-ul-Wahab Al-Khairi v Federation of Pakistan - PLD 1991
FSC 236) cannot affect or fetter the powers of the President under
Article 45, for-
"It is settled principle of constitutional
interpretation that a provision enshrined
in the Constitution shall prevail
notwithstanding anything
contrary
contained in a piece of subordinate
legislation".
For example, section 402C Cr.P.C. provides -
"Notwithstanding anything contained in
section 401, section 402, section 402A
or section 402B the Provincial
Government, the Federal Government or
the President shall not, without the
consent of the victim or as the case may
be, of his heirs, remit or commute any
sentence passed under any of the
sections in Chapter XVI of the Pakistan
Penal Code".
This provision is obviously inconsistent with the power of the
President under Article 45 of the Constitution, which power is not
subject to the limitation of consent of the victim or his heirs and as
held in Abdul Malik v State is, to that extent, void.
Scope of Article 45:
President-
By Article II, Section 2, of the US Constitution, the
"shall have power to grant reprieves and
pardons for offenders against the United
States except in cases of impeachment",
632
Thus, the power under Article II of the US Constitution is much
wider than the power under Article 45 of the Pakistan Constitution.
It is not necessary for the exercise of the power under the US
Constitution that there should have been a trial resulting in
conviction and sentence by a court. "The power extends to every
offence known to the law, and may be exercised at any time after
its commission, either before legal proceedings are taken or during
their pendency or after conviction and judgment....... A pardon
reaches both the punishment prescribed for the offence and the
guilt of the offender". Murphy v Ford (390 F. Supp. 1372) affords
a recent example. President Nixon was pardoned by his successor's
order for offences for which he had not been tried, convicted and
sentenced and it was held that the fact that Mr. Nixon -
"had been neither indicted nor convicted
of an offence against the United States
does not affect the validity of the
pardon".
Pakistan
In contrast, under Article 45 of the
Constitution, the power to pardon, reprieve etc, comes into play
unly after a person has been tried, convicted and sentenced.
However, Article 45 applies to cases in which the Sessions Court
has passed a sentence of death which is subject to confirmation by
the High Court and the sentence has not yet been confirmed. In
such cases, there has been a conviction and sentence. (Eid
Muhammad v State - PLD 1993 SC 17).
(ii)
Power to remit etc. under the Code of Criminal
Procedure:
Chapter XXIX of the Code of Criminal Procedure, by its
sections 401 to 402C, provides for the power to suspend, remit,
commute sentences, that is, sentences awarded by courts after trial
and conviction. Like Article 45, the power under Chapter XXIX
too does not come into operation until there has been a trial,
conviction and sentence.
633
om
H
vie
in
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 335
We have seen that the provisions of Chapter XXIX are,
as has been held in Abdul Malik case, subject to Article 45 of
Constitution; they cannot affect or limit the President's powers
under Article 45 of the Constitution.
The provisions of Chapter XXIX of the Code, as they
stood at the time of the decision in Habib-ul-Wahab v Federation
(PLD 1991 FSC 236), were declared in that case to be repugnant to
the Injunctions of Islam, in so far as they did not provide for the
consent of the victim or as the case may be of his heirs in Qatl and
hurt cases. The new section 402C gives effect to the decision of the
Federal Shariat Court.
Section 401 Cr.P.C. empowers the Provincial
Government to suspend the execution of any sentence, or remit the
whole or any part of the sentence of any person who has been
sentenced to punishment for any offence without condition or upon
any condition which the person sentenced accepts. This provision
does not apply to cases of karo kar, siyah kari or similar other
customs or practices.
Section 401 further provides by its subsection (2), that
when an application is made to the Provincial Goverment for the
suspension or remission of a sentence, that Government may
require the sentencing Judge to state his opinion as to whether the
application should be granted or refused together with his reasons.
If the remission or suspension was granted subject to any
condition and the condition is not fulfilled, the remission or
sentence may, under subsection (3) of section 401, be cancelled
and the person may be arrested to undergo the unexpired portion of
the sentence.
Section 402 Cr.P.C.
Government without the consent of the person sentenced to
empowers the Provincial
commute the sentences of death, imprisonment for life, rigorous
imprisonment in the manner stated therein.
Section 402B empowers the President to exercise the
same powers, in the cases of sentence of death, as the Provincial
Government has under sections 401 and 402. In view of Article 45
of the Constitution, this, it is submitted, seems to be unnecessary.
Section 402B makes the powers of the Provincial
Government under sections 401 and 402 subject to the approval of
the President in cases in which the President has exercised his
power under Article 45 of the Constitution or under section 402A
Cr.P.C.
As has been noticed above, section 402C gives effect to
the decision of the Federal Shariat Court in Habib-ul-Wahab case
by providing that the power of the President or other authority to
remit or commute any sentence passed under Chapter XVI of the
Pakistan Penal Code shall be subject to the consent of the victim.
or as the case may be, of the heirs.
This section. in so far as it makes the power of the
President under Article 45 of the Constitution subject to the
consent of the victim or his heirs is, as held in Abdul Malik case.
void.
Scope of review by courts:
The general rule is that the power to pardon, remit etc. is
an executive discretionary power and the courts will not interfere in
such matters. (Muhammad Sadiq case 1979 SCMR 69; Ayub
Khan case 1979 SCMR 302). In Bagh Sultan case (1979 SCMR
292), a press statement said that in mercy petitions, the executive
authority would be guided by court decisions. This was challenged
on the ground that this was not a proper and legal exercise of the
power under Article 45 of the Constitution, for mercy begins where
justice ends. It was held that mercy and justice cannot be entirely
divorced from each other and whether justice has been done is a
relevant factor in the exercise of mercy power.
634
635
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 336
PART X
BAIL to Persons Accused and Convicted
Chapter 1
Relevant Provisions
There is no provision in the Constitution of Pakistan
relating to bail. The subject is usually considered in the context of
the individual's fundamental right to life and liberty guaranteed by
Article 9 of the Constitution.
In the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898, the provisions
as to bail are to be found, as regards bail to accused persons, in
Chapter XXXIX, sections 496, 497, 498, and as regards bail to
convicts, in section 426. Sections 496, 497, 498 and 426 read as
follows:
"496. In what cases bail to be taken. When any person
other than a person accused of a non-bailable offence is
arrested or detained without warrant by an officer in
charge of a police station, or appears or is brought before
a court, and is prepared at any time while in the custody
of such officer or at any stage of the proceedings before
such court to give bail, such person shall be released on
bail: Provided that such officer or court, if he or it thinks
fit, may, instead of taking bail from such person.
discharge him on his executing a bond without sureties
for his appearance as hereinafter provided:
Provided, further, that nothing in this section shall be
deemed to affect the provisions of section 117, sub-
section (4) or section 117, sub-section (3).
636
497. When bail may be taken in case of non-bailable
offence. (1) When any person accused of any non-
bailable offence is arrested or detained without warrant
by an officer in charge of a police-station, or appears or
is brought before a court, he may be released on bail, but
he shall not be so released if there appear reasonable
grounds for believing that he has been guilty of an
offence punishable with death or imprisonment for life
or imprisonment for ten years:
Provided that the Court may direct that any person under
the age of sixteen years or any sick or infirm person
accused of such an offence be released on bail:
Provided further that a woman accused of such an
offence shall be released on bail, as if the offence is
bailable, notwithstanding anything contained in
Schedule II to this Code or any other law for the time
being in force:
Provided further that a woman may not be so released if
there appear reasonable grounds for believing that she
has been guilty of an offence relating to terrorism.
financial corruption and murder and such offence is
punishable with death or imprisonment for life or
imprisonment for ten years, unless having regard to the
facts and circumstance of the case, the court directs that
she may be released on bail:
Provided further that where a woman accused of an
offence is refused bail under the foregoing proviso, she
shall be released on bail if she has been detained for a
continuous period of six months and whose trial for such
offence has not been concluded, unless the court is of the
opinion that the delay in the trial of the accused has been
occasioned by an act or omission of the accused or any
other person acting on her behalf.
637
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 337
Provided further that
a person accused of an
offence as aforesaid shall not be released on bail unless
the prosecution has been given notice to show cause why
he should not be so released.
(2) If it appears to such officer or court at any stage of
the investigation, inquiry or trial, as the case may be,
that there are not reasonable grounds for believing that
the accused has committed a non-bailable offence, but
that there are sufficient grounds for further inquiry into
his guilt, the accused shali, pending such inquiry, be
released on bail, or, at the discretion of such officer or
court, on the execution by him of a bond without sureties
for his appearance as hereinafter provided.
(3) An officer or a court releasing any person on bail
under sub-section (1) or sub-section (2) shall record in
writing his or its reasons for so doing.
(4) If, at any time after the conclusion of the trial of a
person accused of a non-bailable offence and before
judgment is delivered, the Court is of opinion that there
are reasonable grounds for believing that the accused is
not guilty of any such offence, it shall release the
accused, if he is in custody or the execution by him of a
bond without sureties for his appearance to hear
judgment delivered.
(5) A High Court or Court of Session and, in the case of
a person released by itself, any other Court may cause
any person who has been released under this section to
be arrested and may commit him to custody.
498. Power to direct admission to bail or reduction of
bail. The amount of every bond executed under this
Chapter shall be fixed with due regard to the
circumstances of the case, and shall not be excessive:
638
and the High Court or Court of Session may, in any case.
whether there he an appeal on conviction or not, direct
that any person be admitted to bail, or that the bail
required by a police-officer or Magistrate be reduced.
426. Suspension of sentence pending appeal. Release of
appellant on bail. (1) Pending any appeal by a convicted
person, the appellate court may, for reasons to be
recorded by it in writing, order that the execution of the
sentence or order appealed against be suspended and.
also, if he is in confinement, that he be released on hail
or on his own bond.
(2) The power conferred by this section on an appellate
court may be exercised also by the High Court in the
case of any appeal by a convicted person to a court
subordinate thereto.
(2-A) Subject to provisions of section 382-A when any
person other than a person accused of a non-bailable
offence is sentenced to imprisonment by a court, and an
appeal lies from that sentence, the court may, if the
convicted person satisfies the court that he intends to
present an appeal, order that he be released on bail, for a
period sufficient in the opinion of the court to enable
him to present the appeal and obtain the orders of the
appellate court under sub-section (1) and the sentence of
imprisonment shall, so long as he is so released on bail.
be deemed to be suspended.
(2-B) Where a High Court is satisfied that a convicted
person has been granted special leave to appeal to
Supreme Court against any sentence which it has
imposed or maintained, it may, if it so thinks fit order
that pending the appeal the sentence or order appealed
against be suspended, and also, if the said person is in
confinement, that he be released on bail.
639
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 338
(3) When the appellant is ultimately sentenced to
imprisonment, or imprisonment for life, the time during
which he is so released shall be excluded in computing
the term for which he is so sentenced.
As Interpreted by Courts
It was held by the Privy Council in Lala Jairam Das v
King Emperor (72 IA 120) that -
"Chapter XXXIX of the Code together
with section 426 is and was intended to
contain a complete and exhaustive
statement of the powers of a High Court
in India to grant bail and excludes the
existence of any additional inherent
power in High Court relating to the
subject of bail"
In the view of the Privy Council in Lala Jairam Das.
which the question was whether a High Court in India had power to
grant bail under section 498,
"the scheme of Chapter XXXIX is that
sections 496 and 497 provide for the
granting of bail to accused persons
before trial and the other sections of the
Chapter deal with matters ancillary and
subsidiary to that provision".
It was clarified in Sadiq Ali case (PLD 1966 SC 589, 593) that the
expression "before trial" in the above quoted observation of the
Privy Council "was perhaps not a happy one" for "bail can be
granted to an accused person under sections 496 and 497 of the
Code at any stage prior to the conviction being recorded".
The Privy Council's view in Lala Jairam Das case that
"Chapter XXXIX of the Code of Criminal Procedure dealt
exclusively with the subject of bail to accused persons" and the
question of grant of bail to convicts has been "dealt with fully in
section 426 of the Code" was commented upon by S. A. Rehman J.
in Muhammad Ayub v Muhammad Yaqoob (PLD 1966 SC 1003.
1009) as follows:
"Apparently, their Lordship's attention
was not drawn to the provisions of
section 435 of the Code, which enable
the High Court or a Sessions Judge or a
District Magistrate or a specially
empowered Sub-Divisional Magistrate
to call for and examine the record of any
proceedings before any inferior criminal
court for the purposes of satisfying itself
as to the correctness, legality or
propriety of any finding, sentence or
order recorded or passed etc. and
empowers them, when calling for such
record, to direct that the execution of
such sentence be suspended and if the
accused is confined, that he be released
on bail or on his own bond pending the
examination of the record"
It would be, so wrote S. A. Rehman J. "more correct to say.
therefore, that the question of bail to convicted and accused
persons is exhaustively dealt with in sections 426 and 435 and
Chapter XXXIX of the Code. Under section 426 there is exercise
of appellate jurisdiction and under section 435 that of revisional
jurisdiction whereas the subject of bail to accused persons, prior to
conviction, forms the subject of Chapter XXXIX and is partly
covered by section 435"
640
641
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 339
To this extent, the Privy Council's decision in Lala
Jairam Das case also stands modified.
The Supreme Court, in Muhammad Ayub case, next
considered the view of the Privy Council that the remaining
provisions of Chapter XXXIX of the Code, particularly section
498, were ancillary or subsidiary to the provisions of sections 496
and 497.
In considering that question, the Supreme Court
affirmed the Privy Council's view that section 498 applies only to
the accused persons and does not apply to convicted persons. The
next question considered by the Supreme Court in Muhammad
Ayub case was whether section 498 should be confined to the
category of persons visualized by section 497.
In Sadiq Ali case (PLD 1966 SC 589), the Supreme
Court had held. "keeping the dictum of the Privy Council in view",
that the word "appears" in section 497 need not be confined to
persons appearing in response to a process, and that persons
appearing voluntarily were also covered by section 497. On further
reflection, S. A. Rehman J. thought that this meaning of the word
"appears" would render section 498 redundant. He therefore came
to the conclusion that:
"The view in Sadiq Ali's case may
require a little modification in so far as
the word 'appears' in sections 496 and
497 need not be construed to include
voluntary
appearance, even in
circumstances of grave apprehension of
arrest. This word may be taken to have
been used in sections 496 and 497 in the
same sense as in section 242 or 252 of
the Code, which obviously contemplate
appearance in answer to a process issued
by a court. This interpretation will have
642
the merit of saving section 498 in its
own right".
The position that emerges then would be, so held S. A. Rehman J..
"That under sections 496 and 497,
Criminal Procedure Code, the court can
bail out a person only if he has been
placed under actual custody or appears
in answer to a process issued or is
brought before the court. personally by
the police, or by some other arresting
authority. In other words, these sections
apply when there has been an actual
arrest attracting the court's jurisdiction
or the court is seized of the proceedings
directly, in which bail is requested.
Section 498, however, would be called
in aid before the Court of Session and
the High Court, even where the court is
not seized directly of the proceedings in
question and where no actual arrest has
been made so far but anticipatory bail is
asked for e.g. when the case is still at a
stage of investigation by the police or is
pending in a subordinate court. The
power to grant such anticipatory bail
would thus be confined to the High
Court and the Court of Session and other
courts would be excluded from its
scope".
This interpretation, it was held,
"would seem to be consistent with the
use of general expressions like 'in any
case' and 'any person' in section 498".
643
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 340
The conclusion as to whether section 498 is ancillary or subsidiary
to section 497, as reached by S. A. Rehman J. was expressed thus:
"The better view seems to me to be that
the policy of the law, in respect of bail to
persons accused of non-bailable offences
is laid down in section 497 and the same
policy should be kept in view while
considering the question of bail under
section 498, Criminal Procedure Code.
After all judicial discretion has to be
exercised while granting bail and the
power conferred by section 498 of the
Code cannot be construed to be purely
arbitrary. In this respect, section 498 of
the Code seems to be to be ancillary or
subsidiary to sections 496 and 497 of the
Cude, in the wurds of the Privy
Counci!"
In other words, the policy of the law as laid down in and
the limitations on the grant of bail imposed by section 497, such as
that a person accused of a non-bailable offence shall not be
released on bail "if there appear reasonable grounds for believing
that he has been guilty of an offence punishable with death or
imprisonment for life or imprisonment for ten years", also govern
the grant of bail under section 498.
To this extent, section 498 is, as was held by the Privy
Council in Lala Jairam Das case, ancillary or subsidiary to sections
496 and 497 of the Code. In other respects, however, section 498,
so held S. A. Rehman J.,
a
"occupies the position of
supplementary provision in so far as it
confers not only concurrent but
revisional powers on the High Court and
044
the Court of Session in respect of grant
or refusal of bail by subordinate courts
and the police that enables these courts
to exercise the power of anticipatory bail
in suitable cases".
Thus, section 498, it was held in Muhammad Ayub case, is partly
ancillary and subsidiary and partly supplementary to sections 496
and 497 of the Code. This was again a departure from the view
taken in Lala Jairam Das case.
It will be noted that sections 496 and 497 use the
expression "released on bail" and section 498 uses the expression
"admitted to bail". At one time, the view taken was that this
difference of expressions was intended to mean two different
things. However, in Khushi Muhammad case (PLD 1953 FC 170)
it was held that they mean the same thing and this view was
reiterated in Muhammad Ayub case (PLD 1966 SC 1003, 1011).
This view seems to have received legislative recognition in section
498A, which uses both the expressions "released on bail" and
"admitted to bail".
To complete the survey of the landscape presented by
Chapter XXXIX of the Code of Criminal Procedure, it is to be
noted that the provisions of sections 497 and 498 are subject to
section 498A, which was enacted in 1976. The provisions of this
section are clarificatory in nature; they seem to reiterate what was
already the law; the section provides that-
i)
in order to be released on bail or admitted to
bail, the applicant for bail must be,
a)
in custody; or
b)
present in court; or
645
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 341
ii)
c)
a person against whom a case
stands registered for the time being;
and
an order that a person be released on, or
admitted to, bail, "shall be effective only in
respect of the case that so stands registered
against him and is specified in the (court's)
order or direction".
Chapter 2
Meaning and Concept of "Bail"
When a person is arrested and detained (this detention is
described, in the American legal literature, as "preventive"
detention) in connection with a criminal offence, he is deprived of
his liberty, and the question immediately arises whether his
detention is, in the language of Article 4, clause (4)(a), and Article
9 of the Constitution of Pakistan, "in accordance with law", or to
use the language of Article 199, clause (1), sub-clause (b)(i).
whether he is not being held in custody (i) without lawful
authority, or (ii) in an unlawful manner. (These topics have been
discussed earlier under Article 9 and under Article 199, clause (1),
sub-clause (b)(i) under the heading "Remedies for the Enforcement
of Fundamental Rights"). It is sufficient to say here that, as was
succinctly put by Hamood-ur-Rehman J. in Begum Shorish
Kashmiri case (PLD 1969 SC 15, 30, 31), in 'without lawful
authority' is comprised all questions of vires of the statute itself as
also of the person acting under the statute; there must be a
competent (and valid law) authorizing the detention and the officer
issuing such order (to arrest and detain) must have been lawfully
vested with the power to do so, and the person causing the arrest
and detention must have been duly authorized by such law to do so.
The words "in an unlawful manner" seem to reflect the view that
even technicalities may be decisive in favour of the person
detained, "since where the liberty of the subject is concerned the
646
formalities required must be strictly observed". (Lord Hodson in
Metropolitan Police Commissioner v Hammond (1964) 2 All ER
772, 783). Thus, as Hamood-ur-Rehman J. said in Shorish
Kashmiri case, the words "in an unlawful manner" have been used
deliberately to give meaning and content to the solemn declaration
under Article 2 (now Article 4) of the Constitution itself that it is
the inalienable right of every citizen to be treated in accordance
with law. An arrest and detention in disregard of the procedural
safeguards, constitutional as well as statutory, will, therefore, be in
an unlawful manner.
The authority to arrest and detain a person accused of a
criminal offence, as well as the authority for the continued
detention of such person, is a statutory authority; if there is no law
authorizing such arrest or detention, the same will not be in
accordance with law. If there is such law and the arrest and
detention are under it, the arrest and detention and the resultant
deprivation of liberty will be in accordance with law, within the
meaning of Article 9 of the Constitution. Then, such a law not only
authorizes the arrest and detention of the persons accused, but also
invariably addresses the question regarding the cases in which, or
persons whose continued detention during trial will or will not be
necessary. This question relates to the temporary release on bail of
the persons accused. The law determines as a matter of policy not
only the category of persons to whom and the circumstances in
which bail will be granted but also the question of what is called
"setting of bail"- that is, determination of those conditions that the
accused person will have to meet to gain his release from custody
pending trial or after conviction. (See the "Criminal Procedure and
the Constitution" by Professors Jerold H. Israel, Yale Kanisar and
Wayne R. LaFave, p. 9).
It is important to remember that detention during trial is
regulatory in nature; its purpose is two-fold:
(1)
To secure the presence of the accused at the
trial and thereby to ensure the integrity of the
647
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 342
(2)
judicial process. As was said by Chief Justice
Rehnquist in Salemo (481 US 339: 95 L Ed
2d 697):
"the primary function of bail is to
safeguard the court's role in adjudicating the
guilt or innocence of defendants......."
To secure the safety and the lives of its
citizens. This gives "appropriate recognition
to the dangers a person may pose to others if
released". (Salerno).
Thus, the basic justification for imprisonment during trial is to
guarantee the presence of the suspect in order to ensure proper
judicial disposition of the case. As a corollary, pre-trial
incarceration may protect the judicial process by precluding any
interference with evidence or witnesses on the part of the
defendant. Detention may even serve to protect the accused from
others who have a stake in the disposition of his case, or from
himself, if the accused is violent or unstable or otherwise judged
likely to harm himself". (See "American Criminal Procedure" by
Stephen. A Saltzburg and Daniel J. Capra p. 703). And as has been
held repeatedly by the US Supreme Court, "the government's
regulatory interest in community safety can. in appropriate
circumstances, outweigh an individual's liberty interest". (Chief
Justice Rehnquist in Salerno).
To sum up, "in our society liberty is the norm, and
detention prior to trial or without trial is the carefully limited
exception" and "the primary concern of every government-a
concern for the safety and indeed the lives of its citizens" on its
face does not violate any constitutional guarantee. (Chief Justice
Rehnquist in Salerno).
And despite the fact that in America, the "presumption
of innocence" has been accorded a constitutional status, and the
dictum by Chief Justice Vinson in Stack v Boyle (342 US 1: L Ed
3 (1951)) that-
"Unless this right to bail is
preserved, the presumption of innocence,
secured only after centuries of struggle,
would lose its meaning"
there is little reason to think that the presumption of innocence -
which is no more than a rule of evidence that allocates the burden
of proof to the government and serves as the foundation of the
procedural requirement of proof beyond a reasonable doubt - and
the bail systems cannot co-exist". (See "The American Criminal
Procedure" by Stephen A. Saltzburg and Daniel J. Capra, p. 723.
The decision in Salerno is also an authority for this view).
The Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898, which is the
general criminal procedural law of Pakistan is a prime example of a
law within the meaning of Article 9 of the Constitution.
We have seen that the Code deals with the question of
bail in its Chapter XXXIX. However, it does not define "bail", the
intention being that it is to be understood in its ordinary dictionary
meaning and that if there are more than one dictionary meaning.
the context will determine the meaning. According to the
dictionaries, 'bail" means-
i)
ii)
money etc. required as security, against the
temporary release of a prisoner pending trial;
or
a person or persons giving such security,
known as sureties.
Hence the expression "bail out"-release from a difficulty, come to
rescue.
648
649
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 343
The concept of bail probably dates back to the system
adopted in England after the Norman conquest of 1060. Under that
system, if a member of a community was alleged to have
committed a crime, the community as a whole was required to
pledge its property as security for the accused's appearance at his
trial. Later, it became a business and bail bonding companies
came into existence who would charge fees for standing sureties.
The prospect of imposing a property loss on others in the
community could produce considerable pressure on the accused to
remain in the area and stand trial. The concept of community
responsibility eventually dissolved, but the capacity of the accused
to retain his freedom pending trial by posting security (commonly
called "bail') remained. ("Criminal Justice System" by Professors
Hazel B. Kerper and Jarold H. Israel, 2 ed p. 269). In other
words, bail means security and security can be personal security or
security by sureties.
In the context of Code of Criminal Procedure:
The Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898, makes
distinction between 'releasing on bail" and releasing on his own
bond i.c. personal bond.
Thus, section 169 of the Code empowers a police
officer, to whom it appears that "there is not sufficient evidence or
reasonable ground for suspicion to justify the forwarding of the
accused to a Magistrate" to release the accused "on his executing a
bond, with or without sureties". Section 496 entitles a person
accused of a bailable offence to be "released on bail". Such a
person, when he is arrested by a police officer or when he appears
or is brought before a court, "shall be released on bail" or if the
police officer or the court thinks fit, may, "instead of taking bail
from such person, discharge him on his executing a bond without
sureties for his appearance". Section 499 and the form of "bond
and bail bond" in the sixth schedule to the Code make the position
clearer. Section 499 provides that before a person is released on
bail or released on his own bond, a bond for such sum of money as
the police officer or the court may determine shall be executed by
him and "when he is released on bail, by one or more sufficient
sureties conditioned that such person shall attend at the time and
place mentioned in the bond......... The form of the bond and bail
bond as prescribed in the sixth schedule reads:
"I,
...., do hereby bind myself
to attend in the court of on the
day. And in case of making
default. I bind myself to forfeit to
Goverment.
of
rupees
1,
the
sum
...do hereby declare myself
surety for the above named that he shall
attend the court...... and in case of his
making default therein
I bind
myself to forfeit to Government the sum
of rupee....
The distinction, under the Code, therefore, is between releasing an
accused on his own bond, or releasing him on bail: and releasing
him on bail' means releasing him on the security of sureties. A
surety is a person who is willing to undertake a responsibility by
entering into a recognizance or bond, that the accused person "shall
attend at the time and place mentioned in the bond and shall
continue so to attend unless otherwise directed by the police officer
or the court and that if the accused fails to do so the surety shall
Torfeit the amount of bail". Thus, in Crown v Khushi Muhammad
(PLD 1953 FC 170), Chief Justice Abdul Rashid, speaking for the
Court, said:
"The basic conception of the word "bail"
is release of a person from the custody of
police and delivering him into the hands
of sureties, who undertake to produce
"
21
it
A
650
651
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 344
him in court whenever required to do
This view of the word "bail" was affirmed by the Supreme Court in
Sadiq Ali v State (PLD 1966 SC 589, 597), in which it was said
that "bail is really substitute of one form of custody by another"; it
was reiterated in Mahmood Ali Qasuri v State (PLD 1963, SC
478):
"The connotation of the word "bail".
itself as understood in law, supports the
position...... An accused person is said,
at common law, to be admitted to bail,
when he is released from the custody of
the officers of the court and is entrusted
to the custody of persons known as his
sureties.........
and in the judgment of Mukhtar Ahmad Junejo J. in Hakim Ali
Zardari v State (PLD 1998 SC 1).
Hence the expression such as 'remand in custody' and
*remand on bail'.
Chapter 3
Striking a fair balance between the rights of Society and
individuals:
It is plainly clear that the question of release on bail is
directly related to right to liberty which is one of the fundamental
rights guaranteed by the Constitution, Article 9. Additionally.
arrest and detention of a person must needs produce grave
consequences for the arrestee and his family, prticularly if the
arrestee is the only bread earner of his family. The law of bails, as
has been said in an Indian case (Supdt. v Amiya Kumar Roy (1974)
78 Cal. WN. 320, 325)-
"has to dovetail conflicting
demands, namely, on one hand, the
requirement of the society for being
shielded from the hazards of being
exposed to the misadventures of a person
alleged to have committed a crime, and
on the other, the fundamental cannon of
criminal
jurisprudence viz the
presumption of innocence of an accused
till he is found guilty".
And it was said by Chief Justice Vinson in Stack v
Boyle (342 US 1: 96 L Ed 3 (1951)-
"This traditional right to freedom before
conviction permits the unhampered
preparation of a defence and serves to
prevent the infliction of punishment
prior to conviction. Unless this right to
bail before trial is preserved, the
presumption of innocence secured only
after centuries of struggle would lose its
meaning".
In Hakim Ali Zardari v State (PLD 1998 SC 1, 118, 20) Mukhtar
Ahmad Junejo J. said:
"The concept of bail emerges from the
conflict between the police power to
restrict the liberty of a man who is
alleged to have committed a crime and
the presumption of innocence in favour
of the alleged criminal.
652
653
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 345
"The law of bail is not a static law but is
growing all the time moulding itself with
the exigencies of time, as in times of war
and crisis it leans in favour of the society
and the government while in times of
peace it leans in favour of the individual
and the subject. The main purpose of
keeping an under trial accused in
detention is to prevent repetition of the
offence with which he is charged or
perpetration of some other offence and
to secure his attendance at the trial. Such
object has to be achieved within the
framework of a man's right to
liberty.
To summarise, the objects served by hail are:
i)
to avoid incarceration of innocent persons;
ii)
to prevent the infliction of punishment prior to
conviction:
iii)
to enable the
etc.
to prepare his defence,
to collect evidence to pr
The objectives at (i) and (ii) above are well illustrated by the
following examples given by the US President's Commission on
Law Enforcement and Administration of Justice in their report:
(1)
A man was jailed on a serious charge..... He
could not afford bail and spent 101 days in jail
until a hearing. Then the complainant
admitted the charge was false.
654
(2)
(3)
A man could not raise $300 bail. He spent 54
days in jail waiting trial for a traffic offence,
for which he could have been sentenced to no
more than 5 days.
A man spent 2 months in jail before being
acquitted. In that period he lost his job and his
car and his family was split up.
Incidentally, release of a person on bail serves the same purpose as
his detention, namely, it assures that he will be available to face the
charges at his trial and receive the judgment of the court.
Chapter 4
Ballable and Non-bailable:
An offence can be bailable, which means, according to
section 4(1)(b) of the Cr. P. C. "an offence shown as bailable in the
second schedule (to the Code), or which is made bailable by any
other law for the time being in force" and a non-bailable offence
means any other offence. Thus, an offence is bailable or non-
bailable according as it is so shown in the second schedule to the
Code of Criminal Procedure or as it is so described in any other
law. This is a matter of legislative policy, and it is not necessary
that every cognizable office is necessarily a non-bailable offence.
For example, an offence under section 183 PPC is shown in the
second schedule to the Code as cognizable but bailable.
As we shall see, different consequences flow from an
offence being bailable or non-bailable.
Bail under section 496:
This section applies to any person who is arrested or
detained without warrant by the police, or appears, in answer to a
655
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 346
7003) or is brought before a court but is not a person accused of a
process issued by a court, (Muhammad Ayub PLD 1966 SC
non-bailable offence; that is to say-
i)
ii)
He is accused of a bailable offence; or
His arrest or detention is in connection with
something, which is not an offence, c.g.
security proceedings, to prevent him from
committing breach of the peace or
disturbing
public order under section 107 Cr. P. C. ctc.
Release in bailable and other cases under S. 496;
Bail under section 496 Cr. P. C. is a right of a person
accused of a bailable offence; when a person accused of a bailable
offence is arrested or detained by a police officer, or appears, (that
is, appears in answer to a court process) or is brought before a
court, and is prepared at any time or at any stage of the proceedings
to give bail, "he shall be released on bail". The word 'shall' here is
mandatory; if the arrestee is prepared to give bail, he must be
released on bail. There is here no discretion in the police officer or
court; all that the police officer or the court can do is to release him
on bail. As was held in Mahmood Ali Qasuri v State:
"The policy of the Code seems to be that
in the case of bailable offences the
person accused has the indefeasible right
to grant of bail subject of course to
satisfactory sureties being offered, if
sureties are considered necessary. There
is admittedly no provision in the Code
permitting cancellation of such a bail.
Bail is not a mere privilege in such cases
but a right of the subject whose liberty is
regarded as a precious asset to be
preserved undiminished, If of course the
656
person enlarged on bail subams the
witnesses there may be other remedies at
law open against him. e.g. contempt
proceedings or conceivably even
proceedings to bind him over to keep the
peace or be of good behaviour in certain
circumstances. But to hold that on such
grounds the bail granted under section
496 of the Code can be cancelled
amounts to saying that the High Court
possesses inherent power to override the
express provisions of the Code".
After referring to the observations of the Privy Council
in Lala Jairam Das case and to a case of Indian Supreme Court, S.
A. Rehman J. went on to say-
"
It must be pointed out that i
effect was not given to the
pronouncement of the Privy Council that
the powers to grant bail were exhausted
by Chapter XXXIX read with section
426 of the Criminal Procedure Code and
that section 561-A did not add to such
powers
Thus, it is crystal clear that in bailable offences the grant of bail is
a right and not a favour (Tariq Bashir v State-PLD 1995 SC 34):
it is an indefeasible right, so indefeasible indeed that bail in such
cases cannot be cancelled,
Discretion in bailable offences:
We have seen that the arrestee is entitled to be released
on bail if he is prepared to give bail; this means that the right is
"subject to satisfactory sureties being offered"; that is, satisfactory
to the police officer or as the case may be, to the court.
657
L
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 347
Here the element of discretion creeps in. In other words,
it is in the discretion of the police officer or the court to determine
the satisfactory amount of bail.
Is this discretion unguided or unfettered? Without going
into the question whether the discretion is judicial or administrative
(this is relevant because, a police officer too has the discretion), the
answer is 'No'. The general question of discretion will be
discussed later. Suffice it to say here, that the discretion is subject
to the provisions of section 498 Cr.P.C. which provides that "the
amount of every bond executed under this Chapter shall be fixed
with due regard to the circumstances of the case, and shall not be
excessive.........
Secondly under section 496 the police officer or the
court "if he or it thinks fit, may, instead of taking bail from such
person, discharge him on his executing a bond without sureties for
his appearance........
So, the police officer or the court has the discretion to
release the arrestee on bail or on his personal bond. This discretion
is judicial or at the least quasi-judicial discretion and in
exercising it the bail granting authority will keep in mind the
fundamental right to liberty. Liberty is the norm to which detention
during trial is a limited exception, and the right to bail in bailable
offences must not be allowed to be defeated by excessive bail, that
is, by putting the amount of bail so high as to be beyond the reach
of the arrestee. Thus, even if one has to err, one should err in
favour of the liberty of the arrestee and keeping in view the
circumstances of the case, if the option is between keeping a man
in prison for want of means to provide sureties and discharging
him, that is, releasing him from custody on personal bond, the latter
course should be preferred. This aspect of the matter was dealt with
in Tariq Bashir case (PLD 1995 SC 34, 40). It was noticed that
many under trial accused of bailable offences, or detained for
security purposes i.e. under sections 107, 109 and 110 Cr. P. C. are

Bail to women, minors and sick persons:
It has been seen that under section 497, subsection (1),
first proviso, the court may grant bail to an accused person who is
under the age of 16 yeas or is a sick or infirm person even though
there appear reasonable grounds for believing that he or she has
been guilty of an offence punishable with death or imprisonment
for life or imprisonment for 10 years. It seems therefore that the
cases, in which the accused person is less than 16 years of age or is
a sick or infirm person, even though the offence is punishable with
death or imprisonment for life or imprisonment for 10 years, are on
a par with ordinary non-bailable cases and the court has a
discretion to release or not to release such a person depending upon
the facts of each case (Abdul Aziz v Bashir Ahmad - PLD 1966
SC 658).
The second proviso to section 497 (1) Cr.P.C. is a recent
enactment: it makes special provision for bail to women. A women,
even if she is accused of an offence punishable with death,
imprisonment for life or for ten years, "shall be released on bail, as
if the offence is bailable, notwithstanding anything contained in
Schedule II to this Code or any other law for the time being in
force". But a woman accused may not be released "if there appear
reasonable grounds for believing that she has been guilty of an
offence relating to terrorism, financial corruption or murder and
such offence is punishable with death or imprisonment for life or
imprisonment for ten years, unless having regard to the facts and
circumstances of the case, the court directs that she may be
released on bail".
A woman who has been refused bail under the foregoing
provisions. "shall be realeased on bail if she has been detained for a
continuous period of six months and whose trial for such offence
has not been concluded, unless the court is of the opinion that the
delay in the trial has been occasioned by an act or omission of the
accused or any other person acting on her behalf".
Cases in which the accused has right to bail:
cases-
Besides the cases governed by section 496 Cr. P. C, in
i)
ii)
in which there do not appear reasonable
grounds for believing that the accused has
been guilty of a non-bailable offence
including an offence punishable with death or
imprisonment for life or imprisonment for 10

subsection (1) Cr. P. C., and
in which there are sufficient grounds for
further inquiry into the guilt of the accused
within the meaning of subsection (2) of
section 497,
the accused has a right to be released on bail (Ibrahim v Hayat Gul
1985 SCMR 382).
Further enquiry' means that the facts show or tend to
show that the accused is not guilty or is not guilty of the offence
charged (Arbab Ali case-1985 SCMR 195; Ibrahim v Hayat Gul
(1985 SCMR 382).
In other words, in such cases, the law does not leave it to
the discretion of the court to withhold bail (Ibrahim v Hayat Gul
(1985 SCMR 382). Examples of cases of further inquiry within the
meaning of section 497 subsection (2) are cases in which a
person's name does not find mention in the challan as an accused
person or his name finds mention in column 2 of the challan; or the
facts show that the accused may not be convicted under section 302
or will be convicted for a lesser offence (Shahzaman v State- PLD
1994 SC 65).

Notice to prosecution
The fifth proviso to section 497(1) provides that a person accused
of an offence covered by that section shall not be released on bail
unless the prosecution has been given notice to show cause why he
should not be so released.
Chapter 5
Pre-arrest bail;
It is well sealed that the High Court and the Court of
Session have power under section 498, read with section 497, to
grant pre-arrest bail but this is subject to the conditions enacted in
section 498A which says that a person who is not in custody or is
not present in court or against whom no case stands registered shall
not be released on bail or be admitted to bail.
The jurisdiction to grant bail under section 498 vests
concurrently in the High Court and the Court of Session.
Ordinarily, the applicant must first approach the Court of Session.
The tendency of applications for bail and anticipatory bail being
brought in the High Courts has been deprecated and should be
discouraged (Nisar Ahmad v State PLD 1971 SC 174, 177).
The policy of the law as to grant of bail to accused
persons has been laid down in section 497 Cr. P. C., and section
498 occupies the position of a supplementary provision; also, as
regards orders of subordinate courts, section 498 gives revisional
powers to the High Court and the Court of Session (Mohammad
Ayub v Mohammad Yaqub - PLD 1966 SC 1003, 1015 per S. A.
666
Rehman J.). The words "admitted to bail" in section 498 mean the
same thing as 'released on bail' in section 497 (Mohammad Ayub
Mohammad Yaqub PLD 1966 SC 1003, 1011: Khushi
Muhammad case - PLD 1953 FC 170).
The power to admit a person to pre-arrest bail is an
extraordinary power. The applicant must, therefore, show, not only.
that he is entitled to bail under section 497 Cr. P. C. but also that
ii)
Mala tides
if the court stays its hands until the police
officer had himself exercised his discretion in
the matter and refused, upon arrest to grant
bail. a grave or irreparable harm or injustice
might result which it was in the highest
degree desirable to avoid, while at the same
time, preserving the interests of justice so far
as they related to the charge against such
accused person:
there are not only good prima facie grounds
for the grant of bail in respect of the offences.
alleged but also that if the petitioner were to
be arrested and refused bail, such an order
would, in all probability, be made not from
motives of furthering the ends of justice in
relation to the case but from some ulterior
motives and with the object of injuring the
petitioner or that the petitioner would in such
an eventuality suffer an irreparable harm
(Hidayatullah case PLD 1949 Lah 21: Sadiq
Ali case PLD 1966 SC 589; Murad Khan case
PLD 1983 SC 82; Muhammad Shoaib Suddle
v State 1997 SCMR 1234).
As was held in Zia-ul-Hasan case (PLD 1984 SC 192).
the court has no power to grant bail before arrest unless all the
conditions laid down by the superior courts from time to time are
667
5

Scanned with CamScanner

Page 352
satisfied, the most essential of them being that the intended arrest
would be tainted with malafide which must be specifically stated. It
is in this context that the other condition of irreparable loss is to be
viewed. In that connection, it is the duty of the court granting pre-
arrest bail to examine the question whether such grant of bail
would not frustrate investigation viz-a-viz various factors including
the relevant recovery.
Can the court dismissing ball application direct arrest
of the accused:
The non-granting of pre-arrest bail or cancellation of
interim pre-arrest bail does not necessarily entail the consequence
that the court should order the petitioner to be given into police
custody without there being a request in that behalf by the police
itself. The proper order to pass is to cancel the ad-interim bail and
to leave the petition to be dealt with by the police as they think fit.
He would thus be in no better and no worse position than the
position before he was granted ad-interim bail (Sadiq Ali case PLD
1966 SC 589).
Chapter 6
Order of bail-can it impose conditions
Under section 499 Cr. P. C. before any person is
released on bail or released on his own bond, a bond for such sum
of money as the police officer or the court thinks sufficient shall be
executed by such person and when he is released on bail, by one or
more sufficient sureties conditioned that such person shall attend at
the time and place mentioned in the bond and shall continue so to
attend until otherwise directed by the police officer or the court as
the case may be. Thus, both when the accused is released on bail
and when he is released on his own bond, he has to execute a bond,
that is to say, the requirement to execute a bond is mandatory. The
only discretion in the court is to fix the amount of bond and
whether or not the release will be on bail or on his own bond. It
follows that the court has no power while granting bail to impose a
condition such as that the accused would not deliver any speech of
a political kind (Mahmud Ali Kasuri case PLD 1963 SC 478); or
that he should pay the amount of fine (Faiz-ur-Rehman Sarkar case
1970 SCMR 175; Abdul Rehman v State 1985 SCMR 542). On the
principle that the court cannot impose any condition other than
those expressly permitted to be imposed by law, it seems to follow
that the court cannot in cases under the Code direct that instead of
furnishing bond he should pay cash security (see the judgment of
Mukhtar Ahmad Janejo J. in Hakim Ali Zardari case PLD 1998 SC
1, and the Indian cases cited there). For imposing such a condition,
the High Court cannot even invoke its inherent powers under
section 561A Cr.P.C.
This is the position under the Code of Criminal
Procedure as it stands. Of course, if the law under which bail is
granted provides that any condition can be imposed, the condition
would be valid (Hakim Ali Zardari case PLD 1998 SC 1). The law
under consideration in Hakim Ali Zardari case provides an
example. That law authorized the court to require the bail amount
to be paid in cash. Even under the Code of Criminal Procedure, the
bail granting authority has, under section 513, a discretion "to
permit him to deposit a sum of money or Government promissory
notes to such amount as the court or officer may fix in lieu of
executing such bond".
Chapter 7
Cancellation of bail:
Under section 497, subsection (5), "A High Court or
Court of Session and in the case of a person released by itself, any
other court may cause any person who has been released under this
section to be arrested and may commit him to custody". Thus, the
court which granted the bail, and the High Court and the Court of
Session whether or not the bail was granted by it, have power to
cancel the bail of an accused person.
668
669
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 353
Bail cannot be cancelled without notice to the accused
(Mushtaq Ahmad v State-PLD 1966 SC 126).
Considerations for the grant of hail and for its
cancellation of the same are different. Once the bail is granted by a
court of competent jurisdiction, then strong and exceptional
grounds would be required for cancellation thereof. To deprive a
person on post-arrest bail of his liberty is a most serious step to be
taken, Bail can neither be withheld nor cancelled as punishment
(Tariq Bashir v State PLD 1995 SC 34; also see Mst. Noor Habib v
Saleem Raza - PLJ 2009 SC 529)
When trial has commenced, bail should not ordinarily be
cancelled (Muhammad Ismail v Muhammad Rafiq - PLD 1989 SC
585: Mst. Irshad Begum v Muhammad Afzal - 1985 SCMR 1691).
Chapter 8
Propriety of hearing bail matters by same Judge:
In State v Zubair (PLD 1986 SC 173), it was ruled that if
a Judge of a High Court has heard a bail application of an accused
person, all subsequent applications for bail of the same person or in
the same case should be referred to the same Judge wherever he is
sitting. If it is impossible to do so, order of the Chief Justice should
be obtained. This rule is based on the salutary principle that
successive applications in the same case, if heard by different
judges, can result in conflicting orders and encourage malpractice
by accused persons and thereby bring the judicial system into
disrepute. This rule applies equally to the other courts.
In a recent suo motu matter (PLD 2002 SC 171), the
Supreme Court took judicial notice of the difficulties arising out of
the strict implementation of the above-stated rule and held, in
modification thereof, that-
(1)
(2)
(3)
(4)
(5)
Constitution of the Benches is the exclusive
function of the Chief Justice.
Ordinarily, subsequent bail application by the
same accused or in the same case must be
placed for disposal before the same Single
Judge/Division Bench of the High Court
which had dealt with the first bail application.
If the learned Single Judge who had dealt with
the first bail application is not available and
departure from (2) above is unavoidable, the
learned Chief Justice concerned may refer the
second or subsequent bail application to
another learned Single Judge at the Principal
Seat or Permanent Benches/Circuit Benches.
as the case may be.
Where the first bail application is heard and
disposed by a Division Bench which is not
available either at the Principal Seat or the
Permanent Benches/Circuit Benches at the
time of filing of the second or subsequent bail
application then such bail application shall be
heard by a Division Bench of which one of
the Judges was a Meraber of the Division
Bench which dealt with the first bail
application. If none of the Members of the
Division Bench which heard the first bail
application is available, the learned Chief
Justice concerned may assign the subsequent
bail application to any appropriate Division
Bench at the Principal Seat or the Permanent
Benches/Circuit Benches, as the case may be.
Subsequent bail application shall be filed,
heard and disposed of at the Principal Seat or

Page 354

the case may be, where the first bail

In the event of non-availability of the learned
