earlier bail applications, the office at the
Principal Seat shall obtain appropriate orders
from the learned Chief Justice and the office
at the Permanent Benches/Circuit Benches
shall obtain appropriate orders from the
leamed Chief Justice through fax or on
telephone for fixation of subsequent bail
application before other appropriate Benches,
in the interest of expeditious and inexpensive
dispensation of justice in bail matters.
Subsequent bail application shall not be
entertained unless accompanied by copies of
earlier bail applications and copies of orders
thereon.
Duty of counsel in this matter:
To enable the implementation of the above-mentioned
rule, it is the duty of the counsel for the accused to mention in the
bail application the fact of the previous bail application and its
result. Failure of the counsel to do so would be professional
misconduct (Zubair case-PLD 1986 SC 173, 177).
Chapter 9
Bail after conviction or acquittal:
The general law on bail to a convict is contained in
section 426 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, which is a
complete code on the subject. Though the powers under section
672
426 are controlled by sections 496 and 497 of the Code, yet the
principles of those sections have to be borne in mind in granting or
refusing bail to a convict. (Bihar Khan v State - 1969 SCMR 81).
Under Section 426, an appellate court may, pending the
appeal of the convict, for reasons to be recorded in writing, order
that the execution of the sentence or order appealed against be
suspended and also, if he is in confinement, that he be released on
bail or on his own bond. In exercising the powers under section
426, it should be remembered that an accused stands on a different
footing from a convict. In the case of an accused, the presumption
of innocence has a part to play, but in the case of a convict, that
presumption disappears. (Qaim Ali Shah case 1992 SCMR 2192:
Gul Zaman v State-1999 SCMR 1271, 1277).
The question of bail can also arise in appeals or
revisions against acquittal. An accused is presumed to be innocent
and when he is duly tried and acquitted, he earns a double
presumption of innocence. (Abdul Mateen case - PLD 2006 SC
538).
The sentencing court may also, in certain cases, suspend
the sentence and allow bail to the convict to enable him to file an
appeal. Such bail will be subject to confirmation by the appellate
court. (Section 382A and Section 426, subsection (2A). Cr.P.C)
Indeed, a special law may make different provisions
governing the suspension of sentences of and the granting of bail to
convicts under that law.
673
L
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 355
Chapter 10
Ball by High Court of one Province to an accused to be tried in
another Province:
The Lahore and Sind High Courts have been
consistently granting interim protective bail in respect of offences
committed outside their territorial jurisdictions. This situation
arises when a case is pending before a court in one Province and
the accused happens to be in another Province and the trial court
issues a warrant for the arrest of that person. In Mukhtar Ahmad
Awan v State (1990 P Cr. L J 617), the question has been dealt
with at some length and it has been held that the High Court can
grant interim protective bail to such an accused person to enable
him to approach the competent court in another Province.
Chapter 11
Application of sections 497 and 498 in Special Offences triable
by Special Courts:
It has been noticed that the provisions of the Code of
Criminal Procedure will apply to proceedings governed by special
laws unless their application is expressly excluded. Even where the
application of the provisions of the Code of Criminal Procedure is
expressly excluded the jurisdiction of the High Court and the Court
of Session to deal with bail matters is not excluded in such special
cases till the Special Court has taken cognizance of the offence
(Musahib Ali v State PLD 1975 Kar 909; Zahur Ilahi v State PLD
1977 SC 273, 303). Then it is well settled that a law excluding
jurisdiction of ordinary courts is to be strictly construed, that is to
say, if there is any doubt or ambiguity, it is to be resolved in favour
of the accused. State v Qaim Ali Shah (1992 SCMR 2192, 2217)
and Gul Zaman v State (1999 SCMR 1271) are illustrations of
doubts as to the application of sections 497 and 498 having been
resolved in favour of the ordinary jurisdiction of the High Court
under the Code of Criminal Procedure.
Chapter 12
Excessive ball:
It is a fundamental right guaranteed by the US
Constitution, 8 Amendment, that "Excessive bail shall not be
required.. ..". Bail here seems to have been used in the sense
of "security", so that it applies to cases of release on personal bond
as well as release on the bond of sureties. The 8th Amendment says
nothing about whether bail shall be available at all. It was held in
Carlson v Landon (342 US 524 (1952):
"The bail clause was lifted with slight
changes from the English Bill of Rights
Act. In England that clause has never
been thought to accord a right to bail in
all cases, but merely to provide that bail
shall not be excessive in those cases
where it is proper to grant bail. When
this clause was carried over into our Bill
of Rights, nothing was said that
indicated
different
any
concept...
It was held in Stack v Boyle (342 US 1; 96 L Ed 3-1951) that-
"Bail set at a figure higher than an
amount reasonably calculated (to ensure
the defendant's presence at trial) is
excessive
the Eighth
Amendment".
under
I
6741
675
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 356
The reason why this right against excessive bail was
constitutionally guaranteed is that the result of denying bail and
requiring excessive bail is the same. To grant bail but to require
excessive bail, wholly disproportionate to the circumstances of the
case, may well amount to giving by one hand and taking hack by
another. In the words of Justice Marshall in his dissenting opinion
in US v Salerno:
"If excessive bail is imposed the
defendant stays in jail. The same result is
achieved if bail is denied altogether.
Whether the Magistrate sets bail at $1
billion or refuses to set bail at all, the
consequences are indistinguishable. It
would be mere sophistry to suggest that
the Eighth Amendment protects against
the former decision, and not the latter
The protection against excessive bail is not a constitutional
protection in Pakistan; it is provided by section 498 Cr. P. C:
"The amount of every bond executed
under this Chapter shall be fixed with
due regard to the circumstances of the
case, and shall not be excessive........".
Thus, though the amount of bail is in the discretion of the bail
granting authority, yet the amount must be fixed with due regard to
the circumstances of the case and it will be excessive if the amount
is "set at a figure higher than an amount reasonably calculated to
ensure the defendant's presence at trial".
The amount of bail, fixed by a police officer or a court,
is subject to the revisional powers, under section 498 Cr. P. C., of
the High Court and Court of Session, and if it is excessive it will be
reduced.
Chapter 13
Bail bonds and their forfeiture:
The provisions as to the bail bonds and their forfeiture
are contained in Chapter XLII Cr. P. C.
Sections 514, 514A and 514B lay down the procedure to
be followed when forfeiture of bond has occurred. Forfeiture of
bond occurs when a condition of the bond is violated. It has been
seen that under section 499 Cr. P. C. the condition on which the
accused is released on bail is that he shall attend at the time and
place mentioned in the bond and shall continue so to attend until
otherwise directed by the court. Thus, when the accused fails to
attend at the time and place mentioned in the bond, forfeiture of the
bond takes place.
The question usually arises whether when forfeiture of
the bond has taken place, the whole of the amount of the bond
should be forfeited and recovered from the surety. The leading
authority on the subject is Dildar v State (PLD 1963 SC 47):
"Sureties are not constituted as custodians of
accused persons and in the absence of proof to the
contrary, it may generally be assumed that they do
not gain by standing surety. The system of
releasing accused persons on bail has several
aspects of importance to the administration of
justice generally. It avoids anything in the nature of
punishment in advance, since restraint upon liberty
even when applied for the purpose of ensuring that
a case is duly enquired into and judged, necessarily
involves loss of personal rights. At the same time,
ue release of accused persons on bail assists in the
adn.inistration of justice by preventing over-
crowding in the available spaces of imprisonment.
676
677
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 357
Therefore, in dealing with cases of sureties who are
in default a balance has to be held between undue
leniency, which might lead to abuse of the
procedure and interference with the course of
justice in a large number of cases, and on the other
hand, undue severity, which might lead to
unwillingness on the part of neighbours and friends
to come forward and give bail for persons under
accusation. Finally, in assessing to what extent the
bond should be forfeited, the court would have
regard to such matters as to whether the sureties
have any direct interest through financial or blood
connection with the absence of the accused, and
whether they have done their best to secure his
attendance".
The law has been re-examined in two recent cases
namely Zeshan Kazmi v The State (PLD 1997 SC 267) and Abdul
Bari v Ameer Jan (PLD 1998 SC 50). In Zeshan Kazmi case it was
noted that the observations of Cornelius, CJ. in Dildar case were
made "more than three decades ago, since then there has been
overall deterioration in all spheres of life. The crime rate has
increased manifold. The criminal instinct/propensity has penetrated
in all walks of life.....", and in Abdul Bari v Ameer Jan, these
observations were reaffirmed and in the facts of that case, the
decision of the court below to forfeit 25% of the amount of surety
bond only was set aside. The rule thus is that the extent of
imposition of penalty by the court while forfeiting a bond is within
the discretion of the court which is to be exercised keeping in view
the circumstances of each case.
Chapter 14
Are questions of bail or conditions of bail a matter of
procedure only:
To take an extreme ca e, suppose that the law under
which a person is arrested provides that the offence is bailable or
that the offence is non-bailable, but the court may, in its discretion.
grant bail. Suppose also that A is arrested under the law, and the
court releases him on bail. Suppose further, that the law is.
subsequent to his release on bail, amended and it is provided in the
amended law that an accused arrested for such an offence shall not
be released on bail at all. Such a law will be constitutionally valid
because the Constitution does not provide that bail is a right. Can A
be taken into custody, although the amended law does not say that
persons in the position of A should be re-arrested? That question
will turn on whether bail is a matter of procedure only or whether it
touches substantive rights. If it is a matter of procedure only, the
amended law will, so hold the decided cases, e.g. Colonial Sugar
Refining Company v Irving (1905 AC 369), apply retrospectively.
with the very serious consequence that A will be deprived of his
liberty and sent to prison, to remain there, during the course of the
trial. may be for an indefinite period. Not only are the
consequences serious for A but also for his family.
The question arose in an acute form in Hakim Ali
Zardari v State (PLD 1998 SC 1). The appellant was arrested under
the Ehtsab Ordinance 1997, which empowered the court to release
an accused on bail, but provided that "the amount of bail will be
fixed having regard to the gravity of the charge...... and where
the charge specified any amount in respect of which the offence is
alleged to have been committed, shall not be less than twice the
amount". The appellant was allowed interim bail on his furnishing
bail bond in the sum of Rupees one million with two sureties. On
his request, the appellant was allowed, instead of two sureties, to
deposit prize bonds of the value of two million. Before the
confirmation of the bail, the Ordinance was repealed by the Ehtsab
Act 1997, which provided that the amount of bail would not be less
than the amount specified in the charge and empowered the court
to "direct that the amount be deposited (in cash) in court". The
Ehtsab Bench, while confirming the bail, ordered that the appellant
shall deposit Rupees one crore in cash as the amount of bail.
678
679
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 358
The question was whether the appellant's case had
continued to be governed by the Ordinance or whether the Act in
so far as it empowered the court to order the amount of bail to be
deposited in cash, applied retrospectively to the appellant's case.
The question in the words of Saiduzzamman Siddiqui J. speaking
for the majority, was "whether the condition for deposit of bail
amount in cash.......is a valid condition, in view of the change in
the law". This, the learned Judge observed. "depends on a finding
whether the conditions for grant of bail are matters relating to
procedure or they relate to substantive rights". In other words, the
question was "whether the provisions relating to fixation of amount
of bail and the discretion conferred on the court to order deposit of
this amount in the court under the Act, are only matters of
procedure or they also touch upon the existing rights of the
parties".
Relying upon Adnan Afzal case (PLD 1986 SC 187) and
other cases and some books, the learned Judge concluded:
"The provision in the Act conferring
jurisdiction on the courts to direct deposit
of bail amount in the court instead of
executing bond or offering securities for
the amount in our view related only to a
procedural matter which did not affect the
existing right of the appellant for the grant
of bail under the Ordinance. Whether the
concession of bail allowed by the court is
to be enjoyed by the accused on the
execution of the personal bond, furnishing
of the securities or deposit of the amount
in court is purely regulatory and
procedural in nature in which the person
enlarged on bail, in our view, cannot
claim any vested right. Similarly, the
provision in the Act, that the amount of
the bail should not be fixed by the court
less than the amount mentioned in the
charge, is more beneficial to the accused
as compared to the provisions in the
Ordinance.....the mere fact that the
accused is required to deposit the amount
in court instead of securing the same
through securities or bond cannot be said
to have caused prejudice to the accused or
have taken away any of his vested
rights.....".
In his dissenting note, Mukhtar Ahmed Junejo J. thought that the
interim bail granted to the appellant under the Ordinance and
before the coming into force of the Act, was a matter which
"became a past and closed transaction under the repealed
Ordinance, 1997". The change introduced by the Act, empowering
the court to require the deposit in cash of the bail amount, in the
view of the learned Judge, "was a change in the substantive law
and therefore cannot operate retrospectively to deprive the
appellant of his right to remain on bail in terms of the orders" made
before the Act came into force.
The first observation that falls to be made is that the bail
granted to the appellant under the Ordinance was an interim bail.
That means that the question whether the appellant was entitled to
bail, as of right, had not yet been finally decided under the
Ordinance. That fell to be decided when the bail came to be
confirmed, and by that time, the Ordinance had been repealed by
the Act. Looked at from that angle, the question of the appellant
having acquired a vested right under the Ordinance, or of that right
being affected by the new provisions in the Act did not arise. The
question whether the appellant was entitled, as of right, to bail, was
thus finally decided, not under the Ordinance, but under the Act.
This interim order, by its very nature, did not decide, and was
incapable of deciding, finally the question whether the appellant
was entitled to bail; the interim order was subject to the final order
and as the final order was made under the Act, it was the Act, and
680
681
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 359
not the Ordinance, which governed the question of bail and the
conditions on which it could be granted. That should have, it is
submitted, rendered it unnecessary to raise and decide the question
whether the conditions for the grant of bail were matters relating to
procedural or substantive law.
But since that question was actually decided, we shall
make such comments as the importance of the matter warrants.
What is the proper approach to determining such a
controversy? Is it to see whether the matter is one of procedural or
substantive law? Or, is it what label to apply to the amending
enactment-procedural or substantive?
It is fair to state at the outset that there are no cases "on
which differences of opinion may readily be entertained, or which
are more embarrassing to dispose of, than the cases where the court
has to decide whether or not an amending statute affects procedure
and consequently will operate retrospectively or affects substantive
rights and therefore in the absence of clear contrary intention,
should not be read as acting retrospectively. The distinction
between procedural matters and substantive rights must often be of
great fineness......"
The proper approach, it is submitted, was stated by the
Privy Council in the Yew Bon Tew case (1982) 3 All ER 833), a
case from Malaysia. A motor bus belonging to the respondents
collided with a motorcycle driven by the first appellant with the
second appellant as pillion passenger. Both the appellants were
injured. The respondent was a statutory body and the accident
occurred in the course of the respondents' public duties. Under the
relevant law, the period of limitation for an action was 12 months,
in this case up to 5 April 1973. No action was brought during that
period. On 13 June 1974, the law was amended, and the period of
limitation for such actions was fixed as 36 months. An action was
brought on 20 March 1975. The question was whether the period of
limitation was 12 or 36 months, and whether the amending law was
682
procedural and hence retrospective. The Privy Council observed
that-
there is at common law a prima
facie rule of construction that a statute
should not be interpreted retrospectively
so as to impair an existing right or
obligation unless that result is
unavoidable on the language used. A
statute is retrospective if it takes away or
impairs a vested right acquired under
existing laws, or creates J new
obligation, or imposes a new duty, or
attaches a new disability, in regard to
events already past. There is however
said to be an exception in the case of a
statute which is purely procedural,
because no person has a vested right in
any particular course of procedure....".
But, these expressions, 'retrospective" and "procedural", so said the
Privy Council,
"though useful in a particular context.
are equivocal and therefore can be
misleading......
In the view of the Privy Council.
...the proper approach to the
construction of the 1974 Act is not to
decide what label to apply to it,
procedural or otherwise, but to see
whether the statute. if applied
retrospectively to a particular type of
case, would impair existing rights and
obligations A Limitation Act
683
Scanned with CamScanner

Page 360
may therefore be procedural in the
context of one set of facts, but
substantive in the case of a different set
of facts".
It was, accordingly, held, "that an accrued right to plead a time bar,
which is acquired after the lapse of the statutory period, is in every
sense a right, even though it arises under an Act which is
procedural....".
Returning to Hakim Ali Zardari case, assuming that the
question of bail and its conditions had been finally decided under
the Ehtsab Ordinance 1997, the proper approach, it is submitted,
would have been to ask whether the new provisions in the Act
could be applied retrospectively so as to impair the appellant's
existing rights. One of the existing rights that the appellant had
acquired under the Ordinance was no less than the constitutionally
guaranteed right to personal liberty described as the most cherished
right. "If excessive bail is imposed, the defendant stays in jail. The
same result is achieved if the bail is denied altogether. Whether the
Magistrate sets the bail at $ 1 billion or refused to set bail at all, the
consequences are indistinguishable......" (Justice Marshall in
Salerno-481 US 739; 95 L Ed 2d 697).
This approach should have led, inexorably in our
opinion, to the answer that the new provisions in the Act could not
be applied retrospectively to the case of the appellant. The
condition of cash deposit of as much as one crore could not be
imposed under the Ordinance; it could be, and was, imposed under
the Act. The result of the failure of the appellant to comply with it
was that he had to go to jail. This is how his existing right to
personal liberty under the Ordinance was impaired by the new
provisions of the Act, and this is how the new provisions operated
retrospectively.
